A sad vacancy in my family my beloved James gone & my poor wife distressed. But I desire to bow in humble submission to God's Overruling Providence.

div3.head: 21. Sab.
div3.p: I set off early with Mrs McFarland & Robert to preach at the Funeral of Phebe Patterson at 9 a.m. A large Assembly. Dined at James McClung & called at Mr Alexr. Brownlee's. Find mourning everywhere about Sons &c. gone to resist northern troops.

div3.head: 22. Mon.
div3.p: I intended to go to Staunton but was not well enough. Reading & writing & Sleeping.

div3.head: 23. Tu.
div3.p: Still unwell. I think the result of a sleight attack of Asthma, did not rise till near 8 a.m. Reading.

div3.head: 24. Wed.
div3.p: I went to Greenville took Mrs McF. to Mr Hay's. Made several calls in Greenville, & purchased several articles for domestic purposes. Recd. a letter from James from Mount Jackson, & one from Sister Roxa, written on Monday saying that James had arrived there.

div3.head: 25. Thurs.
div3.p: I am quite unwell. Did not rise till 11 O'clock. Reading. Began to mark out for corn. Wrote to James & to Wm. L. Bent, & sent my Check for $10. which Wm. & N. Bent had kindly given James.

div3.head: 26. Fri.
div3.p: I am somewhat better, but feeble. Studying a little. Recd. a letter from James dated on Tuesday at Harper's Ferry. Has a cold. Knows not his destination.

div3.head: April 26. Fri. (continued)
div3.p: No northern papers by this mail. The Railroad bridges in Maryland are destroyed to prevent northern troops from reaching Washington City. I know not how we can have communication with Phila. or N. York.

div3.head: 27. Sat.
div3.p: Studying, but not very well. Robert had to turn out as a home guard. Very strict police regulations are adopted.

div3.head: 28. Sab.
div3.p: A light shower in the morning & then the day quite cool. Preached at Bethel to a good Congn on our duty as a Chtn. Congn in this time of War. Indications are fearfully threatening now.

div3.head: 29. Mon.
div3.p: Quite unwell. Went to Abm Crist's where Mr Trevoy's child is quite low with Pneumonia. Went to Greenville to send James his red Jacket & white Pants. Saw Rev. Mr. Lambeth, just from Harper's Ferry. Bought 40 lbs Rio Coffee & 2 lbs of Green & 1 lb of Black Tea.
Recd. a letter from James he is well, but feet sore.

div3.head: 30. Tu.
div3.p: Still not well-have a cold. Began to plant corn yesterday-Goodnight helping today.

div3.head: May 1. Wed.
div3.p: Cool. Planting corn. Goodnight & John Rosen assisting. Writing for Wm J. Gilkeson.

div3.head: 2. Thurs.
div3.p: Cooler. Finished planting corn & began to plant Potatoes, all in the NE. field.

div3.head: 3. Fri.
div3.p: Studying. Finished planting potatoes. A chilling day. recd Letters from Sister Roxa & James McFarland. Jas is now quartered at Bolivar 1 mile from Harper's Ferry.

div3.head: 4. Sat.
div3.p: A little rain last night. It has turned cold. Studying.

div3.head: May 5. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a large & attentive Congn Went to Greenville. Dined at Wm Smith's. Preached to a good Congn Home.

div3.head: 6. Mon.
div3.p: It rained a little last night & today there were several fine showers & the wind turned to SW. & it became warmer. Robert went to Staunton to the Guard Training & Mary & Frank went with him. I was engaged writing Wm. J. Gilkeson's Will.

div3.head: 7. Tu.
div3.p: Wrote to Dr. White informing him that I declined going to the General Assembly. Wrote also to Rev. E.D. Junkin & Rev. Wm. T. Richardson. Sent letters also to my sons Francis & James. Mary & Robert returned.

div3.head: 8. Wed.
div3.p: Robert returned to the training. I am reading Newspapers which make me very sad.

div3.head: 9. Thurs.
div3.p: Reading. Visited at the Poorhouse. Mr Hall advising me that I can now get from Washington to Phila. but I will decline going.

div3.head: 10. Fri.
div3.p: A good rain fell gently & cleared off warm. Thanks be to God. I wrote to Col. Patterson. Letters from Dr. White, Rev. S. Brown, Betsey Humphreys & E.L. Holladay. recd Semi-weekly Despatch of of this day.

div3.head: 11. Sat.
div3.p: Pleasant. Robert went to Genl. Muster. Studying. Wrote to Dr. Wm Brown & remitted $1 payment for the Semi-Weekly despatch for six months. Wrote also to Dr. Humphreys.

div3.head: 12. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel & at C. C. School H. to good & attentive Congs. then home.

div3.head: May 13. Mon.
div3.p: The warmest day for 8 months. I was reading & working a little.

div3.head: 14. Tu.
div3.p: Reading. recd Letters from Betsey & from Francis. The latter is Orderly Serjeant in a Troop of Cavalry now in Alexandria. recd a letter from Rev. B.M. Smith. Wrote to Dr. Smith & Dr. John Leyburn. Enclosed a gold Dollar for Mr Van Gelder for Minutes.

div3.head: 15. Wed.
div3.p: Went to Greenville. Visited Alexr. Brownlee, he thinks himself a little better. Bought several articles of Lightner & Co. Mrs McF. who has been absent since Sab. came home with me.

div3.head: 16. Thurs.
div3.p: Reading. Mrs Larew here. Mr Ben. McClung came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 17. Fri.
div3.p: Studying & working.

div3.head: 18. Sat.
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 19. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a large Congn Young Mr Trout came with nearly 300 yds Plaid linsey to make shirts for the Soldiers with a note that they wanted 1000 made by Tuesday night. They were sending the work round to the different Congs. Our ladies appointed to meet at the Ch. tomorrow morning. Dined at Mr Gardner's & preached to a good Congn Came home.

div3.head: 20. Mon.
div3.p: Mrs McF. Mary & Robert went to Bethel. In the afternoon a good rain. Reading.

div3.head: 21. Tu.
div3.p: Reading. Letters from James.

div3.head: 22. Wed.
div3.p: Reading. Wrote to Dr. Wm. Brown & to James McFarland.

div3.head: May 23. Thurs.
div3.p: Went to Greenville. This the day of the election for membs. of the Legislature & for voting on the Ordinance of Secession & the equalization of Taxation. I voted for B. Christian for the Senate, Wm. M. Tate, N. Massie & H.W. Sheffey for the House of D. I voted to equalize the Taxation & to sustain the action of the Convention as Revolution, for it is such. This is the most painful vote I ever gave. The Course of the Administration making actual war upon the South to compel them to remain in the Union, or return into it, seeded to leave me no alternative. I mourn in bitterness over the state of things, but Va. did all she could for peace.
Mary Wallace & John Shields spent the night here.
Reading & Studying. Mrs R. Miday arrived from Winchester.

div3.head: 25. Sat.
div3.p: Went to Hebron & preached to a good Congn After public worship a Congregational meeting was held. A vote was taken & some 15 or 16 voted to take up the subject of electing a Pastor. But then no one would nominate & there being no nomination there could be no election. It was postponed & a Com tee appointed to have the pulpit supplied. Dined at Mrs Wrights & came home.

div3.head: 26th. Sab.
div3.p: Preached the Action Serm. at Hebron & assisted in administering the Lord's Supper. Jerusha M. McPheters & James Waddell Calhoun recd on Examn. Rev. N.W. Calhoun Assisted.

div3.head: May 27. Mon.
div3.p: Went to Staunton. Court day. Took Mary's Rockaway to be repaired. Very high wind-turned to WNW & became cooler. Deposited Money in Bank. Dined at Rev. Mr Baker's with Mr Bowman. Heard Hon. A.H.H. Stuart make a speech.

div3.head: 28. Tu.
div3.p: Reading & working.

div3.head: 29. Wed.
div3.p: Reading, writing & working.
Called at Mr J. Bumgarners. Dined at Mr Merritt's. Bought a side of Upper leather of Sonith for $3.00.

div3.head: 31. Fr.
div3.p: Studying. Harrowing Corn.

div3.head: June 1. Sat.
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 2. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good Congn & in Greenville to a small one. Dined at Dr. Tate's. Home.

div3.head: 3. Mon.
div3.p: Warm. Between 1 & 2 P.M. a fine shower. Needed.

div3.head: 4. Tu.
div3.p: A good shower last night. A little rain today. Robert went to Staunton. Rev. Henry Brown came & spent the night with us; he is in good health.

div3.head: 5. Wed.
div3.p: A shower again last night. Reading.

div3.head: 6. Thurs.
div3.p: Reading. Went to see young Montgomery who is just from Harper's Ferry. Ladies making tents & uniforms for the Soldiers.

div3.head: 7. Fri.
div3.p:
A pleasant Shower. A second Shower. After dinner Mrs McF. & I set off & spent the night Ballard Smith's. Dr. White, recently from Buckhannon, where he owned a good farm in the neighborhood, a good house & lot in town & had a medicinal practice worth $2,500 was leaving that region with his family & servants on on acct of the war & the distracted state of society there.
He spent the night with us. Also Mr Chs. Estill & his wife, who has been teaching in the Military Institute in Charlotte, N.C. associated with Col. Hill, formerly of Lexington, Va. A Mr Richardson also with Mr Estill.

div3.head: June 8. Sat.
div3.p: Went to Mt. Carmel & preached to a good Congn Dined at Mr Bradley's. Spent an hour at the Rev. Wm. Pinkerton's. Spent the night at Capt. Henry's.

div3.head: 9. Sab.
div3.p: Preached what is called a Dedication Serm. in their new church, to a very large Congn after which the Lord's Supper was administered.

Dined at James Smiths & came home. My son Robert was near losing his life today. He was driving Mr Hawpe's horse & Buggy with Mary Hawpe coming home from Mt. Carmel when beyond Greenville the Breech strap broke & the horse ran off & at John Larew's door they were thrown out & Robt was thrown under the feet of the horses in Larew's carriage & they started & the carriage ran over Robt. He was a good deal hurt but no bones were broken. Mary Hawpe was not much hurt. Thanks be to God for their escapes.

div3.head: 10. Mon.
div3.p: At home. Reading. Letter from Francis on Saturday.

div3.head: 11. Tu.
div3.p: Reading & working.

div3.head: 12. Wed.
div3.p: Went to Greenville. Bought of Lightner & Co. Four yds of Black Broadcloth at $5 per yd (cost) & paid for it. This for a Coat for myself & Robert. Visited Mr Brownlee-Called at Adam Hawpe's. A fine shower.

div3.head: 13. Thurs.
div3.p:
This the day of Fasting & prayer appointed by Pres. Davis of the Southern Confederacy. The Congn at Bethel was uncommonly large. The Galery was also full of
Servants. All business was suspended. It was a solemn meeting. At 4 p.m. I attended another Prayer meeting in Greenville. House full. There was another meeting at the Christians Creek school house at 4 p.m.
I feel greatly encouraged by the character of these meetings. If they were generally such, it is a token for good from God, who has inclined man's heart to pray.

div3.head: June 14. Fr.
div3.p: A pleasant day. Reading & Studying.

div3.head: 15. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. recd of Wm. J. Gilkeson $65, money lent him March 23d last with one dollar interest.

div3.head: 16. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a large Congn Dined at John Shields with Mary Wallace. Preached at C.C.S.H. to an overflowing house. Came home.

div3.head: 17. Mon.
div3.p: Reading. Wrote to Wm. Bent & Col. Reid & James McF. Went to the P.O.

div3.head: 18. Tu.
div3.p: Varnishing &c. recd letters from Roxa & Wm. Bent. James came from Shepperdstown on Friday last to Winchester & left for Bunker's Hill on Sunday at 4 P.M.

div3.head: 19. W.
div3.p: Mrs McF. & I visited at S. Hays' Mr Pilson's & Wm Thompson's.

div3.head: 20. Thurs.
div3.p: Reading & working.

div3.head: 21. Fri.
div3.p: Studying. Finished plowing Corn.

div3.head: 22. Sat.
div3.p: Studying.
Preached at Bethel & in Greenville to good Congs.

div3.head: 24. Mon.
div3.p: Went to Staunton. Returned by Mint Spring Col. Reid in my Buggy. Robert returned-absent 6 days.

div3.head: June 25. Tues.
div3.p: Reading & working. Mowing.

div3.head: 26. Wed.
div3.p: Visited Mrs Patterson, Mr McClung & Brownlee. Saw John Wilson direct from Martinsburg where James is & has the Mumps.
Bought 20 lbs of Rio Coffee at 24 cents, cost & ear.

div3.head: 27. Thurs.
div3.p: Varnishing &c. Hauling in hay, 2 loads.

div3.head: 28. Fri.
div3.p: Studying. Began to cut Wheat N. of the house.

div3.head: 29. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. A very fine Rain last night-fell moderately & continued nearly all night. Life for the corn.

div3.head: 30. Sab.
div3.p: Rained till about 3 p.m. moderately. I went to Bethel with Mary & Robert. Only 8 persons more came & half of them when I was about having sung & read & prayed with a few came home.

div3.head: July 1. Mon.
div3.p: Working. Cutting Wheat. A shower in the afternoon.

div3.head: 2. Tu.
div3.p: Cool. Went to Greenville to see Capt. Newton who has come home on a furlough-James belongs to his company. Dined at Mr Newton's. Bought a considerable Bill, chiefly groceries of Lightner & Co. Gave a Check for $40. which pays all to this date. Cutting Wheat. John A. Wright & Mater here.

div3.head: 3. Wed.
div3.p: Working all day-very tired. My hands assisting Mr Wright.

div3.head: 4. Th.
div3.p: Reading. John A. Wright & Mater here harvesting.

div3.head: 5. Fri.
div3.p: Working. Wright & Mater here today also. Letters from Betsey & Dr. H. from James, Wm Bent & Mrs E. Hodge.

div3.head: 6. Sat.
div3.p: Wrote to Dr. Humphreys. Studying. The rain prevented harvesting.

div3.head: July 7. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a large Congn Subject-Nebuchadnezzar's Proclamation found in Daniel Chap. IV throughout. Good attention. About 3 p.m. had a very heavy rain which flooded my meadow & I fear ruined my hay crop this year.

div3.head: 8. Mon.
div3.p: Day warm. My hands at Wright's harvesting. I wrote an article for the Central Presbyterian in regard to forming "The General Assembly of the Confederate States of America" & took it to the Post Office. recd a letter from James, who is in Winchester at his uncle N. Bent's, not sufficiently recovered for duty.

div3.head: 9. Tu.
div3.p: Warm. A shower. I was busy writing. Hands harvesting. At Wrights & here also.

div3.head: 10. Wed.
div3.p: Finished cutting Wheat. Reading. Robert went to Staunton. A shower.

div3.head: 11. Thurs.
div3.p: Hauling in Wheat. A Shower. Cooler.

div3.head: 12. Fr.
div3.p: Fine day-hauling in Wheat. Studying. A light Shower early in the night. Letter from Roxa B. James is well.

div3.head: 13. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. Finished hauling in Wheat. Had 276 Shocks, large bind. Thanks be to God.

div3.head: 14. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel & Mint Spring. Was called on to give notices for all Militia Companies to parade tomorrow at 8 a.m.

div3.head: 15. Mon.
div3.p: All the Militia are ordered out. Our troops in Randolph Co. under Col. Heck it is said were surrounded & had a severe encounter. Spent the day aiding Robert to get ready. I was ill today with Dyssentery, not very bad.

div3.head: July 16. Tu.
div3.p: Had a more comfortable night than I expected. I went to Staunton with Robert who with his Company is called into Service. It is sad to part with my last son-they are now all in the army. May God preserve them. I gave Robert $15. in money, and furnished him everything. I bought a Revolver for him for which I paid $15. Other things $3.25.

div3.head: 17. Wed.
div3.p: I feel feeble but am better. Reading. Jef. mowing & hauling in gleanings-had four loads.

div3.head: 18. Th.
div3.p: Mrs McF. & I went to Staunton. Stopped at Col. Tate's. The Militia are not ready to leave. Saw Robert. I think he is likely to do well.
There is a Regiment of 900 Arkansas troops encamped opposite Col. Tate's. Saw Dr. B.M. Smith, Mr Richardson & Mr Boardman.

Came home by Mint Spring where the ladies had prepared a dinner for the Fairfield McDowell Guards commanded by the Rev. Capt. John Miller; a fine company of 80 men. It was a pleasant entertainment & they took with them all they left which was more than they ate. Capt. Miller handsomely thanked the ladies in the name of the Company & I responded in the name of the ladies & then prayed at the request of Capt. Miller. Home. A good shower.

div3.head: 19. Fr.
div3.p: Warm. Studying. Hauling in Hay, two loads.

div3.head: 20. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. Cutting Oats. Mary went to Staunton with Mrs McPheeters. Sent for Robert who came home late.

div3.head: 21. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel with more than usual liberty, I thank God, & the people seemed very solemn & I was told that it was a comforting sermon to Christians.

div3.head: 22. Mon.
div3.p: It was raining when I woke & had rained a good deal in the night & it continued to rain all day without intermission & pretty heavily, but not so as to make a flood, & continued till about 10 p.m.

div3.head: 23. Tu.
div3.p: I got my horse shod at Lightner's. Heard of a great Battle fought near Manassas Junction. Called to see Samuel McAden. Cutting Oats.

div3.head: 24. Wed.
div3.p: Went to Staunton. Great excitement about the recent victory. But difficult to learn the results. Dined at Mr Keysers. Saw Dr. B.M. Smith Rev. Messrs Blain, Campbell & Thomas.

div3.head: 25. Thurs.
div3.p: I was quite unwell last night & did not rise today till near noon.
Cleaned up 14 Bs of wheat gleanings. Finished hauling in hay.
I went to see John Hays who has come home wounded on Sunday last at Manassas Junction, through his shoulder & neck-a very narrow escape.
Rev. Mr Thomas spent the night with us. I am glad to hear from Francis-John Hays saw him on last Saturday & conversed an hour with him. He was well & reputed a good soldier.

div3.head: July 26. Fri.
div3.p: Studying. Hauling in oats, 3 loads.

div3.head: 27. Sat.
div3.p: Cloudy & raining a good deal. Studying.

div3.head: 28. Sab.
div3.p: This day has been appointed by a unanimous Resolution of the Confederate Congress on which "the people are invited to offer up their united Thanksgiving & praise for the mighty deliverance" wrought on last Sabbath in the glorious victory obtained at Manassas. I preached & endeavored to give God the Glory due to his name; & in the Afternoon in Greenville. Had good Congs. & good attention. Came home.

div3.head: 29. Mon.
div3.p: Hauling in Oats. Preached at the Funeral of Samuel McAdden. Letters from James & Roxa. James has suffered much with Neuralgia.

div3.head: 30. Tu.
div3.p: Went to Staunton. Wrote to James. Robert has volunteered. If he goes this will greatly embarrass my home business, but I desire patiently to submit to the will of Providence.
Cutting oats. Very warm. A letter from Francis.

div3.head: Aug. 1. Thurs.
div3.p: Reading chiefly of the wonderful victory that God has given us, July 21st.

div3.head: 2. Fr.
div3.p: Studying. Raking up Oats.

div3.head: 3. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. Got in more oats. Brought home the flour of ten Bushels of gleaned wheat.

div3.head: 4. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good Congregation.

div3.head: 5. Mon.
div3.p: Varnishing. Cutting oats. Very warm.

div3.head: 6. Tu.
div3.p: Visited the Gibson family. They are much afflicted & take wrong views of our Political affairs. Rev. Mr Withrow & wife dined here. Finished cutting oats.

div3.head: Aug. 7. Wed.
div3.p: Working. Got in the last of our Oats. A better crop than our neighbors.

div3.head: 8. Thurs.
div3.p: Working. Hauling Plank. Ben. McClung & Mrs Dossey came & spent the night here. I went to see a Mr Trice who has Typhoid Fever at his uncle's & is very ill. There was a tremendous rain while I was there & a great flood. Not near so much rain at home & but a little flood.

div3.head: 9. Fr.
div3.p: Studying. Mrs Dossey went to Mr Henderson's to be leached & returned. Another fine rain.

div3.head: 10. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. B. McClung went home. Mrs Dossey staid. Fine showers in the afternoon.

div3.head: 11. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel & at Mrs Sproul's. Spent the night at Mrs Sproul's pleasantly.

div3.head: 12. Mon.
div3.p: Returned home, calling at Mr Randolph's & Mr Bumgarner's. Went to Miss Abney's to see Lieut. Grills-did not see him, but left a bundle for him to take to James.

div3.head: 13. Tu.
div3.p: Working & Reading. Mater helping to haul out manure. Robert came home.

div3.head: 14. Wed.
div3.p: Reading. Robert returned to Staunton. Mary & I visited Lizzie Brawford.

div3.head: 15. Thurs.
div3.p: Had some Asthma last night & headache this morning that I did not rise till 11 O'clock. A letter from Dr. Hays of Columbia, Ten. brings the sad intelligence that our daughter Humphreys is not now living, in all probability, as all her physicians thought she could not live more than 24 or 36 hours. The letter was dated the 8th inst.

div3.head: Aug 16. Fri.
div3.p: Unwell, could not study.

div3.head: 17. Sat.
div3.p: Studying a little. It began to rain early & it increased till noon, then ceased.

A letter from Ten. brought the distressing inteligence of the death of our beloved daughter Betsey Humphreys. She was taken with Bileous Fever on Sab. July 21st & died Aug. 8 at 7 O'clock P.M. It is a heavy stroke on us but I trust she was a sincere Christian, & is therefore now with her Saviour. May God accompany this bereavement with a blessing to us all & especially to my dear Sons.

div3.head: 18. Sab.
div3.p: Rain. Preached at Bethel to a small Congn Not well. A horid murder was perpetrated last night at Mr Grim's by a man named Randolph killing his wife-cutting open her bowels with a large disk. The woman died before day.

div3.head: 19. Mon.
div3.p: Warmer. Reading & working. I suffer at night with the Asthma. Rest badly.

div3.head: 20. Tu.
div3.p:
Heavy Rain. In the afternoon took Mrs McFarland to Staunton to consult with Dr. Waddell about a very sore finger from which she has suffered much for ten days. He opened it we went to Col. Tate's & spent the night there. Robert, my son spent the night with us. He has been to Manassas to see James. Did not see Francis who was removed to Leesburg. He brought many momentos from the Battlefield. James sent a minnie Rifle, which
was found the day after the Battle.

div3.head: Aug. 21. Wed.
div3.p: Robert handed me Forty dolls. from James of which I am to remit $7.50 to N. Bent, & retain the remainder for him. Came home to dinner, & there went to see Lizie Brawford & returned.

div3.head: 22. Thurs.
div3.p: Had a bad night with Asthma. Reading.

div3.head: 23. Fri.
div3.p: Spent a restless night with Asthma. Rev. Wm. Pinkerton preached at Bethel & Rev. H. Brown followed with a good exhortation. Mr Brown came home with us.

div3.head: 24. Sat.
div3.p: Cooler. Mr H. Brown preached a very good Sermon on "Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian" & Mr Wm. Pinkerton followed with a good address. I went to see Mr Trotter who is suffering much with pain in his leg, supposed to be neuralgia. Robert came home.

div3.head: 25. Sab.
div3.p: Mr Pinkerton unwell, did not return. Mr Brown preached on Dan. 5:6 "His thoughts troubled him" a good sermon. I introduced the Ordinance. A solemn day.

div3.head: 26. Mon.
div3.p: Spent an uncomfortable night with coughing. Did not rise till near noon; feel very weak.

div3.head: 27. Tu.
div3.p: Still very feeble. Rain. Plowing for wheat NW. field. Remitted to Dr. Wm Brown $5.67-being $5. from Bethel Congn to procure religious reading for the Soldiers & 67 cents for the Central Presbyterian for John Merritt for the remainder of the year.

div3.head: Aug. 28.
div3.p: I spent a bad night. Lay in bed till 11 a.m. I am exceedingly weak-do not know the cause. I feel so dull I can hardly read. Rained all day.

div3.head: 29. Thurs.
div3.p: Still very unwell & feeble. James Rosen died today & I have not been able to go to see him. A very heavy rain this forenoon.

div3.head: 30. Fri.
div3.p: Still feeble. John Hays came for me to go & see Mr Trotter. I went; he is very ill & low & I suppose will die today. Alas. He is a good man. He knew me & ansd. my questions satisfactorily. Went to see Mary Pilson who is confined to to bed, but I hope in no danger.

div3.head: 31. Sat.
div3.p: I was so broken down by my ride yesterday that I rested badly & did not rise till 10 a.m. Mr Monroe came this morning to let me know that Mr Trotter died yesterday at 4 p.m. & would be buried today at 11 a.m. Alas. I cannot go. I am very weak & unwell today.

div3.head: Sept. 1. Sab.
div3.p: Very feeble. Went to Bethel in doubt whether I would be able to preach. Providentially Rev. A.B. McCorkle was there & preached a short but very good discourse.
I dined with him at Mr Bumgarner's. Robert came home this morning.

div3.head: 2. Mon.
div3.p: Took Calomel last night-am better, but weak. Robert left us. A messenger came to inform me that Lizzie Brawford died this morning.
Dr. Wm. S. White came & spent the night with us. Mary at Mr Brawford's.

div3.head: Sep. 3.
div3.p: Preached at Mr Brawford's at Lizzie's Funl. to a large assembly Rev. A.B. McCorkle there.

div3.head: 4. Wed.
div3.p: Set of for Pby. at 7 a.m. to Mount Horeb church. Attended to the business of Pby. was appointed chair man of a Com tee . on our church Relations. Spent the night at Mr James Crawford's.

div3.head: 5. Thurs.
div3.p: Reported on the church relations & it was adopted Unanimously, except Mr Miller & Mr Irwin wished a provisional separation at first. Mr Miller Preached. Staid at Mr Crawford's & had a bad night with Asthma.
I was appointed a Comsr. to aid in organizing the Gen. Assy. of the Con. S. of A.
Spent the night at Dr. Walker's where Rev. Mr. Custer boards. Had Asthma. These two lines belong to the next day.

div3.head: 6. Fri.
div3.p: Presby. finished its business & it adjourned to meet during Synod.

div3.head: 7. Sat.
div3.p: I remained to spend the Sab. & returned to Dr. Walkers. Asthma.

div3.head: 8. Sab.
div3.p: I preached in the morning. Rev. S. Brown administered the Lords Supper & Dr. White preached in the afternoon. We three Ministers came & spent the night at Saml. Finley's. Asthma.

div3.head: 9. Mon.
div3.p: Set out for home. Took Robert home in my Buggy, as he wanted James' Minie Musket. He bid us all Farewell & returned to camp. Had a bad restless night.

div3.head: Sept. 10. Tues.
div3.p: Remained in bed till noon. I am very feeble.

div3.head: 11. Wed.
div3.p: In bed all day, chiefly from debility.

div3.head: 12. Thurs.
div3.p: Have bad nights-distressing cough & have to sit up in bed. Rose in the afternoon.

div3.head: 13. Fri.
div3.p: No better. In bed all day.

div3.head: 14. Sat.
div3.p: Had another bad night, but am a little better today. Remained in bed till 5 p.m.

div3.head: 15. Sab.
div3.p: Had a rather better night. Rose at 11 a.m. Have a little more strength. Alas, I could not go to Bethel to preach the Word. Mary went. A good Congn & a good Prayer meeting. A letter from James.

div3.head: 16. Mon.
div3.p: Perhaps improving. Rose at 10 A.M. Reading. Wrote to James.

div3.head: 17. Tu.
div3.p: I do not think I am any better today. Did not rise till after 10 a.m. recd another sad letter from Dr. Humphreys his youngest & far favourite child Philip died of Diphtheria on the 10th inst. Alas, how mysterious.

div3.head: 18. Wed.
div3.p: Not so well. Mr Gilkeson came to see me. Mrs Dr. Baldwin & Miss Stuart came to see us. I did not rise till after noon.

div3.head: 19. Th.
div3.p: I rose a little after 9 a.m. & feel decidedly stronger & better. Wrote to Dr. Humphreys.

div3.head: 20. Fri.
div3.p: Rode to Mr Bumgarners with the purpose of going to see Mrs Sproul, but found I was not able. Returned & called to see John Rose. Mr Blain came to see us.

div3.head: Sept. 21. Sat.
div3.p: I am somewhat better. Mr Blain remained & went to Mr Bumgarners & returned.

div3.head: 22. Sab.
div3.p: Went to Bethel. Rev. John S. Blain preached an excellent sermon from Acts 12:20. It was ingenious original, simple & evangelical & well delivered. I am quite weak.

div3.head: 23. Mon.
div3.p: I am very feeble & unwell today. Mrs Hallady left us today-Mary took her to Staunton. She goes with Mr & Mrs Bradley, if possible, to join her daughter in Wilkesbarre. She has been here four months. Jef. took her baggage.

div3.head: 24. Tu.
div3.p: I am a little better.

div3.head: 25. Wed.
div3.p: Not so well. Finished plowing for wheat. Mrs Gilkeson & Sally dined here. Mr Pilson came to see me. Mr Henderson here. Took blue pill.

div3.head: 26. Thurs.
div3.p: I am a little stronger. recd a letter from James & ansd. it. Began to rain at dark.

div3.head: 27. Fri.
div3.p: It rained heavily, I think, all night & continued all the forenoon. Wind NE. In the afternoon the wind changed to SE & very high, with heavy showers. At 5 p.m. the wind turned W. & it began to clear off.

div3.head: 28. Sat.
div3.p: Was asthmatic & did not rest well. Did not rise to breakfast. Oppressed in my breathing. recd a letter from Robert from their Camp on the head waters of South Branch of Potomac, date 24th.

div3.head: 29. Sab.
div3.p:
Did not rise till 8 a.m. Still very weak. Went to Bethel & preached an hour in my
usual manner. Felt much exhausted, but did not feel the full effect till I went to bed before Sunset, when the sense of fatigue was greater than I ever felt after preaching. Did not rest well.

div3.head: Sept. 30. Mon.
div3.p: I feel badly-did not rise till 10 1/2 a.m. feeble & Asthmatic. Drilling wheat.

div3.head: October 1. Tu.
div3.p: I had a bad night last night. I think the worst yet. Feel badly. Did not rise till 11 a.m. Feel much oppression in my breast. Yesterday & today Mr Henderson has been drilling wheat for me in the NW field. Sowing Timothy seed also on it. Drilled 19 bushels on the field, supposed to be 1 1/2 Bs an acre anlly.
Paid Mr Henderson $5. for drilling.
Rev. Mr Harris & Mr Gilmer a Candidate for the ministry came & spent the night. Also the Rev. Dr. Wm. Brown from Richmond.

div3.head: 2. Wed.
div3.p: Messrs. Harris & Gilmer left us after breakfast. Dr. Brown remained till after dinner. It was a very pleasant visit to us. I am still suffering much with asthma. After supper Robert came, having been sent from the army with the sick of his Regiment, about 50 in number. He got a furlow for 10 days. Has the Mumps, but not badly.

div3.head: 3. Thurs.
div3.p: I believe I am no better. Did not rise till 11 a.m. Robert & Mary went to Greenville. Sowed nearly Seven Bushels of wheat on the lot in front of the house. Finished Seeding.

div3.head: Octr. 4. Fri.
div3.p: I think I am a little better. Robert went to Staunton-heard that on yesterday the Federal troops, 5000 strong, attacked our at Greenbrier river (2700) & were repulsed. We lost 4 killed Thank God. Robert is quite unwell today.
On Yesterday I received Ten dollars, a present from Robert McAden, son of Samuel, on a account of my attention to his aunt & his Father.

div3.head: 5. Sat.
div3.p: I had very little Asthma last night & feel better, but have a troublesome cough. I feel very weak. I was called on today to preach at Henry Aden's at the funeral of his step daughter Catharine Hall who died last night yesterday & his daughter Sarah who died last night, both of Typhoid fever. Alas, I am not able to go. Mary Lewis sat up last night at Mr McPheeters' as Mrs McP. & Jerusha are both very ill. Mrs McFarland went down today.

div3.head: 6. Sab.
div3.p: Spent an uncomfortable night. Very Weak. Went to Bethel; held a prayer meeting. I delivered two exhortations & prayed. Took a Collection for Domestic Missions. I feel badly.
Went to bed & applied a mustard poultice to my breast which relieved me much.

div3.head: 7. Mon.
div3.p: Rested better & feel better today. It began to rain early & rained heavily nearly all day. Wrote to James & enclosed a letter to Gen. Jackson.

div3.head: October 8. Tues.
div3.p: It rained very heavily last night. I rested tolerably. Not so well this morning, but better in the afternoon. Wrote to Dr. Wm. & Saml Brown.

div3.head: 9. Wed.
div3.p: Rested pretty well. Maria Blackwood & Peggie Anne Lambert, Mrs Tate Wallace & Mrs Dossey spent last night with us & left us today before dinner.
I still feel a good deal unwell. Writing.

div3.head: 10. Thurs.
div3.p: Mrs McFarland sat with sick at Mr McPheeters'. I rested badly-ate my breakfast in bed. I am more unwell today.

div3.head: 11. Fri.
div3.p: Again rested badly, but better after Breakfast. Able to study a little.

div3.head: 12. Sat.
div3.p: Breakfasted in bed. I am about as on yesterday. Studying & preparing for Synod.

div3.head: 13. Sab.
div3.p: Put mustard on my breast last night & am better today. Preached to a good Congn & nearly an hour without much exhaustion-thanks be to God. John Randolph of Middlebrook died yesterday of Apoplexy. Alas few men go into eternity with so gloomy a prospect.

div3.head: 14. Mon.
div3.p: Better. Rose near 4 O'clock a.m. Breakfasted at 5 & set out as soon as light for Staunton & arrived about 7 1/2 O'clock took the Cars for Richmond & arrived about 5 p.m. Lodged at [blank space] kept by Mrs Morton, with Dr. Brown & wife, Mr Saml. Brown also there. Rested pretty well. Fare to Richmond $6. Hackhire.

div3.head: October 15. Tues.
div3.p: Pretty well. Spent a good part of the morning in an excursion through the city. Procured a passport to go to Petersburg. At 4 p.m. took the Cars for Petersburg. Was taken in a Carriage to Capt. Robt D. McIlwaine's where I had every comfort. Dr. Dabney Preached an excellent Sermon.

div3.head: 16. Wed.
div3.p: Had some Asthma last night. Attended closely to business. I was made chairman of a Com tee of ten on the present & prospective state of the Pbn. Ch in the Confederate States.
Rev. Henry Alexander preached on "this one thing I do.

div3.head: 17. Thurs.
div3.p: Attended the sittings of the Synod & of the Com tee diligently. Dr. White took tea with me. Dr. M.D. Hoge preached a noble sermon on

div3.head: 18. Fr.
div3.p: I rested better last night. Attended closely the meetings of Synod & of the important Com tee of which I am Chairman. I felt jaded & did not attend preaching in the evening. Retired early.

div3.head: 19. Sat.
div3.p: Did not rest so well. This has been a busy day & I attended closely.
Heard Dr. Moore preach & Mr Wharey in the evening. The sermon of the latter was good, but the effort to be eloquent was too apparent.

div3.head: October 20. Sab.
div3.p: Dr. Wm. Hoge preached an excellent Sermon from Prov. 1:20 to [blank space]. I closed with prayer. In the afternoon the Lord's Supper was administered by Dr. Wilson (2), Dr. Ramsey (1) & myself (3)-a solemn service.
Rev. Dr. John Leyburn preached at night. I still have some Asthma at night.

Left Petersburg for Richmond at 9 a.m. Went on invitation directly to the house of my valued friend Rev. Dr. M.D. Hoge where I & my friend Dr. White were cordially received. Called on Mr & Mrs Brown. They Spent the evening with me. Heard Humphrey Marshall speak.

div3.head: 22. Tu.
div3.p: I had a bad night with Asthma & feel badly this morning. There is a fine misty rain from the NE. Dr. Hoge procured passports for Dr. White & myself to go to Manassas although they are refusing them almost universally.

div3.head: 23. Wed.
div3.p: I rested better last night.

At 7.50 O'clock left Richmond & reached Manassas at 5 p.m. Maj. Boyles refused us a passport to Centreville & we went on without. Met no obstruction & reached Gen. T.J. Jackson's head quarters about 8 p.m. over 7 miles of the worst road I have travelled on wheels for 20 years. Genl. Jackson sent an Ambulance for us, by Henry White. At Genl. Jackson's head quarters I was introduced to Genl. Johnston the commander in Chief & Maj. Genl. Smith. My son James met me at Manassas.

div3.head: October 23d Wed. Continued.
div3.p: My Son Francis Met me at Genl. Jackson's-I was rejoiced to see him after an absence of nearly 5 years. After family worship conducted by me, we lay down-Genl. J. gave me his own Cot & he & Dr. White lay on the floor without bed or matrass.

div3.head: 24. Thurs.
div3.p: Rested imperfectly. Breakfasted at Genl. J's tent with the Genl. Dr. White Mr. Pendleton, son of the Col. Robert Grattan &

Col. Harman called to see me & gave me a Check for $600. for his wife. My sons came & waked with them to James' tent saw many of my young friends. Col. Harman allowed James & James Hays to be with me all day. Capt. Doyle was very polite in going with me round the field & shewing the fortifications &c.
My Son Francis is on the sick list & is boarding at a Mr Jameson's. I went there with him & James & I staid for dinner. They seem a very pleasant & kind family.
There are probably 30,000 men encamped in sight of Centreville & they are Strongly fortifying all the commanding positions.

I was introduced to many high Officers-two Col. Stuarts & Capt. McLaughlin of the Artilery. Supped with Genl. J. Attended a prayer meeting at Henry White's & addressed & prayed with about 50. Spent the night as the preceding. Bid my son Francis farewell. He is not well.

div3.head: October 25. Fri.
div3.p: Rested pretty well. Woke about 2 O'clock A.M. Gen. J.'s servt. Geroge made a fire at 3 & I arose. The Genl. Also would rise-George brought a lunch-James came on a Mule which Col. Harman let him have with permission to go with me to Manassas & the Countemien which Genl. Jackson gave me. About 4 a.m. I set out on Genl. Jackson's horse. The morning was very cold but fine moonlight. Reached Manassas before sunrise. There parted with my dear Son James & took the cars for Staunton. Reached home in safety about dark. Glory to God.

div3.head: 26. Sat.
div3.p: So much fatigued I could not study.

div3.head: 27. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good Congn but came home much fatigued. Mary & her children went to Mrs Sprouls's, intending tomorrow to go to Mr Harrison's.

div3.head: 28. Mon.
div3.p: did not rest well. Could do but little. Visited Mr McPheters & family. He is very unwell, the others are all better.

div3.head: 29. Tu.
div3.p: I am better. Went the P.O. Letters to Rev. Mr Harris, Mrs E. Brown & to & from Robert. Visited Mr Pilsons family who are much afflicted, also Henry McCadden's & Ann McCadden. Went to Greenville & home. Mary returned from Mr Harrison's.

div3.head: 30. Wed.
31. Thurs.
div3.p: Called to see Mrs Randolph & came home. Sent by Mr F. White $25 to Dr. White for Dom. Missions.

div3.head: Novr. 1. Fr.
div3.p: Day cool & unpleasant, & I am so unwell I cannot study. Began to rain early in the night.

div3.head: 2. Sat.
div3.p: It rained incessantly all night & very heavily this morning. Studying. Went to Mr Gilkeson's-Francis very ill-did not see him. Mr Mc Pheeters worse. Jeff went to Staunton for Dr. Wm. McChesney to come & see Mr McP.
Mrs McFarland went to sit up at Mr Gilkeson's.

div3.head: 3. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel a Funl. Sermon at the request of Mrs Quarels on act. of the death of her son James W.Q. who was in the retreat of Genl. Garnet & came home & died of typhoid fever, aged 26. He was a baptist, joined the ch at 14 & died Oct. 8. The young women whose names I also mentioned were Methodists, the step daughter & daughter of Henry McCadden-Catharine J. Hall & Sarah E. McCadden. I am fatigued.

div3.head: 4. Mon.
div3.p: Last night, apprehending that the atmosphere of my study was unwholsome to me to sleep in, I removed to our old bed room & had a much better night & I am better today. Writing an abstract of the Minutes of Synod for the Central Presbyterian.

div3.head: 5. Tues.
div3.p:
I rested pretty well & feel still better. A messenger came to request me to preach at the Funeral of Capt. Saml. Lambert who died if Typhoid fever on the top of Allegheny, and
his remains were sent home. Had a pretty large Congn Visited John Frenger & his Son Wm. who have been ill with typhoid fever & John Hays, with the same disease. Came home & took Mrs McF to Mr Gilkeson.

div3.head: 6. Wed.
div3.p: Went to Greenville to the Election voted for Jef. Davis for Pres. & Stevens for Vice Pres. Col. J.B. Baldwin for Congress & Jno. Hendren for the Convention. Dined at Wm. Smith's. Put Cloth into the hands of Mitchell to make me a Coat.

div3.head: 7. Thurs.
div3.p: I went to bed unusually well last night and slept comfortably till near 4 a.m. when I woke with a distressing sense of oppression. After an hour or more Mrs McFarland a mustard poultice on my Stomach & I obtained gradual relief but was unwell through the day. I wrote to Robert.

div3.head: 8. Fri.
div3.p: I am pretty well, but for several days have felt that irritation in my skin that admonishes me of that troublesome eruption. I have been studying.

div3.head: 9. Sat.
div3.p: Studying about noon it began to rain & rained heavily till near night. Wrote to Dr. Humphreys. recd letters from Robert & James.

div3.head: 10. Sab.
div3.p: Foggy, gloomy, chilly. I rested badly in the early part of the night from incipient eruption in my left leg chiefly. Preached at Bethel to a good Congn

div3.head: 11. Mon.
div3.p: In consequence of the eruption making me so uncomfortable, though but little appears I set out for Crawford's Springs.
Dined at Robert Dunlap's.
Was very kindly recd by the Crawford family-Mr & Mrs C. Mr & Mrs Morris, Harriet, Mary, Josephine, Wm. &c. 22 hunters there.

div3.head: Nov 12. Tu.
div3.p: Drinking sulphur water. Day very nice. Hunters killed nothing yesterday or today & are discouraged.

div3.head: 13. Wed.
div3.p: The hunters left, lovely day. I am better.

div3.head: 14. Thur.
div3.p: Morning cloudy. No pay would be recd Set off for home at 9 a.m. Dined at Wm. Dunlap's-all very kind, found all well, Deo gratiae. Letters from Francis & James-the latter encamped at Kearnstown, near Winchester. Came from Manassas to Strasburg on Friday night.

div3.head: 15. Fri.
div3.p: This the day appointed by Pres. Davis as a day of Fasting & prayer. We had a very good Congn & a Sermon interesting meeting. Rev. John H. Harris with us.

div3.head: 16. Sat.
div3.p: A sprinkling of snow last night-the first. Day very cold. Mr Harris preached well.

div3.head: 17. Sab.
div3.p: This our Communion Sab. recd Mr Johnathan Hauber on Cert from Waynesboro & Miss Mary Guy, daughter of Wm Guy of Deerfield, on Examination. Mr Harris made a very long prayer & preached 1 hour & 25 min. The Sermon did not please me.
We had a very good Congn & good attention.

div3.head: 18. Mon.
div3.p: Visited John Franger, who is probably near death. He has a hope.
Paid Mr Mitchell for making me a coat $4.50. being 50 cents less than his price. Dined at Dr. Tate's.
Received from James $20. to keep for him.

div3.head: Nov. 19. Tu.
div3.p: Went to visit Mrs Sproul. She is very unwell-confined to bed, but better. I fear, however, she will never recover much.

div3.head: 20. Wed.
div3.p: Preached at the Funeral of John Franger. Called to see John Hays-he is improving. The Symptoms of the eruption-the irritation in my legs & back very troublesome & keeps me awake at nights.

div3.head: 21. Thurs.
div3.p: Set off for Crawford's Springs. Dined at Wm. Dunlap's.

div3.head: 22. Fr.
div3.p: Reading & drink sulphur water.

div3.head: 23. Sat.
div3.p: Reading & writing &c.

div3.head: 24. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Variety Springs to the invalid convalescent Soldiers. There are about 120 there. Dr. Jon G. Boatwright is the Surgeon & Lieut Bailey the milatary officer.

div3.head: 25. Mon.
div3.p: Came home. Threshing Oats.

div3.head: 26. Tu.
div3.p: Writing a Sermon. Cleaning Oats.

div3.head: 27. Wed.
div3.p: Preparing for my journey to Augusta. Threshing Wheat half the day. Rain.

div3.head: 28. Thurs.
div3.p: Left home about noon for Staunton on my way to Augusta Ga. to form the Genl. Assembly of the Pbn. Ch. in the Confederate States of America. Mary & Frank went with me to Staunton. Spent the night at Col. Tate's. Had Asthma.

div3.head: Nov 29. Fri.
div3.p: Left Staunton at 7.15' for Richmond & arrived there at 5.15' p.m. Prof. Campbell, Rev. W.S. Richardson & J.D. Armstrong, Esqr. in Company. Lodged at Dr. Hoge's.

div3.head: 30. Sat.
div3.p: Left R. at 5 a.m. in company with Rev. Dr. Wm. Brown. Breakfast in Petersburg. Dr. A.B. Ramsey, Mr S. McCorkle, Dr. Foote, &c with us. Through Weldon & Raleigh to Greensboro, & arrived at 9 30' p.m. Staid at a hotell.

div3.head: Dec. 1. Sab.
div3.p: Rev. J. Henry Smith, the Pastor, preached in the afternoon, Dr. Brown & Dr. Foote at night. Became acquainted with Mr Sloan (an Elder) Mr Jesse H. Lindsay an Elder also & who accompanied us to the Genl. Assly. also Mr [blank space] Sterling, Teacher. Left G. at 9.30' p.m. & reached Charlotte N.C. at 3 a.m. Slept 4 hours & breakfasted.

div3.head: Dec. 2. Mon.
div3.p: Morning pleasant. In the afternoon, began to rain. When near Winnsboro, the hindmost Car in which most of us were ran off the track & the wheels were torn from under it & it was very much wrecked by being dragged over the ends of the ties for about 30 yards. But then the coupling broke which saved our lives. No one was hurt-blessed be God. Lodged at the Congaree House, Columbia.

div3.head: 3. Tues.
div3.p:
Cs. Last night it rained in torrents. Left Columbia at 6.30' & Branchville at
11 a.m. and arrived at Augusta Ga at 3 p.m. Dined at the Southern States Hotel without charge to us. I was taken to Judge R.H. Warren's. Pretty well, but a little Asthma.

div3.head: Dec. 4. Wed.
div3.p: Rev. Dr. Jos. R. Wilson & Dr. Wm Brown called on me to indicate a plan that is seemed had been agreed upon by some, I know not who-that I should be appointed to preside till the Assembly was organized, & that I should nominate the Rev. Dr. B.M. Palmer to preach the Opening Sermon. I agreed to the plan at once & on going to church, Rev. Dr. Jno. N. Waddel, in a very complimentary manner nominated me to preside in Organizing the Assembly. He put it to vote & it was unanimous. I then took the Chair & after a few words nominated Dr. Palmer & he was appointed unanimously. He preached what would be called an intellectual discourse, but too studiedly Ornate for my taste.
I then Organized the Assy. with prayer & continued to preside till Moderator & Clerks were chosen.

div3.head: 5. Thurs.
div3.p:
Clear, Frost. I was appointed Chairman of the Com tee of Bills & Overtures; a most important trust. I attended closely to the business of the Assembly & my Com tee . I am sorry we cannot have Worship in
Judge Warren's family; & indeed we have almost no intercourse but at meals. Their hospitality is all I could wish.

div3.head: Dec. 6. Fri.
div3.p: Clear & warmer. I coughed very much last night. Attended diligently to the duties of the Assembly.

div3.head: 7. Sat.
div3.p:
Mild & pleasant. Engaged as yesterday. During a debate I rose to speak & had the floor clearly-but Rev. Peyton Harrison rose after me & went on in his loud manner, regardless of me-I stood till he was done & then said My brother Harrison goes on without noticing any one. This produced a smile. But after the Assy. adjourned he came by where I was, & said I had publickly insulted him, & he was not going to suffer it; & that he was aware of my course towards him heretofore. I said, why what does this mean Br. H. I intended no insult, but this is your habit in the Judicatories to begin & go on, no matter who has the floor. He denied it. (Dr. Ramsey & Dr. Wm. Brown sustain me in this.) I said I never in all my life intentionally wounded the feelings of any brother. Well, he said you have wounded mine. I said I must have an explanation of this.
He said I will give it some time. We then parted. I related the matter to Dr. Ramsey, who expressed wonder that offence should have been taken.

In the evening I went to consult Dr. Brown. When I had finished my statement of the affair to him, Mr Harrison came into his room on an errand. I insisted that he should sit down, & he did so after some hesitation. I then with much feeling, protested that I had no intention of wounding his feelings, & then asked him what he referred to in my former conduct toward him. He said it was a letter I had written to the Board of Education, when he was talked of to succeed Dr. Van Rensselaer, that it had been industriously circulated, & that although he did not want the office, the letter had defeated his election. That I had represented him as old=66 when he was only 59 & that he was feeble. He had not seen the letter, but understood that I had spoken of him kindly which he regarded as so much the worse. I said I had very much forgotten the contents of my letter, but it was written conscientiously. I thought he was then unable to preach which I
regarded as a serious disqualification for the office. He said he was able to preach at that time. I said, if he wished it, I would incidentally bring the matter up in the Assembly & explain. He said, No, he did not wish it-that he was satisfied; & so the matter ended.

It is painful to me to think that he has been entertaining those feelings towards me in regard to that letter, altogether undeserved & yet meeting me everywhere just as formerly. He is a man to whom I have never had an unkind feeling, but the sincerest friendship. Whom can I confide in?

div3.head: Dec. 8. Sab.
div3.p: Day very mild & pleasant. I feel badly early in the morning. I heard Dr. Palmer preach a good Sermon, on Eph. 4:30. And praise not the Holy Spirit &c.

div3.head: 9. Mon.
div3.p: Attending the Assy. & Com ttee . Dined at Saml Clark's. In the evening attended a meeting of the Assy in behalf of Foreign Missions-Rev. Messrs Lockridge, Wright (Chacktaw) & Williams delivered addresses.

div3.head: 10. Tu.
div3.p:
Warm. Sitting with open windows. Engaged as yesterday. Dined with Mr Shear. An evening meeting of the Assy. about
Evangelical Labours for the Coloured people. Rev. Dr C.C. Jones made an excellent address.

div3.head: Dec. 11. Wed.
div3.p: Since the 5th the weather has been unusually mild. This evening the wind East. Dr. Lacy dined with us.

div3.head: 12. Thurs.
div3.p: Clear & cool. The inteligence reached us of the burning of a large portion of the City of Charleston last night. Attended to business. Dined with my Old Friend Rev. Dr. S.S. Davis. He is the only man I saw here 40 years ago that I have now met with. He lives on the Sand Hills, 3 miles from the City. His family consists of his wife & daughter, his sister in law Miss Cummins & a Mrs Smith.

div3.head: 13. Fri.
div3.p: Clear & colder. Rested better last night. Attended to business as usual. No afternoon or evening Sessions.
A meeting of the Citizens today for the relief of the sufferers by the fire in Charleston, & $6,300 were subscribed. Our Assy. subscribed $231, additional.

div3.head: 14. Sat.
div3.p: Clear & cool. The Assy. had their sessions Sat. late. Dined at Dr. Walkers.

div3.head: 15. Sab.
div3.p: Clear & cool, great irritation in my back. I was urged to preach this morning in the Pbn. Ch. but declined. Rev. S.R. Houston preached & Dr. Leland & Dr. Pratt administered the Lord's Supper. Heard an interesting address on Indian Missions by Rev. Dr. Kingsbury, missionary to the Chocktaws.

div3.head: Decr. 16. Mon.
div3.p: The Assy. held three sessions today & pressed business to completion. We had devotional Services at the close & I offered the last prayer, except the adjourning prayer by the Moderator.
Thus terminated this assembly remarkable for the harmony & good Spirit that prevailed. The God of love & peace was certainly with us. Spent the night at the Southern States Hotel.

div3.head: 17. Tues.
div3.p: Left Augusta at 7 a.m. & arrived at Columbia, 130 miles, at 4 p.m. Spent the night at the Congaree House.

div3.head: 18. Wed.
div3.p: Clear. Left Columbia at 8 a.m. & reached Charlotte N.C. 110 miles at 3 1/2 p.m. Left C. at 7 1/2 p.m. & reached Raleigh, 170 ms. at 5 a.m. A beautiful moon-light night.

div3.head: 19. Thurs.
div3.p: Clear. at Franklinton 27 miles from Raleigh. By Weldon to Petersburg at 4 p.m. & Richmond at dark. Spent the night pleasantly at Dr. Hoge's.
Left Richmond at 7.30' a.m. & arrived at Staunton at 4 p.m. Got a seat in Mr Treseys buggy to Mint Spring & there met my son Francis & reached home about 7 p.m. Blessed be God.

I found my dear son Robert at home prostrated with Typhoid Fever. He has been down & very ill for some time-was brought in a common waggon to Staunton on Wednesday.
This morning Francis & Mary brought him home in a Spring waggon. He is very weak, unable to raise himself up in bed.
Francis has been at home since the 6th inst. suffering much from time to time with Neuralgia in his head & whole right side.

div3.head: Dec. 21. Sat.
div3.p: I feel much fatigue. A messenger came with the tiding of the death of Mrs Matilda Sproul & the request that I should preach at her funeral tomorrow. Dr. Tate comes to see Robert-he is somewhat better today.

div3.head: 22. Sab.
div3.p: I preached at Sprouls. Rev. H. Brown preached at Bethel. I returned fatigued.

div3.head: 23. Mon.
div3.p: Robert is, we think a little better. I am so wearied that I can do nothing.

div3.head: 24. Tues.
div3.p: The Dr. came to see Robert who is some improving. A letter from sister Roxa to say James has been in a hard battle but escaped unhurt. Blessed be God. I still feel very languid.

div3.head: 25. Wed.
div3.p: CHRISTMAS. Thanks be to God for his mercies to us all. Robert is suffering but little. The same is true of Francis; the Others are well. Mrs Gilkeson dined with us.

div3.head: 26. Thurs.
div3.p: Day mild. Robert did not rest well, but no worse. Mr McPheeters & Jerusha here. Tonight Robert suffered much with pain in his bowels. Poultices of warm mush relieved him.

div3.head: 27. Fri.
div3.p: I am not well; Robert perhaps a little better. Mr Jas Henderson spent the day here.

div3.head: Dec. 28. Sat.
div3.p: Cold. Studying. Dr. Hall here. Robert I think is better. Andw Bratton here.

div3.head: 29. Sab.
div3.p: Pleasant. Pretty good Congn I preached about the events of the last year.

div3.head: 30. Mon.
div3.p: At home. Robert still better. Liz Very unwell. Joe Fix working here.

div3.head: 31. Tues.
div3.p: I am not well enough to go from home. Robert not so well. Liz. better. Mr Gilkeson Mr Stover & Dr. Tate here.

This night terminates the year 1861. Blessed be God mercies have abounded through the year. But it has also been a year of great affliction. My sons all in the army & all have been sick & in danger. James is now well, & in Genl. T.J. Jackson's army, encamped at Winchester.

Robert has been ill for a month with Typhoid Fever-is somewhat better but not yet able to sit up even in bed. But I trust, by the blessings of God, he will recover. It was a great mercy he got home, & that Francis got home to help nurse him.
Francis is at home on sick furough. Is better however & will return to the army shortly. My blessed wife enjoys fine health. Mary & her children are also well.
I am becoming more & more infirm. I am now threatened with that troublesome eruption Psoriasis.

div3.head: 1862. January 1. Wednesday
div3.p: Uncommonly warm, but the wind very high. I am quite unwell. Too weak to ride out. Robert better. Francis and Mary went to Mr Bumgarner's.

div3.head: 2. Thurs.
div3.p: I am still unwell. Francis had a distressing attack of Neuralgia. Sat up all night & is utterly prostrated. to Robert improving slowly.
I went to the Post office. Paid the Miss Heydens for 10 yds. of Jeans at $1.50 & 10 yds. of Linsey at .75=$22.50

div3.head: 3. Fri.
div3.p: I am better-all better but Frank & Rhoda who were taken sick last night. Colds I suppose-day threatening.

div3.head: 4. Sat.
div3.p: Trying to study, but not well.

div3.head: 5. Sab.
div3.p: Very cold. My daughter has sore throat & Frank has a red rash. I suppose both their cases partake of the nature of Diphtheria.
I went to church on horseback. The roads covered with a sheet of hard ice-dangerous riding. Few hearers-20 to 25. I was very cold coming home.

div3.head: 6. Mon.
div3.p: Ground white with snow. Dr. Tate came to see the Sick. Rhoda quite unwell. Mary worse. Frank perhaps a little better.

div3.head: 7. Tues.
div3.p: Family a little better. I went to Greenville on horseback to return property subject to the Confederate States War Tax. Dined at Dr. Tate's. Had all my horses rough Shod all round. Called on Mrs Graham, Mrs Jackson & Mrs James Hays. Dr. Tate here.

div3.head: Jany. 8. Wed.
div3.p: At 6 a.m. Francis set off for Richmond-Jeff. took him to Staunton. I wrote by him to Dr. Brown & enclosed $35. for the Central Presbyterian from subscribers in advance-no names sent.

div3.head: 9. Thurs.
div3.p: Mary Lou has Scarlett Fever. Others better. Mrs McFarland & I went to Mrs Mary E. Wallace's & at 2 O'clock p.m. I married her to Mr Wm. W. King, & recd. a fee of $20. Returned home. Day very fine.

div3.head: 10. Fri.
div3.p: This a very warm day for the Season. All better but Mary Lou. Robert sat at the table at dinner-the first time since he was taken sick. Francis returned.

div3.head: 11. Sat.
div3.p: Day pleasant. Studying. All still better

div3.head: 12. Sab.
div3.p: Marvelously warm for the season. Francis sick. Mrs McF. & I alone went to Bethel. A good & attentive Congn

div3.head: 13. Mon.
div3.p: Rode to Jos. Smith's-not at home. Dr. Tate here. Rode to James Hall's & paid him for Rhoda's hire $30. & for Moses' work 27 days $13.50. Day cold, Thermometer fell all day.

div3.head: 14. Tu.
div3.p: We are all better, but Mary Lou is suffering from itching of the eruption of the scarlet fever. It began to snow early in the night & snowed moderately-about 3 inches deep this morning. Very little snow fell through the day. Letters form James, Roxa B. & Dr. Humphreys all well. James gives an account of their winter campaign to Bath in Morgan Co. It was hard service.

div3.head: 15. Wed.
div3.p:
Half an inch of small hail last night. This morning sleet. Then Rain & it began to clear off in
the afternoon. Mary Lou better. Robert can walk through the house-has a most craving appetite. I am preparing the Minutes of Synod for the press.

div3.head: Jan. 16. Thurs.
div3.p: Writing. In the afternoon visited the family of Alexr Gardner who have lost two children with Diphtheria & Mrs G. & their oldest daughter Margaret are now confined to bed with it but better. Went to Joseph Smith's paid him $110. by Check in full for Jeff's hire for last year, & $3.50 for a pair of shoes he bought for him. Gave him a new note for $110 for this year's hire.

div3.head: 17. Fri.
div3.p: Reading & studying.

div3.head: 18. Sat.
div3.p: Day mild. Rain. Studying.

div3.head: 19. Sab.
div3.p: Day warm & damp & a little showery. Mrs McF. & I went to Bethel-a small Congn. Preached.

div3.head: 20. Mon.
div3.p: Not well; feeble. Two very heavy thunder-showers. Killed a Beef Cow-Wm. Silars assisting. The Beef weighed 550 lbs.

div3.head: 21. Tues.
div3.p: The wind NE. & moderate rain all day.

div3.head: 22. Wed.
div3.p: Cool & damp. Reading & Writing.
On the 20 remitted by Check to Dr. Wm. Brown $27. This with $35. sent by Francis on the 8th inst. is in full for 31 copies of the Central Presbyterian.

div3.head: 23. Thurs.
div3.p: Finished preparing Minutes of Synod for the press.

div3.head: 24. Frid.
div3.p: About 10 A.M. it began to snow with a furious driving NE. wind. Continued all day. With great difficulty I could keep warm in my study. Preparing the Minutes for Mailing & wrote to Dr Brown.

div3.head: Jan. 25. Sat.
div3.p: Sent the Minutes to the P.O. by Frank. Studying a little. Sent the Shoemaker Murkly 8 bushels of ears of Corn at .75 per B. for double B. About 4 P.M. unexpectedly James arrived to the great joy of us all after an absenc of over 9 months. He is on sick furlough, but is better since he left Romney. Blessed be God for his mercies to us all.

div3.head: 26. Sab.
div3.p: Colder. Preached at Bethel to a small Congn.

div3.head: 27. Mon.
div3.p: Working & reading.

div3.head: 28. Tu.
div3.p: Reading & studying. A messenger came for me to preach tomorrow at the funeral of Dr. Tates son John, aged 3 y. who died of Diphtheria.

div3.head: 29. W.
div3.p: Left home at 8 a.m. Preached at Mrs M.M. Tate where the child died, to a goodly number. The Parents greatly distressed. Dined at Mr Humphreys. Roads very bad. I on horseback. Came home quite fatigued. Day very mild.

div3.head: 30. Thurs.
div3.p: Rained much in the night & this morning. Reading & studying.

div3.head: 31. Fr.
div3.p: Studying &c. Very gloomy day.

div3.head: Feb. 1. Sat.
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 2. Sab.
div3.p: Last night, before 11 O'clock, I awoke with a chill, which continued nearly all night with headache & pain in my back. I could not rise this morning-in bed all day-headache continued. Could not preach at the Funl of Andy McClure's child which was burned to death.

div3.head: Feb. 3. Mon.
div3.p: It began to snow in the night, & in the morning snowed very fast till near noon when it ceased-about 8 inches deep. I rose after 9 O'clock, took some Physic & am better but feel very weak.
Francis left us today having been here since Dec. 6th. James went with him to Staunton. He has an offer of the place of Reporter for the Richmond Examiner at $15. per week.

div3.head: 4. Tu.
div3.p: Day clear & pleasant but cool & roads almost impassable. Reading & working.

div3.head: 5. Wed.
div3.p: Reading & working. Mr Pilson came to see me & staid several hours. We had a number of hands to husk corn in the Barn-did not finish.

div3.head: 6. Thurs.
div3.p: It began to rain in the night & continued heavily till near noon. Sent a letter to the Office of Maj. Gen. T.J. Jackson deploring his resignation &c. recd. a letter from Sister Roxa giving an account of Genl. Jackson's resign. & the cause.

div3.head: 7. Fri.
div3.p: Took leather to Lowry to make shoes for the black women. Visited Sally Ann McCaden, Gardner's family & Wm. Wilson. Evening threatening.

div3.head: 8. Sat.
div3.p: Snow covered the ground this morning. Preparing for the Sabbath.

div3.head: 9. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a small Congn. Roads bad.

div3.head: 10. Mon.
div3.p: Cold. Preached to a large Congn. at Thos. A. Lightner's at the Funl. of John Lightner, Son of Jacob, a member of the College Company, who died in the hospital in Winchester of Typhoid Pneumonia. Body here.

div3.head: Feb. 11. Tues.
div3.p: Doing little but reading. Snowed in the afternoon.

div3.head: 12. Wed.
div3.p: Visited Sally Ann McCadden & communicated to her the solemn intelligence that in the opinion of Dr. churchman, she would not recover. She received it calmly. Called at Mr Gardner's & Col. Wilson.

div3.head: 13. Thurs.
div3.p: A very pleasant day. Reading & working.

div3.head: 14. Fri.
div3.p: Threatening. James left us to return to camp near Winchester at 6 a.m. to take the Cars at Staunton by the way of Manassas. He is not well-has a very bad cold & cough, is not fit to go into camp. I am reading & studying.

div3.head: 15. Sat.
div3.p: A little snow fell in the night, but in the morning it fell fast & continued till 1 p.m. about 5 inches fell. Reading & studying.

div3.head: 16. Sab.
div3.p: Cold. Preached at Bethel to a good Congn. for the day & the state of the roads.

div3.head: 17. Mon.
div3.p: A gloomy day. In the forenoon it rained moderately & froze. Reading.

div3.head: 18. Tu.
div3.p: Reading Writing & Working.
Robert & Mary visiting. Day pleasant.

A letter from Francis-he has commenced Reporting for the "Examiner" in Richmond, the 10th. Sent a letter to the office for Dr. Wm Brown & containin a Check for $10.50 Ten dollars from Mrs Angelina Mish to pay two years arrears for the "C. Pbn." & for this year & $3. to send Papers to the Soldiers of Capt. Humphrey's & Capt. Lilley's Companies.

div3.head: Feb. 19. Wed.
div3.p: It began to rain in the night & continued all day with very little abatement. Very gloomy. Working.

div3.head: 20. Thurs.
div3.p: I set out early for Staunton to attend a pro re nata meeting of the Pby. to dissolve the Pastoral relation between Rev. Saml. Brown & the church of Windy Cove, which was done. I dined at Mr Baker's & attended to some business. Letters received from Francis & James. James still unwell, has permission to stay a few days at his uncle's.

div3.head: 21. Fri.
div3.p: Reading & Studying.

div3.head: 22. Sat.
div3.p: Rained moderately all day & in the evening very heavily. The Miss Wilsons & Miss Mary Pringle spent the day here. I was studying. Letters from James & Roxa.

div3.head: 23. Sab.
div3.p: Not well last night. Day mild. Preached at Bethel to a tolerable Congn.

div3.head: 24. Mon.
div3.p: The night had been warm & the morning was mild, but the wind sprung up from the West & was very high. It blew down much of my fence. I was reading & working.

div3.head: 25. Tues.
div3.p: Cold. Went to the Post Office & visited Sally Anne McCadden, who is very low. Called at Col. Wilson's & Mr Gilkeson's.

div3.head: 26. Wed.
div3.p: Began to plow for Corn in the NW. or Hill field. About 2 P.M. it began to rain & continued all the the afternoon. Sent Jeff. in search of Dr. Tate for Robt who is suffering grievously with Piles has a good deal of Fever &c. I was reading & working.

div3.head: Feb. 27. Thurs.
div3.p: Brought home 4 Bls. of Flour & paid Mr Gilkeson one borrowed of him. I was preparing for the Fast day.

div3.head: 28. Fri.
div3.p: This day was appointed by Pres. Davis as a day of Humiliation, Fasting & Prayer; & although very cold, we had a very large & solemn Congn. which I regard as very encouraging.

div3.head: March 1. Sat.
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 2. Sab.
div3.p: Snowed a little last night. This morning Rained & then turned to sleet & hail with vivid lightening & heavy thunder while hailing. Then the wind turned W. & it ceased.
It was so stormy I did not go to Bethel. Calvin Swink came to inform me of the death of Sallie Ann McCadden.

div3.head: 3. Mon.
div3.p: Thick fog, then Rain all the afternoon & froze much on the Trees. I preached at the Funeral of Sallie Ann McCadden on Job. 14:20. the same text from which I had preached at the funeral of her mother 36 years ago. Came home in the rain. Found Rev. E.D. Junkin in my house-he spent the night with us. High West wind at night.

div3.head: 4. Tu.
div3.p: Everything covered with ice. The day cold. I am very dull; engaged in reading.

div3.head: 5. Wed.
div3.p: Working a little & reading. Wrote to Rev. Jas. Morrison.

div3.head: 6. Thurs.
div3.p: Called at Mr Gilkesons & went to the Post Office. Unfavourable Rumors of wars. Working.

div3.head: March 7. Fri.
div3.p: Very cold. Last night I suffered from a stitch (a sharp pain) in my right breast, but today am pretty well but very chilly & dull. Reading.

div3.head: 8. Sat.
div3.p: Day pleasant. Received letters from Francis from Dr. Wm. Brown & Wife. Also one from James, who has re-enlisted for three years or during the war. This is to me a painful necessity, as I shall have no one to aid me in my Farming. I cannot attend to it as it ought to be, but the will of the Lord be done. May God preserve his soul & body & may I live to see him at home again free from the alarms of war.

div3.head: 9. Sab.
div3.p: Day pleasant. Preached at Bethel to a good & very attentive Congregation.

div3.head: 10. Mon.
div3.p: Mild & Showery. Plowing. Dr. Tate came to see Robert. I was fixing my saddle &c. Wrote to James.

div3.head: 11. Tu.
div3.p: Rode down to Mr Gilkesons. Dined at Mr James Henderson's. Setting my saws.

div3.head: 12. Wed.
div3.p: Went to Greenville. The people in great trouble about the Militia all being called out. Paid my store Bills & Mr Lightner's Act. for Smith-work &c. Settled with Mr Wm. Smith & paid him in full. Bought a Quarter of sole Leather, 11 1/2 lbs at 50 cents per lb. Paid.

div3.head: 13. Thurs.
div3.p: Rain from NE. Working, Reading & studying.

div3.head: 14. Fri.
div3.p: Gloomy-thick fog. Studying. Robert went to Staunton. This the day for 3 Regiments of Militia to rendevous in Staunton, to reinforce Genl. T.J. Jackson, who has fallen back from Winchester.

div3.head: March 15. Sat.
div3.p: A very thick fog this morning & continued more or less through the day. Also much rain fell. I was studying. It seems there has been no mail from Richmond for several days. The Cars doubtless employed about the Army. Conflicts must be near, but all our armies in Va. are falling back, it seems.

div3.head: 16. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good Congn. A number of volunteers & Militia men present, who go immediately to join the Army. I pressed the importance of fervent importunate prayer. Luke 18:1-8.

div3.head: 17. Mon.
div3.p: Day tolerably pleasant. Robert & I were making a Corncrib in the Barn. Fatigued. recd. a letter from James. The Army was on the 13th 2 1/2 miles below Strawsburg, but would probably move the next day, falling back. The Union troops had taken possession of Winchester & advanced to Newtown.

div3.head: 18. Tus.
div3.p: Rode to the P.O. Dined at Mr Christian's. Emaline Sproul has been very ill with Pneumonia but is better, able to be up. Called at Mr Pilson's & Mr Blackwood's & went to Adam Hawpe's to see Jeffery, who is likely to not live long. Came home late.

div3.head: 19. Wed.
div3.p: At home, reading & working. Day threatening. About 5 p.m. began to rain.

div3.head: 20. Thurs.
div3.p: Day very damp & uncomfortable. I went to the P.O. & to the sale of S. McCadden's property. A letter from Francis & Rev. F.H. Bowman. Rained very heavily at night, & then hail, thunder & lightening. A true Equinoctial.

div3.head: March 21. Fri.
div3.p: This morning snowing 1 1/2 inches. The day somewhat Cloudy. I was reading & studying.

div3.head: 22. Sat.
div3.p: About one inch of fresh snow on the ground. Engaged in Study. Sally & Lovey Gilkeson here.

div3.head: 23. Sab.
div3.p: Day uncomfortably cold. Preached at Bethel. The men so generally gone, Congn. small. Heard that Gen. Johnston had achieved a great victory near Luray lost 180 killed & took 6000 prisoners! Can it be so?

div3.head: 24. Mon.
div3.p: A chilly gloomy day. Reading.

div3.head: 25. Tues.
div3.p: Day cold. Went to the P.O. called at McCaddens & at Squire Blackwood's. Went to Greenville. I learn there was no foundation whatever for the reported victory. But Gen. T.J. Jackson had a battle on last Sab. 3 ms. below Newton & was repulsed by a vastly superior force & it is said with considerable loss. John Wilson & Robt. Grass of Capt Newton's Comp. killed. I trust in God my dear son James is safe.

div3.head: 26. Wed.
div3.p: I caught cold yesterday, & suffered much with a "stitch" in my side last night. Did not rise today till near noon. I am not very well today.

div3.head: 27. Thurs.
div3.p: I am pretty well. Went to Staunton in my Buggy. Roads horribly bad. Went to the hospital-saw a man who saw James on Monday. He is safe-thanks to God. Rode to Augusta church & lodged with Rev. F.H. Bowman.

div3.head: 28. Fri.
div3.p: Preached to a small Congn. Good attention.

div3.head: 29. Sat.
div3.p: Day very damp & unpleasant. I preached to a better Congn. & Baptized Mr Bowman's first born Son Wm. Francis. I had baptized the Father.

div3.head: March 30. Sab.
div3.p: The day Chilly & damp; the trees loaded with ice. Rained much last night. I preached & aided in administering the Lord's Supper. A pretty good Congn. for the day & roads. I have caught some cold.

div3.head: 31. Mon.
div3.p: Day clear & warm. Came to Staunton & spent several hours there. Dined at Mr Davis Kayser, with Dr. White a Refugee from near Wheeling & Mr Echols, whose brother Col. Echols is here wounded-his arm broken. I saw Dr. McGuire who informed me that a man from Newton told him as I understood, that he had helped to bury our dead, & there were 82. Mr Baker, the Clerk at the Hospital, told me there were 148 wounded on their books. I came home.

div3.head: April. 1. Tu.
div3.p: Day threatening. Wrote to Rev. Dr. Wm. Brown & enclosed a letter to Wm. Fr. Clemmitt & a Check to his Order for $55.00 for Printing the Minutes of Synod.

div3.head: 2. Wed.
div3.p: Reading & mending a plow.

div3.head: 3. Thurs.
div3.p: Very warm & pleasant day. Went to Mr Halls to get Mose to work for me occasionally. Went to Greenville. Dr. Tate gave me $70. sent by my son James to keep for him. Visited Alexr. Brownlee's family & especially his daughter Margaret whose husband John W. Wilson was killed in the battle near Winchester. Visited also Issabella Doak, James Hays & Samuel Hays.

div3.head: April 4. Fr.
div3.p: Had a Chill last night & did not rise today till near 10 O'clock. Quite unwell. Could not study. Reading. Molly Bumgarner here.

div3.head: 5. Sat.
div3.p: Rained in the night & this morning. I am reading & studying:-am better today.

div3.head: 6. Sab.
div3.p: Day pleasant-good Congn. Preached with more liberty than usual-thanks be to God. There was very solemn attention. Collection-Publication.

div3.head: 7. Mon.
div3.p: Cloudy. About 9 a.m. it began to Snow from the NE. & about 2 1/2 inches fell when it began to rain. I was preparing the Minutes of Synod for mailing.

div3.head: 8. Tues.
div3.p: It rained moderately in the night & all day today & sometimes heavily & it froze very much in Isicles on the trees. It was one of the most gloomy days I have seen. I was reading & studying.

div3.head: 9. Wed.
div3.p: This day is even more gloomy & uncomfortable than yesterday. There has been hail & snow more or less falling nearly all day, & the ice on the trees increasing & some are breaking. I have felt very dull-doing little.

div3.head: 10. Thurs.
div3.p: Morning gloomy, but cleared & the ice fell off the trees. I went to the Post Office & Mailed 200 copies of the Minutes of Synod. Called to see Wm. Wilson.

div3.head: 11. Fri.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a small Congn. Mr Bowman disappointed me. Mr B. came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 12. Sat.
div3.p: Mr Bowman preached well to a good Congn. & returned with us. recd Mrs Martha Jerusha Wilson on Examn. wife of James Wilson.

div3.head: April 13. Sab.
div3.p: The Lord's Supper was administered & the season was on the whole pleasant. Mr Bowman preached well. There was a good congregation was a good num & there was good attention. Mr. Bowman again with us.

div3.head: 14. Mon.
div3.p: Mr Bowman left us. I was preparing for Presbytery. Mr Pilson called took supper.

div3.head: 15. Tues.
div3.p: Rained till noon. At 2.15' set out for Pby. Roads horrible. I stopped in Staunton & gave Mr Taylor (merchant) $200. to deposit for me in the Valley Bank. Also paid Mr Kayser's Clerk, N. Conway, $53 for the Com tee of Publication. Rode in the rain to Col. Wm. A. Bell's & spent the night there, 5 miles from Staunton.

div3.head: 16. Wed.
div3.p: Col. Bell accompanied me to Union church 5 miles. Rev. E.D. Junkin preached the opening Sermon for Mr Walker the Pastor, who was the last Modr. I spent the night at Dr. Hendren's.

div3.head: 17. Thurs.
div3.p: Day warm & pleasant-attended Presbytery. Rev. Richard McIlwain preached a good Sermon. He is the Chaplain of the 44 Regt. Va. Volunteers, Col. Scott. I returned to Dr. Hendren's.

div3.head: 18. Fri.
div3.p: day pleasant. Mr Walker preached the Missionary Sermon. Held an hour of Devotional Services I made an address & Dr. White also, & I made the closing prayer at the adjournment about 2 1/2 P.M. I returned to Dr. Hendren's. Rain.

div3.head: 19. Sab.
div3.p:
I preached at the church. Text, Rev. 22:17. Intelligence came that Gen. T.J. Jackson had had fallen back beyond Harrisonburg & the enemy is advancing
and that Gen. Johnston was ordered to fall back from Shanandoah mountain. This is producing great uneasiness. They are removing the sick from hospitals both at Stribbling's Springs & Staunton to some place E. of the Blue Ridge. I rode in a very heavy rain to Mr Hanger's & dined there, & then then rode to Col Bell's. I found them sending off their two sons, John & Wm. & two Negro men for safety to Nelson or Amherst. I spent the night there. They seem in great affliction. Mrs Bell gave me 8 lbs. of crushed Shugar, cost 28cents per lb.

div3.head: 20 April, Sab.
div3.p: Rained all night, & all day today with occasional abatement. I deemed it my duty to go directly home & the roads being worse I think than I ever saw them, I came across by Hebron church. Reached home about noon. Saw a number of the men of Johnston's army, now in command of Col. Baldwin. The head of the Column is at Buffalo Gap. I am fatigued.

div3.head: 21. Mon.
div3.p: It rained all night & is still raining heavily. It is necessary for Robert to leave home to get out of the reach of the Enemy, though he is not yet fit for service. I sent Jeff. with him to Staunton this morning. Johnston's Army is at Valley Mills. Rained all day.

div3.head: 22. Tues.
div3.p: No rain of consequence today. No mail. Brought home the last of my flour. I have now 20 Barrels. Reading & working.

div3.head: 23. Wed.
div3.p: Visited Mr Gilkeson's & Col. Wilson's. Rumors that the Yankees are at Buffalo Gap, & that Johnston has orders to fall back farther.

div3.head: 24. Thurs.
div3.p: It snowed or rained all the afternoon.

div3.head: April 24. Thurs. continued.
div3.p: Mr McPheeters was in Staunton & heard that Robert said he was going to Charlottesville-heard that Genl. Jackson has recd. from 7 to 11 thousand men of a reinforcement.(?) Johnston's army remains as yesterday.

div3.head: 25. Fri.
div3.p: Very gloomy. I am Studying. Hear that Johnston's army remains near West View.

div3.head: 26. Sat.
div3.p: Gloomy morning. Studying. Cleared off.

div3.head: 27. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good & attentive Congn. I laboured to shew Christians that they might enjoy Peace of mind even in the midst of war.

div3.head: 28. Mon.
div3.p: Reading & working. Day very pleasant.

div3.head: 29. Tues.
div3.p: Mr Merritt came here early & we rode together to Westview where Genl. Edwd. Johnston's army is encamped. It rained on us nearly all the way there, then cleared off. I dined very pleasantly with Col. Baldwin & Mrs Baldwin Maj. Ross B. Christian & called on Rev. Capt. Miller, Capt. Humphreys, Capt. Robt. & John Lilley, Ajutout Steptoe & Rev. Richd Mc Ilwaine. Called to see Thompson McClure. The Provost Marshall, Maj. J.S. Hoffman. Came home.
It is reported that New Orleans is in the hands of the enemy. I am encouraged to believe that we will not be here subjected to the Yankee troops as soon as I had feared.
Day unpleasant & wet. Reading & working.

div3.head: May 1. Thurs.
div3.p: Rain. Gloomy. I am very dull, not well. A letter from Wm. L. Bent.

div3.head: May 2. Fri.
div3.p: Day very pleasant. I am well. I went to Greenville. Dined at Wm. Smith's. Went to see Mary Pilson, who is very weak, but some better. Called to see Genl. Carson & his wife & sister in law, Miss [blank space]. They have recently lost an interesting Child.
Saw the Cadets from Lexington over 200 going to join Genl. Jackson's army who are now about to attack Bank's army, it is said.

div3.head: 3. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. recd. a letter from Dr. Humphreys. Date Apl. 16th from the Army of Corinth. He is surgeon of the 20th Regt Ten. Vols. Thinks there is 150,000 men there.

div3.head: 4. Sab.
div3.p: Preached to a good & attentive Congn. Robert came home & to church, is not well.

div3.head: 5. Mon.
div3.p: I am not well-ate my breakfast in bed. Robert has sore throat is threatened with Diphtheria. Went to Staunton to put himself in Dr. Waddell's care. To my perfect astonishment, Gen. Jackson's Army is passing through Staunton towards Buffalo Gap. I know not what it means.

div3.head: 6. Tues.
div3.p:
Went to Staunton to see my sons. Robt. is quite unwell-he has quinsey-is gargling with a solution of Sal Ammoniac. Dr. Waddell thinks he will be well in a few days. Saw the 5th Regt. coming in & met James at the Depot. He is very well & looks fat & hearty. I visited him at his Camp & he went with me to see Robert. Dined at Rev. Mr Bakers, with Rev. Dr. R.L. Dabney, now Adjutant Genl. to Maj. Genl. Jackson,
