but on the Sab. having the privilege of preaching. I was exceedingly gratified with the interview. I also met there Rev. A.B. Carrington & Rev. Paul C. Morton the latter chaplain to the 23 Regt. & the former to the 37. I met with many friends & acquaintances. Spent a pleasant day. But I cannot comprehend Genl. Jackson's movement, unless it be to surprise the army west of us.
I called on Genl. Jackson twice at his head quarters at the Virginia Hotel, & he recd. me very kindly.

div3.head: 7. Wed.
div3.p: I am not very well. Doing little. We are planting Corn in the hill field.

div3.head: 8. Thurs.
div3.p: Finished planting corn. Planting potatoes in the garden. Mr Adam Swink came for me to preach at the funeral of a Child of Harvey Lambert, a boy about 13 yrs. died of Diphtheria. There is a report that Gen. Johnson had a battle with federal troops west of us yesterday, & that he drove them beyond their encampment. It is also reported that there has been some hard fighting on the Peninsula.

div3.head: 9. Fri.
div3.p: Day the warmest for six months. I went & preached at Harvey Lambert's at the Funeral of his son Cyrus aged 12+ yrs. Heard that Genl. Ed. Jonson's army had a hard fight with the enemy yesterday at McDowell & repulsed them. Our loss 300 in killed & wounded. Gen. J. wounded in the ankle & Col. Harman in the arm. My family heard the cannon.

div3.head: 10. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. I hear John Humphreys is wounded in the face. Has come to R.S. Wallaces today.

div3.head: May 11. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel. Before Sermon I visited Lieut. Robt. Glasgow at Mr J. Bumgarner's very low with Typhoid Fever, & at the request of his mother prayed for him in church. He died at 5 O'clock p.m. I preached in Greenville to a very good Congn. then came home.

div3.head: 12. Mon.
div3.p: Reading & studying. Plowing more ground for Oats.

div3.head: 13. Tues.
div3.p: Studying. Rev. Henry Brown came & spent the night here-brought a letter from Robert-he is better.

div3.head: 14. Wed.
div3.p: began to rain at sunrise & increased. It was a very fine rain. Mr Brown staid all day.

div3.head: 15. Thurs.
div3.p: It rained but little last night or this morning. But rained in the Afternoon. Mr Brown left us.

div3.head: 16. Fri.
div3.p: I think it rained all night. Rained in the morning & in the afternoon-but little going to Bethel & returning. This day was appointed by Pres. Davis for special prayer in reference to the war. The Congn. was small on act. of the weather. The prayers by the Elders were very appropriate.

div3.head: 17. Sat.
div3.p: I went to Hebron & by appointment of Pby. Preach a Sermon & presided in the Installing Rev. Thos. L. Preston. Rev. Mr Richeson delivered the Charges to the Pastor & people. Congn. small.

div3.head: 18. Sab.
div3.p: Morning very pleasant. Preached at Hebron, & assisted in administering the Lord's Supper. Stopped out of a shower & dined at Wm. H. Bell's.

div3.head: 19. Mon.
div3.p: Reading & working. Sowed more oats.

div3.head: 20. Tues.
div3.p: Visited Capt. John Humphreys, who is severely wounded in the mouth. Dr. Tate came to see Robert. finished sowing Oats.

div3.head: May 21. Wed.
div3.p: Warm. Went to see Wm. Bumgarner, who came from the Army sick; also to see Mr Bell, son in law to John Brownlee, who has had Typhoid Pneumonia & is very unwell. Called to see Wm. Wilson. Finished harrowing Oats.

div3.head: 22. Thurs.
div3.p: Reading & working. Planting Potatoes.

div3.head: 23. Fri.
div3.p: Studying. Finished planting potatoes.

div3.head: 24. Saturday
div3.p: Rained moderately till near noon. Reading & Studying. No Newspapers this week.

div3.head: 25. Sab.
div3.p: Frost in some places-none here. Preached at Bethel & at Mr J. McClung's to good Congns. Spent the night at Mr Wallace's.

div3.head: 26. Mon.
div3.p: A little frost in some places. Capt. Humphreys is much better. Visited Mrs Charlotte Tate, Mrs Patterson, at D.C. Gilkeson's, John Brownlee's, Mr Eckart's & Col. Wilson's. Francis came home this morning. Reported that Jackson had retaken Winchester & many Prisoners.

div3.head: 27. Tuesday
div3.p: Reading only. Day pleasant.

div3.head: 28. Wed.
div3.p: Went to Staunton & made a number of calls & heard of the complete victory which God gave to Genl. T.J. Jackson at Winchester & the immense quantity of Military stores taken at Martinsburg & it is said 2000 prisoners, or more.

div3.head: 29. Thurs.
div3.p: Reading & working.

div3.head: 30. Fri.
div3.p: Preached at the Funl. of Fannie Templeton daughter of Maj. Saml. M.T. A fine Shower. Hail.

div3.head: May 31. Sat.
div3.p: Day Foggy & gloomy. I feel very dull. I can study very little.

div3.head: June 1. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel & at Christian's Creek School House & then came home.

div3.head: 2. Mon.
div3.p: I attended the Funeral of a Mr Anderson who was wounded at the battle of Kernstown. Rev. Wm. Pinkerton preached. I visited Mr Brawford, who is very ill, but a little better; James Trotter has typhoid Fever saw also Wm. Bumgarner & young Mr Quarles. A heavy rain.

div3.head: 3. Tu.
div3.p: I Baptized two Children for Mrs Somers, who is a member of Rocky Spring church.

div3.head: 4. Wed.
div3.p: It rained yesterday afternoon & I think nearly all night & very heavily today till late in the afternon so as to produce a flood.
Inteligence reached us of hard fighting near Richmond both on Saturday & Sunday last, & on both days we were victorious. Glory to God.

div3.head: 5. Thurs.
div3.p: Reading & working.

div3.head: 6. Fri.
div3.p: Reading & studying. About 6 P.M. my son James arrived very unexpectedly. He has been sick & was off duty for some time, was several days in Winchester, & has been allowed to come home to recruit is health.

div3.head: 7. Sat.
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 8. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel & then went to Greenvill, but a Methodist was preaching & I did not. Heard that Gen. Jackson was attacked at Port Republic this morning.

div3.head: June 9. Mon.
div3.p: About 8 a.m. heard the booming of cannon in the direction of Port Republic. I went to visit Mrs Abe Crist whom I found very ill. I then went to Staunton to hear the news. I heard that yesterday Ewel's command engaged Freemont's army & drove them back-our loss said to be 18 killed & 200 wounded. Today it is said that Jackson is fighting Shields, east of the Shanandoah River & below Port Republic. Dined with the Miss Braggs, Mrs Coleman & Dupey. Came home through a considerable rain.

div3.head: 10. Tues.
div3.p: Raining. I am not well & on act. of the rain could not go to preach at the funeral of Wm. Smith's youngest child. Rained all day.

div3.head: 11. Wed.
div3.p: I had a bad night with Asthma-the worst this year. Felt oppressed in the afternoon; went to bed but got up before 11 & sat till day. Not well today. Working & reading. I hear today that on Monday Gen. Jackson drove Genl. Shields several miles & took 300 prisoners, several pieces of Cannon.

div3.head: 12. Thurs.
div3.p: I had another bad night with Asthma. So feeble today I cannot set out for N. Providence.

div3.head: 13. Fri.
div3.p: Had Asthma last nigh. Set off early for N. Providence & without stoping arrived in season. Rev. R.C. Walker preached-I prayed. Went to visit my valued Friend Rev. J. Morrison, who is very feeble & declining. My visit seemed to be exceedingly grateful to him. I also enjoyed it as the revival of a very trusted & fine friendship.

div3.head: June 14. Sat.
div3.p: I spent a wretched night with Asthma I preached at the church to a good & attentive Congn. Spent the night at the Rev. Mr Junkin's.

div3.head: 15. Sab.
div3.p: I rested better; slept in bed all night. This morning I am quite unwell, but after breakfast better. I preached to a Very large & solemn Congn. & aided in administering the Lord's Supper. Mr Morrison was at church both yesterday & today but yesterday just after I read the first Hymn, he was seized with one of his Epileptic fits & was carried out. After preaching I came home, much fatigued.

div3.head: 16. Mon.
div3.p: I slept pretty well except that cramp in my legs roused me frequently. I feel fatigued & feeble.

div3.head: 17. Tues.
div3.p: Rested badly-quite unwell. Set out to visit Mrs Trotter, but learned that she died last night & was to be buried today at 3 p.m. & no sermon to be preached on account of the sickness of the son & daughter. I called at James Wilson's & went to see Col. Wilson's son Wm.

div3.head: 18. Wed.
div3.p: I am better. Reading. Wrote to Dr. Dabney.

div3.head: 19. Thurs.
div3.p: Unwell. James left home for the Army. Francis took him in the Rockaway. I visited the Trotters-James & Emma quite unwell. Called at Mr Bumgarner's & Halls. Our Army has crossed the Blue Ridge.

div3.head: 20. Fri.
div3.p: Reading & studying-not well. Francis returned. He found the army 7 miles this side of Charlottesville & left James-they marched at 4 a.m. towards C.

div3.head: 21. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. Robert & Mary went to Staunton.

div3.head: June 22. Sab.
div3.p: I am very unwell, yet went to Bethel & preached to a good Congn.

div3.head: 23. Mon.
div3.p: I am better. I called to see Genl. & Mrs Carson & Mr Atkinson. Robert went to the variety Springs-Francis went with him to bring back the horse.

div3.head: 24. Tues.
div3.p: I still feel very languid. Working & reading. Mowing the meadow in front of the house. Mose & a Refugee Mr Wood assisting. Francis Returned.

div3.head: 25. Wed.
div3.p: Francis went to the Variety Springs. I went to engage Mr Henderson to cut my wheat with his Reaper. Genl. Carson & his wife spent the day here.

div3.head: 26. Thurs.
div3.p: Still Mowing & making hay in the front meadow. I am Reading & working.

div3.head: 27. Fri.
div3.p: Rev. John S. Watt, Miss Lizzie Pilson Miss Jennie Pringle & Joseph Wright spent the day here. Mowing the Lot N. of the house.

div3.head: 28. Sat.
div3.p: Raining a little this morning & a little more about noon. I am Reading & studying.

div3.head: 29. Sab.
div3.p: Went to Bethel Mr Watt preached. In the afternoon I preached at Mint Spring, a Funeral discourse in consequence of the death of two children of Alexr. Gardner in Jany last. Also I baptized two of Mr Gardners children.

div3.head: 30. Mon.
div3.p: I preached at the Funl. of Wm. Wilson son of Col. Wm. W. who died of Consumption. Mr Watt came home with us.

div3.head: July 1. Tues.
div3.p:
Mr Watt left us, Francis went to Staunton to have Roberts furlough extended. The report by Telligraph is that we are daily victorious below
Richmond, & the battle had now continued since last Wednesday=7 days. The cannonading has been terrible this afternoon. I have heard it distinctly in my study, doors & windows shut. And now while I write (7.20' p.m.) the reports are often more frequent than I write words. The wind is from the direction of Richmond & a dense atmosphere.

O, may God have mercy on our sinful bleeding country, & may he spare my dear son James, who I suppose is in the battle with Genl. T.J. Jackson, & may God grant us a complete victory, that we may have peace.
Hauled in five loads of Hay. Mowed the lot N. finished it.

div3.head: July 2. Wed.
div3.p: It began to rain moderately in the night & through the greater part of the day very heavily but no flood. Toward evening it ceased. At home reading. Feel very dull. A letter from James-he is safe-glory to God.

div3.head: 3. Thurs.
div3.p: Mary & I set off early. Called to see Mrs Crist Mr Pilson's family, & then Preached at the Funl. of Mr Archd. Christian's youngest child. Then went & preached at the Funl of the youngest child of Saml. Hays Jr. then went to Greenville & called to see Capt. Moore, a wounded soldier. I called also to see Mr Trice who has had his arm dislocated. Came home much fatigued.

div3.head: 4. Frid.
div3.p: Reading & working. Mowing, making & hauling in hay. Wonderful inteligence of victories near Richmond gained by our troops. Thanks be to God.

div3.head: July 5. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. I am suffering from hoarsenes since Thursday.

div3.head: 6. Sab.
div3.p: I had a distressing night with Asthma. Did not rise till after 8 a.m. Very weak.

div3.head: 7. Mon.
div3.p: I was so unwell this morning I was not able to go to preach at the Funl. of John Sproul, the oldest child of Archd. G. Christian. Mrs McFarland & Francis went. I could do nothing but read. Finished hauling in a fine crop of Hay.

div3.head: 8. Tues.
div3.p: I am a little better, but very feeble. Francis went to bring Robert home but met him returning Heard through a friend that James is still safe. Began to cut Wheat.

div3.head: 9. Wed.
div3.p: Cutting Wheat-after dinner Mr Henderson came with is Reaper & 4 hands. I feel very weak today, unable to sit up all the time. Received an interesting letter from James describing the horrible slaughter in the battles near Richmond. Blessed be to God, he is safe.

div3.head: 10. Thurs.
div3.p: Spent an uncomfortable night, & am very weak. Sent for to see Mrs Abe Crist. Called at Mr Pilsons & Col. Wilson's. Cutting grain as yesterday. It rained about noon & in the evening again.

div3.head: 11. Fri.
div3.p: It rained a good deal in the night & heavily this morning; ceased about noon. I am still very unwell.

div3.head: 12. Sat.
div3.p: I spent an uncomfortable night & did not rise till 1 p.m. Mr Henderson & his hands nearly finished cutting my wheat with cradles. Jef. nearly finished. Dr Tate here.

div3.head: July 13. Sab.
div3.p: Still very unwel-could not go to Bethel & disappointed a good Congn. Did not rise till 3 p.m. Robert & Mary went to Bethel.

div3.head: 14. Mon.
div3.p: I am somewhat better-rose about 7.30' a.m. Jeff. finished cutting wheat this morning in the afternoon he & liz. went to help Mr Wright.

div3.head: 15. Tues.
div3.p: I am better. Began to haul in Wheat.

div3.head: 16. Wed.
div3.p: Very warm. I continue better but weak. Francis helping to haul in Wheat. At 3 p.m. a very heavy shower, a little hail & high wind.

div3.head: 17. Thurs.
div3.p: I had a bad night-coughed much. Am very weak today. Sent for, while in bed, to preach at the Funeral of Issabella Doak-could not go. Grain too wet to haul in. About 3 p.m. a shower.

div3.head: 18. Fri.
div3.p: It rained heavily early last night. I feel badly this morning-very weak. The rain continued moderately a good part of the day. I was reading & studying as I could. I am better.

div3.head: 19. Sat.
div3.p: I rested rather better last night. I am preparing for the Sabbath.

div3.head: 20. Sab.
div3.p: I am very weak & unwell, but went to Bethel & preached in my usual manner for nearly an hour. I was more than I expected. I thank God for the strength to preach Christ, though it be in weakness.

div3.head: 21. Mon.
div3.p: I am somewhat better. Day pleasant. Hauling in wheat.

div3.head: 22. Tues.
div3.p: I am better than for two weeks past. Hauling in Wheat; Francis assisting. Robert is greatly afflicted with weakness in his limbs.

div3.head: July 23. Wed.
div3.p: The morning cloudy & threatening & about 1 p.m. it began to rain heavily. Before noon finished hauling in Wheat-about 370 Doz. large bind. I thank God that have got in, in good order, the largest crop in bulk I have ever had-filling the mow entirely & 60 Doz. on the Barn floor. A letter from James; on Sunday the 19 he was with the Army at Gordonsville & well.

div3.head: 24. Thurs.
div3.p: Not so well. Preached at the Funl. of Mrs Abe Crist I trust a good woman. Mrs Susan A. Gardner (wid.) came on a visit. Two hands plowing corn.

div3.head: 25. Fri.
div3.p: not well. Studying a little.

div3.head: 26. Sat.
div3.p: Still unwell-rest badly at night. I am trying to study.

div3.head: 27. Sab.
div3.p: A worse night-feel very badly. Did not rise till after breakfast. Bowels disordered. Lay on the sofa till 10 a.m. then went to Bethel & preached an hour in a manner which astonished myself. Took a collection to aid the sick & wounded Soldiers. Came home greatly exhausted.

div3.head: 28. Mon.
div3.p: Mrs McFarland sat with Mr John Rosen, who I fear will die. She & Francis went to Staunton today. I am a little better. Mr Rosen died this evening.

div3.head: 29. Tues.
div3.p: I am more feeble today than I have been-Unable to go to Mr Rosen's funeral.
I have sold 108 Bushels of corn to Byers & Co. at One dollar per bushel-they took it away. Also 60 Bs. of Oats at 60 cents & taken away.

div3.head: July 30. Wed.
div3.p: A little stronger. Mrs McFarland & I set out for Crawford's Springs-Dined at Mr Wm. Dunlap's. Day warm. Reached Crawford's at 5.30' p.m. fatigued.

div3.head: 31. Thurs.
div3.p: Cloudy & damp. Do not feel much better, but rested better last night.

div3.head: August 1. Fri.
div3.p: A little better. Mrs McFarland & I rode over to Mr David Kunkles & spent the day. Mrs K & I visited a Mr Moneymaker, a Soldier wounded at Port Republic, who I fear will die. Mary & Mary Lou & Francis came out. Asthma.

div3.head: 2. Sat.
div3.p: I had a very restless & bad night. This morning Francis took his mother home. I am very feverish-pulse about 100.

div3.head: Sab. 3.
div3.p: I am very unwell & feeble. Could not go to Methodist preaching only half a mile off. Rev. Wm. G. Campbell called & spent the night with me.

div3.head: 4. Mon.
div3.p: I still spend restless & uncomfortable nights. So unwell I feel it my duty to go home. Dined at Wm. Dunlaps. Letter from James, Dr. Wm. Brown & a most admirable one from Maj. Gen. Jackson.

div3.head: 5. Tues.
div3.p: The day very warm. I believe I am more feeble today than heretofore-rested very badly last night.

div3.head: 6. Wed.
div3.p: Had still a worse night & very feeble today. About 1 p.m. a very heavy rain. Frank Lewis went to join his mother.

div3.head: August 7. Thurs.
div3.p: Had a rather better night, but am very weak today. Have taken blue pill for two nights. Cutting Oats-greatly injured by the storm yesterday.

div3.head: 8. Fri.
div3.p: Rested still better, but am very feeble. Sold 60 Bs. more of Oats.

div3.head: 9. Sat.
div3.p: Did not rest well & am more unwell, as I think, than any day yet; took a blue pill last night. Can hardly read. Finished cutting Oats a poor crop. Francis went to Staunton.

div3.head: 10. Sab.
div3.p: Had a bad night & feel very badly this morning. Did not rise till 8 a.m. Pulse 102 & about 100 all day. In great doubt I went to Bethel-prayed & preached 3/4 of an hour to my own astonishment. But then was excessively exhausted. Read Gen. Jackson's letter from the pulpit before prayer.

div3.head: 11. Mon.
div3.p: Rested rather better, & am somewhat better.

div3.head: 12. Tues.
div3.p: Did not rest well. Rode in my Buggy to Samuel Hays. We hear that Genl. Jackson's Army has had a battle on last Saturday with Genl. Pope's & drove the enemy 5 miles taking a number of prisoners. John Hays was wounded in the hand not in battle. As far as I can learn James is safe, blessed be God.

div3.head: 13. Wed.
div3.p: I am rather better. Rode to Mr Gilkeson's. Francis G. quite unwell with Quinsey. Wrote to Dr. Wm Brown.

div3.head: 14. Thurs.
div3.p: Some better. Took Francis to Staunton on his way to Richmond. Drew Dividend on State stock $30. recd. payment for 108 Bs. Corn & 180 Bs. of Oats=$216. Dined at Dr. Waddell's.

div3.head: August 15. Fri.
div3.p: Fatigued. Reading.

div3.head: 16. Sat.
div3.p: Studying, but still unwell.

div3.head: 17. Sab.
div3.p: Rested badly. Breakfasted in bed. Put forth all my strength for an hour in preaching. Fatigued.

div3.head: 18. Mon.
div3.p: Rested badly again & feel very unfit for any duty. Sold two Barrels of flour to Mrs Mater at $7.25. Transferred 10 Bls. to 20 Govt. Bags which I have sold to the Govt. at $7.25 per Bl. Went to visit Mr Trevey who has Typhoid Fever. Called to see the two Mrs Rosens.

div3.head: 19. Tues.
div3.p: Rested badly. Went to Staunton & delivered the ten Bls. of Flour to Capt. Henderson, Commissary, & recd. payment =$72.50. Got my watch cleaned & repaired(?) by Merrideth, charge $2 1/2 . Dined at Col. Tate's. Called at Mr Bakers & at the hospital called on Mr Johnston.

div3.head: 20. Wed.
div3.p: I am still quite unwell. Mary & her Children returned from Pond Gap.

div3.head: 21. Thurs.
div3.p: Taking blue pill. I am very feeble.

div3.head: 22. Fri.
div3.p: Still much Unwell. Studying a little. Two interesting letters from James-one written the day after the battle (10th inst.) but missent.

div3.head: 23. Sat.
div3.p: A heavy shower last night. Plowing for wheat the last three days. I am a little better. Studying. Robert is improving.

div3.head: 24. Sab.
div3.p: A little better. Preached at Bethel & with more strength than for some time past.

div3.head: 25. Mon.
div3.p: Went to the Post Office-visited Mr Trevy, Mr Treu & Adam Hawpe. A letter from Francis-he is reporting for the Whig at $20 per week.

div3.head: Aug. 26. Tues.
div3.p: At home reading. P.M. visited Mrs Clayton-then Mr Fauber's at the Poorhouse.

div3.head: 27. Wed.
div3.p: Went to Mint Spring, Blouth's Store & Greenville Dined at Wm. Smith's. Attended at the Funeral of Old Mrs Rosen & heard Mr Shirey preach. Fatigued.

div3.head: 28. Thurs.
div3.p: I feel much better. Reading. Plowing.

div3.head: 29. Fri.
div3.p: Commencement of Communion Services. Rev. T.L. Preston Preached well. A good Congn. Mary & Frank went to Staunton. Mr Preston spent the night with us. A pleasant man.

div3.head: 30. Sat.
div3.p: Mr Preston again preached a good sermon to a large Congn.

div3.head: 31. Sab.
div3.p: Last night I was taken very unwell, my bowels very much disordered-fever & headache & it continued through the day. I had to remain in bed all day. All the family went to church but Jeff. This is a very mysterious providence; God grant that it may be blessed. Mr Preston had all the services to perform & learn, did well.

div3.head: September 1. Mon.
div3.p: Still unwell-bowels still disordered. Remained in bed. Showers.

div3.head: 2. Tues.
div3.p: Spent a restless night Bowels still disordered. Sent for Dr. Tate. He came & prescribed only spirits of Turpentine. I am some better today.

div3.head: 3. Wed.
div3.p: Rested badly. A little frost. Wm. Bent came this morning. In the afternoon I was much more unwell.

div3.head: Sept. 4. Thurs.
div3.p: I spent a very feverish night. After breakfast felt better. Wrote in bed to Genl. Jackson to get a furlough for Geo. Rosen. Wrote to Dr. White & a paper for Presby.

div3.head: 5. Fri.
div3.p: Had a worse night than the last. Took Castor Oil which did well. I am better. Wm. Bent left us. Dr. Tate came.
We learn that our James recd. a flesh-wound in the calf of his leg in the late battle & is in hospital near the scene of action.

div3.head: 6. Sat.
div3.p: Still no better-more unwell in the afternoon. In the evening better. Robert went to Staunton expecting James but he did not come.

div3.head: 7. Sab.
div3.p: Had a good night's rest & am better. The family went to Bethel. Rev. P. Curtis preached, & came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 8. Mon.
div3.p: Did not rest quite so well. In the morning comfortable-took a little chicken soup & rice & some bread broke in it & felt more unwell-fever & headache.

div3.head: 9. Tues.
div3.p: I had a pretty good night, & a tolerably comfortable day. Mr Pilson came to see me. I hear our army is in Maryland. James I hear is in an Hospital at Aldie near Leesburg.

div3.head: 10. Wed.
div3.p: I rested tolerably well. The Eruption is appearing on my legs & is troublesome. I rose & dressed about noon-very weak. Up till 4 p.m. not so well. We hear James is doing well.

div3.head: Sept. 11. Thurs.
div3.p: I rested pretty well last night & feel better today. There was a little drizzle of rain this morning, then clear. Cut Cloverseed, in the meadow. My poor neighbour James Hall was buried today.

div3.head: 12. Fr.
div3.p: I am better today-rose at 9 a.m. & continued up all day. I have more strength.

A letter from James last night dated the 2d inst. informs us of his wound & his situation. The ball still remains in his leg, alas. He is very desirous to get home, but there is no transportation from that place.

div3.head: 13. Sat.
div3.p: There was a pleasant shower last night. I slept pretty well, & think am still improving. I rose about 9 a.m. & remained till 8 p.m.

div3.head: 14. Sab.
div3.p: Rested rather better than usual. Rose before breakfast. Too weak to go to church-the family went. To our great surprize & delight Mr Merritt brought James (our son) out from Staunton, where he arrived last night in company with one of Mr Doyle's sons (Jack.) His wound seems to be doing well & he is in fine health.
There was no preaching today at Bethel.

div3.head: 15. Mon.
div3.p: I think I am increasing in strength. I feel in hopes it may be found that the bullet is not in James' leg.

div3.head: 16. Tu.
div3.p: I went to see Mrs Hall. She is better. I feel quite feeble. Mrs Donaghee & Mrs Gray came to see us. Mr Ladd took tea here. Rev. J.S. Blain & his son Francis came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 17. Sept. Wed.
div3.p: Improving slowly. Plowing.

div3.head: 18. Thurs.
div3.p: Went to Bethel. This the day appointed by Pres. Davis as a day of Thanksgiving to God for our recent victories. There was a good Congn. & Rev. Henry Brown preached an appropriate & impressive sermon from Psm. 126:3 "The Lord hath done great things for us whereof we are glad."
We also took a subscription for the Confederate States Bible Socy. amounting to $100.50 as a thank offering. Mr B. came home with us & I sent him on to Staunton.

div3.head: 19. Fri.
div3.p: Mrs Mish & Miss Matilda & Miss Blair came & dined with us.

div3.head: 20. Sat.
div3.p: Studying & feel pretty well, thank God.

div3.head: 21. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good Congn.

div3.head: 22. Mon.
div3.p: Took Robert to Staunton to enter on duty as a soldier. He has been at home nine months-appears to be perfectly well except that his limbs probably would not yet stand a march. I purchased at the Central Bank for Mary Lewis $800. in Confederate States 8 per cent Bonds to run till 1874. Also $500. of the same for myself.

There was a happy Capture of the Federal Army at Harper's Ferry, comd. by Genl. White & containing 11000 men a vast quantity of arms & 2 millions in stores. Hard fighting on Wednesday last at Sharpsburg.

div3.head: 23. Tues.
div3.p: Some Asthma-not well. Reading &c.

div3.head: Sept. 24. Wed.
div3.p: Had a bad night with Asthma, ate my breakfast in bed. Better through the day. Went to the Post Office. It rained moderately for some hours. The news for our cause is cheering.

div3.head: 25. Thurs.
div3.p: Mrs Gilkeson & Lovey, two Miss Sprouls & Mary McPheeters spent the day here. I am pretty well. Clear & Very cool.

div3.head: 26. Fri.
div3.p: The low ground white with frost. Mowing corn. Hauling in Cloverseed.

div3.head: 27. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. Treading out seed Wheat. Robert came home sick-sore throat.

div3.head: 28. Sab.
div3.p: The eruption is again troublesome. Preached at Bethel to a moderate Congn. Mr Nicholas Perkins of Wytheville spent the night here.

div3.head: 29. Mon.
div3.p: Cleaned 15 Bs. of Wheat for seed. I am not very well.

div3.head: 30. Tues.
div3.p: Preached at D.C. Gilkeson's at the funl. of his daughter Margaret, a lovely girl aged over 13 years. Dined at Mr Merritt's came home much fatigued.

div3.head: October 1. Wed.
div3.p: After dinner Mrs McF. & I went to Staunton to Synod, to stay with Mrs Coleman & the Miss Braggs. Dr. Ramsey preached a noble sermon-"to me to live is Christ." Had a bad night with Asthma.

div3.head: 2. Thurs.
div3.p: Very warm. Feel badly today in consequence of Asthma. Mr McIlwaine preached a good Sermon. Dined at Mr Tinsley's. Could not attend preaching at night.

div3.head: October 3. Fri.
div3.p: Sat up all last night with asthma & feel badly today. Attended Synod. Dined at Dr. Stribling's heard no preaching today, as the Synod was in session.

div3.head: 4. Sat.
div3.p: Slept well last night & I feel pretty well today. Had an intensely interesting discussion about Chaplains in the Army & the hospitals. Finished a very pleasant meeting. Dined at Mr Bakers.

div3.head: 5. Sab.
div3.p: Heard Dr. Wm Hoge preach an excellent sermon. After dinner came home.

div3.head: 6. Mon.
div3.p: Quite unwell last night-did not rise till noon. Then better. Mary has Diphtheria. Dr. Tate here yesterday & today.

div3.head: 7. Tues.
div3.p: Quite unwell. Went to Jonathan Brown's to see Mrs Quarles. Visited at Mr Britain's, Saml. Hays' & John Wrights. Sowed 6 Bs. of Chester Co. Pa. Wheat.

div3.head: 8. Wed.
div3.p: I am no better. Rode to the Post Office.

div3.head: 9. Thurs.
div3.p: I felt better in the morning & went to Rosen's sale, but felt so unwell I had soon to come home. There is a burning sensation in my breast, that I know not the cause of, but I regard it as very unfavourable.

div3.head: 10. Fri.
div3.p: I am still suffering & I now think it is an attack of Dispepsia. Studying a little.

div3.head: 11. Sat.
div3.p: Suffering from Dispepsia. Finished harrowing wheat. I have sowed 21 Bs. on the NE. field & there is probably 3 acres remaining. Cloudy today but only a sprinkle.

div3.head: 12. Sab.
div3.p: Still suffering. Preached at Bethel to a thin Congn. Day cool & threatening. Robert came home.

div3.head: October 13. Mon.
div3.p: I am no better. There was a falling mist all day & once a Shower. I have commenced an abstract of the Minutes of Synod for the C. Presbyterian.

div3.head: 14. Tues.
div3.p: I am a little better. Robert returned to Staunton sent Jeff. with him. Finished my Abstract. It rained a little last night & this morning.

div3.head: 15. Wed.
div3.p: Pain in my stomach continues. Rode to Greenville. Dined at Mrs Graham's. Tom has returned from Fort Delaware. Came home by Mint Spring. Bought a Quarter of sole leather-12 1/2 lbs. at 75 cents Paid $9.40.

div3.head: 16. Thurs.
div3.p: Day pleasant. Reading. Wrote a letter to Maj. Gen. T.J. Jackson & communicated the paper adopted by the Pby. of Lexington in reference to offering prayer for him & his army. Visited Mr Wright's family & prayed with them.

div3.head: 17. Fri.
div3.p: Wrote to Rev. E.D. Junkin & J. Morrison. The Miss Gilkesons spent last night here. Mr Gilkeson, Mr Burnwell & Dr. Tate here.

div3.head: 18. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. I am somewhat better.

div3.head: 19. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good Congn. a Funeral Serm. for George Trainer. Narcissus F. Quarles Both killed in Battle at Manassas Aug. 30 last & Robert Doyle, thigh broken by a ball Aug. 28th at Manassas & died of his wound at Aldie Sept. 25th 1862.

div3.head: 20. Mon.
div3.p: Sent by Mr McPheeters to Dr. Wm. Brown the The Obituary Minutes of deceased members of Synod.

div3.head: October 21. Tues.
div3.p: Bought 8 yds of common brown Cotton goods of Palmer at 80 cents per Yd.

div3.head: 22. Wed.
div3.p: A very high wind kept me at home.

div3.head: 23. Thurs.
div3.p: Went to Staunton to get the tire cut on the right hind wheel of my buggy, cost $1.25 Bought 10 yds. coarse cotton for Jef's shirts 3/4 wide, 55 cents. came home by Joseph Smith's-supper at Mr Gilkeson.

div3.head: 24. Fri.
div3.p: Suffered much last night with Cramp & Eruption. Mr Pilson dined with us. James went to Staunton.

div3.head: 25. Sat.
div3.p: I suffered very much last night with the eruption, especially upon my thighs in the early part of the night; toward morning I slept. Studying.

div3.head: 26. Sab.
div3.p: I rested better. About midnight it began to rain moderately with the wind NE. & continued till morning. It rained all day today-sometimes heavily. I did not go to Bethel-sent Jeff. no person there I regret not being able to preach today.

div3.head: 27. Mon.
div3.p: Went to Staunton on my way to Crawford's Springs. The eruption on my legs has so increased & I suffer so much with it, I can delay no longer. Robert went home with James. It rained all night last night. Staid at Col. Tate's.

div3.head: 28. Tues.
div3.p: Rose at day-break & had a good breakfast in my room-reached the Depot at 6.30' but did not leave till 10' to 9 Fare to Pond Gap, $1. arrived there at 10-Was very kindly recd.

div3.head: 29. Wed.
div3.p: Rested pretty well. No Dispepsy, but I find as yet no improvement in the eruption-otherwise well. Cold-heavy frost.

div3.head: October 30. Thurs.
div3.p: The eruption troubled me last night & kept me awake today it is worse than it has been my legs more swelled & irritated. The sulpher water seems to have its usual effect as a diuretic, but has not yet abated the irritation.

div3.head: 31. Fri.
div3.p: I rested better last night. There is still much irritation, but I think the eruption looks as if it was beginning to dry up. Today it is warm & pleasant.

div3.head: November 1. Sat.
div3.p: still warm-became hazy. I rested well last night. The eruption on my legs is drying & the heat of the fire is not so uncomfortable but my legs still swell & it hurts me to walk.

div3.head: 2. Sab.
div3.p: Improving slowly. A delightful day. I grieve that I cannot preach at Bethel today, as it is the Sab. before the Communion. But doubtless God has wise reasons for ordering it thus. Mr David Kunkle called to see me.

div3.head: 3. Mon.
div3.p: Day clear & cool. I had a good night-the eruption is dried up and the irritation greatly abated. I have read Alexander's Moral Science with pleasure & profit. Also Wayland's Political Economy, abridged from which I learned but little.

div3.head: 4. Tues.
div3.p: Very cold. Did not rest well in the early part of the night. Left my kind friends the Crawfords. They will receive no compensation. I am amazed at the kindness of this family-may God bless them.

div3.head: Novr. 4. Tuesday continued.
div3.p: Dined at D. Kunkle's. Mrs K. gave me 3 1/2 lbs of tallow. Came to Staunton in the Cars-fare $1.00. Staid at Mrs Coleman's.

div3.head: 5. Wed.
div3.p: Did no rest well-irritation in my thighs. Called with Robert at Col. Harman's office. Robt is to take down 15 conscripts to the Army, to set off to-morrow. Bought of D. Kayser 10 yds. of brown Cotton at 65cents pr Yd. James came for me with my Buggy-home to dinner, all well D.G.

div3.head: 6. Thurs.
div3.p: I had a bad night with Asthma, brought on by my lodgings the preceding night. Did not rise till 10 a.m.

div3.head: 7. Fri.
div3.p: Rested well. Went to Bethel-Our Services preparatory to the Communion began-Rev. E.D. Junkin preached a good sermon & came home with us. The day very Cold.

div3.head: 8. Sat.
div3.p: Cold. Mr. Junkin preached again & even a better Sermon than on yesterday & delivered with great energy. The weather so cold our Congs. are small.

div3.head: 9. Sab.
div3.p: Milder. Mr Junkin preached an excellent sermon. The service solemn. No additions! Alas. I feel much disappointed, for I had fondly hoped that my son James would have professed religion. He has I think been very thoughtful & serious of late.

div3.head: 10. Mon.
div3.p: The eruption troublesome last night-better now. Reading Newspapers mostly. Mrs McFarland & James went to visit at Mish's & Sproul's.

div3.head: 11. Tues.
div3.p:
Pleasant. I am writing for Synod. Wrote to Rev. Dr. G. Howe & enclosed the Obituary
Minute of Synod respecting Dr. Thornwell for his family & for the Synod of South Carolina. Also wrote to Dr. Wm. Brown, enclosing the Original paper for publication. Also a note for the discontinuance of the Richmond Whig.

div3.head: Nov. 12. Wed.
div3.p: Preached at the Funl. of Adam Miller. Husking & hauling in Corn.

div3.head: 13. Thurs.
div3.p: Reading & seeding a text. Mr Fauber brought his wife Miss Ferguson & two Miss Bernards here the young ladies are Refugees from Portsmouth.

div3.head: 14. Fri.
div3.p: Beautiful weather, seems like Indian summer. Finished getting in our Corn; husked it on the stalk-have about 200 Bushels of good corn-the nubbins are all sound.

div3.head: 15. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. Cribbed all the corn. I think the Eruption is cured.

div3.head: 16. Sab.
div3.p: Gloomy & damp. Preached at Bethel to a small Congn. then at 3.30 p.m. preached at John Wright's a Funl. discourse on account of the death of Joseph Wright, a good young man who die in Camp. Robert returned from the Army where he had gone with men.

div3.head: 17. Mon.
div3.p: Reading. James went with Robert to Staunton. Commenced preparing the Minutes of Synod for the Press.

div3.head: 18. Tues.
div3.p: Writing minutes.

div3.head: 19. Wed.
div3.p: Preached at Mr Towberman's at the Funl of his little daughter, aged 3 yrs. 2 mos & 7 days. Dined at the Gardners & prayed with the family. John & Peggie Ann Lambert spent the night here.

div3.head: 20. Thurs.
div3.p: Writing Minutes for the Press.

div3.head: November 21. Fri.
div3.p: day much cooler. Killed a Hog Weighing 183 lbs. Studying & reading. Robert came home about dark & staid only about half an hour-expects to go tomorrow with some troops to reinforce Col Imboden going from Shanandoah mountain to attach the Yankees in Crabbottom.

div3.head: 22. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. We hear Robert did not go today.

div3.head: 23. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel on the Power of the Cross. A pretty good & attentive Congn. I had some liberty.

div3.head: 24. Mon.
div3.p: Transcribing Minutes. James went to Staunton. The troops did not go to Col. Imboden's.

div3.head: 25. Tues.
div3.p: Still busy preparing Minutes. Dr. Donaghe came to see Jeff. who is quite sick.

div3.head: 26. Wed.
div3.p: Nearly finished the Minutes for the Press. Jeff. Much more unwell. Dr. D. sent for but did not come. Day Cold.

div3.head: 27. Thurs.
div3.p: Minutes all arranged. Mr Smith sent a Rockaway for Jeff. I fear he will die. Day cold.

div3.head: 28. Fri.
div3.p: Studying. Killed our Beef (bull) Wt 633 lbs. Hide 110 lbs.

div3.head: 29. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. About 2 inches of snow fell last night. The day cloudy & chilly.

div3.head: 30. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel on Luke 8:18, Take heed how ye hear I trust I was faithful. Strict attention. May Gods blessing follow.

div3.head: December 1. Mon.
div3.p: Working & Reading. I am suffering much with pain in my back from stooping.

div3.head: 2. Tu.
div3.p: The pain in my back worse-I am suffering much.

div3.head: 3. Wed.
div3.p: My Back worse today.

div3.head: Decr. 4. Thurs.
div3.p: Very cold. My pain is not relieved I have rubbed the part with spirits of Turpentine but without effect. It is not in the spine but in the bone that joins the thigh-bone to the spine on the right side. I can do nothing but lie on the sofa & read a little.

div3.head: 5. Fri.
div3.p: My back felt better in bed & I did nor rise till after 2 P.M. About 10 a.m. it began to snow & about 2 1/2 inches.

div3.head: 6. Sat.
div3.p: Rested badly last night & did nor rise till after 2 p.m. Rev. Dr. Wm. Brown, a dear friend, came to visit us. Robert came home has been down to Jackson's Army, which is is below Fredericksburg.

div3.head: 7. Sab.
div3.p: Still rest badly. This the coldest morning for several years. Dr. Brown went to Bethel with the family, Mrs McFarland remained with me. Dr. B. preached to about 50 persons & returned & spent the night here.

div3.head: 8. Mon.
div3.p: Very cold. I did not rest well. Sent Frank with Robert to Staunton. Mr Brown left us-his visit has been a very pleasant one to me. Mr. Gardner came with the sad inteligence of the death of Adam Swink-Aged 76.

div3.head: 9. Tues.
div3.p: This morning I married Col. Rudolph Turk & Miss Rebecca B. Wilson & immediately from there went & preached at the Funl. of Adam Swink. The exertion made my back much worse.

div3.head: 10. Wed.
div3.p: My back still painful. Reading.

div3.head: 11. Thurs.
div3.p: I am perhaps a little better. Reading. Hannah, a Servant belonging to N. Bent came here this morning from Winchester.

div3.head: Decr. 12. Fri.
div3.p: Spent an unpleasant night-lay in bed till after 10 a.m. Reading.

div3.head: 13. Sat.
div3.p: Trying to study, but I can sit very little at my table, my back is so uncomfortable.

div3.head: 14. Sab.
div3.p: I preached at Bethel to a pretty good Congn. & my back stood it better than I expected.

div3.head: 15. Mon.
div3.p: Very warm. James went to Staunton. My back improves, but very slowly. Reading.

div3.head: 16. Tues.
div3.p: Great change in temperature. A heavy Shower before day. Killed nine hogs, wt. 1874 lbs. Ira Swartzley, John Weaver & George Rosen assisting.

div3.head: 17. Wed.
div3.p: Called at Mr. Gilkeson's-went to J. Smith's to see Jeff. Poor fellow, he is very low & I fear will not recover. I talked to him & prayed with him. Dined at Mr Gardner's-Called to see the Swinks. Met Wm. Swink H. Lambert & Mr Towberman there. I had recd. from Mr Towberman 1 Bushel of Salt from the Smyth Co. works & he now refused to take pay, & asked me to accept it as a present from him, as I had preached at the funeral of his child. Miss Lizzie Wilson here.

div3.head: 18. Thurs.
div3.p: Day cold. Reading. Visited Mrs J. Hall.

div3.head: 19. Fri.
div3.p: Milder. Studying. Robert came home.

div3.head: 20. Sat.
div3.p: Very cold. Studying. James McClung & James Wm. Wallace came here & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 21. Sab.
div3.p: Very cold. I preached at Bethel to a moderate Congn. & had good attention.

div3.head: 22. Mon.
div3.p: Went to Staunton. Dined at Mr Baker's recd. $12.28 Dividend on Confederate Stock up to Jan 1st 1863.

div3.head: December 23. Tues.
div3.p: The day being mild, Mrs McF. & I left home & dined at John Brownlee's called at James Smiths, & spent the night at Mr Ballard Smith's: had Asthma.

div3.head: 24. Wed.
div3.p: Came to Greenville-made several calls & dined at Mrs Graham's-came home & found Mr Wm Bent had come here last night.

div3.head: 25. Thurs.
div3.p: Christmas. Though I have no regard for this day in a religious point of view, it has many interesting associations.

Blessed be God we are all in good health. Mr Bent & I went to visit Mr James Bumgarner, who has Typhoid Fever & I had an interesting conversation with him on the subject of religion & found him very accessable.

div3.head: 26. Fri.
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 27. Sat.
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 28. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good Congn.

div3.head: 29. Mon.
div3.p: Went to Joseph Smith's, & paid him $110. for Jeff's hire for the year now closing. I think Jeff. is a little better, but still in a very critical state. Robert went to Staunton. A number of young people here this evening, unexpected by us.

div3.head: 30. Tues.
div3.p: Rode to Mrs Hall's & paid her $33. Rhoda's hire for 1862, & agreed to hire Mose at the rate of $100. for the whole year & take him after he returns from Richmond, provided he goes.

div3.head: December 31. Wed.
div3.p: I went to the Post Office & thence to Mr. Pilson's where they have had much sickness two now sick-one, Annie, very sick.
Called to see a child of Mr Stricklers Trevy's which is sick. Came home. Day cold I have increased my cold, but, blessed be God this last night of the year, I & my family are well.

div3.head: 1863. January 1. Thursday
div3.p: Clear & pretty cold. Glory be to God that I see the beginning of another year, & am in tolerable health. I have a cold & cough & some pain in my back, but am pretty comfortable. My Family also are pretty well. Mary & her children are out visiting. Robert also, & he is pretty well, & expects in a few days to go into service. James' wound is nearly healed, & he expects to return to the Army very soon. Francis is in Richmond, pretty well. Dr. Humphreys was well when last heard from, & his children except the youngest which was recovering from Diphtheria.
Wm. L. Bent went to Staunton today & took hannah Nat's woman with him. I was sent for to see Mrs Hall who is quite unwell.

div3.head: 2. Fri.
div3.p: Went to see Mrs Hall. She is better. I paid her for Moses' Services, last year, 68 days at 62 1/2 Cts. = $42.50. Gave my note for Moses' hire ($100.) with the reserve that if he goes to work for the Govt. a reduction must be made, or if he returns unfit for service

div3.head: 1863. Jany. 3. Sat.
div3.p: A very fine pleasant day. I preached at the Funeral of Elisabeth Lettitia Gardner, daughter of Alexr. G. aged 18 y. 2 m. who died of the hip disease. A large Congn

div3.head: 4. Sab.
div3.p: At 10 a.m. Preached at Mr Pilson's, at the Funeral of his child Jane Anna, aged 7 yrs & 7 months. A very large Congn Then rode to Bethel & at 12 1/2 O'clock preached again. Called at Mr Bumgarner's. There was a fierce little shower. Home.

div3.head: 5. Mon.
div3.p: Went to Greenville & took some work to Mr Grubert. Dined at Alexr. Brownlee's-visited Miss Catharine Bumgarner who has fever.

div3.head: 6. Tues.
div3.p: It rained moderately till noon. At home working & reading. Nat Burwell dined here.

div3.head: 7. Wed.
div3.p: Very cold. At home-Reading.

div3.head: 8. Thurs.
div3.p: Cold. This my birth-day-I have completed my 75th Year-an age that even in my youth I never thought to reach. Blessed be God. I am in pretty good health, & able to study & preach with less fatigue than could be expected. But the time of my departure must be at hand. God grant that while I live I may live to his glory & then that I may die to his glory, Amen & amen.

div3.head: 9. Fri.
div3.p: Mrs Issabella Hall, widow of James Hall, died this morning. She was a good woman & one of my warm friends.

div3.head: 10. Sat.
div3.p: Snow 3 inches till noon, then Rain. Preached at the Funl. of Mrs Hall.

div3.head: Jany. 11. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a small Congn

div3.head: 12. Mon.
div3.p: Threshing Wheat. Mr Gilkeson furnished 2 horses & 2 hands, Geo. Rosen sent one, Col. Wilson one & Lewis Mater & Mose & my two sons were all.

div3.head: 13. Tues.
div3.p: Again threshing Wheat-had the same hands as yesterday except none from Col. Wilson, but one from Mr Henderson. This evening James Patterson & his niece-Miss Lizzie P. Rebecca Tate & Susan Humphreys came & spent the night here.

div3.head: 14. Wed.
div3.p: Mr Gilkeson's two hands, Wash & John assisting to clean wheat. Our Visitors left us. I went to Staunton & took James & Robert in on their way to the army near Fredericksburg. I left with Woods & Gilkeson a Copper Tea-kettle to be sold. Also with Dr. A. Kayser 2 1/3 yds of French Black Broadcloth to be sold-also a Sattin vest Pattern. Dined at Mr Woods with Sister Martha (Wm.) Bent on his way to Farmville to see her husband.

div3.head: 15. Thurs.
div3.p: Cleaning Wheat & hauling it to mill. Wash & John assisting. Wind very high.

div3.head: 16. Fri.
div3.p: Cleaning Wheat. Gilkeson's John assisting.

div3.head: 17. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. Hauling Wheat to mill.

div3.head: 18. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a small Congn Cold. The 3d. Sab. in Jany 1823 just 40 yrs. ago I first preached in Bethel. I endeavored to improve the Occasion.

div3.head: Jany. 19. Mond.
div3.p: Hauling Wheat to Mill. I think I have about 175 Bushels in Cochran's Mill. Wrote to Dr. Wm Brown, & enclosed my Check for $97.50 in payment for 39 Copies of the Central Presbyterian. I advanced the money for five. Letters from Francis & N. Bent.

div3.head: 20. Tues.
div3.p: Snowed a little in the morning, & about 1 p.m. & then in the evening snowed very fast. I went to Bethel to meet the Session-none came but Mr Pilson & Blackwood. Several of the Commissioners met-Messrs. Pilson, Wm. F. Smith, A. Sproul & Jas. Hays. I suffered with cold.

div3.head: 21. Wed.
div3.p: I think it snowed nearly all night & this morning till 9 O'clock. It is probably about a foot deep, but a good deal drifted.

div3.head: 22. Thurs.
div3.p: Reading. Wrote a note to Dr. Wm. Brown sending my Check for $2.50 for the C. Pbn. for Wm. M. Bell, enclosed to Francis. Thawing.

div3.head: 23. Fri.
div3.p: Threshing. Finished the Wheat, & threshed the the Cloverseed off the Straw. From Mr Gilkeson 1 hand 3/4 of a day-came at 10 a.m. from Mr Henderson 2 hands, Mr Rosen 1, & Mr Greever 1. I superintended & am much fatigued.

div3.head: 24. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Cleaning Wheat. Rosen's Joe assisting.

div3.head: 25. Sab.
div3.p: Preached at Bethel from the same Text that I had preached from there just 40 yrs. ago.

div3.head: 26. Mon.
div3.p: Reading & working. Sending Wheat to Mill. A letter from James.

div3.head: Jany. 27. Tues.
div3.p: A heavy Shower last night. Sent the last of my Wheat to mill-248 Bs. the largest crop I ever had-thanks be to God.

div3.head: 28. Wed.
div3.p: About 10 O'clock last night it began to Snow, & continued all night; this morning it was about 8 inches deep. But it continued without intermission & even increased with a Strong North wind. It snowed steadily all day with the Thermometer at +30. At dark it fell a little & the wind dulled, but it continued to snow till about 10 p.m.

div3.head: 29. Thurs.
div3.p: This morning it clear & pretty cold. The Snow is about 16 inches deep where not drifted.

Yesterday Mrs Charlotte Tate, Relict of James Tate, died, & I was sent for to preach at her funeral today at 11 a.m. But I thought I could not endure the exposure & the long ride in such deep snow, & did not go. I regret much that I could not-She has been one of my choicest friends for 40 years. Reading.

div3.head: 30. Fri.
div3.p: Clear & not very cold. Studying.

div3.head: 31. Sat.
div3.p: Studying. In the evening, a Regt. of Cavalry commanded by Col. Witcher came & encamped on Mr McPheeter land, North of our house, said to be 670 in number-they are from S.W. Va. were under Gen. Marshall & are now to join
Lieut. Atkins & a Mr Prichard, (sick) staid all night with us.

div3.head: February 1. Sab.
div3.p: Morning mild, Rain in the afternoon. Bad traveling from drifted Snow. Preached at Bethel to a small Congn

div3.head: Feby. 2. Mon.
div3.p: Day mild. Reading & began to record the Minutes of Synod of 1861. Wrote only three Pages. A letter from Francis-wrote to him.

div3.head: 3. Tues
div3.p: Perhaps the coldest day this winter. Recorded a little more than 4 pages of Minutes.

div3.head: 4. Wed
div3.p: Intensely cold. So cold in my Study I could do nothing. The coldest day for three years. Brought home 4 Barrels of flour.

div3.head: 5. Thurs
div3.p: Too cold to do anything. It began to Snow early last night & snowed all day today, without cessation. At dark began to rain, & froze.

div3.head: 6. Fri
div3.p: Much milder. Crust on the Snow. Wrote to Mrs E.H. Brown, & to Robt P. McF. A letter was also written to James.

div3.head: 7. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Clear & pretty cold. I have not been out of my own gate this week & only to the Barn last week.

div3.head: 8. Sab
div3.p: Milder. Preached at Bethel to a pretty good Congn for the state of the roads.

div3.head: 9. Mon
div3.p: The day mild. Reading & recording Minutes of Synod. Letters from Robert & James.

div3.head: 10. Tues
div3.p: Pleasant. The snow almost gone. Reading, writing & working. Mr & Mrs gilkeson took tea with us.

div3.head: 11. Wed
div3.p: Sleet-then a little rain. Reading.

div3.head: 12. Thurs
div3.p: Preached at the Funl of Mrs Hefner (at the Britton place.) James Hays & wife here.

div3.head: 13. Fri
div3.p: Preached at the Funl. of a daughter of Wm Cochran's (Cornelia aged 12). Dined at Mr Bumgarner's.

div3.head: Feby. 14. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Mary went to see Jeff. One side is paralyzed. In other respects better. A letter from James by John Pilson Gilkeson.

div3.head: 15. Sab
div3.p: I think it rained moderately nearly all night, & a while this morning. We all went to Bethel, & I preached to a tolerable Congn for the day.

div3.head: 16. Mon
div3.p: Threshing Oats & Cloverseed. Wm Rosen & Gilkeson's Jem. assisting. Paid Mr Rosen $1.00 Mr Pilson came & paid me salary collected in his own district $191.90 being $64 voluntary, beyond pew-rent. Paid also salary collected by B.F. McClung-Pew-rent $74.50, additional $73.50. Also, collected by Mr McClung in Capt. Humphrey's District, Pew-rent 68.50, additional $36.50 total = $444.90 I learn by Mr Pilson that the Commissioners aimed to to add $300. to the salary this year.

div3.head: 17. Tues
div3.p: It began to snow in the night & this morning it was about 4 inches deep. But it continued to snow till about 2 p.m. when it was about 6 inches deep. A letter from James. Mary wrote to him today.

div3.head: 18. Wed
div3.p: Mist & rain & freezing-very unpleasant. George Rosen just from the Army-saw my sons on last Sab-both well. Robert enclosed to me $60.00 for safekeeping. Mr A.A. McPheeters, called & I paid him in full Mr Englemans Bill in full for sawing & lumber $11.50 Geo. Rosen's Joe came at 10 1/2 O'clock to help to haul wheat. Had 55 Bushels.

div3.head: Feby. 19. Thurs
div3.p: Cleared off mild & the snow dissolved rapidly.
Rosen's Joe came today & we cleaned the Cloverseed-Had 4 Bushels. John Gilkeson took tea with us. Caroline (black woman) was confined.

div3.head: 20. Fri
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 21. Sat
div3.p: Went to Greenville. Mr Burch soled & heeltaped Moses' shoes, 75 cents. I found the leather I paid Mr Burch in full including work done today $8.00 Dined at Dr. Tate's-Called at Mr L. Bumgarner's to see the sick-Miss Burck very ill-others better. Paid Mr Lightner my Blacksmith's Act. for 1862--$15.00 He threw off $4.00. About dark it began to Snow.

div3.head: 22. Sab
div3.p: It doubtless snowed all night, & in the morning furiously till about noon, when it began to abate & at 1 p.m. ceased. It is about 10 inches deep, but drifted. It was manifest there would be no Congn at Bethel, so I did not go; indeed it was too stormy.

div3.head: 23. Mon
div3.p: Cleared off early, but cold. I wrote to Dr. Wm. Brown, authorizing my name to be attached to an "Address to Christians throughout the World," a Copy of which was sent to me asking my name. I think it is pretty well prepared & I trust will do good.
Mrs McFarland sent $5. for Papers for soldiers & Mary Lewis & her two Children one dollar each for Dr. Hoge's mission.

div3.head: 24. Tues
div3.p: Recording Minutes of Synod. 4 pages.

div3.head: 25. Wed
div3.p: Employed as yesterday. Lieut. Seville called.

div3.head: Feb. 26. Thurs
div3.p: It rained last night & today very heavily till noon. And being warm the snow melted very rapidly & made a flood. I was recording Minutes, 4 pages.

div3.head: 27. Fri
div3.p: Quite mild. Writing and working.

div3.head: 28. Sat
div3.p: Sent Frank to Greenville Mrs McF. & Mary went to Mr Rosen's. John Pilson dined with me.

div3.head: March 1. Sab
div3.p: Morning threatening. Had snowed & rained a good deal in the night, but cleared off. Preached at Bethel to a tolerable Congn We were all there.

div3.head: 2. Mon
div3.p: Went to Staunton. Deposited in the Valley Bank $60. to the credit of R.P. McFarland & $30 to the credit of James N. McFarland. I also deposited for myself Five Hundred dollars to be invested in 8 percent Con. States Bonds. Dined at Davis A. Kayser's. Calle at Col. Wm P. Tates. Also called on Wm. L. Clark Esqr. of Winchester. Supped at Wm. J. Gilkeson's & Paid Mrs G. for 4 3/4 lbs of Tallow at 40 cents per lb.
On Yesterday a Basket was put in Mary's Rockaway containing as we found today 22 lbs. of Candles contributed by some of our friends. A letter from James.

div3.head: 3. Tues
div3.p: I suffered much last night with cramp in my legs from walking so much yesterday. Today I am so much fatigued I can do nothing but read.

div3.head: 4. Wed
div3.p: Sold to James Hays 15 Bushels of corn at $3. per Bushel & prepaid me $45. This seems an enormous price, but I am told $4 is paid in Staunton & 4.50 has been offered. These prices undoubtedly arise from our depreciated currency. Mose helping Wrights to thresh.

div3.head: March 5. Thurs
div3.p: Cold. Studying a little. Miss Mollie Bumgarner & Miss Wilson dined here. Mose again helping Wrights to thresh cloverseed.

div3.head: 6. Fri
div3.p: Went to Greenville, dined at Mrs Graham's. Called at Mr L Bumgarner's-all better but the youngest boy. Engaged 30 Flour barrels from Mr Supple at 3 barrels for one bushel of Wheat.

div3.head: 7. Sat
div3.p: Studying but dull. Sifted my cloverseed, had three & a half bushels, very clean seed. Rain in the night. On Thursday last Miss Bumgarner brought us a present of 12 1/4 lbs of Brown Sugar.

div3.head: 8. Sab
div3.p: Mild. I preached at Bethel to a pretty good Congn and I think with more liberty than usual. In the night there was rain, with thunder & Lightening.

div3.head: 9. Mon
div3.p: Working & reading. Began to plow for corn.

div3.head: 10. Tues
div3.p: Began to snow after daybreak & continued with some abatement till near 2 p.m. I preached at Mr Jas. Henderson's at the Funl. of Carlisle Reppitoe who was wounded at Manassas Aug. 30th 1862, in the knee, & died at Aldie in Oct. & was buried there, but his body was now brought on by Mr Henderson to be buried at Bethel.
Mrs Womeldorf, his Mother sent me $5.

div3.head: 11. Wed
div3.p: Reading &c. Wrote to Mr Morrison.

div3.head: 12. Thurs
div3.p: Studying a little. I was quite unwell last night, caused I think by eating hot slimcake for supper which disordered my bowels. Day Cold.

div3.head: 13. Fri
div3.p: Cold piercing. Studying. Mrs Towberman here. Letters from Robert & Wm. Bent.

div3.head: March 14. Sat
div3.p: Milder. Worked hard mending a Plow.

div3.head: 15. Sab
div3.p: Day cold & uncomfortable, roads bad. Preached at Bethel to a moderate congregation.

div3.head: 16. Mon
div3.p: Last night, therm. at +26 vivid lightening & heavy thunder, especially about 10 O'clock. This morning a very thick Fog, which gradually passed away before night but continued very cloud. Reading.

div3.head: 17. Tues
div3.p: Last night it cleared off-this morning very thick fog. Cleaned up before noon. Working.

div3.head: 18. Wed
div3.p: This morning like Spring: about noon the wind turned NE & became cold. I went to Greenville-dined at Alexr. Brownlee's-called to see the sick at Mr L. Bumgarner's & Mr Britain's-Geo. Britain has typhoid Fever.

div3.head: 19. Thurs
div3.p: About 10 a.m. it began to snow & continued till night, then ceased a few hours, say 4 inches deep. I was reading &c.

div3.head: 20. Friday
div3.p: Vernal Equinox. It snowed, I think all the latter part of last night, & today very fast till 1 P.M. then some abatement, but towards evening again increased I think now about 9 inches deep. Studying-A letter from Francis.

div3.head: 21. Sat
div3.p: It snowed in the night about 2 inches more, so that it is about 11 inches of pretty solid snow. Today it has been misting, either snow or rain & very gloomy. Studying.

div3.head: 22. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a small Congn The traveling is very bad. Snow melting fast, ground soft. I am hoarse & taking cold.

div3.head: March 23. Mon
div3.p: I am suffering with a cold in my head that I can scarcely read. Recdd Letters from My son James-all still quiet with them. Also a letter from Rev. Wm. E. Baker.

div3.head: 24. Tues
div3.p: This has been one of the gloomiest days I ever saw. The fog so thick one could see but a short distance. About 2 p.m. it began to rain & continued till night. I have been very unwell with my cold. Reading. Brought away 10 Bs. of wheat from the Mill, & sent an Order to give Mr Gilkeson 9 Bs. for threshing.

div3.head: 25. Wed
div3.p: Sent to Greenville & got from Mr Supple thirty flour-barrels for which I gave ten bushels of wheat. This at $4.00 for wheat would be = $1.33 1/2 per Bl. sent the Barrel to Cochran's Mill.

div3.head: 26. Thurs
div3.p: James Hall paid me $30. for 7 weeks boarding of Caroline & her child, & took them away. Jac. Zimmerman brought us a letter &c. from Robt. & news from James-all well. Thanks be to God. Preparing for the Fast day.

div3.head: 27. Fri
div3.p: This day was appointed by Pres. Davis for fasting, humiliation & Prayer. The Congn at Bethel was large & it was to me an interesting day. May God grant an answer to our prayers, in this awful crisis of our affairs.

div3.head: 28. Sat
div3.p: It began to rain in the night & this morning rained very heavily till about noon. Then Cleared. A letter from Dr. Humphreys. Studying.

div3.head: 29. Sab
div3.p:
Day very chilly. Preached at Bethel to a good Congn It was a funeral discourse in consequence of the death of
Lieut. John W. Wilson aged 32 who was killed in the Battle of Kearnstown March 23d 1862, & Miss Alice C. Birch of Missouri, who died Feb. 22d 1863 at her Uncle's Mr Lewis Bumgarner's in Greenville, aged 17 yrs. I also endeavored to improve the occasion in reference to our Communion next Sabbath.

div3.head: March 30. Mon
div3.p: Day cold. Recdd letters from Dr. Humphries & my son James. Sold ten Blls of Flour to Richard W. Quesenberry at 21 per Bl & Recdd payment $210.

div3.head: 31. Tues
div3.p: It began to snow in the & this morning is about 7 inches deep. But it melted fast. Reading.

div3.head: April 1. Wed
div3.p: The cold is penetrating. Could not go from home to visit. Not one spring day yet. I have not felt well. Could only read.

div3.head: 2. Thurs
div3.p: Called at Mr Towbermans & at Mr Gardner's then visited Adam Hawpes-was very kindly received & I hope my visit was productive of good. Called to see Saml. Hays Jr. just from the army, bringing home the extra baggage of the Regt. Called at Saml. Hays Sr.

div3.head: 3. Fri
div3.p: Sowed Cloverseed on part of the NE field where Wheat is sowed Went to Bethel Rev. S.L. Preston preached an excellent Sermon from Is. 61:1,2. There was a pretty good & attentive Congn

div3.head: 4. Sat
div3.p: Session met. Recdd two on Examn. & two on Cert. Mr Preston preached a discourse that was quite intellectual but not so well adapted as on yesterday.

div3.head: 5. Sab
div3.p: A good Congn Mr Preston preston preached well. Recdd one more on Examn. On the whole a pleasant Communion season. The day became pleasant.

div3.head: April 6. Mon
div3.p: I went to visit Mrs Dorsey who is very unwell. Was out in a heavy shower of rain & snow. Visited Mrs John McClure & George Britain. Another Shower of Rain & Snow.

div3.head: 7. Tues
div3.p: Went to Staunton, dined at Mr Taylor's. Recdd of Mr D.A. Kayser $45. for 2 1/2 yds broadcloth sold for me, which 2 years ago cost $10. Also Recdd of Mr Wood $10. for a Copper tea-kettle sold for me which cost

Received the printed Minutes of Synod. Receive of B. King Esqr. of Roswell, Ga. three Bunches of Cotton yarn No. 12 worth $20. per bunch, as a Present-thank God. Bought Cotton yarn for my son, paid $5. for it.

div3.head: 8. Wed
div3.p: Rode to Sink. Spring to Pby. Lodged at Rev. Mr See's.

div3.head: 9. Thurs
div3.p: Heavy frost, attended Pby. closely. Again at Mr See's.

div3.head: 10. Frid.
div3.p: day mild. Attended Pby. Again at Mr See's.

div3.head: 11. Sat
div3.p: In Pby. Adjourned. Lodged with Mrs E. Em. Cue.

div3.head: 12. Sab
div3.p: Dr. White preached. I introduced the Communion Service & Rev. Saml. Brown followed & closed. Dined at Mr Hugh G. Guthries & spent the night at Mr David Gilkeson's.

div3.head: 13. Mond.
div3.p: Called to see Jeff. & came home. Settled with Mr Wm. A. Gilkeson & paid him in full of all dues $13.75 Sold two Bls. of flour to the Miss Palmers at $24 per B.

div3.head: 14. Tues
div3.p: Finished plowing for Corn. Began to plow for oats in the Hill Field. Recording Minutes of Synod.

div3.head: 15. Wed
div3.p: It rained heavily all day abating in the evening. Recording Minutes of Synod.

div3.head: April 16. Thurs
div3.p: Cloudy & cool. Recording Minutes. Bought at Arbor Hill 6 yds. of Osnaburgs at $1.50 per yard. Paid $25. for stuff for a pair of Pantaloons for Robert, called Casimere, 1 1/4 yard wide.

div3.head: 17. Fri
18. Sat
div3.p: Studying & working. Harrowing Cornground.

div3.head: 19. Sab
div3.p: Rev. Wm S. Blain preached for me a good Sermon

div3.head: 20. Mon
div3.p: Mr Blain left us. I went to Staunton. It rained on me heavily. It rained in showers till about 3 p.m. I tried to make arrangements for taking $1500 more in state stocks, i.e. Confederate 8 pr Cts. Bought half a bunch of Cotton yarn No 10. 2 1/2 lbs for $9.00. Called on Mr Clark.

div3.head: 21. Tues
div3.p: Recorded six pages of Minutes.

div3.head: 22. Wed
div3.p: Recording Minutes. Wrote to James and received a letter from him.

div3.head: 23. Thurs
div3.p: Rained much last night & much today. Labouriously recording Minutes, 6 Ps.

div3.head: 24. Fri
div3.p: Finished Recording the Minutes of Synod. The paper is so bad, I have been 7 days recording 31 Pages.

div3.head: 25. Sat
div3.p: Wrote to Col. Preston. Studying &c.

div3.head: 26. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good Congn

div3.head: 27. Mon
div3.p: Rode to Staunton to put the Minutes of Synod in the hands of Mr. Hugh G. Guthrie to take to the Genl. Assy. at Columbia for Review. Heard a speech from Col. John B. Baldwin, a Candidate for Congress.

div3.head: April 28th. Tu.
div3.p: Working & reading.

div3.head: 29. Wed
div3.p: Went to the P. Office. Pd my Postage Act. for Newspapers for 1862 & letter Postage to this date; also for a landside and plowpoint = in all $3.50 Paid Mr Supple for a supposed deficiency in the 10 Bs. of Wheat I thought I sent him $4. I think it must have been stolen out of the barn, in the night.
Had my horse shod round with steel toed shoes.

div3.head: 30. Thurs
div3.p: Reading & working.

div3.head: May 1. Fri
div3.p: Studying & working.

div3.head: 2. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Preached at Wm Bell's of Hebron at the Funl. of his child aged 4 yrs. died of Scarlet Fever.

div3.head: 3. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel-good attention & good Congn Preached at C. C. School house. House full. Came home.

div3.head: 4. Mon
div3.p: Reading & working. Finished harrowing in Oats in the hill field. Sowed in it 19 Bushels. Sowed 7 Bushels in the NE field.

div3.head: 5. Tues
div3.p: Mrs McF. & Mary visiting. Planted Corn in lot N. of the house.

Heard that a great battle was fought on Sab last at Fredericksburg, with heavy loss on both sides-General Jackson severely wounded Gen. Hill sleightly-that we took 10,000 prisoners & were in possession of the heights beyond Fredericksburg. This news makes me feel very anxious about my sons.

div3.head: 6. Wed
div3.p:
Recdd a letter from James, written on the Battlefield while a fierce cannonade was going on. It was not dated, but I suppose was written on
Friday, May 1 (No, it was written Apl. 30th Thursday) as it was postmarked Richmond, May 2. It created intense feeling, but I trust God has spared my dear Sons, in ansr. to our prayers & theirs.
I had purposed to go to Staunton today to learn what I could, but the day was too Stormy. it rained a good deal last night & very much today.

div3.head: May 7 Thurs
div3.p: Cold NE. wind. Went to Staunton, but could get very little reliable news from the Army. I believe Roberts Brigade was not in Battle but held in reserve. I believe it is true that Gen. Jackson has had his left arm amputated & is wounded in the right hand. Alas. The Battle was most bloody.

div3.head: 8. Fri
div3.p: Day damp & cool. Studying and Reading.

div3.head: 9. Sat
div3.p: Studying. We have heard from apparently good authority, that James is safe. Blessed be God.

div3.head: 10. Sab
div3.p: An interesting letter from James. He describes the late battle as the severest he has been in, but thanks be to God he escaped without a wound. A letter from Mrs Col. M. Harman says the Regt. in which Robert is is all safe. Preached at Bethel & Greenville & came home.

div3.head: 11. Mon
div3.p: Marking out for corn in the SE field. I delivered 55 Bushels of Oats to Abram whom Col. J.M. Lilley sent for them Price $2.00 per bushel.

div3.head: 12. Tues
div3.p: Reading & working. Planting Corn in the SE. field. Wrote to B.G. Worth, Wilmington, N.C. & to B. King Esqr. Roswell, Ga.

div3.head: 13. Wed
div3.p: No letter from Robert yet. Visited at Wm. Cochran's whose daughter Margaret is sick. Called at Mrs Doak's & Mr Merritt's.

div3.head: May 13. Wed Continued.
div3.p: The sad inteligence has reached me today of the death of my valued noble friend Lieut. Genl. Thomas J. Jackson. It has produced a feeling of sadness & distress such as I have rarely experienced on the death of any one. It is a national Calamity of no ordinary weight. May God raise up another to fill his place & may our hopes rest more on God & less on man.
Finished planting corn in the SE. field.

div3.head: 14. Thurs
div3.p: Planting Potatoes.

div3.head: 15. Fri
div3.p: Planted Sorgum. This the last of my Spring planting. Benjn. McClung & James Patterson came & spent the night with us. I agreed to sell them 12 Barrels of Flour & some Bacon for the Army.

div3.head: 16. Sat
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 17. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a very full house. Dined at James McClung's & preached there to a good Congn Mrs McFarland & I spent the night at Mr Wallace's. He is quite unwell. Mrs Dorsey is better.

div3.head: 18. Mon
div3.p: We & Mr Mc Clung's family dined at Mr A.F. Humphrey's. I left Mrs McFarland there & came home.

div3.head: 19. Tues
div3.p: I delivered at Mint Spring for Jas. Patterson, sold to the Govt. for the Army, 206 1/2 lbs. of Bacon. Called to see Jacob Rosen who has come home from the Army badly wounded-his Jawbone badly broken. Called to see Jeff. he is better. I brought home 7 Bls. more of Flour-I have not at home 9 whole Bls. & some more. I left at the Mill 12 Bls which I have sold to the Govt. through J. Patterson at $24. I have sold 32 Bls. of Flour for $721.

div3.head: May 20. Wed
div3.p: Day pleasant but too dry for vegetation. Wrote to Robert & James & Recdd an interesting letter from James. Rhoda very unwell-confined to bed.

div3.head: 21. Thurs
div3.p: So afflicted with a cold in my head, I could do nothing. Rhoda still very unwell.

div3.head: 22. Fri
div3.p: Still very unwell-did not rise till after 10 a.m. and had to lie on the sofa. My Bones aching. Rhoda a little better. I went to bed about 4 p.m.

div3.head: 23. Sat
div3.p: Very little better. Rose about 8 a.m. Studied a little.

div3.head: 24. Sab
div3.p: A little better. Preached at Bethel to rather a small Congn Rhoda better. Mrs McF. came home.

div3.head: 25. Mon
div3.p: Still unwell. No rain, but a thick mist at time. A letter from Robert.

div3.head: 26. Tues
div3.p: Studying. My cold is worse. Alexr. McComb came to see me. Sally Gilkeson here.

div3.head: 27th. Wed
div3.p: Studying. Cleared off without rain!

div3.head: 28th. Thurs
div3.p: I went to Greenville to attend the General Elections, which I have seldom done, but in these times I regard it as duty to vote for good men. I voted for Thos. S. Flournay for Govr. Saml. Price Lieut. Gov. both Elders in the Pbn. Ch. J.R. Tucker. Aty. Genl. J.B. Baldwin, Congs. J.M. McCue, H.W. Sheffey, & James Walker for the house of Delegates.

div3.head: 29. Fri
div3.p: Preached at Hebron to a very small Congn Dined at Mrs Wright's. Came home. A little rain.

div3.head: 30. Sat
div3.p: Mrs McFarland went with me to Hebron. I preached to a good Congn Went to Westview & spent the night with Rev. S.L. Preston & Baptized his first born son Wm. Caruthers Preston.

div3.head: May 31. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Hebron to a very large Congn & had a good deal of liberty-gratis Deo. Three were admitted on Examn. & two on Cert. Came home to dinner. A little Asthma last night.

div3.head: June 1. Mon
div3.p: Unwell. Reading.

div3.head: 2. Tues
div3.p: Took to Cochrans Mill 11 1/2 Bshs of Oats, of the the crop of 1861, weighing 33 1/2 lbs per Bushel. I have sold them to the C.S. Govt. at 8 cents per lb. So they brought $2.68 1/2 per B.=$30.88.
I took also 25 Bs. of Corn for the Govt. at $4.50 pr. B. Mr Harris paid me in full $143.38.

div3.head: 3. Wed
div3.p: Reading.

div3.head: 4. Thurs
div3.p: Went to Staunton. Vested $1500 in 8 pr. cent. Confederate States Bonds & deposited them in the Central Bank: also $500 in 7 pr. ct. but Recdd not the Bond, but only a certificate. We hear James arrived in Staunton; sick.

div3.head: 5. Fri
div3.p: Studying. Mary went to Staunton for James & brought him home. He is not sick, but has had a bad cold & speak only in a whisper.

div3.head: 6. Sat
div3.p: Went to Staunton & preached for Mr Baker, & baptized Cornelia Lenoir the Child of Col. Wm P. & Sarah Ann Tate. Vested $400 more in Con. S. Stocks, 7 pr. Ct. Brought John Wright home. James is no better. The loss of voice is rather alarming.

div3.head: 7. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a rather thin house.

div3.head: 8. Mon
div3.p: Quartermaster Bell sent out two Waggons for a stack of Hay which I agreed to sell to the Government.

div3.head: 9. Tues
div3.p: Studying; Several lady Visitors here.

div3.head: June 10th 1863
div3.p: Reading.

div3.head: 11. Thurs
div3.p: At home. Dr. Humphreys & his two Children & & Julia came. Dr. Tate here to see James.

div3.head: 12. Frid.
div3.p: Went to Staunton to get James' leave of absence extend & it was for another week. Recd of the Quartermaster for 5190 lbs of hay, at $1.50 per hundred, $77.85. Took another $100. in Confederate State Stocks at 7 pr. Ct. Thus I now have $1000 in Va. Six's $15002000 in Confed. 8's & $5001000 in Confed 7's in all $4,000.
Dined at Addison Waddell's with Mrs McClung.

div3.head: 13. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Blistered James' breast & throat.

div3.head: 14. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel & at Mint Spring. Dined at Mr Towberman's & baptized the two children at their own house on account of their little boy being unwell. James better. I heard him speak aloud for the first time this morning. He went to Bethel.
Dr. Humphreys went to Bethel & went home with some of his relations.

div3.head: 15. Mon
div3.p: Reading. Warm & exceeding dry.

div3.head: 16. Tues
div3.p: Working & reading.

div3.head: 17. Wed
div3.p: Reading & Studying. The warmest day this sumr.

div3.head: 18. Thurs
div3.p: Still warmer. Working & reading. Mowing clover in front of the house. A light shower & very high wind. The Thermr. fell 30 degrees in a few hours.

div3.head: 19. Frid.
div3.p: Took James to Staunton on his way to the army. He & I dined at Col. Tate's; He will have to walk to the army-no transportation to be had. A very fine Shower in the afternoon.

div3.head: 20. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Shower & hail.

div3.head: June 21, 1863. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a pretty good Congn Dr. Humphreys came home with us. At 4 p.m. I preached at Cochran's Mill at the late residence of Mr Quessenberry who was shot thro' heart & killed instantly on Sunday May 3d. in the Battle of Chancilorsville. His widow desired me to preach a Funeral Discourse.

div3.head: 22. Mon
div3.p: Dr. Humphreys took the Children to see their other relations. I am Reading & working. Received a letter from Robert, written in Camp near Winchester, giving an account of the taking of that place & nearly all Milroys Army. But few lives lost; blessed be God.
A letter also from Francis who is unwell, & is coming home.

div3.head: 23. Tues
div3.p: Reading & working. Mowing, making & hauling in Clover hay. Cannon were heard.

div3.head: 24. Wed
div3.p: Reading.

div3.head: 25. Thurs
div3.p: Reading. Day very damp, but little rain.

div3.head: 26. Fri
div3.p: Unwell. Studying a little. A little rain.

div3.head: 27. Sat
div3.p: Still unwell, but better. Studying.

div3.head: 28. Sab
div3.p: Rain. Preached at Bethel to a small Congn

div3.head: 29. Mon
div3.p: Cloudy & some rain. Reading.

div3.head: 30. Tues
div3.p: This afternoon took a Chill & was very unwell. Mr McPheters who has been to the army & saw Robert called to give us the news.

div3.head: July 1. Wed
div3.p: Spent a restless & uncomfortable night-had mustard to my breast. Did not rise till 11 a.m. feel weak.

div3.head: July 2. Thurs
div3.p: I am still feeble. Showry. Mowed a little but ceased-weather too unsettled. Reading.

div3.head: 3. Fri
div3.p: I am better. Mowed a little more & hauled in a load of hay. Dr. Humphreys & Mrs McF. went to Mr. Blackwood's. I have been reading. Very warm.

div3.head: 4. Sat
div3.p: Studying. About noon a very heavy thunder-shower, & a moderate rain most of the afternoon. Dr. Humphreys & Mrs McFarland returned.

div3.head: 5. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a pretty good Congn On account of rain had to give up my afternoon service.

div3.head: 6. Mon
div3.p: Cloudy & rain in the evening. Dr. Humphreys left us to return to Tennesseex. I rode to Mr Hendersons & Wm Silers'. [x but did not ultimately go]

div3.head: 7. Tues
div3.p: Rain. Working. Mr McPheters brought us the news of a great battle said to have been fought at Gettysburg Pa. between Genl. Lee's & Hooker's armies on last Thursday, Friday & Saturday.

div3.head: 8. Wed
div3.p: Reading & Working.

div3.head: 9. Thurs
div3.p: Went to Staunton hoping to hear from my sons but did not. Drew interest on my investments up to the 1st inst. $54.14 Dined at Col. Baldwin's. Learned a good deal about the tremendous Battle at Gettysburgh Pa. perhaps the bloodiest of the war.

div3.head: 10. Fri
div3.p: Began to cut Wheat. At home, reading, &c.

div3.head: 11. Sat
div3.p: Mr Ferguson from the army reporting my sons safe on Frida Saturday, the 4th at noon-thanks be to God. Studying. Cutting Wheat.

div3.head: 12. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel & at James McClung's to good Congs. Came home. Day warm.

div3.head: July 13. Mon
div3.p: Rained heavily this morning & was rainy & damp all day. Mr Douglass called.

div3.head: 14. Tues
div3.p: Cut some wheat. About 3 p.m. a very heavy shower.

div3.head: 15. Wed
div3.p: I suffered last night with pain in my bowels & today feel very feeble. Mr Henderson sent me 4 hands to help to cut my harvest.

div3.head: 16. Thurs
div3.p: Capt. John Humphreys here last night. I am to feeble to go to Staunton to the called meeting of Presby. Black Jack Cradleing wheat-finished cutting wheat.

div3.head: 17. Fri
div3.p: Studying. Wheat not dry enough to bring in.

div3.head: 18. Sat
div3.p: Grain still too wet. Studying.

div3.head: 19. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good Congn Then in Greenville to a good Congn & came home. Letter from James.

div3.head: 20. Mon
div3.p: Hauling in Wheat in good order. Wrote to James. He writes in a delightful Christian spirit.

div3.head: 21. Tues
div3.p: Finished hauling in Wheat. 205 Dozens.

div3.head: 22. Wed
div3.p: Mowing. Got my horses shoes removed all round. Visited May Newton, Wm Thompson & Mrs Echard.

div3.head: 23. Thurs
div3.p: Mrs King & her three youngest Children spent last night & today here. I went to Staunton. Saw 900 Yankee prisoners put on the Cars for Richmond. Dined at Mr Woods with Genl. Imboden, Mrs McClung & Agnes & Add. Waddell & Mr Davis Kayser & wife. A heavy shower late in the evening.

div3.head: 24. Fri
div3.p: Reading & working. Killed a Calf, Wt. 34 lbs. $63. Skin $[blank space] Making & hauling in hay.

div3.head: 25. Sat
div3.p: Studying. At the hay, 2 load more.

div3.head: 26. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel & CC Sch House to good Congs. Spent the night at Mr Pilson's. N. & Wm. Bent came to my house.

div3.head: July 27. Mon
div3.p: Taking cold. At night had Asthma badly.

div3.head: 28. Tues
div3.p: Very feeble & feverish. N. Bent went to Staunton. A very heavy rain in the afternoon. Flooded my meadow.

div3.head: 29. Wed
div3.p: Working & reading. Dr. Humphreys & Theda came here yesterday & are still here.

div3.head: 30. Thurs
div3.p: Had another bad night with asthma. Reading & writing.

div3.head: 31. Fri
div3.p: Quite unwell. Put mustard on my stomach which relieved the Asthmatic symptoms. Capt. Humphreys here.

div3.head: August 1. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Better.

div3.head: 2. Sab
div3.p: I am very unwell. Suffered much last night with a "stitch" in my left breast & soreness on pressure; also an inflammation of my left tonsil rendering deglution painful.
