I feared the effects of preaching but preached at Bethel to a large Congn for over an hour:-was much exhausted, & suffered much with my breast & throat.

div3.head: 3. Mon
div3.p: I spent a wretched night last night with the stitch in my breast: coughing was agony. I did not rise till 11 a.m. Nat. & Wm Bent left us after early Dinner. Mary & Frank went with them to Staunton.
Mr Hemp hauling in my share of the hay from the NW. field
Dr. Tate came to see me & prescribed. Applied a blister to my left breast, did not rise well. Took a blue pill.

div3.head: 4. Tues
div3.p: Spent another uncomfortable night. Stitch not so sharp. Remained in bed all day.

div3.head: 5. Wed
div3.p: Another restless night-applied the blister again. Remained in bed till 1 p.m. Dr. Tate came again.

div3.head: 6. Thurs
div3.p: In bed all day. Applied another & more effective blister. Mr Pilson came to see me.

div3.head: Aug. 7 1863.
div3.p: In bed all day blister very sore.
Dr. Tate came to see me. Letters from James & Robert.

div3.head: 9. Sat.
div3.p: In bed all day. Had a high fever last night. Tried another Blister tissue did not do well. Mr Gilkeson & Mrs Wright came to see me.

div3.head: 10. Sab
div3.p: Less fever last night. Applied another Blister. Mary & her children went to Bethel & took David, but brought him back. Rev. Gershom Goble, providentially was at Bethel & preached & came & dined here. Blister rose well.

div3.head: 11. Mon
div3.p: Somewhat better. Dr. Tate here. Mr Gilkeson also.

div3.head: 12. Tues
div3.p: About as yesterday. At 1 p.m. rose & dressed-the first time for a week. I feel great debility. Cutting Oats for 3 days pasted. Mrs Larew & Lizie Wilson here. Dr. Humphries also came.

div3.head: 13. Wed
div3.p: But little change. Rose earlier. Dr. Humphries took David away with him. Finished cutting Oats.

div3.head: 14. Thurs
div3.p: More fever last night, not so well today. I am suffering from the Blister applied last Sab There was a heavy shower last night.

div3.head: 15. Fri
div3.p: Rested rather better last night, but more feeble & feverish today. Rose at 11 a.m. went to bed at 3 p.m. A very heavy thunder gust with hail. Letters from R. & J.

div3.head: 16. Sat
div3.p: Spent a very feverish night, my left side very sore. In the afternoon better-in bed all day.

div3.head: 17. Sab
div3.p: Had Asthma-did not rest well-better this morning. The family went to Bethel-I lay in bed till noon & remained up till near 5. The internal soreness has left my breast. Good Congn at Bethel & a good prayer-meeting.

div3.head: Aug. 17. Mon
div3.p: Did not rest very well.
Mr D. Carlisle Gilkeson & wife & Mrs Jas. McClung came to see me & Dined here. I rose a little before M. & remained till 5 p.m.

div3.head: 18. Tues
div3.p: Rested badly. Mrs Pilson came to see me. Rose at noon-up several hours. Finished hauling Oats.

div3.head: 19. Wed
div3.p: Cool. In bed all day. Mrs Gilkeson & Saml. Hays came to see me.

div3.head: 20. Thurs
div3.p: In bed all day. Poulticed the sores arising from the blisters-very troublesome.

div3.head: 21. Fri
div3.p: Had a bad night with Asthma. More unwell than heretofore-feel depressed-not in soul but in spirits. In bed all day. This the national Fast, but alas, I could not attend. The Elders held a Prayer meeting.

div3.head: 22. Sat
div3.p: More depressed-fever-restless. Dr Tate here: was sent for. Began to plow for Wheat.

div3.head: 23. Sab
div3.p: Rested rather better last night & am a little more comfortable-fever rather less. In bed all day-no preaching at Bethel, alas! Dr. Tate came prescribes Spts of Turpentine.

div3.head: 24. Mon
div3.p: Spent a restless night-feel badly, but by degrees improved.

div3.head: 25. Tues
div3.p: Another restless night. Dr. Tate & Dr. Humphries here. Felt badly in the afternoon.

div3.head: 26. Wed
div3.p: No better. Ground too hard to plow. In the afternoon more comfortable.

div3.head: 27. Thurs
div3.p: A bad night with Asthma. Spent an uncomfortable day & the worse for company.

div3.head: Sept. 6. Sab
div3.p: Did not rest quite so well. Rev. Wm. Morrison spent the night her and preached at Bethel today. All the family went to church. A letter from Robert & a Certificate of his church membership. Also a Check for $35.

div3.head: 7. Mon
div3.p: Had a bad restless night-slept little. Much depressed today. Applied Jemson leaves to the boils, but nothing seems to do good. I suffer much with pain at times.

div3.head: 8. Tues
div3.p: Had a rather better night but am no better on the whole.

div3.head: 9. Wed
div3.p: Slept a good deal, but suffering much. A letter from James. Dr. Tate came & cut open the Boil which is now ascertained to be a Carbuncle. No pus but only Blood came out.

div3.head: 10. Thurs
div3.p: Another painful night-rest much broken. Dr. Humphreys came to spend a few days with me.

div3.head: 11. Fri
div3.p: Slept rather more. Today more feverish & restless than for some time. Dr. H. went to Staunton & got me a vial of Tincture of Hyosciamus for $1.50 & 3/4 lb of of Epsom Salts for $1.50 Dr. H. applied Tinc. of Iodine to my Carbuncles.

div3.head: 12. Sat
div3.p: Rested a little better. Wm F. Smith Dr. Tate, Dr. Wm. Brown, Rev. Wm. Morrison & Mr & Mrs Henderson here.

div3.head: 13. Sab
div3.p: No better. Wm. Morrison preached at B. & C.C. Schl. H. All the whites at Ch.

div3.head: Sept. 14. Mon
div3.p: Another bad night. Rev. Mr Crawford & wife & Mrs Brown spent the day here & greatly distressed me by too much conversation.
Rev. Dr. Wm. S. White dined here.
I feel a sense of great exhaustion.

div3.head: 15. Tues
div3.p: Had a very bad feverish night, & today not as well as usual.

Sent to Staunton 34 lbs of Cheese & 28 of Butter to be sent by Express to G.W. Gretter, Richmond. John Lambert & Peggy Ann & Tirza L. dined here. John L. Brought a Certificate of Ch. member-ship to be Recdd into Bethel Ch. as my son R. also had, being received in the Army.

div3.head: 16. Wed
div3.p: A letter from James-he seems very anxious about me. Mr Gilkeson called. Mrs McChristian E. Sproul & Jack Kreders here. This my best day for a week-but had a bad night last night. Hyossiamus affected my head.

div3.head: 17. Thurs
div3.p: Better today-some Diarhea.
Messrs. Gardner, S. Pilson & M. Pilson here.

div3.head: 18. Fri
div3.p: My Bowells very much disordered & this morning marked symptoms of Dyssentry appeared. Sent for Drs Tate & Humphreys & they came. Took injections of Starch & Laudanum which relieved me much. It rained heavily nearly all last night.

div3.head: 19. Sat
div3.p: Symptoms of Dysenterry disappeared but returned in the evening. D.H. left me.

div3.head: Sept. 20. Sab
div3.p: Last night was one of great suffering from pain in my bowels. Today I am relieved, thanks to God.
Mary & Robert went to Staunton where Robert expects to go to the Lord's Table for the first time. May God abundantly bless it to him.

div3.head: 21. Mon
div3.p: I spent a pretty comfortable night & today am free from pain or disordered bowels. Dr. Tate here. Robert went to Staunton.

div3.head: 22. Tues
div3.p: Spent a feverish night & very uncomfortable night. Today I am better, no fever.

div3.head: 23. Wed
div3.p: Rested tolerably am better today than since I was taken-pulse down to 74. Dr. Tate & wife & Miss Sally Tate here. A letter from James dated Friday last-he is well & the army was daily expecting to move.

div3.head: 24. Thurs
div3.p: Rested tolerably, better. Finished plowing for wheat in the Hill field.
Went to the other room & lay on the sofa an hour & more while the study was cleaned.
Borrowed of Mr Gilkeson 12 Bs of white-straw Mediterranean wheat & 6 Bs of red straw=18 B.

div3.head: 25. Fri
div3.p: Better. Began to sow Wheat in the Hill field. Robert & Mary went to Mr Bumgarner's.

div3.head: 26. Sat
div3.p: A heavy white frost. I continued to gather strength.

div3.head: 27. Sab
div3.p: Better. Rev Wm. Morrison preached. Good Congn Robert left us to return to the Army.

div3.head: Sept. 28. 1863. Mon
div3.p: I feel still an increase of strength, but am likely to be troubled with a cutaneous eruption consequent, as I believe on the use of Laudanum in my recent attack of Dyssentary. At 1 1/2 O'clock p.m. I rose & dressed-the first time for nearly two months.
Remained up several hours. Finished sowing wheat in the Hill field. Sowed 4 Bs. of Redstraw on the N. end & 12 Bs. Whitestraw on the other end, in all 16 Bs.

div3.head: 29. Tues
div3.p: I suffered very much the early part of last night with the eruption on my limbs aggravated, I believe, by sitting up & walking-remained in bed all day.

div3.head: 30. Wed
div3.p: Greater suffering from the eruption last night-nothing gives me relief. Returned to Mr Gilkeson two Bs. of wheat.

div3.head: October 1. Thurs
div3.p: Had a more comfortable night. Taking salts & cream of Tarter & drinking Sassafras tea. A little rain.

div3.head: 2. Fri
div3.p: Before day it began to rain & rain all day, sometimes very heavily. Ceased at 5 p.m. The Eruption is extending on my back; threatens to be very extensive. Last night I was a good deal harassed by it.

div3.head: 3. Sat
div3.p: Rested better last night. Wrote to G.W. Gretter about the Sugar ordered & the Butter & Cheese sent. Wrote to Rev. James Morrison.

div3.head: 4. Sab
div3.p: Had a violent attack of Diarrhea last night & feel badly today.

div3.head: October 4. Sab continued.
div3.p: Mrs McF & Mary went to Bethel-Rev. Wm. W. Morrison preached, & again at Mr McClung's. A good Congn at Bethel.

div3.head: 5. Mon
div3.p: The Tumour on my left breast very sore-poulticing it. Dr. Humphries came & cut into it with the Spring lanet, but did not reach the matter.

Mr Kurtz came here (one of the Staunton Police) with a note from Mayor N.K. Trout, saying that Bacon had been found with Patsey, a black woman, who says she Recdd it by a black man & that she had bought it from Rhoda. I wrote to Mr Trout giving Rhoda a good character for honesty.

div3.head: 6. Tues
div3.p: Had a restless night with what seems to be another large Carbuncle on my left nipple-are poulticing it. Eruption more troublesome.

div3.head: 7. Wed
div3.p: A good deal of suffering last night, but rather easier today.

div3.head: 8. Thurs
div3.p: This morning the Carbuncle or Boil began to discharge & is easier, but the eruption harasses me so much that it seems to almost a matter of life or death that I should go to the sulpher spring, for otherwise it seems as if it would spread all over me, & I am too weak to bear it. Mary & Frank went to Staunton.

div3.head: 9. Fri
div3.p: Rose at 11 a.m. & dressed & at 1 p.m. Mrs McF & I set off for Staunton & arrived at 3, much exhausted. Stayed at Col. Tate's. Stood it better than my fears.

div3.head: October 10th 1863.
div3.p: Suffered very much last night with the eruption. After breakfast, at 7.45' took the Car for Pond Gap Fare $1.25 each=2.50. Mr D. Kunkle sent us over to Mr Crawford's where we were kindly Recdd by all. I am very feeble, but blessed be God I have stood wonderfully what I regarded as a most desperate effort.

div3.head: 11. Sab
div3.p: I slept well last night-the eruption scarcely troubled me any-my arms trouble me today. I slept a good deal today.
Too cool to drink sulphur water well. Frost.

div3.head: 12. Mon
div3.p: Another pretty comfortable night. Better & Stronger today. The water doing good.

div3.head: 13. Tues
div3.p: A good deal disturbed last night by the irritation which seemed somewhat increased. Dr. Humphries came to see us & dined here & then went to see Peggy McC. All well at home, thanks be to God.

div3.head: 14. Wed
div3.p: More comfortable last night. Day cloudy & damp. My appetite is even craving & my strength increases though the eruption does not seem to disappear as formerly & is still troublesome, but is dryer. Mrs McF. walked to Mr Kunkle.

div3.head: 15. Thurs
div3.p: Had a bad night. Took Salts which operated almost too freely, but may do good. A very heavy rain this morning.

div3.head: 16. Fri
div3.p: Rest broken. Today better. Very great Rain. In the evening cleare off.

div3.head: October 17. Sat
div3.p: Rested tolerably, eruption a little troublesome; but I am so much better I have resolved to return to Staunton on my way home. Dined at David Kunkles; they are very kind-gave us 4 pieces of Castings, worth $[blank space]. Came to Staunton fare $2.50 Gave Crawford's Servants $1.25 Staid at Col. Tate's.

div3.head: 18. Sab
div3.p: My Buggy came for me & we reached Bethel in time for Worship. Wm Morrison preached a pretty good sermon, we took a collection for him of $100. He preached six Sabbaths. I am much fatigued.

div3.head: 19. Mon
div3.p: Rain early but cleared off & at 8 O'clock Mary & I set off for Salem. Dined at Rev E. Junkin's & spent the night at Mr Wm White's in Lexington-his wife is suffering exeedingly with Neuralgia in her head. Much fatigued.

div3.head: 20. Tues
div3.p: Set out at 8 1/2 a.m. & drove 14+ 2 ms. to Mrs Moffet's & dined there-returned to the turnpike 2 ms. & drove 10 ms. to Buckanon & 2 more to Col. J.S. Anderson's where we enjoyed their elegant & Christian hospitality.

div3.head: 21. Wed
div3.p: Drove 19 ms. to Botetort Springs & dined there with Mr Cocke who has a School for 125 girls-charges $39.00 per month for every thing except musick. Seems a good School. 8 miles to Salem. Staid at Mr Lewis much fatigued. Eruption troublesome.
The Synod was opened with a good Sermon by Rev. Dr. Wm. J. Hoge.
On my motion Rev. Andw Hart was unanimously elected Moderator.

div3.head: Octr. 22.
div3.p: Attended Synod. Dr. Atkinson Preached well. Dr. Bocock as usual. Dined at Dr. Moorman's.

div3.head: 23. Fri
div3.p: An admirable address from Dr. M.D. Hoge. An able discussion on the Union of the New School with us. Rain. Did not go to hear Mr Peck in the evening.

div3.head: 24. Sat
div3.p: Very interesting addresses on the State of religion in the Army by Drs. Pryor & B.P. Lacy. Synod had a night Session.

div3.head: 25. Sab
div3.p: Dr. M.D. Hoge preached a noble Sermon I made the first prayer. The Lord's Supper was administered in the afternoon by myself & Dr. Leighton Wilson & B.P. Lacy. Dr. Dabney preached at night. Took tea at J.B.S. Logan's.

div3.head: 26. Mon
div3.p: Did not rest well-great irritation in my skin & some Asthma. Synod had a session till 11 a.m. Since Thursday I have staid with the Miss Shireys-Lutherans. Returned to Col. Edmondson's.

div3.head: 27. Tues
div3.p: Set out for home at 9 a.m. & Reached Buchanan at 3.15 p.m.-Staid at the Rev. Andw Hart's-day very cold-caught cold.

div3.head: 28. Wed
div3.p: Reached Lexington at 2.15 p.m. 24+1. Staid Mr Wm. White's.

div3.head: October 29. Thurs
div3.p: Dined at Mrs E. Witherow's & came home-much fatigued. Thanks be to God.

div3.head: 30. Fri
div3.p: Quite unwell-in bed all day. Headache & the eruption aggravated.

div3.head: 31. Sat
div3.p: I am better-able to read & study a little.

div3.head: November 1. Sab
div3.p: Feeble & indisposed. Preached at Bethel, having been silent three months. Suffering with the Eruption.

div3.head: 2. Mon
div3.p: A restless suffering night.

div3.head: 3. Tues
div3.p: Suffered with the eruption as before. Breakfasted by candle-light & at 5.40' a.m. set out for Staunton & arrived at 7 1/2 took the Cars for Pond Gap & Crawford's Spring & was kindly Recd & drank the water freely.

div3.head: 4. Wed
div3.p: Rested better the latter part of the night. Much less irritation in my back & elsewhere.

div3.head: 5. Thurs
div3.p: I am sensibly better, had a good night's sleep. The day quite warm-sulphur water good.

div3.head: 6. Fri
div3.p: I think I am improving.

Genl. Imboden passed this morning, going West with two Regiments of Cavalry, who are armed & fight as Infantry. I conversed with him a while. Saw John Merrit & Dr. King-also made the acquaintance of Capt. Berkley, Adjt Genl. to Genl. I also Capt. Harrison of Staunton, & a Mr Horring.

div3.head: 7. Sat
div3.p:
Day uncomfortably cool. I feel discouraged today there is more irritation in my legs & shoulders & back. I wrote home.
A Mr. Chipley spent the night here-a sensible man. 62 Regt. Mounted Infantry, col. Smith, gives a sad account of their Chaplain Laferty. 18 Regt. Col. Imboden & surgeon King.

div3.head: Nov. 8 1863. Sab
div3.p: This day has been spent in silence & solitude. How gladly would I have been preaching Christ. I seem not to be improving in regard to my disease, & feel somewhat discouraged. But the Lord's will be done.

div3.head: 9. Mon
div3.p: Very cold-snow showers. Mr Morris set off for Tye River. My Eruption more troublesome. I fear I am not to be cured by Sulpher water.

div3.head: 10. Tues
div3.p: Had a pretty good night & am better & am more encouraged. Correcting Minutes of synod.

div3.head: 11. Wed
div3.p: A very cold night. I am about as yesterday. Gn. Imboden's troops returned today.

div3.head: 12. Thurs
div3.p: My shoulders & arms suffered last night. I left the kind family of Crawfords to whom I am so much indebted-may God reward them.
Reached Staunton about sunset, met my horses there & came home found all well but Julia, thanks be to God.

div3.head: 13. Fri
div3.p: Suffered severely with the Eruption in my right thigh. In other respects I am as usual. Studying.

div3.head: 14. Sat
div3.p: More comfortable. Studying. Rain in the evening.

div3.head: 15. Sab
div3.p: A pretty confortable night. Heavy rain through most of the night-the day fair. Preached at Bethel.

div3.head: 16. Mon
div3.p: Cool. I am better. Visited John Wright who is dying I think. Letters from Robert & James.

div3.head: Nov. 17. Tues
div3.p: Went to Greenville in my Buggy. Bought of Wm. Smith 8 lbs of sole leather at $5. pr. lb. & 3 lbs of Uper leather at $6.50 pr. lb.=$59.50 to make James a pair of Boots. Mr Smith gave me all the leather at $1.50 below the selling price. Recdd of John Newton 150 lbs of salt at 10 cents per lb.=$15. Now selling at 50 cents pr. lb. Dr. Humphreys came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 18. Wed
div3.p: Reading & writing.

div3.head: 19. Thurs
div3.p: Went to Staunton in my Buggy to attend to various items of business. Engaged Rev. S.D. Stuart to assist at our Communion on the last Sab in Nov.

div3.head: 20. Fri
div3.p: My neighbour John Wright died at 3 O'clock a.m. Reading & studying a little.

div3.head: 21. Sat
div3.p: Raining early & increased. I had to go to Wrights in a heavy rain. Preached a Funeral Sermon to a goodly number for the day. I fear I have taken cold.

div3.head: 22. Sab
div3.p: This morning before breakfast, Mrs McFarland, going to the kitchen, sliped on the plank & fell & hurt her back I fear badly; we had to carry her in, & she has suffered much all day-able to help herself very little. May God grant her a speedy recovery.
I preached at Bethel with as much ease as usual.

div3.head: 23. Mon
div3.p: Mrs McFarland rested better than I expected Can help herself a little, but suffers much.
A letter from James. I am reading & writing.

div3.head: 24. Tues
div3.p: Mrs McF. worse. Sent for Dr. Tate & Dr. Humphreys. Dr. Tate did not come. Dr. H. came late & cupped Mrs McF. She suffers much & can help herself very little.

div3.head: Nov. 24. Tues (continued)
div3.p: Sent the Minutes of Synod, prepared for the Press, to Rev. Dr. Wm. Brown by Mr James Henderson.

div3.head: 25. Wed
div3.p: Mrs McF. rested more comfortably last night. Still no material improvement. I am not very well.

div3.head: 26. Thurs
div3.p: Mrs McF. rested pretty well-could turn herself in bed. I am feeble today can do nothing. In the Evening better.

div3.head: 27. Fri
div3.p: Sent off letters to Rev. Dr. Dabney & Mr Saml. McCorkle. Mrs McF. a little better, but still keeps her bed. Recd a letter from Robt. P. McF. I fear from the statement in the Northern Papers, that Capt. Beall & his party of 60 men & officers have been captured, that my son Francis is one of them. If so, may God bless to him the sad providence.

div3.head: 28. Sat
div3.p: Heavy showers from the S.W. till noon, then cleared off. Mrs McF. we think improves slowly-still in bed. I am not at all well-stomach disordered. Studying.

div3.head: 29. Sab
div3.p: Mrs McF. a little better. I preached at Bethel to a good Congn & had good attention. O for God's blessing.

div3.head: 30. Mon
div3.p: Very cold. Killed six hogs, Wt. 880 lbs. & not very fat-corn scarce. Wm. Siler & Dr. Humphreys assisting. I could not even go to see them.

div3.head: December 1. Tues
div3.p: Mrs McF. much improved. I am still complaining & by no means well.

div3.head: 2. Wed
div3.p: Last night the eruption on my left thigh troubled me. Mrs McF. much better.

div3.head: 3. Thurs
div3.p: I am better; also Mrs McF. Killed a young steer. The beef weighed 426 lbs. I propose selling it. Pd. Wm. Silers for killing hogs $5 & for the Beef $1.50

div3.head: December 4. Fri
div3.p: Sent my beef to Staunton. Dr. Humphreys went & sold it at 50 cents pr. lb.=$213. I sent also 7 Bs. of ears of corn, being the full tithe of my crop. Dr. H. also paid the Confederate tax on Coin, notes, currency &c. $13.14. I am taking a bad cold.

div3.head: 5. Sat
div3.p: Spent a very uncomfortable night with Coughing & the eruption. Went to Bethel-called at Mr Bumgarner's. Met the session & received on Certificate Robt. P. McFarland & John M. Lambert, Recdd in the Army by Rev. C.S.H. Sa. & Mrs R. Miller Vanlear (wife of Wm) and on Examination Susan C. Gillum, daughter of Mrs G. of Greenville. The Session also suspended from the Communion of the church Wm Gibson & his wife for absenting themselves from the church & its ordinances for many years.
Rev. Saml. D. Stuart preached. I have a bad Cold.

div3.head: 6. Sab
div3.p: I am better. The Session Recd on Examn. Estelle Via Argenbright. Mr Stuart preached a good Sermon on the love of God, 1 John 3:10. I served both tables at Mr Stuart's request. He came & dined here. Mrs Steel of Staunton & her daughter & son came came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 7. Mon
div3.p: Languid. Reading &c. Mrs Henderson came & brought me 3 yds of the best homemade flannel I ever saw, worth at present $10. a yd. at least. A very generous present indeed.

div3.head: December 8. Tues
div3.p: Cold. Took my waggon to Lightner's for repairs. Took the Steer's hide to Mr Smith to tan on the shares-Weighed 75 lbs. took no rect. Made several calls.
Recd of John Newton 55 lbs of County Salt at 12 cents per lb. Paid $6.50 in full.

div3.head: 9. Wed
div3.p: I went to Mr Gilkeson's & to the Post Office. A letter from Rev. E.D. Junkin, asking me to aid at a protracted meeting, but my health is too inform. A letter also from my son Robert-he is safe.

div3.head: 10. Thurs
div3.p: Working, Wearied. Caught cold.

div3.head: 11. Fri
div3.p: Do not feel well. Mrs McFarland continues to improve slowly. Recd letters from Dr. Wm. Brown & his wife containing the sad inteligence that our son Francis is a prisoner in Fort McHenry! May God bless the awful providence to his soul. We killed a Beef Cow; Net Beef, 465 lbs. Tallow 30 lbs. Hide.

div3.head: 12. Sat
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 13. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a rather thin Congn, the Home guard being out. In the evening I was so unfortunate as to sprain my left foot badly.

div3.head: 14. Mon
div3.p: My foot better. Reading. Letter from James.

div3.head: 15. Tues
div3.p: Went to Mr Gilkeson's about threshing. Called at Mr Henderson's & dined at Mr Palmer's.

div3.head: 16. Wed
div3.p: Reading & working. Chilling wind.

div3.head: 17. Thurs
div3.p: It rained in the night & it froze as it fell: the same through the day. Many branches broke off the locust trees around the house.

div3.head: December 18. Fri
div3.p: Day very chilly. Reading.

div3.head: 19. Sat
div3.p: Very cold. My sprained foot once more swelled & painful. Studying. Wm. Larew came to see us.

div3.head: 20. Sab
div3.p: Very cold. Preached at Bethel to about 30 hearers. The Guards again called out today. At 8 p.m. Therm. at +12 very cold.

div3.head: 21. Mon
div3.p: A little more moderate. My foot more painful. Frank went to Greenville & got James' Boots & Shoes for Liz. Recd a letter from Robert. I can do very little. About 9 p.m. our son James arrived from the Army on Furlow for 15 days. He is very well. This is a kind Providence for me for which I thank God.

div3.head: 22. Tues
div3.p: I rest badly at night. Mrs McF is not improving. We enjoy James' company.

div3.head: 23. Wed
div3.p: James went to Staunton. Dr. Humphreys came from the excursion of the Home Guards.

div3.head: 24. Thurs
div3.p: Cold Dr. Humphreys took Theda & Mary's children to Mr Wallace's to spend a few days. I scarcely ever felt such languor & inefficiency.

div3.head: 25. Fri
div3.p: Another Christmas day I have seen. Blessed be God. I have tolerable health though lame from the sprain of my foot & I feel many of the infirmities of age. Mrs McFarland, alas, seems to recover very slowly from the effects of her fall. Servants all absent.

div3.head: 26. Sat
div3.p: At home studying. James out about servants.

div3.head: 27. Sab
div3.p: An interesting day. The session Recd my son James into the communion of the church on Examn. and I asked the prayers of the church for my son Francis. Preached to a good Congn

div3.head: December 27. Sab Continued
div3.p: This day at 10 1/2 O'clock a.m. I married James Bumgardner Jr. & Mary Mildred Bumgardner, the first second marriage I ever solemnized on the Sabbath. I do not regard it as wrong but I did it with reluctance.

div3.head: 28. Mon
div3.p: Day very unpleasant & I remained at home. James went to Staunton to se about a man servant. The prospect is bad from the scarcity & the enormous prices asked.

div3.head: 29. Tues
div3.p: Went to see Dr. Trummond about a servant: was unsuccessful. I feel much discouraged but trust God will provide.

div3.head: 30. Wed
div3.p: Went in search of a servant & I trust have been successful. A man belonging to the estate of Adam Swink, named Zek, is for hire. I went to see all the heirs & obtained their cheerful consent that I should have him & I trust he will suit me.

div3.head: 31. Thurs
div3.p: Rained in the night & about day it began to snow & continued till about noon-2 inches fell.
I went to Mr Gardner's & Mr Towberman's to arrange about Zek. Mr Gardner would have let me have him for $250, but Mr Towberman insisted on $300, which sum I am to pay & cloathe him.

div3.head: 1864. January 1. Friday.
div3.p: Intensely Cold. It is a great mercy to me that I have not to leave home today. Dr. Humphreys went to Staunton & hired July to Mr Evans for $150. & cloathing.

God has been merciful to my family another year. I am in tolerable health for my age. My wife is slowly recovering from the effects of her fall. Robert in the army & well: James at home on Furlough, also well-both Lieutenants. Mary & her children well. Dr. Humphreys & his children well & here. Francis' sad condition is the great grief of the family-a prisoner & in irons & it is said to be tried for piracy, but as I understand it, they were commissioned as Privateers.

div3.head: 2. Sat
div3.p: Intensely cold. The Therm. fell regularly all day yesterday from 33 till this morning when it was at Zero. I was studying.

div3.head: 3. Sab
div3.p: The day was so cold, & I was not very well, that I was afraid to go to Bethel. James went & said there were a good many there.

div3.head: 4. Mon
div3.p: James left us to return to the Army-Frank went with him to Staunton before 7 a.m. Dr. H & David left us. James Hall & Mr. Adams came for Mose-Adams has bot' him-was not satisfied with his cloathing although good except a hat. But to avoid trouble I paid him $55. in addition to his hire.

div3.head: 5. Tues
div3.p: Sent Frank to Greenville & to get Judge shod all round. Got Julia's shoes. I have been reading.

div3.head: 6. Wed
div3.p:
Mr. Gardner came to tell me that Zeke is unwilling to live so far from his wife, but has no
other objection to living with me. This is an embarrassing affair-may the Lord order it all for his glory & the good of all concerned.

div3.head: Jan. 7. 1864.
div3.p: Very Cold. Went to Mr Gardners to see Zeke, who after much trouble to persuade him agreed to come & live with us; & he came & began to work. Glory to God, the perplexity is ended. I gave my Bond for $300 & cloathing to A. Gardner.

div3.head: 8. Fri
div3.p: Studying. Mr Pilson called to see us. This is my Birthday. Today I am 76 years of age. Glory be to God that I enjoy so much health at such an advanced age, & blessed be his name that he still permits me to preach Christ. May I live more to his glory while I do live.

div3.head: 9. Sat
div3.p: Very cold. I suffered much from coughing last night. Studying, thought I can hardly keep warm.

div3.head: 10. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to 36 hearers. Very Cold.

div3.head: 11. Mon
div3.p: At home-Reading. Letter from James.

div3.head: 12. Tues
div3.p: Went to see Wm. Hall about Rhoda-he says there is no doubt I can keep her. I agreed to pay $50. hire.

div3.head: 13. Wed
div3.p: Day promising but became damp & chilly.
I went to Staunton & drew Dividends for myself for Va. Stock $30. Confederate Stocks $119.89 = $149.89 for Mary-Va. Stock $54. Confed. $35.34 = 89.34.

div3.head: 14. Thurs
div3.p: Reading & working. Wrote to James.

div3.head: 15. Fri
div3.p: Reading. I still feel the fatigue of Wednesday.

div3.head: 16. Sat
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 17. Sab
div3.p: Preached to a good & attentive Congn.

div3.head: Jan. 18. 1864
div3.p: Reading & working. Sent July to Mr B. Brawford's where Mary has hired her. Mr. Henderson brought his threshing Machine here.

div3.head: 19. Tues
div3.p: Mr Henderson threshed my wheat & finished by 3 p.m. then cleaned till night. Mr H. brought 2 hands & Mr Gilkeson sent 2 & Rosen one. Very blustery.

div3.head: 20. Wed
div3.p: Cleaning Wheat. Mr Henderson's Mason helping.

div3.head: 21. Thurs
div3.p: Finished cleaning Wheat; had 'tis said 95 Bushels. I must take 30 Bs. out of this & so will have 65 for home use.

div3.head: 22. Fri
div3.p: Mr. Henderson came to thresh my Oats, but broke his main shaft. I am reading & studying. Mild day.

div3.head: 23. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Day very mild.

div3.head: 24. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good Congn. Day very mild. Took a Collection for Foreign Missions.

div3.head: 25. Mon
div3.p: Went to the Post Office-letters from Robert & James. Paid Lowry for mending Shoes $4. Mr Henderson finished threshing Oats & cloverseed. Brought two hands.

div3.head: 26. Tues
div3.p: Went to Greenville. Took leather to Mr Burch to have shoes made for Rhoda. Dined at Dr. Tate's. Paid my Blacksmith Bill to Mr Lightner $42.00 he generously threw off $8.37. Bought 1/2 lb. Epson salts for $2.50

div3.head: 27. Wed
div3.p: Working & reading.

div3.head: 28. Thurs
div3.p: Finished cleaning Oats-had 142 Bushels.

div3.head: 29. Fri
div3.p: Unwell-bowels much disordered-strength prostrated.

div3.head: 30. Sat
div3.p: Still unwell; in the afternoon better. Studying.

div3.head: 31. Sab
div3.p: Still very unwell, but preached at Bethel as usual to a good & attentive Congn. Much fatigued.

div3.head: Feb. 1. Mon
div3.p: Still unwell but better. Reading.

div3.head: 2. Tues
div3.p: Not so well. Mrs Gilkeson & Mrs Lawrence here.

div3.head: Feb. 3. 1864. Wednesday.
div3.p: Took medicine & am better. Day cold. Letter from James, enclosing a Check for $40.00 in part payment for his boots.

div3.head: 4. Thurs
div3.p: Brought home 5 Barrels & 70 lbs of Flour. The proceeds of 30 Bs of wheat. Flour now sells at $125. here.

div3.head: 5. Fri
div3.p: I am pretty well-studying. Mrs McFarland rode to Geo. Rosen's-the first attempt, & stood it pretty well. Thanks to God.

div3.head: 6. Sat
div3.p: Studying. In the afternoon rained moderately.

div3.head: 7. Sab
div3.p: About an inch of snow last night. Preached at B. to a small Congn. extempore. Dr. Humphreys came home with us.

div3.head: 8. Mon
div3.p: Reading. John Gilkeson here. Dr. Humphreys left us.

div3.head: 9. Tues
div3.p: Working at various things.

div3.head: 10. Wed
div3.p: Reading, &c.

div3.head: 11. Thurs
div3.p: Reading. George Rosen & wife here.

div3.head: 12. Fri
div3.p: Delivered in Cochran's Mill 5 1/2 Bs of Wheat making 55 1/2 there now. Delivered to the Govt. 60 lbs. of Pork, 4 Bs. of wheat & 14 1/2 of Oats. I sold $155. Va. Bank notes at 3 1/4 for one = $504.

div3.head: 13. Sat
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 14. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel with a good degree of liberty to a very large, attentive & solemn audience. Mrs McF at Ch. first time for 12 weeks.

div3.head: 15. Mon
div3.p: Began to Snow about noon, 1 I. fell; ceased in the evening. Plowed the garden. Dr. Humphreys came.

div3.head: 16. Tues
div3.p: Morning not cold, but the wind high & the Ther. fell rapidly & it became very cold. Dr. H. left here.

div3.head: 17. Wed
div3.p: Intensely cold. The Therm. only rose from 0 to +8 & fell to -2 at 9 p.m. John Shields dined here.

div3.head: 18. Thurs
div3.p: Still very cold. Mary went to Mrs Kings. Mr Pilson came to see me. A letter from Francis.

div3.head: Feb. 19. Fri
div3.p: Studying. Gave Mr Henderson an order for 3 1/2 Bushels of Wheat as Toll & gave him 7 Bushs. of Oats & paid him $10. for hands threshing.

div3.head: 20. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Mr McPheeters called here.

div3.head: 21. Sab
div3.p: Much harrassed for some time with the Eruption-especially in my arms. Rested badly. Preached at Bethel to a good & attentive Congn. Mrs McFarland out again.

div3.head: 22. Mon
div3.p: Working & reading. Mary returned.

div3.head: 23. Tues
div3.p: Very mild. Working & reading. Mary went to Mr Bumgarner's. Mrs Wright, Mrs Jno. Silor & Sallie Gilkeson here.

div3.head: 24. Wed
div3.p: Reading. Began to plow for Corn in the NW field.

div3.head: 25. Thurs
div3.p: Working. Paid Mr Palmer for a pair of U.S. Pantaloons for James $40. Paid Wm. Hail $30.00 being Rhoda's hire for last year. Plowing.

div3.head: 26. Fri
div3.p: Studying & reading.

div3.head: 27. Sat
div3.p: Had a suffering night with the eruption. Studying. Robert came home on Furlough of 15 days.

div3.head: 28. Sab
div3.p: Much suffering again. Preached at Bethel to a still larger Congn. Dr. Humphreys & little David came home with us.

div3.head: 29. Mon
div3.p: Robert & Mary went to Staunton. I took Mrs McFarland to Mr J. Bumgarner's & I went & preached at the funeral of Wm. Beard Jr. of the army & a member of Bethel Ch. He died at the hospital at Orange C.H. He was a good young man.

I had a conversation with Dr. Humphries about his plans for Theda, telling him that it did not suit me to give her a permanent home here. He said he did not expect it-that it was because of Mrs McFarland's great anxiety to have her, that he left her here.

div3.head: Feb. 29th. 1864 continued.
div3.p: I told him that it was from no mercenary motive that I did not keep her but a desire for quiet, & in proof of this I gave him up his Bond for $150. & several years interest.

div3.head: March 1. Tues
div3.p: A cold NE rain all day & it froze on the trees. Working & reading. A little Snow.

div3.head: 2. Wed
div3.p: Reading & Studying.

div3.head: 3. Thurs
div3.p: Studying. Mr M. Pilson came here today and brought seven sheep, a present from a few of my people. Mr Pilson gave one, Adam Hawpe one, Mr Trice & Wm Smith united in buying one for me from Mr Pilson for $75. Carlisle Gilkeson (who originated the scheme) one, John McClure one, Mrs Margt. M. Tate one & Mr Cochran one, worth as estimated $475. A few days ago Francis M. Gilkeson gave Mrs McFarland one & John Shields gave Mary Lewis one. Thanks be to God for such friends.

div3.head: 4. Fri
div3.p: Studying. Visited Saml. Hays. John at home.

div3.head: 5. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Have a distressing cough.

div3.head: 6. Sab
div3.p: Reading. Robert went to Staunton. Our Son Francis came home this morning. I have not seen him for a year & a half & he has been nearly 3 months in a Yankee prison.

div3.head: 7. Mon
div3.p: Reading. After dinner a pain suddenly struck me in the Back which has disabled me for almost everything.

div3.head: 8. Tues
div3.p: Reading. After dinner a pain suddenly struck me in the Back which has disabled me for almost everything.

div3.head: 9. Wed
div3.p: Reading. Back very painful.

div3.head: 10. Thurs
div3.p: Rained all day. Back better. Studying.

div3.head: 11. Fri
div3.p: Rain. In the afternoon fair. Back improved. Robert left us for the Army. Francis took him to Staunton.

div3.head: 12. Sat
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: March 13. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel with a good degree of liberty. Solemn attention. My son Francis there.

div3.head: 14. Mon
div3.p: Not well. Reading. Recd. some Minutes of Synod & the Manuscript & the Bill for Printing Binding &c. $275.00 & for Postage on Minutes $8.00 Drew a Check for $283.00 to Rev. Dr. Wm. Brown.

div3.head: 15. Tues
div3.p: Went to Staunton. Gave my Check to E.M. Taylor, Esqr. for $700. to be invested in 4 pr. Ct. Bonds for the Payment of my own & Mary's taxes. Dined at Col. Baldwin's. Suffered with cold.

div3.head: 16. Wed
div3.p: Very cold. Had to stay at home. Reading.

div3.head: 17. Thurs
div3.p: Studying. Mary & Lizzie Wilson went to see Mrs Dorsey. Mrs McPheeters Jerusha & Robert & Susan Wright here.

div3.head: 18. Fri
div3.p: Studying. Wind high. Plowing for Oats, SE field.

div3.head: 19. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Mary returned. Mrs Dorsey better.

div3.head: 20. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good & serious Congn.

div3.head: 21. Mon
div3.p: Francis left home for Richmond. Reading. Began to record the Minutes of Synod of 1863.

div3.head: 22. Tues
div3.p: Cold. About 10 a.m. began to Snow furiously with a strong NE wind. About dark it abated. Recording Minutes. Lizzie & Mary Pilson here.

div3.head: 23. Wed
div3.p: Snow about 8 inches where not drifted. Reading & clearing away snow blown into the houses.

div3.head: 24. Thurs
div3.p: Not very well. Reading & writing a little.

div3.head: 25. Fri
div3.p: It began to snow early & with little intermissions continued all day. I was studying.

div3.head: 26. Sat
div3.p: About 5 inches of wet Snow. Studying.

div3.head: 27. Sab
div3.p: Preached to a moderate Congn. Roads bad.
Enclosed a $10. note from Mrs R.M. Van Lear to Dr. Wm Brown for Papers to be sent to Soldiers.

div3.head: March 28. 1864. Mon
div3.p: Went to Greenville on business. Dined at A.W. McClure's-called at Mr Britton's & Mr Brawford's. Settled with Mr Burch & paid my Bill & Mary's in full =54 dolls 50 Cts.

div3.head: 29. Tues
div3.p: Reading. Wrote to Francis. Very Stormy-several inches of snow; then a very heavy rain, then more Snow.

div3.head: 30. Wed
div3.p: Gloomy. Snow still lying. Reading.

div3.head: 31. Thurs
div3.p: Very dull. Reading.

div3.head: April 1. Fri
div3.p: Snow, Rain, Snow. Reading & working.

div3.head: 2. Sat
div3.p: Snowed in the night 6 inches. Cloudy. Studying.

div3.head: 3. Sab
div3.p: Prepn. Sab Preached at Bethel to a small Congn. Roads bad. Last week our church was robbed of a large portion of Carpet, the hangings behind the Pulpit, the two Pulpit hymn-books, &c, the Porcelain Pitcher & two tumblers off the pulpit.

div3.head: 4. Mon
div3.p: It began to snow about 7 a.m. & continued till noon & a little more in the afternoon. Recording minutes.

div3.head: 5. Tues
div3.p: Snowed much in the night & today till noon-is about 9 inches deep. Recording Minutes.

div3.head: 6. Wed
div3.p: Reading. Letter from James.

div3.head: 7. Thurs
div3.p: Pleasant. Sent a keg of eatables to James. Studying.

div3.head: 8. Fri
div3.p: This the day appointed by Congress & Pres. Davis for Fasting humiliation & Prayer. Had a very large & solemn Congn. at Bethel. Mrs McF. staid at Mr Bumgarner's.

div3.head: 9. Sat
div3.p: An uncommonly heavy rain all day. I went to Bethel, it being the day preceding our Communion. Only 7 hearers. Rev. Wm. Pinkerton with me. Dined at Mr Bumgarner's Mrs McF. remained & Mr Pinkerton. I came home.

div3.head: 10. Sab
div3.p: Morning pleasant-rain in the afternoon. Went to Bethel-good Congn. Mr Pinkerton preached a good SerMon

div3.head: April 10. Sab continued.
div3.p: Had a pleasant Communion but alas no additions.

div3.head: Apl. 11. Mon
div3.p: Reading & writing. Mary went to Mr Pilsons.

div3.head: 12. Tues
div3.p: Recording Minutes. Letter from James.

div3.head: 13. Wed
div3.p: Reading and Studying.

div3.head: 14. Thurs
div3.p: Set out to visit the sick-Called at Mr Cochran's. Dined at Mr Tates. Spent some time at Mrs Pattersons-she is suffering much with Neuralgia in her face. Visited Mrs Doxey at her Father's she is better-spent the night at Mr Gilkeson's-an uncomfortable night.

div3.head: 15. Fri
div3.p: Visited Mr McClung & Alexr Brownlee. Came home-weary.

div3.head: 16. Sat
div3.p: Very unwell, have caught cold-can hardly read.

div3.head: 17. Sab
div3.p: A little better. Preached at Bethel. Collection made last Sab for religious reading for Soldiers was $

div3.head: 18. Mon
div3.p: My cold very oppressive. Writing a little.

div3.head: 19. Tues
div3.p: Better. Preparing for Presbytery.

div3.head: 20. Wed
div3.p: Too unwell to set out for Presbytery. A letter from Robert.

div3.head: 21. Thurs
div3.p: Set off for Lexington-dined at Mr Turk's in Newport. Reached L. at dusk. Roads very bad.

div3.head: 22. Fri
div3.p: attending Pby. Dined at Col. Prestons-tea Dr. White's.

div3.head: 23. Sat
div3.p: attending Pby. Dined at Col. Reids, tea at Mr Ruffner's.

div3.head: 24. Sab
div3.p: Mr Bowman preached. Saml. Brown & I conducted the Communion Service. At night a tremendous rain.

div3.head: 25. Mon
div3.p: Visited the Grave of my lamented friend Genl. T.J. Jackson. Called on Dr. White. Took Rev. H. Brown in my Buggy to Mr Morrison's. Alas, how my friend Morrison has failed in both body & mind. Had a bad night with Asthma-had to sit up much of the night.

div3.head: April 26th 1864. Tues
div3.p: Came home. Dined at Mr Sproul's-Called on Mrs Brown & Mrs Dr R. McChesney & Mr Wm. Beard. Much fatigued.

div3.head: 27th Wed
div3.p: Wrote to Dr. Wm. Brown. So prostrated, I can only read & sleep.

div3.head: 28. Thurs
div3.p: Feel much as yesterday. Wrote to James.

div3.head: 29. Fri
div3.p: Still feeble & languid. Finished sowing Oats, 16 Bs.

div3.head: 30. Sat
div3.p: Very feeble. Trying to study. Wm. Swink here.

div3.head: MAY 1. Sab
div3.p: Day pleasant. Preached at Bethel & felt but little exhaustion-this very remarkable. Thank God.

div3.head: 2. Mon
div3.p: Reading. Wrote to Dr. White. A letter from James.

div3.head: 3. Tues
div3.p: Cold. The mountains both E. & W. covered with Snow. Preached at the funeral of a Son of Reuben Lambert aged 10 yrs.

div3.head: 4. Wed
div3.p: A letter Robert-says we have 80 miles of Entrenchment from the Blue Ridge to 20 miles below Fredericksburg. Mary went to Mr Wallace's.

div3.head: 5. Thurs
div3.p: Working & studying.

div3.head: 6. Fri
div3.p: Took Mrs McF. to Mr Lightner's-got the Spring of my Buggy mended. Planting Corn in the NW field.

div3.head: 7. Sat
div3.p: Finished planting the NW field. Plowing for Sorgum. It is rumored that a great battle has been fought in N. Va & heavy loss on both sides-John Hays came home wounded.

div3.head: 8. Sab
div3.p: Feeble. Preached at Bethel.

div3.head: 9. Mon
div3.p: No definite news from the army. Went to see old Mrs Engleman & then to George Rosen's.

div3.head: 10. Tues
div3.p: Still feeble but better. Planted Sorgum below the barn. Sheared the Sheep had 2 lbs. washed wool.

div3.head: 11. Wed
div3.p: Preached at Jas. Wilson at the Funl. of his child E. 1 year. Lieut. Col. Clarence Derrick spent the night with us. Wind NE.

div3.head: May 12. Thurs
div3.p: Rained heavily this morning. Col. Derrick is a pleasant Gentleman-Commands a Battallion of about 650 men-about 550 with him at Staunton. Dr. Humphries here all day. Rain.

div3.head: 13. Fri
div3.p: Preached at the Funl. of Cicero Bare who died of a wound Recd. on the 6th inst. in Lee's army-died at Gordonsville. Rain.

div3.head: 14. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Excellent Showers.

div3.head: 15. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a thin Congn. The reports continue to arrive of a terrible Battle on Thursday-it is said that the 5th Regt. Va. Infantry went in with 400 men & came out with only 150, & that the 52 also suffered severely. Oh, my Sons, my Sons! But the Lord Reigns.

div3.head: 16. Mon
div3.p: We learn through a letter from John Wright that our Son James, if alive is a prisoner, Alas. The enemy took a fortification in which he was.

div3.head: 17. Tues
div3.p: A great rain. A letter from James written in the trenches on the 9th-Shews an excellent Spirit. Reading. No Papers from Richmond for a week.

div3.head: 18. Wed
div3.p: Went to Staunton-met Dr. Reid of Richmond & his son. Traded a Bl. of Flour for 3 Bunches of cotton-Nos. 10, 10, 12. Also another Bl. for 15 yds of Cotton & 20 yds of Osnaburgs, For 1 lb. Coperas $5. new issue paid! Came home through a Very heavy rain.

div3.head: 19. Thurs
div3.p: Much fatigued. Visited Reuben Lambert's children-4 ill with Diptheria-Wm very ill. Col. Derrick came here at dark & staid about 2 hours. In the late fight near New Market, out of 5 companies of his Battallion in from 5 to 10 minutes he lost 2 killed & 59 wounded. The loss heavy, but our victory complete.

div3.head: May 20. 1864.
div3.p: Called at S. Hays' & spent the night at Ballard Smith's.

div3.head: 21. Sat
div3.p: Preached at Mount Carmel. Staid at Rev Mr Pinkerton's-at dinner of morsel of food seemed to stick for a moment in the passage to my stomach, which was followed by very serious consequences. It left a sense of soreness & extended to my lungs. I rested badly.

div3.head: 22. Sab
div3.p: Felt badly, but preached-ate dinner at Mr Pinkertons & spent the night at James Smiths.

div3.head: 23. Mon
div3.p: Had a bad night-rose early & set off for home before breakfast. Called to consult Dr. churchman-had a painful ride home. Took an emetic which did not operate well & some cathartic pills-used mustard poltices freely.

div3.head: 24. Tues
div3.p: Another night of suffering. Day similar.

div3.head: 25. Wed
div3.p: A bad night. Dr Tate came to see me.

div3.head: 26. Thurs
div3.p: A little better night-pain not so accute. Dr. Humphreys came to see me.

div3.head: 27. Fri
div3.p: Rested badly. Dr. Tate came again-he & Dr. H. consulted. Perhaps a little better.

div3.head: 28. Sat
div3.p: Somewhat better, but still suffering.

div3.head: 29. Sab
div3.p: After sleeping, I awake exceedingly oppressed but I am a little better. Dr Tate here. No labor for Christ.

div3.head: 30. Mon
div3.p: Rested better. More comfortable in the morning, less so in the afternoon. Mr A.F. Humphreys here-gave me 2 1/2 Bs. of Corn worth at present prices $45 or 50. Mr R.T. Wallace also here.

div3.head: May 31. Tues
div3.p: Rested tolerably-am a little better. Mrs Gilkeson & Mrs Plunket here.

div3.head: June 1. Wed
div3.p: A little Better. Mr Pilson here. Mary & the children went to Staunton.

div3.head: 2. Thurs
div3.p: Better. Thank God, a letter from James, dated Fortress Monroe, May 15. He is in good spirits & well treated-destination-Fort Delaware. Dressed & up.

div3.head: 3. Fri
div3.p: Improving. Rose near 1 p.m. & up till after 6. Mr Faber called to see me.

div3.head: 4. Sat
div3.p: Not so well-rose ate 10 a.m. Up till 2 p.m.

Sad tidings. One report is that Robert was killed on Monday last. A Telegram from Francis dated the 2d inst. says "Robert in hands of Enemy-Reported seriously wounded." The Lord reigns & he will do what is best for him that Christ bought with his blood, I submit. A Telegram from Francis dated today, says-Robt. was shot through the heart; never spoke. Alas, alas!
Sent Frank to Staunton for Mr Stuart-he declined to come fearing a Cavalry raid on the town. A great battle on Friday near Richmond reported we successful.

div3.head: 5. Sab
div3.p: Did not rest well-in bed all day.

div3.head: 6. Mon
div3.p: As yesterday-but dressed & out of bed for a few hours. The Yankees are in Staunton. Our troops fought them yesterday but fell back to Waynesboro. Gen Hunter with 8 to 10,000 troops in Staunton.
We are told that Mr Cattell heard a telegram read that Robt . was not hurt-O that it may be so.

div3.head: 7. Tues
div3.p: Exceedingly prostrated last night-better today. Yesterday Dr. Humphreys took two of my horses away for safety.

div3.head: June 8. 1864. Wed
div3.p: This a day of great excitement but thanks to God, though quite unwell, I am pretty calm. There have been in all eleven Yankees here (Averills men). They crossed at pondgap-took my horse Squire 14 yrs old a saddle & bridle & a few bushels of Oats-the offered no violence & did not search the house. We gave most of them some breakfast. A Jos. Little, said to be a chaplain who once taught music here, I understand charged them not to disturb us.

div3.head: 9. Thurs
div3.p: More feeble. Sad accounts of my neighbours losses, especially in horses.

div3.head: 10. Fri
div3.p: A little better. About 9 a.m. we heard sharp musketry firing form Arbor Hill up the turnpike for an hour. It is said 3 yankees were buried. It was Col. McCauslan's men skirmishing & falling back. It is said Staunton was evacuated this morning. They went up both roads.

div3.head: 11. Sat
div3.p: Slowly improving. Mr Henderson came to see me.

div3.head: 12. Sab
div3.p: No Congn. at Bethel I suppose-few have horses to go-I have not & could not preach if there. Alas! for the change.

div3.head: 13. Mon
div3.p: Genl. Breckenridge with 10,000 men passed up on yesterday-but I cannot learn by what route.

div3.head: 14. Tues
div3.p: Dr. Humphreys came & brought my two horses-thanks be to God. No yankees this side of Lexington.

div3.head: 15. Wed
div3.p: McPheeter's Lou came from Lexinton. The yankees did much damage there, but have gone on-our troops pursuing.

div3.head: 16. Thurs
div3.p: More feeble. Cannon heard by some yesterday & today-thought to be in the direction of Lynchburg. Rode out for an hour-the first since May 23d.

div3.head: 17. Fri
div3.p: Rode to Mr Gilkeson's. Frank Gilkeson says he saw a member of Roberts company who said R. was wounded but not badly. O, to be relieved from suspense.

div3.head: June 18. Sat
div3.p: More unwell-Very feeble, could not ride out-not so well as a week ago.

div3.head: 19. Sab
div3.p: No better. After much hesitation, I went to Bethel-was too weak to preach-the elders held a prayer meeting, & I made an addres-dined at Mr Bumgarner's-came home fatigued.

div3.head: 20. Mon
div3.p: A little better. Reading.

div3.head: 21. Tues
div3.p: False rumor of Yankees in Middlebrook.

div3.head: 22. Wed
div3.p: Somewhat Stronger. Working & reading.

div3.head: 23. Thurs
div3.p: A letter from Dr. Saml. B. Morrison of June 6th informing me that on that morning he had found the body of my Dear Son Robert, covered with earth, he supposes where he fell, & had it reburied & the grave markd. A letter from Capt Humphreys, describing the circumstances in which he fell; also letters of sympathy from Mrs E.H. Brown & Dr. B.M. Smith. We have been held long in suspense, now the sad reality is known. Glory to God, we have satisfactory evidences of his Piety.

div3.head: 24. Fri
div3.p: Better. Studying.

div3.head: 25. Sat
div3.p: Stronger. Studying. Extremely warm.

div3.head: 26. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a very small Congn. The Army from Lynchburg is passing down both roads.

div3.head: 27. Mon
div3.p: I rode to Mint Spring-Genl. Earlys Corpse passed down-say 15,000 with 72 pieces of Artillery. Genl. Breckenridge on the other road with say 12,000. Col. Derrick came to see us, but returned to camp.

div3.head: 28. Tues
div3.p: Col. Derrick came & brought all his extra baggage. Began to mow, in front meadow.

div3.head: 29. Wed
div3.p: Not so well. Reading & working.

div3.head: June 30. 1864.
div3.p: Not well-rode to Mr Hendersons.

div3.head: July 1. Fri
div3.p: Still unwell. Wrote to Dr. Brown.

div3.head: 2. Sat
div3.p: better. Studying.

div3.head: 3. Sab
div3.p: Unwell-preached at Bethel-good Congn.

div3.head: 4. Mon
div3.p: Better. Working & reading. Cutting Wheat.

div3.head: 5. Tues
div3.p: Harvesting wheat. Heard Rev. Mr Preston preach a good funeral Sermon at Mr Speck's-funl. of his son.

div3.head: 6. Wed
div3.p: Mowing. Reading.

div3.head: 7. Thurs
div3.p: Studying a little.

div3.head: 8. Thurs Fri
div3.p: Visited S. Hays & wife, who are unwell. Studying.

div3.head: 9. Sat
div3.p: Studying. My strength increased.

div3.head: 10. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel-good Congn. A Shower.

div3.head: 11. Mon
div3.p: Reading. Letters from Francis & Roxa. Harvesting.

div3.head: 12. Tues
div3.p: Cutting Wheat. Reading.

div3.head: 13. Wed
div3.p: Do. Reading & writing minutes.

div3.head: 14. Thurs
div3.p: Had Cholera Morbus last night-it ceased by noon. I rose at 2 p.m. but could not sit up-very weak-went to bed about 5. Finished cutting wheat.

div3.head: 15. Fri
div3.p: Hauling in Wheat. Letters from Francis Mrs E. Brown & Wm. L. Bent. I am a little stronger.

div3.head: 16. Sat
div3.p: Hauling in wheat. Mr Henderson came after breakfast with his Mower & cut grass in the front meadow till night, for which I paid him $30. in the new Issue. Wrote to Dr. M.D. Hoge & Rev. F.H. Bowman.

div3.head: 17. Sab
div3.p: Rev. T.L. Preston preached at Bethel an invitation a Funeral Sermon, in consequence of the death of my beloved son Robert. The Congn. was very large. Dr. Humphreys & his children came home with us.

div3.head: 18. Mon
div3.p: Attacked with Dyssentery-much pained. Could not preach at the Funl. of Mr Saml. Hays, Elder.

div3.head: 19. Tues
div3.p: Rested pretty well-Still symptoms not much better-in bed all day-sent for to preach at the Funl . of Archd . S. Sprouls oldest son, Jam. Eliza McPheeters died today, aged 50. A drizzle of rain.

div3.head: 20. Wed
div3.p: Symptoms a little better-sent for Dr. Tate, he came. In bed all day. A little shower, Geo. Rosen called.

div3.head: 21. Thurs
div3.p: Health about as yesterday. Cocking hay. In bed all day. Took more Ipicac & salts.

div3.head: 22. Fri
div3.p: The State of my bowls seems much better. I dressed about 2 p.m. could sit up but little & in one hour had to return to bed. Hauling in hay.

div3.head: 23. Sat
div3.p: Still better, but in bed all day. Dr. Tate here.

div3.head: 24. Sab
div3.p: Better, but very weak-dressed about noon & out of bed 3 hours. Prayer meeting at Bethel.

div3.head: 25. Mon
div3.p: Better. Rose at noon & remained up till night. There was a pleasant rain before day this morning.

div3.head: 26. Tues
div3.p: Rose at 9 a.m. up all day. Miss Mary Pringle & Lizzie Wilson here. I dined with the family.

div3.head: 27. Wed
div3.p: Up all day. A letter from John Gilkeson written June 7th says James was well. I wrote to James.

div3.head: 28. Thurs
div3.p: Working. Wrote to Genl. R. Patterson.

div3.head: 29. Fri
div3.p: A letter from James dated June 7th. A glorious revival in Fort Delaware-Glory to God. Cutting Oats. Mary & Frank went to Staunton. Studying.

div3.head: 30. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Got in the Oats. John Hays here.

div3.head: 31. Sab
div3.p: Very feeble-Preached at Bethel-was exceeding exhausted-came home & went to bed.

div3.head: Aug. 1. Mon
div3.p: Better. Wrote to Francis & to Rev. Dr. Wm. S. White.

div3.head: August 2, 1864. Tues
div3.p: Heat oppressive. Wrote to Rev. Dr. Dabney & Brig. Gen Lilley who is severely wounded & in Winchester. A very pleasant shower this afternoon.

div3.head: 3. Wed
div3.p: Preached a Funl . Serm. on the death of Saml. Hays at his late residence.

div3.head: 4. Thurs
div3.p: I am stronger. Hauling in hay.

div3.head: 5. Fri
div3.p: Went to Bethel. Rev. F.H. Bowman preached a good sermon & came home with us.

div3.head: 6. Sat
div3.p: Recd. three females on Examn. Mr. Bowman again preached a good serm. to a good Congn. A Shower.

div3.head: 7. Sab
div3.p: Mr Bowman preached, all his services were very acceptable. Lord's Supper administered, a pleasant season. A Child of Mr Brawford's buried. I made a brief address. My health & strength improved.

div3.head: 8. Mon
div3.p: More feeble. Finished hauling in hay-last of harvest.

div3.head: 9. Tues
div3.p: Working & reading.

div3.head: 10. Wed
div3.p: Visited at Mr Sproul's-much sickness there. A very fine Shower-came home.

div3.head: 11. Thurs
div3.p: Got all the tires of my buggy cut at Lightner's. Called at James Hays' came home-a pleasant little shower.

div3.head: 12. Fri
div3.p: Asmatical-much indisposed.

div3.head: 13. Sat
div3.p: At home. Studying & reading.

div3.head: 14. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel. A good Shower.

div3.head: 15. Mon
div3.p: Preached at the funeral of Wm. S. Sproul, aged 36. A good Shower. Came home fatigued.

div3.head: 16. Tues
div3.p: Visited the Brawford family. A shower.

div3.head: 17. Wed
div3.p: Quite unwell-Feverish.

div3.head: 18. Thurs
div3.p: A feverish night-in bed till 10 a.m. Better. The best rain for three months.

div3.head: Aug. 19th Fri
div3.p: Rained & Drizzled all day. I could not set out for Augusta Ch. not well.

div3.head: 20. Sat
div3.p: Left home at 7 a.m. & reached Augusta Ch. just in time to preach. Mrs McF. & I staid at Mr Bowman's.

div3.head: 21. Sab
div3.p: Had Asthma. Preached to a good Congn.

div3.head: 22. Mon
div3.p: Came to Staunton. Mrs Turk very ill. Met Rev. Drs. Reid & Stiles-pleasant Br. came home. Fatigued.

div3.head: 23. Tues
div3.p: Preached at the Funl . of D.C. Gilkeson. He is a great public loss, aged 49 in Oct. next. Dined at Mrs Patterson's & came home-much fatigued.

div3.head: 24. Wed
div3.p: Rose at noon-Rev. J.S. Blain here.

div3.head: 25. Thurs
div3.p: Had a bad night-lay on the couch. Very weak. Rev. Wm. E. Baker & family here. A Shower.

div3.head: 26. Fri
div3.p: Still feeble, but a little better.

div3.head: 27. Sat
div3.p: Reading & Studying. I am still better.

div3.head: 28. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel-much fatigued.

div3.head: 29. Mon
div3.p: A restless night. In bed till noon.

div3.head: 30. Tues
div3.p: Still unwell-rose at 10 a.m.

div3.head: 31. Wed
div3.p: Asthma a little better. Preached at A. Gardner's a Funl. discourse on the death of their Son Wm. who was killed in Battle in May last.

div3.head: September 1. Thurs
div3.p: Reading.

div3.head: 2. Fri
div3.p: Asthma-rose at 10 a.m. Studying a little.

div3.head: 3. Sat
div3.p: Asthma still-finished hauling manure on the hill field. N. Burwell here all night.

div3.head: 4. Sab
div3.p: Better-weak. Preached at Bethel. Some liberty.

div3.head: 5. Mon
div3.p: Asthma-rose at 11 a.m. Went to Rev. Mr Crawford, near death, I suppose. He is in a happy frame of mind. Heavy rain in the night & toward morning.

div3.head: Septr. 6. Tues
div3.p: Asthma still. Rained moderately all day. Unwell-reading a little.

div3.head: 7. Wed
div3.p: Asthma, but better. Reading &c.

div3.head: 8. Thurs
div3.p: I was so unwell & the day so wet I could not go to Presbytery.

div3.head: 9. Fri
div3.p: Mrs Mc Farland & I went to Mt. Carmel to Pby. Spent the night at Mr Donnells.

div3.head: 10. Sat
div3.p: Attended Pby . I returned to Mr Donnell's, and Mrs Mc Farland went to James McClure's.

div3.head: 11. Sab
div3.p: Spent a feverish night-very unwell all day. Spent a bad night at Ballard Smith's. I think it is inflamation of the Diaphragm that gives me so much pain. Applied Mustard poultices.

div3.head: 12. Mon
div3.p: Dined at Wm. F. Smith's-Home.

div3.head: 13. Tues
div3.p: Still suffering. Rose about noon. Rev. Mr Stuart & wife & daughter dined here.

div3.head: 14. Wed
div3.p: Had a bad night but am a little better. Did not rise till near 3 p.m.

div3.head: 15. Thurs
div3.p: Very unwell this morning-sent for Dr. Tate-he came-better in the evening-in bed all day. Had Col. Derricks horse shod all round.

div3.head: 16. Fri
div3.p: Had one of the most distressing nights of my life from Asthma, today better-in bed all day.

div3.head: 17. Sat
div3.p: Better. Rose at 8 a.m. Studying a little.

div3.head: 18. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel in great weakness.

div3.head: 19. Mon
div3.p: Reading & working. I am better. Recd. a most affectionate letter from Genl. Patterson.
Reading & working-pretty well.

div3.head: 21. Wed
div3.p: Reading & working. A fine rain at night.

div3.head: Sept. 22, 1864. Thurs
div3.p: It rained all last night. Reading &c.

div3.head: 23. Fri
div3.p: Reading & studying a little. Col Derrick's Servant came here with the sad inteligence that he and nearly all his Battallion & Brigade were taken prisoners on Monday last near Winchester.

div3.head: 24. Sat
div3.p: Studying-dull. A Shower.

div3.head: 25. Sab
div3.p: News came that the enemy were near Staunton. Went to Bethel-no Congn. returned.

div3.head: 26. Mon
div3.p: Spent much time hiding property. Sent my horses to A.F. Humphreys'. Rumors of a large Cavalry force of the enemy in Staunton. May the Lord protect us.

div3.head: 27. Tues
div3.p: The Enemy still in Staunton. Pickets out.

div3.head: 28. Wed
div3.p: We hear that the enemy have left Staunton.

div3.head: 29. Thurs
div3.p: The enemy's cavalry came back through Staunton, & took the road to Spring Hill-were routed.

div3.head: 30. Fri
div3.p: Had my horses brought home.

div3.head: October 1. Sat
div3.p: A good Rain. Studying.

div3.head: 2. Sab
div3.p: Clear. Preached at Bethel to 30 or 40 hearers.

div3.head: 3. Mon
div3.p: Much rain. Visited Lizzie Wilson-has fever. Dr. Humphreys spent the night with us.

div3.head: 4. Tues
div3.p: Reading &c. Dr. H. went to visit the Army.

div3.head: 5. Wed
div3.p: Went to Greenville. Dined at Mr Newtons & Called to see Mrs Mollie Bumgarner. Dr. H. here.

div3.head: 6. Thurs
div3.p: Attending to various things. Mr Larew here.

div3.head: 7. Fri
div3.p: Reading. Finished plowing for wheat.

div3.head: 8. Sat
div3.p: Studying & working. Very cool.

div3.head: 9. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel-frost in some places. The day quite cold.

div3.head: Octr. 10th 1864. Mon
div3.p: Had an uncomfortable night. Rose at 9 a.m. Reading & preparing for Synod.

div3.head: 11. Tues
div3.p: at 7.15' a.m. Left home-dimed at Jas. Gilkeson's in Brownsburg-reached Col. Reid's at Sunset.

div3.head: 12. Wed
div3.p: Rev. A. Hart opened Synod-no business done.

div3.head: 13. Thurs
div3.p: A scene of great Interest in receiving our New-School Brethren-an excellent spirit prevailed. Dined at Rev. John Miller's.

div3.head: 14. Fri 15. Sat
div3.p: attending Synod, but the eruption distressing.

div3.head: 16. Sab
div3.p: Dr. Reid preached-I introduced the Communion & Mr Price & Dr. Brown assisted.

div3.head: 17. Mon
div3.p: Synod adjourned at 2 p.m. I came to Mr Patton's.

div3.head: 18. Tues
div3.p: Called to see James Smith just returned from Fort Delaware. Came home. Eruption harrassing.

div3.head: 19. Wed
div3.p: Reading & preparing to go to the Springs.

div3.head: 20. Thurs
div3.p: Took Zeke to bring back my horse & rode to Crawford's Springs, but could not be accommodated at Brinkley's, & was invited to stay at David Kunkle's, which I did, & was treated with great kindness. They sent for the water but it had neither taste nor smell of sulphur but twice. I therefore think it has done me less good than usual. Suffered much.
Preached on the Sab at the School-house, for the Methodist minister, Mr Rippetoe. Friday came home. Mr Kunkle, in addition to all kindness, presented we $25.

div3.head: 29. Sat
div3.p: Eruption still troublesome. Studying a little.

div3.head: 30. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel. Eruption better.

div3.head: 31. Mon
div3.p: Reading & variously employed. Legs better.

div3.head: November 1. Tues
div3.p: Mrs Mc Farland & I visited Maj. Newton, whose leg was amputated, & Dr. Tate, who was sick.

div3.head: Nov. 2d 1864. Wed
div3.p: Snow & then rain. Reading. I wrote to James. Eruption much better.

div3.head: 3. Thurs
div3.p: Feel very dull. Studying. A drizzling rain.

div3.head: 4. Fri
div3.p: Studying-Reading & writing. High wind.

div3.head: 5. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Dr. Tate here.

div3.head: 6. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel. Prepn. Sab Solemn attention.

div3.head: 7. Mon
div3.p: Reading. Dr. Humphreys came to see Mary Lou.

div3.head: 8. Tues
div3.p: Visited Col. Wilson & Lizzie: both a little better.

div3.head: 9. Wed
div3.p: Reuben Lambert putting props against my house.

div3.head: 10. Thurs
div3.p: Mending my Buggy & Studying.

div3.head: 11. Fri
div3.p: Preached at Bethel. N. Bent came & his woman Hannah who is to stay with us.

div3.head: 12. Sat
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good Congn. Mr. John Hamilton came home with us & I paid a Note for $70 which his son Lieut. John E. Hamilton held on my Son R.P. McFarland for a silver Lever Watch bought of him.

div3.head: 13. Sab
div3.p: Rev. S.D. Stuart preached a good SerMon I performed all the Communion Service. Two very interesting additions-Archd. Sproul & Lettitia M. Tate. A pleasant Comn. Very cold. Mr Stuart & wife spent the night with us.

div3.head: 14. Mon
div3.p: Recd. of the public Salt 100 lbs. at 30 cents.

div3.head: 15. Tues
div3.p: Day of special prayer appointed by Pres. Davis. a good Congn. I trust the Lord will ansr. in mercy.

div3.head: 16. Thurs
div3.p: Preached at the Funl . of Col. Wm Wilson, aged 71 1/2 yrs. a good citizen & a kind neighbor.

div3.head: 17. Fri
div3.p: Mary Lewis & I went to Staunton on business. Dined at Arnold's-came home in a heavy rain.

div3.head: Nov. 19, 1864. Sat
div3.p: Studying a little. N. Bent came.

div3.head: 20. Sab
div3.p: Went to Bethel-only 14 hearers. Two Elders prayed & I lectured extempore on Psm. 63. Rain-unpleasant.

div3.head: 21. Mon
div3.p: Rained all day. Reading & writing.

div3.head: 22. Tues
div3.p: One inch of snow last night. Working & writing. Cold.

div3.head: 23. Wed
div3.p: Finished preparing the Minutes of Synod for the press.

div3.head: 24. Thurs
div3.p: Reading & writing.

div3.head: 25. Fri
div3.p: Reading, writing & working.

div3.head: 26. Sat
div3.p: Working & studying.

div3.head: 27. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a moderate Congn.

div3.head: 28. Mon
div3.p: Sent N. Bent to Staunton on his way to Farmville. I was repairing the wheelbarrow.
I sent the Minutes of Synod for the press by N. Bent.

div3.head: 29. Tues
div3.p: Working. Lieut Frank Wood & Dr. Crawford here.

div3.head: 30. Wed
div3.p: Visited Maj. Newton, Alexr Brownlee, Jas. McClung, Mrs Gilkeson. Spent the night at R.T. Wallace's.

div3.head: Dec. 1. Thurs
div3.p: Visited John McClure's & John McClure Jr. (Wounded) Mrs Patterson, Margt. M. Tate's & James Bumgarners & came home.

div3.head: 2. Fri
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 3. Sat
div3.p: Studying, but am very dull.

div3.head: 4. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel on the Sanctification of the Sabbath by Order of Synod. Took a Collection for Dom. Missns.

div3.head: 5. Mon
div3.p: Reading. Wrote to James.

div3.head: 6. Tues
div3.p: Visited at J. Bumgarner's, J. Larew's & Hays'

div3.head: 7. Wed
div3.p: At home-very dull. Corn all husked & in the barn.

div3.head: 8. Thurs
div3.p: Reading. Cold. Zeke helping Plunkit to butcher.

div3.head: 9. Fri
div3.p: Very cold. At 4 p.m. began to snow. 4 inches fell.

div3.head: 10. Sat
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 11. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel, the day cold-few hearers.

div3.head: Dec. 12. Mon
div3.p: Reading. Day Very cold.

div3.head: 13. Tues
div3.p: At home-reading.

div3.head: 14. Wed
div3.p: Day mild. Called at Mr Gardner's, the Post Office & at Wilson's. A letter from Francis.

div3.head: 15. Thurs
div3.p: Not well. Killed 4 hogs = Wt. 716 lbs.

div3.head: 16. Fri
div3.p: Reading.

div3.head: 17. Sat
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 18. Sab
div3.p: Began to rain in the night & rain or drizzle all day-damp & chilly-did not go to Bethel.

div3.head: 19. Mon
div3.p: Reading. Day mild.

div3.head: 20. Tues
div3.p: Working. Mr Rhodes took away the tithe of my hay = two waggon loads.
Capt. Roberts came this evening & bought Julia of Mary Lewis for $4,000.

div3.head: 21. Wed
div3.p: This morning, when I was dressing, Mrs McFarland & Mary Lou rushed into my room & Julia following them in an insane rage with an axe. I seized the poker & ran out & Rhoda & Liz were holding Julia & trying to get the axe from her which she was holding up over her head & trying to get at us. Rhoda cried to me to get out of the way, which I did & locked the door believing I could not contend with her & the axe. They got the axe from her & took her to the kitchen. I sent for Mr Mc Pheeters & he & Capt. Roberts came & tied her & I sent her in the Waggon to Staunton and Mr Mc Pheeters had her put in Jail.
This has been a distressing day to us all, but Blessed be God who preserved all our lives. And I feel much indebted to the other servants whose fidelity has been instrumental in saving our lives.

div3.head: Decr. 22. Thurs
div3.p: Intensely cold. Could do nothing.

div3.head: 23. Fri
div3.p: Intensely cold. Find I cannot hire Zeke, James Swink & Mr Towberman both want him.

div3.head: 24. Sat
div3.p: Cold less severe. Frank went to Greenville. I sent Miss Tabby Dotson an order on B. McClung for 70 lbs. of Flour for carding & spinning 3 lbs of Merrino wool. Got shoes for Rhoda & Liz. I rode to Wilson's.

div3.head: 25. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel. Congn. Good for the times.

div3.head: 26. Mon
div3.p: Went to Staunton-roads very bad. Paid taxes, amounting to $412.73. Also Mary's Taxes $181.20.

div3.head: 27. Tues
div3.p: At home. Unwell.

div3.head: 28. Wed
div3.p: Still unwell. Mary went to Staunton. Rain.

div3.head: 29. Thurs
div3.p: Last night at dark began to snow, 5 inches fell. Wrote to Dr. B.B. Donaghe that I would take Jeff. hire to be fixed when we find what labor he can do. Sent Frank to tell Jeff that I had hired him.

div3.head: 30. Fri
div3.p: Studying. Jeff whom I have hired came to see me. Lieut. Peery of the 23 Battalion here.

div3.head: 31. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Snow fell about 4 inches.

div3.head: Jan. 1. Sab
div3.p: The day cold. Preached at Bethel to a small Congn On the Lord's controversy with us as a nation.

Glory be to God that at my advanced age I enjoy so much health. My beloved wife enjoys so much excellent health. Mary Lewis is well & her son Frank. Mary Lou still suffering somewhat from her spinal affliction-uses crutches but is better. My Son Francis is in Richmond Reporting the proceedings of Congress for the Richmond Enquirer &c. Robert I trust is in heaven. James, alas, is a Prisoner in Fort Delaware since May last, but all our information is that he enjoys good health & spirits. Dr Humphreys is well, & his two children are here on a visit, & very well.

div3.head: 2. Mon
div3.p: Day a little milder. Quietly at home all day. Reading.

div3.head: 3. Tues
div3.p: Began to snow about noon. Wm. A. Humphreys came with the sad news that John P. McClure died today.

div3.head: 4. Wed
div3.p: The day so cold I could not go to preach at the Funeral of John P. McClure. Jerusha & Robt. Mc Pheeters here.

div3.head: 5. Thurs
div3.p: At home. Mr Henderson brought his threshing Machine here.

div3.head: 6. Fri
div3.p: Rained moderately all day-thick fog. Feel very dull. Reading.

div3.head: 7. Sat
div3.p: Unwell-rose at 10 a.m. Better. Preparing for the Sabbath.

div3.head: 8. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good Congn although the day was very cold & the roads very bad. This is my birth day-I am 77 years old. Blessed be God that at this advanced age he gives me the powers of body and mind that enables me to preach Christ with, I believe, a good degree of acceptance.

div3.head: Jan. 9. 1865. Mon
div3.p: Went to Mr James Bumgarner's to got a Boy to help to thresh & get wood. Mrs Eleanor Patterson died this evening.

div3.head: 10. Tues
div3.p: It rained so I could not go to preach at the Funl. of Mrs Elinor Patterson-a choice Christian & dear Friend.
Mr Henderson & three hands came & threshed out my wheat. Mr Bumgarner's Frank & Rosen, Joe & Lewis Mater & John Murkley also.

div3.head: 11. Wed
div3.p: Not well. Reading.

div3.head: 12. Thurs
div3.p: Engaged as yesterday.

div3.head: 13. Fri
div3.p: Reading & working. Hauled 7 loads of wood.

div3.head: 14. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Thermometer fell all day. Cold-high wind.

div3.head: 15. Sab
div3.p: Took cold yesterday. In my study, & spent a restless & uncomfortable night & this morning not well enough to leave my bed. All afternoon & alas, disappointed a good Congn

div3.head: 16. Mon
div3.p: I am better today but feeble-able to do but little; a letter from James-thanks be to God, he was well the last of November.

div3.head: 17. Tues
div3.p: I am more unwell-could not read but little.

div3.head: 18. Wed
div3.p: Not so well. Working a little. Another letter from James, is well.

div3.head: 19. Thurs
div3.p: Working-mending the wheat-fan. Cold. I am poorly.

div3.head: 20. Fri
div3.p: Working & reading. I am rather better.

div3.head: 21. Sat
div3.p: Mr Lockridge came with a six mule team & got a load of straw for the Govt. which I promised a Mr Wright letter.
It has rained or hailed & sleeted all day & froze on the trees, that now at 8 p.m. they are crashing. I have seen few such days.
Finished cleaning wheat: had 86 Bs. This with 15 for seed = 101 Bs. Had only six Bs of Oats-had used a little crop 8 or 10 Bs.

div3.head: 22. Sab
div3.p: The day very gloomy-ground covered with ice & the trees loaded. I thought it unsafe to ride, and thought noone would go to Bethel & I did not go. Mr Gilkeson called.

div3.head: Jan. 23. Mon
div3.p: Rained much. Reading. Recd. the first No. of the Daily Sentinel, date Jan. 21st subscribed for six months.

div3.head: 24. Tues
div3.p: Not well-rested badly. Day very cold. Reading.

div3.head: 25. Wed
div3.p: Very Cold. Sallie Gilkeson was here last night.

div3.head: 26. Thurs
div3.p: So cold I can do nothing.

div3.head: 27. Fri
div3.p: Still colder.

div3.head: 28. Sat
div3.p: Cold & still can do nothing.

div3.head: 29. Sab
div3.p: A little moderated. Preached at Bethel to a good Congn for the day.

div3.head: 30. Mon
div3.p: Rested badly, not well today, rose at 9 a.m.

div3.head: 31. Tues
div3.p: I am better Mrs Trevey, Lizzie & Mary Pilson & Miss Steele spent the day here. Mary Lewis took David & Theda to Mr Wallace.

div3.head: February 1. Wed
div3.p: Resting & working. Mary returned.

div3.head: 2. Thurs
div3.p: Cold. Reading. Sent a letter to Francis.

div3.head: 3. Fri
div3.p: A little Snow-started to rain & froze. Reading. Able commissioners have gone to Washington to negotiate about peace. Alas! I have not the slightest hope from the temper of our enemies, that anything will be accomplished. May God bless the effort.

div3.head: 4. Sat
div3.p: I am not well-rested badly. Trying to study.

div3.head: 5. Sab
div3.p: Not well. Mrs McF & I went to Bethel. She had not been there since the Sab before Christmas. Day very cold-a pretty good Congn

div3.head: 6. Mon
div3.p: I am better. Letter from Dr. Wm. Brown.

div3.head: 7. Tues
div3.p: It began to snow about 1 a.m. & continued all day. Working.

div3.head: 8. Wed
div3.p: Very cold. Mr A. Gardner here-I paid him Zeke's hire $300.00 Paid also my Postage account in full for last year.

div3.head: 9. Thurs
div3.p: Reading &c. Day very cold.

div3.head: 10. Fri
div3.p: A little milder. Reading.

div3.head: 11. Sat
div3.p: I am quite unwell today-not able to study.

div3.head: 12. Sab
div3.p: Spent a restless night-did not rise till near 1 p.m. Could not go to Bethel. The Therm. fell regularly till the afternoon.

div3.head: 13. Mon
div3.p: The coldest morning for 9 years -12. The day piercing cold. Rained well.

div3.head: 14. Tues
div3.p: A little moderated. I continue very unwell.

div3.head: Feb. 15, 1865.
div3.p: Spent a bad night. Took physick. Rose in the afternoon.

div3.head: 16. Thurs
div3.p: Still very feeble & unwell. Sent Francis' trunk to Staunton.

div3.head: 17. Fri
div3.p: More unwell-very uneasy. At 10 a.m. began to snow & it continued to fall fast all day.

div3.head: 18. Sat
div3.p: had a bad night & Still very unwell-headache & backache.

div3.head: 19. Sab
div3.p: More unwell. Sent for Dr Tate-he came. Thinks my attack rather of the nature of Bronchitis than Pneumonia. Finished burning my Chest with mustard &c.

div3.head: 20. Mon
div3.p: No better. The cold weather bad for me.

div3.head: 21. Tues
div3.p: My health no better today. In the morning I felt better-worse in the evening. Mr Gilkeson & Pilson & Dr. Tate here-too much company for me.

div3.head: 22. Wed
div3.p: More comfortable in the morning-evening worse.

div3.head: 23. Thurs
div3.p: Spent a wretched night & this one of my very worst days-nervous symptoms predominate.

div3.head: 24. Fri
div3.p: Not so well-sent for Dr Tate-he thinks me better. Mr Gilkeson here Genl. R. Lilley came & spent the night with us. He is a noble young man-eminently pious.

div3.head: 25. Sat
div3.p: More depressed this morning than heretofore. In the course of the day rallied much.

div3.head: 26. Sab
div3.p: Rested better than the previous night. Not so much depressed this morning-better through the day-Glory to God. No preaching at Bethel now for three Sabbaths. Alas!

div3.head: 27. Mon
div3.p: Rather better. Dr. Tate came. Dr Humphreys came & spent the night. I am suffering with nervousness & headache.

div3.head: 28. Tues
div3.p: Spent a very sick & restless night from the use of Ipicac. Lizzie Wilson, Dr Hammond and Mrs Henderson here.

div3.head: March 1, 1865. Wed
div3.p: A very gloomy day. I am much better, rested pretty well last night. Medicine did well.
It is said the Yankees are Coming up the Valley, 8000 men. I trust me & mine to the protection of our God.

div3.head: 2. Thurs
div3.p: Very gloomy & raining & cold. Had to send Frank & Jeff. away with our horses. The enemy said to be in & near Staunton. Family busy arranging. I am some better-appetite good.

div3.head: 3. Fri
div3.p: Still gloomy & raining but indications of clearing. Jeff got home last night. There was skirmishing & fighting with the enemy yesterday at 2 p.m. near the Waynesboro could hear the Cannonading distinctly. I learn the Yankees all left Staunton last night, but have their camp 2 to 3 miles below towards Fisherville. I think I am improving and gaining Strength.

div3.head: 4. Sat
div3.p: Had my clothes on 2 1/2 hours. The first time for 2 weeks. Jeff went to get news-heard the Yankees had defeated Early badly-taken 1500 prisoners & part of his artilery. They are now from Fisherville to Rockfish Gap.

div3.head: 5. Sab
div3.p: Rested pretty well & am better-sat up 2 1/2 hours. Another lonely Sab people scattered with their horses &c. The report is that the enemy have crossed the Blueridge & today sent 1000 to 1200 prisoners down the Valley from Staunton.

div3.head: March 6, 1865. Mon
div3.p: Slept non last night, till after 1 a.m. I am better & stronger today-up around 5 p.m. Dr Tate came to see me. It is reported that Gen. Johnston has defeated Sherman-important for our cause if true. Dr Humphreys Wm Gilkeson & John Withrow dined here on their way in search of Negros & stolen horses, heard that it was not true that Johnston had defeated Sherman.

div3.head: 7. Tues
div3.p: Rested pretty well, am still better. Jeff went for the horses.

div3.head: 8. Wed
div3.p: I am still improving. Last night Frank & Jeff returned with the horses. Rose at 8 1/2 a.m. Ret. at 7 1/2 p.m.

div3.head: 9. Thurs
div3.p: I was so nervous. I rested badly & feel badly today. Rose at 8 1/2 a.m. Up 11 hours.

div3.head: 10. Fri
