div3.p: Rested much better, but feel weak. This the day of the National Fasting, Prayer & Thanksgiving, alas, I am not able to go to Bethel. I have aided in all similar occasions. All the family went but me. May the Lord be with them. I am glad to learn there was a good Congn & 4 prayers.

div3.head: 11. Sat
div3.p: Slept well & feel much better-Blessed be God.
The joyful inteligence has just reached us that James, our son, so long a prisoner, is now in Richmond. Glory to God.

div3.head: 12. Sab
div3.p: Unable to go to Bethel-they held a Prayer meeting. [Reported that the Yankees were defeated on Friday & are now returning but we know not by what route.] Not true.

div3.head: March 12th. Sab continued.
div3.p: This morning, about dark our beloved James reached home to our great joy, and in good health. Glory be to God who has heard and thus graciously answered our prayers.

div3.head: 13. Mon
div3.p: I am much better today than since I was confined. I rose & breakfasted with the family for the first time.

div3.head: 14. Tues
div3.p: I continue to improve. The warm weather favours me.

div3.head: 15. Wed
div3.p: A fine rain. Reading. I am gaining strength.

div3.head: 16. Thurs
div3.p: I spent a most uncomfortable night. Rose at 11 a.m. Am very feeble & unwell an unfortunate backset. Day sultry & showery. I am truly delighted that in my absence my son James askes a blessing at the Table & conducts Family Worship. Glory to God.

div3.head: 17. Fri
div3.p: I have not improved since yesterday, though I rested better last night. Did not rise till 11 a.m.

div3.head: 18. Sat
div3.p: Rested pretty well. Rose at 9 a.m. I am somewhat better.

div3.head: 19. Sab
div3.p: Slept well, but, alas, too feeble & unwell to go to Bethel. all the family went-day fine, & a good Congn

div3.head: 20. Mon
div3.p: I slept pretty well, but am by no means well. Rose at 8 a.m. Taking Mercury & Chalk. James went to Churchville for Jeans.

div3.head: 21. Tues
div3.p: Vernal Equinox. Rained all the afternoon. Took Salts.

div3.head: 22. Wed
div3.p: More unwell-rose at 2 p.m. but had to lie on the sofa.

div3.head: 23. Thurs
div3.p: Still more unwell-in bed all day. Planted potatoes in the Garden. Began to plow for corn.

div3.head: 24. Fri
div3.p: No better. Sent for Dr. Tate. In bed all day.

div3.head: March 25, 1865. Sat
div3.p: Slept sufficiently, but I am more unwell this morning, better in the afternoon. Dr. Tate came, advises more mercury & chalk. Sent Frank to Staunton for them. Mr Stuart to preach tomorrow.

div3.head: 26. Sab
div3.p: Mr Stuart spent the night here and preached at Bethel today to a good Congn I am better, but in bed all day.

div3.head: 27. Mon
div3.p: Cold morning. I am better-rose after dinner & dressed & sat up & reclined till after supper. Recd the gratifying news that Gen. Jos. E. Johnston had gained a signal victory in N.C. near Raleigh over Gen. Sherman. If so, God be praised.

div3.head: 28. Tues
div3.p: Did not rest well. Rose at 10 a.m.-up till 6 1/2 p.m.

div3.head: 29. Wed
div3.p: Rested well. Rose at 9 a.m. Reading all day. Up till 7 p.m.

div3.head: 30. Thurs
div3.p: I am gaining strength. Rose at 7 1/2 a.m. A good rain fell from about midnight till some time in the afternoon.
I have read with a good degree of interest the Journal of Tyerman & Hennet-finished it this evening.

div3.head: 31. Fri
div3.p: I am improving-Up 13 hours. Mr Pilson & Col. Turk came to see me. Sent to H.H. Lyle's foundary for a new Plow-paid 6 1/2 Dolls, in Specie. He kindly sent me three extra shears.

div3.head: April 1. Sat
div3.p: Began to plow for Oats in the Orchard. Samuel & John Pilson spent the day here. Brainard McClung the night.

div3.head: 2. Sab
div3.p: Rose to breakfast. With some fears I went Bethel. Mr Stuart preached a good Sermon on the "Rich Fool"-Took a collection for circulating the Centl. Presbn. in the Army. Came home fatigued.

div3.head: April 3. Mon
div3.p: Cleaned the Dining room Clock. Sowed Clover & Timothy seed on the Hill Field.

div3.head: 4. Tues
div3.p: I am comfortable-reading. Mary & James visiting.

div3.head: 5. Wed
div3.p: The sad inteligence has reached us that Richmond has been abandoned to the enemy! The communication was so obstructed that Gen. Lee's army could not get supplies. The last rumor is not reliable: Gen. A.P. Hill said to be killed.

div3.head: 6. Thurs
div3.p: Exciting rumors afoot that a Yankee force of 12,000 men are coming up the Valley & are within some 50 miles of Staunton. James went to Staunton to get the news. Gen. Lomax's Division is said to be skirmishing with them & falling back. The news from Richmond is very sad-may God protect his people & my poor Son.

div3.head: 7. Fri
div3.p: The Enemy down the Valley have fallen back to Cedar Creek. It seems the fighting near Richmond has been very terrible & the loss tremendous. Mrs McF. & James went to visit at Mr Kunkle's.

div3.head: 8. Sat
div3.p: Mr Benjn. F. Mc Clung came to get flour for the Army. I let him have four Barrels-the Govt. give $400 per B. in an order on the Treasy. where I presume there is no money. My bowels are a good deal disordered today-mucus passages.

div3.head: 9. Sab
div3.p: I took medicine last night & am better. Preached at Bethel to a good Congn People seem sad & many desponding.

div3.head: 10. Mon
div3.p: Not well. Reading. Rumoured that Lynchburg has fallen.

div3.head: 11. Tues
div3.p: My bowels still disordered-took salts & Ipecac.

The Startling inteligence has reached us that Genl. R.E. Lee for want of amunition & provisions had to surrender his whole army on last Sunday morning to Genl . Grant. This will probably close the war.

div3.head: 1865. April 12. Wed
div3.p: The news is that Gen. Jos. E. Johnston surrendered his army 8 days before Gen Lee surrendered. This makes it still more certain that we are conquered.

div3.head: 13. Thurs
div3.p: I am better. Reading & studying.

div3.head: 14. Fri
div3.p: Studying. Sowed 8 Bs. of Oats on the West end of the Orchard.

div3.head: 15. Sat
div3.p: I suffered with a "stitch" in my breast this morning & had to apply mustard. Was too unwell to go to Bethel, but the heavy rain prevented a Congn from assembling. James went & found noone there. Nathl. & Wm. Bent came this morning on their way to Winchester.

div3.head: 16. Sab
div3.p: Lord's Supper administered. Rev. S.D. Stuart Preached. No additions. I am much Better today. A large number of Soldiers returned from the Army present. It was a pleasant meeting.

div3.head: 17. Mon
div3.p: James took the two Mr Bents to Staunton with their Baggage in my waggon. Sent 75 lbs. of Flour, and about 5 lbs of Butter to Rev Mr Stuart, who has been kind in preaching for me. Mr Pilson here this evening.

div3.head: 18. Tues
div3.p: Reading & working. James went to McClung's Mill.

div3.head: 19. Wed
div3.p: Do. A rumour has reached us that Pres. Lincoln & Sec. Seward have been Assassinated. They certainly deserved to die, but it is sad that death came in that form, & that they should be plunged into eternity with so much blood on their souls. Do not feel able to go to Presbytary.

div3.head: 20. Thurs
div3.p: Reading and working.

div3.head: 21. Fri
div3.p: Empoyed putting a Lock of the Cellar door. Studying.

div3.head: 22. Sat
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: Apl. 23. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel in my usual manner, without much fatigue. A pretty good & attentive Congn

div3.head: 24. Mon
div3.p: Still a sense of fatigue. Reading.

div3.head: 25. Tues
div3.p: Planting Corn in the NW field. Reading.

div3.head: 26. Wed
div3.p: Finished planting corn. I was working.

div3.head: 27. Thurs
div3.p: Plowing for Sorghum & Potatoes N. of the house. Reading &c.

div3.head: 28. Fri
div3.p: Finished the plowing. Studying.

div3.head: 29. Sat
div3.p: A shower. Rev. Henry Brown spent the night here, had walked from the McNutts to preach to us, having heard that I was sick & did not know that I was able to preach.

div3.head: 30. Sab
div3.p: Mr Brown preached well, on the recognition of our friends in the future world. He went to preaching Middlebrook.

div3.head: May 1. Mon
div3.p: Planting Sorgum. I was reading.

div3.head: 2. Tues
div3.p: Planting Potatos N. of the house. Reading.

div3.head: 3. Wed
div3.p: Went to Geo. Rosens & Dined at Mr Gilkesons.

div3.head: 4. Thurs
div3.p: Brought home from McClung's Mill nearly seven Bls. of Flour. Shore our sheep.

div3.head: 5. Fri
div3.p: Reading & working. An excellent Rain. James paid Miss Abney for Seven new Flour Barrels at 37 1/2 cents each in Specie $2.62 1/2

div3.head: 6. Sat Sat
div3.p: The warmest day since last August. Studying.

div3.head: 7. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good & attentive Congn

div3.head: May 8th 1865. Mon
div3.p: Mr David Kunkle & wife here. Dr Humphreys came from a Political meeting in Staunton.

div3.head: 9. Tues
div3.p: A good rain. At home. Working & reading.

div3.head: 10. Wed
div3.p: Feel very languid. Reading.

div3.head: 11. Thurs
div3.p: A little better. Studying. Moses repairing fences. Heavy rain.

div3.head: 12. Fri
div3.p: As yesterday. Studying.

div3.head: 13. Sat
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 14. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel. Congn thin subject our duty now to the U.S. as Christian citizens.

div3.head: 15. Mon
div3.p: Went & got some work done at Lightners shop. Dined at Mrs Smith's-got a supply of leather-called at Mr Burch's, Mr Brownlee's, Mr Templetons & Mr Merritt's & came home-fatigued.

div3.head: 16. Tues
div3.p: Felt much fatigue. Working, sent for to preach at the Funeral of a child of Mr Tints Cooles in Greenville. James went today & was paroled by Capt Wilson.

div3.head: 17. Wed
div3.p: Dined at Mr Merritt's. Preached at Mr Newton's at the funeral of Mr Coole's child-came home excessively fatigued.

div3.head: 18. Thurs
div3.p: Still feel fatigued. Reading & working.

div3.head: 19. Fri
div3.p: Studying, showers.

div3.head: 20. Sat
div3.p: Studying. A fine shower.

div3.head: 21. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good Congn with some liberty.

div3.head: 22. Mon
div3.p: Working and reading.

div3.head: 23. Tue.
div3.p: Working.

div3.head: 24. Wed
div3.p: Reading. Harrowing Corn.

div3.head: 1865. May 25. Thurs
div3.p: Working. Rev. J.S. Blain & Susan B. Came & spent the day & night. Finished harrowing corn.

div3.head: 26. Fri
div3.p: Rained much in the night & nearly all day. Cold and disagreeable. Mr Blain & daughter staid all day. I could not set out for New Providence.

div3.head: 27. Sat
div3.p: Mr Blain & Susan left us. The morning so cool & damp & my health so feeble, I felt constrained to decline going to New Providence. Sent an appointment to preach in Greenville tomorrow.

div3.head: 28. Sab
div3.p: Went to Greenville-heard the Rev. Mr Gaver of the Methodist Church, preach. I preached at 3 p.m. The Congn large & attentive. Came home.

div3.head: 29. Mon
div3.p: Rested badly. Reading.

div3.head: 30. Tues
div3.p: Went to Mint Spring & met N. Bent in the stage.

div3.head: 31. Wed
div3.p: Studying. Finished going over our corn the 2nd time.

div3.head: June 1. Thurs
div3.p: Sent 15 Bs. of wheat to mill-have then now 35 Bs. to be ground.

div3.head: 2. Fri
div3.p: Went to Staunton in my Buggy-James with me on horseback. Sold my Flour to Mrs Bolin at $8.00 pr. Bl. in Greenbacks. Brought 3 Bunches Cotton Yarn, Nos 10, 11. 12 at $3. pr. B. also 10 yds shirting Cotton at 42 cents Dined at Col Tate's. Came home fatigued.

div3.head: 3. Sat
div3.p: Spent a suffering night-breakfast in bed. Studying. Miss S. Henry & Lizzie Wallace & Lizzie Wilson here.

div3.head: 1865. June 4. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel with some liberty to a large & attentive Congn Recd. a letter from Francis who has returned to Richmond. Thank God that he is safe.

div3.head: 5. Mon
div3.p: Sent six Barrels of flour to Staunton. Reading.

div3.head: 6. Tues
div3.p: At home Reading. Rode to Wm. Hall's.

div3.head: 7. Wed
div3.p: Heard that Mr John Shumaker was very ill. I went to see him, but found he had died before day of Bileous choic.

div3.head: 8. Thurs
div3.p: Spent an uncomfortable night. Breakfasted in bed. Sent 7 bls. more flour to Staunton. Mr Blain & Susan here.

div3.head: 9. Fri
div3.p: Not well. Mr & Miss Blain left us. Plowing Corn. Rain. Rev. Chaplain Little of the Yankee Army, 1st Va. Regt. here.

div3.head: 10. Sat
div3.p: Mr Little sick-staid all day. Another good rain.

div3.head: 11. Sab
div3.p: Mr Jos. Little left us, well. Preached at Bethel to a good Congn for the day.

div3.head: (10. Sat
div3.p: The coloured woman Caroline began to work for us at 50 cents per week.

div3.head: 12. Mon
div3.p: Feel extremely feeble. Reading a little.

div3.head: 13. Tues
div3.p: No stronger. Wrote to Rev. Wm. Pinkerton, decling to go to preach a Funeral Sermon for McClung Patton-Also wrote to Dr. A. Leyburn, Resigning my office of Trustee of Washington College. Finished plowing corn the second time. Reading.

div3.head: 14. Wed
div3.p: The ground too wet to cultivate. Working & reading.

div3.head: 15. Thurs
div3.p: Working & Reading. Mrs McF. & I visited Mrs Faber.

div3.head: June 15th. Thurs Continued.
div3.p: A simple kind of man, who said his name was Hamilton, came to my study-said he felt a considerable interest in Religion & approved of the Presbyterian doctrine & had been immersed & believed he was converted & his sins pardoned last August. He seemed very much to desire to have Bible although he said they had one at home. He wanted the one on my study table which I told him I could not spare. I gave him a Testament & told him, I thought Bibles could soon be obtained. I had to leave the room a moment, & directly he came out with his coat wrapped close around him & went away. Shortly after I missed my Bible-he undoubtedly stole it.

div3.head: 16. Fri
div3.p: Reading & studying. James spent last night in Staunton. He brought me perhaps 1 1/2 lbs of sugar, 1 lb. ground Coffee, & a bottle of Extract of J. Ginger & a paper of Farina & a number of Newspapers, sent me by Chaplain Joseph Little of the 1st Va. R. Yankee.

div3.head: 17. Sat
div3.p: Plowing Corn & Sorgum.

div3.head: 18. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel with some liberty to a very large Congn

div3.head: 19. Mon
div3.p: Unwell this morning. Feeble. Reading a little.

div3.head: 20. Tues
div3.p: I have a distressing Cough of long continuance. Working.

div3.head: 21. Wed
div3.p: Better. Working.

div3.head: 1865. June 22. Thurs
div3.p: Unwell-Reading.

div3.head: 23. Fri
div3.p: Spent a distressing night with Asthma. I think I have not had it for a year past. Today quite unwell. Did not rise till 9 1/2 O'clock, bad head ache-could read but little.

div3.head: 24. Sat
div3.p: Rested better, but can study very little.

div3.head: 25. Sab
div3.p: Rested badly, asthmatic & feeble. Preached at Bethel 30 minutes to a good & attentive Congn Prisoners nearly all home.

div3.head: 26. Mon
div3.p: Not well. Rain. Cannot plow Corn. Mrs McF. & James went to Mr Blackwoods on a visit & returned.

div3.head: 27. Tues
div3.p: Began to cut wheat. This morning early, Liz, being now free, left us without making it known to any of the white family. A foolish negro.
I spent a distressing night with coughing: did not rise till 8 a.m. Went to bed again at 2 p.m. Applied Mustard to my breast.

div3.head: 28. Wed
div3.p: Sent to Mr Bumgarner's for Mary-she is not able to come home-nervous. I had another bad night; taking salts & Ipicac-head ache-in bed all day. Delightful weather. James, Jeff & Frank harvesting wheat.

div3.head: 29. Thurs
div3.p: Another bad night with asthma. Cutting wheat. In bed all day except from 4 to 5 p.m. Nasal defluction.

div3.head: 30. Fri
div3.p: Finished cutting wheat-100 doz. Had a very feverish night. Sent for Dr. Churchman could not come-weaker today.

div3.head: 1865. July 1. Sat
div3.p: No better. Dr. Churchman did not come & I sent for Dr Wilson, he came. Says I have Bronchitis badly in both lungs. Left me some powders-Mercury & chalk, Ipicac & Quinine.

div3.head: 2. Sab
div3.p: No better. Wrote a note to the session to press for the supply of the pulpit, as I did not know when I could if ever, I am not suffering much, but my lungs are oppressed & I am getting weaker. Pulse through the night 100 or more & hard. In the day gets down to 84 to 90.

div3.head: 3. Mon
div3.p: Hauled in our Wheat. I rested better, have little fever, but much prostrated. Dr Humphreys came to see me. He speaks favourably of my case. Mr Pilson, Blackwood & Merritt came to see me about procuring a supply for the pulpit.

div3.head: 4. Tues
div3.p: I am still improving, Thanks be to God. Dr. Watson came-left mercriat of Iron & quinine. Rev. E. Thomas, Jas. Calhoon, F.M. Gilkeson, Sally Gilkeson & Jerusha McPheeters came to see me.

div3.head: 5. Wed
div3.p: Not so well. A.F. Humphreys & wife-also Liz. Wilson Miss Mary Lizzie Larew & Miss Mary Pringle. Mowing.

div3.head: 6. Thurs
div3.p: Rested well. Better. Mrs Faber, Mrs King & Mrs Christian came to see me. Mowing.

div3.head: 1865. July 7. Fri
div3.p: Better. About 11 a.m. put on my Clothes-up till near 3 p.m. Appetite good. Mrs James Henderson here-also Mrs C. Wright & Miss Polly Larew. James went to Staunton & bought two sythe snaths at one doll. each. Mowing.

div3.head: 8. Sat
div3.p: Still better-dressed at 9 a.m. & up till 7 p.m. Mowing.

div3.head: 9. Sab
div3.p: Better-rose at 8 a.m. & up till 7 p.m. Mrs McFarland staid at home with me-others went to Bethel. Rev. Mr Houston preached to a good Congn

div3.head: 10. Mon
div3.p: Somewhat astmatic. Rose at 8 a.m. Up till 8 p.m. Day rainy & gloomy-thick fog. Sold Mr Plunket a B. of Flr.

div3.head: 11. Tues
div3.p: Had a very bad night with Asthma & feel very badly today. Working a little & reading. Mowing.

div3.head: 12. Wed
div3.p: Rested pretty well. Mowing. 4 hands half a day.

div3.head: 13. Thurs
div3.p: I improve in health very slowly. Four hands mowing and making hay.

div3.head: 14. Fri
div3.p: Asthmatic this morning. I continue very feeble. Same hands mowing & making hay. Finished cutting front meadow.

div3.head: 15. Sat
div3.p: Had Asthma badly-sat up bolstered in bed all night. Rose at 3.45' a.m. & made a fire. I feel great exhaustion. Finished our mowing. Had Morgan shod all round.

div3.head: 16. Sab
div3.p: Asthma badly again. Too weak to go to Bethel. The white family all went. Mr Houston preached & came here to dinner, and then went to preach at Mint Spring.

div3.head: July 17. Mon
div3.p: Rained nearly night. I still have Asthma. Sat up & reclined on the sofa till 1 a.m. then went to bed till morning, but had to rise early & kindle a fire. Had asthma all day.

div3.head: 18. Tues
div3.p: Spent most of the night reclining on the Sofa. After daybreak went to bed. Asthma through the day. Hauling hay into the barn.

div3.head: 19. Wed
div3.p: Out of bed till 2 a.m.-then so unwell had to lie down. Did not rise till noon-feel badly. Hauling in hay.

div3.head: 20. Thurs
div3.p: In bed all night-slept pretty well-bad headache this a.m. Hauling in hay. Asthma much abated, but I am very weak.

div3.head: 21. Fri
div3.p: Rested pretty well, but feel much debility. Hauling hay.

div3.head: 22. Sat
div3.p: Night oppressively warm. Rested pretty well. James went to a Picnic at Christian's Creek School House.

div3.head: 23. Sab
div3.p: Feel much debility. I ventured to go to Bethel. Mr Houston preached to a large Congn I came home much fatigued, but I think not injured. Glory to God.

div3.head: 24. Mon
div3.p: I feel stronger today. Reading Newspapers.

div3.head: 25. Tues
div3.p: Cutting Oats. James & Frank went to the mountain.

div3.head: 26. Wed
div3.p: Rode to Mr Hendersons. Finished cutting Oats. Reading.

div3.head: 27. Thurs
div3.p: Did not rest. Reluctantly set out for Greenville, Mrs Mc Farland with me-staid at Wm. F. Smith's Mr John Newton came down & administered to me the Oath of Amnesty to authorize me to solemnize Marriage. In the evening at 8 O'clock

div3.head: 1865. July 27. Thur (continued).
div3.p: I solemnized Marriage between Matthew Thompson McClure & Sarah Catherine Bumgardner. A pleasant company there.

div3.head: 28. Friday
div3.p: Rode out to see Mr James McClung, who is very low-prayed with him-returned to Greenville & dined at Mrs Graham's staid till 4 p.m. & came home. Found Rev. John S. Blain here. Rev. Mr Stuart spent yesterday at my house.

div3.head: 29. Sat
div3.p: Not so comfortable today-could read but little. Pain in my side troublesome-applied mustard.

div3.head: 30. Sab
div3.p: So unwell did not rise till 1 p.m. & went to bed again a little after 5. Applied mustard to my side again & felt relieved for some hours, but the pain returned. The white family all went to Church-Mr Houston they say preached well. Day cool.

div3.head: 31. Mon
div3.p: Rained nearly all day. I in bed all day. Side worse-sent for Dr. Tate-he came & prescribed Mercy. & chalk with Ipicac Salts. Warm applications.

div3.head: August 1. Tues
div3.p: A bad night-no better-in bed still. Dr. Wm. Brown mad us a pleasant visit.

div3.head: 2. Wed
div3.p: Dr. Brown left us. Mr Pilson came to see me.

div3.head: 3. Thurs
div3.p: Another suffering night. Sent for Dr. Tate-he came & renewed the former prescription. Applied dry hops.

div3.head: 4. Fri
div3.p: No change for the better. Mr Preston preached at Bethel today & came to see me.

div3.head: 5. Sat
div3.p: Last night was one of great suffering & today I suffer pain almost constantly.
Rev. Henry Brown preached at Bethel today & came here, also Mr Preston & Dr. Humphreys. Dr Tate came & he & Dr. H. conferred about my case.

div3.head: 6. Sab
div3.p: I do not remember ever to have passed such a night of pain as last night.
Today the Lord's Supper was administered at at Bethel-Rev. S.D. Stuart preached & Rev. H. Brown administered the Ordinance. Alas, I was not able to be there. Mrs McF. staid with me.

div3.head: 7. Mon
div3.p: Suffering not quite so intense last night, but I am no better today. I am sorely afflicted.

div3.head: 8. Tues
div3.p: A worse night still-feel badly today, but the character of my disease has not changed, & there is no abatement of the symptoms.
Last night my sufferings were terribe-the worst night yet-easier through the day-but pain constant.

div3.head: 1865. Aug. 10. Thurs
div3.p: Last night applied Cloroform and oil to my side which relieved me of pain & I have had but little since. Glory be to God, I am better in other respects. Mary went to the Springs.

div3.head: 11. Fri
div3.p: Last the pain returned & toward morning was severe-my rest was much broken, but today I am in a great measure free from pain.

div3.head: 12. Sat
div3.p: Felt some pain all night but could sleep. But little pain today, but not comfortable.

div3.head: 13. Sab
div3.p: Some pain all night, but slept. Bowels disordered. Took oil. Some pain all day. Mrs McF. & James went to church-Mr Huston preached.

div3.head: 14. Mon
div3.p: Suffered extremely last night with pain my bowels it seems Bileous diarhea, but today some symptoms of Dysentery have appeared. Took Rhubarb & soda & then salts & Ipicac. Pain continuous, but not so severe.

div3.head: 15. Tues
div3.p: Rested pretty well last night-symptoms better. Dr. White & Rev. Saml. Brown spent last night with us-a very pleasant visit. Bowels still disordered, & some neuralgia still in my side. Sit up none.

div3.head: 16. Wed
div3.p: Had a bad night-bowels pained & much disordered. Today symptoms of dysentery manifest-much pain.

div3.head: 1865. Aug. 16th continued.
div3.p: Took Mercury & chalk & Castor Oil. Sent for Dr. Tate. He came & prescribed.

div3.head: 17. Thurs
div3.p: Rested pretty well, contrary to expectation, & today my bowels have been quiet & I pretty easy. Dr. Tate here again.

div3.head: 18. Fri
div3.p: Rained all night. Rested pretty well-bowels quiet. Rose & dressed at 10 a.m. & up till 4 p.m. bowels uneasy. This the first time since I have dressed since the 31 ult.

div3.head: 19. Sat
div3.p: I took oil last night & had to take a second dose in the night. I was very restless & suffered a good deal of pain. Rose & dressed at 10 a.m.-up till 5 1/2 p.m. Weaker.
Mrs Pilson came to see me & spent the day here.

div3.head: 20. Sab
div3.p: More unwell in the morning-better-rose at 11 a.m. Up till 5 1/2 p.m. No preaching at Bethel today. Pby. met.

div3.head: 21. Mon
div3.p: Rested tolerably-rose at 7 1/2 a.m. Dined with my wife-the first time for 3 weeks-feel stronger-appetite good. I trust I am in a fair way to recover-thanks be to God.

div3.head: 22. Tues
div3.p: I think my improvement continues. I wrote a historical sketch of my life for the Board of Education & a letter to my son Francis. Mary returned from the Springs in improved health. A very heavy Rain. Finished plowing for wheat.

div3.head: 23. Wed
div3.p: A little stronger. Reading &c.

div3.head: 24. Thurs
div3.p: Asthma & pain in my side last night. Feel very badly today-sneezing & eyes & nose running water. Mr Pilson here.

div3.head: 1865. Aug. 25th. Frid.
div3.p: Head so uncomfortable from sneezing & nasal defluction. I did not rise till 10 a.m. the latter Continued throughout the day. A little desultary reading. Hauling manure.

div3.head: 26. Sat
div3.p: Another uncomfortable night-laborious breathing. Burned my breast with mustard & took Merc & chalk and salts & Ipicac. In bed all day.

div3.head: 27. Sab
div3.p: Rose at 9 a.m. but not able to go to Bethel. Feel weak, but I am better. All the white family went to Church. Mr Houston preached. Congn said to be good. Returned to bed at 5 p.m.

div3.head: 28. Mon
div3.p: Not so well this morning-cough very troublesome. Did not rise till 10 1/2 a.m. Mrs King & Miss Mary Julia Baldwin and Rev. Wm. Pinkerton came to see me & dined here. Up till 5 p.m.

div3.head: 29. Tues
div3.p: Rather better today-reading.

div3.head: 30. Wed
div3.p: Still improving. Sowed wheat today on the West end of the orchard field. This afternoon I rode out through my fields-the first ride for more than a month.

div3.head: 31. Thurs
div3.p: Gaining Strength. Repairing window-rode out.

div3.head: September 1. Fri
div3.p: Last night much fatigued. Today pretty well. Men making rails.

div3.head: 2. Sat
div3.p: Sent to Staunton, care of D.A. Kayser, for Rev. Dr. Brown seven years of the Central Presbyterian & 2 1/2 yrs. of the Phila. Presbn. Mary & James went to Hebron. I was reading.

div3.head: September 3. Sab
div3.p: Sick this morning, went to Bethel. A good Congn Mr Houston preached a pretty good serMon A very fine shower in the evening. Much fatigued.

div3.head: 4. Mon
div3.p: Feeble today-Oppressed with the heat.

div3.head: 5. Tues
div3.p: Am stronger & better. Francis McF. Swoop came to see me, to consult me about going to the Theol. Semy. to prepare for for the Ministry. I think well of the young man. I lent him a Greek Grammar & my Hebrew Bible. Studying a little.

div3.head: 6. Wed
div3.p: Pretty well; p.m. not so well-attacked pretty violently with Diarhea, I think from eating peaches & one or two pears. Continued badly all night.

div3.head: 7. Thurs
div3.p: Continued to suffer all day & all night. Could not get the disease checked.

div3.head: 8. Fri
div3.p: Still suffering, but less. Mrs Sarah Ann Tate & Mrs Martha Ann Christian dined ere. Bolivar Christian came in the afternoon.

div3.head: 9. Sat
div3.p: A day of suffering-disease not checked. Some sleight symptoms of Dysentary-much prostrated.

div3.head: 10. Sab
div3.p: Spent a better night than I expected-taking broken doses of salts & Ipicac. Dr Tate sent for-came & advised a blue pill. Mary Lou has high fevers in the night-her case is I think a threatening one. No preaching at Bethel.

div3.head: 11. Mon
div3.p: Had a comparatively comfortable night-today much better. Dr. Humphreys came to see us.

div3.head: 12. Tues
div3.p: Had hoped to be up today, but am not so well, bowels still disordered. Began to so wheat among the corn N. half of the field. Lancaster Wheat.

div3.head: 1865. Sept. 13th Wed
div3.p: Much better. Rose at 9 a.m. and remained up all day. Mr John Pilson dined here. In the afternoon Mr Matthew Pilson came to see me. Began to cut up corn preparatory to seeding the ground.

div3.head: 14. Thurs
div3.p: I am still improving-dined with the family. Cutting up corn with an additional hand.

div3.head: 15. Fri
div3.p: Finished Cutting up corn. I am improving still.

div3.head: 16. Sat
div3.p: Last night I was violently attacked with Diarhea almost resembling Asiatic Cholera. It continued all night, & through the day, but less violently. I am much prostrated. In bed all day. Took Oil.

div3.head: 17. Sab
div3.p: In bed all day. Last night took a blue pill & Rubarb & soda, which I think did me much good. No preaching at Bethel, alas. Mr Pilson wrote for Mr Houston but he did not come. Day very pleasant.

div3.head: 18. Mon
div3.p: I am better-rose at 8 a.m. up till 9 p.m.

div3.head: 19. Tues
div3.p: Rose to breakfast. The day uncomfortably cool. Better.

div3.head: 20. Wed
div3.p: Still improving. Doing nothing but reading.

div3.head: 21. Thurs
div3.p: Mrs Jas. Henderson & Mrs Mary Larew here. Reading.
Studying & working. I am pretty well.

div3.head: 23. Sat
div3.p: Not quite so well today. James & Mary took Mary Lou to Staunton to go to Miss Baldwin's School, who generously offers her boarding & tuition gratis.

div3.head: Sept. 24. Sab
div3.p: Am pretty well. Went to Bethel prepared to preach, but Rev. Robt. J. Taylor, hearing of my sickness & an invitation being sent him by Mr Pilson through Mr Wm White, came from Lexington expressly to preach for me; and he preached an excellent sermon from Psm. 107:43.

div3.head: 25. Mond.
div3.p: James went to Staunton. Mary returned.

div3.head: 26. Tues
div3.p: Rested badly. Finished sowing wheat-sowed 9 Bush. where the Corn was cut up. Mrs McFarland & James went to Staunton to meet N. Bent who is to come up today.

div3.head: 27. Wed
div3.p: Mrs McF. & James Returned & brought home a keg of sugar containing 40 lbs (yellow Coffee) at 18 cents. All though Rio Coffee at 35 cents, 20 lbs. Butter 54 lbs. at 30 cents pr. lb.

div3.head: 28. Thurs
div3.p: Dined at Mr James Bumgarner's-rode to Greenville & in the Evening married Jacob L. Swartzel & Lousia A. Bloulle. Spent the night at Wm. F. Smith's.

div3.head: 29. Fri
div3.p: Returned home. Taking cold badly.

div3.head: 30. Sat
div3.p: Spent an uncomfortable night-not well today.

div3.head: October 1. Sab
div3.p: Another uncomfortable night. My legs much irritated by coughing-feared to preach, but preached over 50 minutes. Dined at Mr Bumgarners. Came home & applied mustard to my breast.

div3.head: 1865. Octr. 2. Mon
div3.p: Rested badly, but went to Staunton on my way to synod, dined & spent the night at Col. Tates.

div3.head: 3. Tues
div3.p: Spent a very feverish night; pulse yesterday 100, today 100. Too unwell to proceed. John Pilson brought me home-much fatigued.

div3.head: 4. Wed
div3.p: Spent a feverish night, in bed all day. Pulse 95.

div3.head: 5. Thurs
div3.p: Spent a more uncomfortable night than the proceeding-took Oil-rather better-in bed all day.

div3.head: 6. Thurs. Fri
div3.p: Last night & this morning very unwell. My disease a distinctly marked case of Bronchitis. Pulse in the morning 104 in the afternoon 80. In bed all day cough a little less troublesome.

div3.head: 7. Sat
div3.p: Another bad night, pulse as yesterday. Sent for Dr. Tate he came & prescribed-in bed all day. James went to Staunton & bought 8 yds of Casimere for a Suit, at $2.25 = 18.00

div3.head: 8. Sab
div3.p: Spent a wretched night with asthma-slept at none but while bolstered up in bed. Took blue pill last night & oil this morning. Ipicac every 4 hours. Not well-in bed all day. Pulse 95 & 84.

div3.head: October 9. Mon
div3.p: Had a more comfortable night. Pulse after breakfast 104, declined to 84. In bed all day except I rose to marry Alexander Strauther & Mary Maria Smith, coloured persons.

div3.head: 10. Tues
div3.p: Rested pretty well. Rose & dressed at 9 1/2 a.m. up till 4 1/2 p.m. Dr. Tate came to see me-continued the Ipicac.

div3.head: 11. Wed
div3.p: Rested pretty well but the Eruption on my limbs is becoming quite troublesome-James started to the Sulphur Spring, formerly Crawford's to get me sulphur water. Rose at 8 1/2 a.m. & up all day-dined with the family.

div3.head: 12. Thurs
div3.p: Spent a wretched night from the Eruption in my limbs-rose at noon. James arrived with the Sulphur-water & I began to drink. I cannot perceive either taste or smell of sulphur, but I hope for benefit as I experienced last year.

div3.head: 13. Fri
div3.p: Cool. Busy about Minutes of Synod.

div3.head: 14. Sat
div3.p: It began to rain early & rained heavily all day. The Eruption very troublesome. Wrote to Dr. Brown about the Minutes of Synod-could do nothing else.

div3.head: 15. Sab
div3.p: Suffered very much with the eruption last night.

div3.head: 1865. Octr . 15th Sab (continued)
div3.p: With some fears I went to Bethel not intending to preach. The day cool & damp. Many supposed I would not be there. There was a very small Congn Mr Pilson prayed & I exhorted for perhaps 20 minutes & prayed. I think my lungs are nothing worse, but the eruption no better.

div3.head: 16. Mon
div3.p: Had a much more comfortable night than for some time past. But today feel very dull & languid. Killed a Heifer weighing 337 lbs. Mr Henderson assisted and borrowed a hind quarter weighing probably 85 lbs as that was the weight of the other.

div3.head: 17. Tues
div3.p: Had a pretty good night-I think the irritation is somewhat abated. I was much on my feet in the afternoon which irritated the eruption on my feet.

div3.head: 18. Wed
div3.p: Rested only tolerably. Raining. With much reluctance I set out with Mrs McF in the rain for Mr Blackwoods, where at 11 1/2 O'clock a.m. I married Emmet Brooks & Mary L. Wilson. It rained so heavily & incessantly that we were compelled to stay all night.

div3.head: 19. Thurs
div3.p: Rested better than I expected-came home to dinner. Traveling does not suit me.

div3.head: 20. Fri
div3.p: I think the eruption is worse-last night my thighs were much afflicted-today my leg is much irritated.

div3.head: October 21st. Sat
div3.p: Rested better-left leg sorer. Studying a little.

div3.head: 22. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel, I think without any serious injury. I felt the effect on my lungs & my sore leg was perhaps a little worse. Thanks be to God for the privilege of Preaching his precious Gospel.

div3.head: 23. Mon
div3.p: Rested imperfectly, but I think the eruption on my legs is beginning to dry up. Reading Newspapers.

div3.head: 24. Tues
div3.p: More comfortable-less irritation. Reading & Studying.

div3.head: 25. Wed
div3.p: My right leg has become more diseased. I have been reading all day & seeking a suject for the Sab

div3.head: 26. Thurs
div3.p: Eruption more irritated. Studying.

div3.head: 27. Fri
div3.p: Mr Henderson here with his machine threshing our Wheat & Oats. Mary & Frank went to Staunton and brought home Mary Lou.

div3.head: 28. Sat
div3.p: Eruption about the same. Studying. Dr. Humphries & Theda came here.

div3.head: 29. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good Congn & with some liberty thanks be to God. A good deal fatigued.

div3.head: 30. Mon
div3.p: Preached at Wm. Swink's at the Funeral of Katy Palmer, aged 88 in Decr . Much fatigued.

div3.head: 31. Tues
div3.p: I am better. Finished a letter to Dr. McElhenny & wrote Rev. Dr. Plumer.

div3.head: 1865. Nov. 1. Wed
div3.p: My legs are a great deal better. Dr. Wayland formerly of Waynesboro in this County but who removed to Missouri 28 yrs ago came to see me in company with Mr Jacob Vanlear. He is an Elder in the Presbyterian Ch. & was a member of the Synod of Missouri week before last. He gave me much interesting information-it was a pleasant visit. They dined with us.

div3.head: 2. Thurs
div3.p: Reading, working & studying. Day mild.

div3.head: 3. Fri
div3.p: The eruption is leaving my limbs, thanks be to God. It rained moderately all day. I was studying.
Col. R. Turk came & spent the night with us. A pleasant man.

div3.head: 4. Sat
div3.p: Rained nearly all day as yesterday. Studying.

div3.head: 5. Sab
div3.p: The day uncomfortably cold. Preached at Bethel to a good Congn for the day, & with more comfort to myself than lately. There was solemn attention.

div3.head: 6. Mon
div3.p: Spent a restless night with coughing & headache

div3.head: 7. Tues
div3.p: My Cough contines at night-little by day. Very languid. Had two black men hired getting wood.

div3.head: 8. Wed
div3.p: Cough no better-not well otherwise. Same two black men husking corn. Mrs McF. & James went to Staunton to bring out Roxy Bent, who was expected there on her way here. They returned and brought her. Seven years ago she visited us.

div3.head: Nov. 9. Thurs
div3.p: I spent a wretched night, coughing, and lungs enflamed. Did not rise till 2 p.m. Alas, I could not go to Bethel, & this the day appointed by our Synod for Fasting & prayer. They say a good Congregation assembled.

div3.head: 10. Fri
div3.p: I rested rather better last night & feel better this morning. Dr. Humphreys & his brother John here all night. I rose at 10 a.m. not so well through the day. Used tea made of Bonc sot or thorough wort.

div3.head: 11. Sat
div3.p: Did not rest well-unable to go to Bethel & this the day preceding our Communion. Rev. Wm. Pinkerton preached. I did not rise till noon. The day Cold.

div3.head: 12. Sab
div3.p: Rested better. With great fear I went to Bethel Mr Wm. Pinkerton preached an excellent SerMon I introduced the Comn. Service & served the first table. Had no additions, Alas. I felt fatigued & breast sore.

div3.head: 13. Mon
div3.p: The first part of the night I could not rest-lungs sore & a greater degree of nervousness than I ever felt-had to take some stimulating cordial in the night. Today I am better than for a week, thanks be to God.

div3.head: 14. Tues
div3.p: Day very mild. I am still better. About noon the Rev. Dr. Wm. S. White came & made us a delightful visit. He is on an agency for Washington College.

div3.head: 1865. Nov. 15. Wed
div3.p: Dr. White left us for home. I rode out in the afternoon. Called at Mr McPheeters'. Went to see L. Brown to get him to work for me. Rode to Arbor Hill-then home. Still improving.

div3.head: 16. Thurs
div3.p: Day very mild. Rode to Greenville. Got Mitchell to cut out a Frock-Coat of Blue Clothe from my old Cloak. Dined at Mr L. Bumgarner's. Called at Mr Birch's to get him to foot a pair of Boots for Frank. Bought various articles. Came home somewhat fatigued.

div3.head: 17. Fri
div3.p: Studying. I wonder that I am so well.

div3.head: 18. Sat
div3.p: Pretty well. Studying.

div3.head: 19. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel with more strength, ease and liberty than for some months past. Thanks to God.

div3.head: 20. Mon
div3.p: Working & Reading. Hands husking corn.

div3.head: 21. Tues
div3.p: All employed as yesterday. Weather cleared off fine.

div3.head: 22. Wed
div3.p: Brown, son & Nephew & Lewis Mater husking corn. Mrs McFarland & I made a visit to Mr Jacob Vanlears, and I Baptized two children of Mr Wm. Vanlear, his wife being a member of the Church. Spent the night at Mrs King's.

div3.head: 23. Thurs
div3.p: Did not rest well-dined at Mr Pilson's. Home.

div3.head: 24. Fri
div3.p: I find I have caught some cold coming home & am not so well today. Misses Virginia Gilkeson & Sally & Lovey G. here all night. Finished getting in our Corn.

div3.head: Nov. 25. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Finished hauling in Cornfodder.

div3.head: 26. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel to a good Congn subject a Revival. Day very mild & pleasant.

div3.head: 27. Mon
div3.p: Not well. Mrs McF. & went to visit Mrs Mish who has been very ill. She is a little better-prayed with her. Dined at Mr Kunkle's-he not at home.

div3.head: 28. Tues
div3.p: At home-reading.

div3.head: 29. Wed
div3.p: Had an uncomfortable night. Resting. Got a sack of Salt (Marshals) 240 lbs. cost $5.50.

div3.head: 30. Thurs
div3.p: Rested better. Mary Lewis & I went to Staunton to return taxable property for the Revenue, but the Assessor could not attend to it. Made some calls & returned home.

div3.head: December 1. Fri
div3.p: Wrote to Rev. S.L. Stuart, & on to send note to Rev. John C. Backus, D.D. Baltimore. Mrs McF. & James & I went to Bethel where we expected Rev. Wm. Pinkerton to preach on the occasion of the reinterment of the Remains of James McClure who fell in battle near Petersburg, but we found it had been done yesterday.

div3.head: 2. Sat
div3.p: So unwell I can study but little.

div3.head: 3. Sab
div3.p: Still unwell-lungs imflamed-with some fears, went to Bethel & preached as usual 3/4 of an hour. Fatigued. Recd. from Dr. Brown a Book for the Records of Synod. It seems of excellent quality-cost $5.50 in Baltimore. Express, 50 cents.

div3.head: 1865. Dec. 4. Mond.
div3.p: Reading. Mrs Dr. Hays & Susan here.

div3.head: 5. Tues
div3.p: Reading & working.

div3.head: 6. Wed
div3.p: Writing a Biographical sketch of myself for the Board of Education.

div3.head: 7. Thurs
div3.p: Wrote to Francis. Reading & Writing. Killed a steer 1,555 lbs. hide 91 lbs. Tallow.

div3.head: 8. Fri
div3.p: Went to Bethel to attend a meeting of the Session to purge the Roll of members, especially in regard to coloured members who are now becoming very irregular. We also resolved to recommend the election of three additional Elders.

div3.head: 9. Sat
div3.p: Studying.

div3.head: 10. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel. Congn rather thin. Gave notice of of the election of Elders at a future day, but soon.
Reading Newspapers. The Presidents Message is conservative & perhaps all we could expect. But the opening of Congress seems to promise no good to the south.

div3.head: 12. Tues
div3.p: Mrs McFarland & I went to Mr Bumgardner's-I thence to Mr John J. Larew's, where I married Joseph Hinston Waddy & Mary Elisabeth Larew Returned to Mr. B's.

div3.head: 13. Wed
div3.p: Spent a wretched night-great sense of oppression laborious breathing but seemed not asthma. Came home feeling badly.

div3.head: Dec. 14. Thurs
div3.p: Spent an uncomfortable night. My Study was cold & I lay on a Couch in the sitting-room. I am unwell all day, cannot even read. Mrs Pilson & Jerusha McPheeter dined with us. Last night half an inch of snowfall. Cold today.

div3.head: 15. Fri
div3.p: Rested badly the latter part of the night when the room got cold-suffered with headache-rose at 9 a.m. Reading &c. Dr. Humphreys here.

div3.head: 16. Sat
div3.p: Very cold. I am a little better. Reading & Studying.

div3.head: 17. Sab
div3.p: Much indisposed. Day more moderate-went to Bethel & preached to a moderate Congn without any notes.

div3.head: 18. Mon
div3.p: Much indisposed-in the evening comfortable. Reading.

div3.head: 19. Tues
div3.p: Much better. Killed ten Hogs weighing 182, 142, 159, 171, 169, 185, 156, 142, 126, 161. Total 1591 lbs. Sold the two last = 287 lbs at $10. pr. 100. Returned for domestic use 1304 lbs.

div3.head: 20. Wed
div3.p: Reading & preparing my List for the U.S. Assessor.

div3.head: 21. Thurs
div3.p: Still breakfast in bed. Near 9 a.m. I left home to go to Mr Wm. Cochran's where I married John A. Wilson and Ellen J. Cochran. The change of temperature was so sudden-the wind so high, keen & penetrating that I suffered very much. I fear the effect on my lungs. I reached home about 3 p.m. very much exhausted. Mary Lou came home.

div3.head: 1865. Dec. 22. Fri
div3.p: Last night my lungs were so irritated that at midnight I had to rouse Mrs McF. to apply mustard to my breast. I suffered much with my head-not a proper headache but a painful & bewildered feeling. More mustard to my breast and to my forehead. I rose & dressed but had to recline on the sofa nearly all day. Could not read.

div3.head: 23. Sat
div3.p: Slept sufficiently, but much distressed with my head. Did not rise till noon & then felt very badly when up. My lungs are better, but my head not.

div3.head: 24. Sab
div3.p: Rested imperfectly-head a little better. Rose at 9 a.m. felt badly & cannot explain how-better in the evening. The day so inclement I would not have gone to Church had I been well. I suppose none were there. The rain froze on the trees.

div3.head: 25. Mon
div3.p: Christmas. The day very mild & fine. I did not feel well, & did not rise till after 9 a.m. My head seems more disordered today than heretofore. I cannot read with any comfort. I fear the case is becoming serious. Dr. Humphreys & David came. The Dr prescribed I bathed my feet & applied mustard to the back of my neck.

div3.head: 26. Tues
div3.p: Dr. H. went to Staunton. I am much better today.

div3.head: 27. Wed
div3.p: Dr. H. left us & took the children away. I married at my own house Henry Hill & Amanda Lewis, coloured persons.

div3.head: December 28. Thurs
div3.p: I am much better today. Reading

div3.head: 29. Fri
div3.p: Still better. I have today hired Jeff. for another year-I must pay him $100. & give him a winter suit consisting of coat, vest, pantaloons & shoes.

div3.head: 30. Sat
div3.p: It began to snow in the night & continued moderately till near noon-about 4 inches, I think, fell. I continue better. Studying.

div3.head: 31. Sab
div3.p: Very unwell this morning, but made a great effort to go to Bethel & became better-preached as usual to a good Congn for the day. Came home better.

div3.head: 1866. Jan. 1. Mond.
div3.p: Day cloudy, damp and gloomy. I am better than yesterday, but not well. God in Mercy has permitted me to see another New Year in the flesh, very probably the last. And although I am very infirm & suffer a good deal, I have numerous mercies for which I here record my fervent gratitude to God.

I have also much to be thankful for in regard to my family. My dear wife enjoys pretty good health. My son Francis is still in Richmond & connected with the Newspaper Press-health not very good. James is at home, managing the farm-in good health & I hope will be a great comfort to us.

Mary Lewis also at home in pretty good health, except occasionally her nervous system becomes disordered. Frank enjoys fine health & goes to school to Miss Pringle at Mint Spring. Mary Lou is now apparently suffering nothing from her spinal affection & is going to the Augusta Female Seminary in Staunton. Dr. Humphreys & his children are well.
Wrote to Gen. Patterson & Rev. Dr. Joseph Smith.

div3.head: Jan. 2. Tues
div3.p: It began to snow in the night & continued moderately all day. I am not well. Spent the day in reading & writing.

div3.head: 3. Wed
div3.p: I am better. James took Mary Lou to Staunton. Recd. a letter from Francis with a box of good things. Reading.

div3.head: 4. Thurs
div3.p: Growing colder. This morning my head ached much. I have been reading, mostly Newspaper.

div3.head: 5. Fri
div3.p: Still unwell in the morning, & do not rise till near 9 a.m. The day so cold I could not study & hardly read.

div3.head: 6. Sat
div3.p: So unwell I could not study or read. Lay on the sofa.

div3.head: 7. Sab
div3.p: Very unwell all night. In the morning a little better. Though very unfit I went to Bethel & preached 3/4 of an hour to a pretty good Congn. The wind had changed to NE. & I suffered from cold coming home. Mrs Mish died this morning.

div3.head: 8. Mond.
div3.p: Had a bad night & asthma this morning & much indisposed all day.

This is my Birth-day-I am this day 78 years old. Alas, my health is bad. I am warned that life must soon close. This morning at 5 1/2 O'clock James left home for Richmond to seek & bring home the remains of our dear son Robert P. McFarland who fell in battle. The coldest day.

div3.head: 9. Tues
div3.p: Felt better this morning, but still indisposed. I have hired Zeke till Jeff. gets well at the rate of eight dollars per month. He began this morning.

div3.head: 10. Wed
div3.p: I am better. Sent Frank to Staunton-recd. a Telegram from James that he will be up on Friday.

div3.head: 1866. Jan. 11. Thurs
div3.p: I am suffering much with the irritation in my skin, although there is very little eruption, & it is increasing. Yesterday & today I have been taking cold & my cough is troublesome.

div3.head: 12. Fri
div3.p: I am better. Studying. Sent Zeke to Staunton with the waggon, to meet James. They reached home about 11.30 p.m. with Roberts remains. The train of Cars was detained by a Collision.

div3.head: 13. Sat
div3.p: I am tolerably well. Day mild.

Mr McPheeters & his two sons came & brought their spring waggon to convey the coffin to the graveyard. A number of our friends were assembled there, & we committed Dear Roberts remains to their permanent resting place, till the Resurrection of the Righteous. The cost of the removal was $57.00

div3.head: 14. Sab
div3.p: I am better than for several days. Preached at Bethel to a large Congn. & with some liberty-thanks to God. Had another Election for Elders-80 votes given by ballot. A.S. Sproul recd. 77. B. Mc Clung 76. James Hays 61. Wm. F. Smith 43. Jas. Beard 24 & John Lambert 22.

div3.head: Jan. 15. Mond.
div3.p: It began to snow about 10 a.m. & continued till night, 3 inches fell. Reading Newspaper. Col. R. Turk came here to dinner & staid all night.

div3.head: 16. Tues
div3.p: Col. Turk took his horse which I have had the use of gratis for about 17 months. Only Reading.

div3.head: 17. Wed
div3.p: Not very well. Mr Mat. Pilson dined with us & made us a pleasant visit. I was quite unwell in the evening & through the night.

div3.head: 18. Thurs
div3.p: Very unwell this morning-headache, did not rise till noon. Then better. Dr. Humphreys here.

div3.head: 19. Fri
div3.p: Rather better-rose at 7.45' a.m. but could only read a little till the afternoon. This morning James went with Dr. Humphreys to Staunton on his way to Tennessee.

div3.head: 20. Sat
div3.p: Mary & Frank went to Staunton to see Mary Lou. James to Greenville. I am still unwell-could not study.

div3.head: 21. Sab
div3.p: Still not well & the day very cold & the roads very rough, but I went to Bethel & preached as usual to a good Congn. for the day.

div3.head: 22. Mon
div3.p: At home. Reading. Wrote to Genl. Patterson.

div3.head: 23. Tues
div3.p: Reading & writing. I feel better.

div3.head: 24. Wed
div3.p: Last night I was distressingly nervous, & headaches. Today I am much unwell. The day very gloomy-mist is freezing on the trees & I fear will break them.

div3.head: 25. Thurs
div3.p: Reading. Recd. the 1st Weekly N.Y. Journal of Commerce of Jan. 18th No. 666.

div3.head: 26. Fri
div3.p: I am rather better than usual.

div3.head: 27. Sat
div3.p: Health as usual. Wm. F. Smith & A.F. Sproul came to confer with me about the Eldership to which they have been elected. They both seem about equally diffident & distrustful of themselves. They fear they never can pray in public. May the Lord direct them.

div3.head: 28. Sab
div3.p: Day very damp & chilling. I am better than usual. Preached at Bethel to a good Congn. & with more liberty than usual. Thanks be to God that I am still able to preach thus.

div3.head: 29. Mon
div3.p: Not quite so well. Reading. Mr James Hays came to confer with me about the Eldership to which he has been elected. He speaks of being conscious of a want of the requisite qualifications, but I hope will accept.

div3.head: 30. Tues
div3.p: In the night I was taken very unwell-oppression & headache. Did not rise till near noon. Headache all day. Mrs McF & Roxa Bent went to visit the Hays families.

div3.head: 31. Wed
div3.p: I am better. The day too cold for me to go from home. Mrs McF. & Roxa returned. I was reading.

div3.head: February 1. Thurs
div3.p: Very unwell, could not go to preach at the Funeral of Wm. Beard. A good man-a member of Bethel Church for nearly 35 years, but recently a wreck both in body & mind.

div3.head: Feb. 2. Fri
div3.p: Day cold. Bought a of Mr Jacob Brubeck for $150. on a liability of 90 days. James negotiated the purchase-I had not mentioned.

div3.head: 3. Sat
div3.p: Very cold-high west wind. Feel dull-can study but little.

div3.head: 4. Sab
div3.p: Rested badly, not well, but with fears went to Bethel and preached. Day very cold. Had very little liberty. Came home a good deal exhausted. Mary & Roxa went away for a weeks visiting.

div3.head: 5. Mon
div3.p: Morning very cold. Reading newspapers.

div3.head: 6. Tues
div3.p: A little more moderate. Reading.

div3.head: 7. Wed
div3.p: I have uncomfortable nights. Seldom sleep much before 11 O'clock-nervous & restless-eruption troublesome. After midnight I sleep better. Still eat my breakfast in bed & rise about 8 a.m. Very dull today. Reading.

div3.head: 8. Thurs
div3.p: Not so well-can read little, & hardly sit up.

div3.head: 9. Fri
div3.p: Eruption troublesome-better otherwise. James took a ton of hay, which I gave him, to Staunton & sold it for $13.00. I have been reading & studying.

div3.head: 10. Sat
div3.p: Not so well-uncomfortable nights. Studying a little.

div3.head: 11. Sab
div3.p: Better than usual for me. Day very mild-preached at Bethel to a very good Congn. with some liberty. But I read the Pastoral Letter of the Genl. Assy. twenty minutes, which exhausted me very much.

div3.head: Feb. 12. Mon
div3.p: Tolerably well. Raining early & continued to rain moderately till about 3 p.m. Sent James to Staunton to pay the tax on my land laid by the United States Government which he did, amounting to seven dollars & seventy cents $7.70.

div3.head: 13. Tues
div3.p: Day pleasant. Working. Lizzie Merritt here.

div3.head: 14. Wed
div3.p: Tolerably well, but taking cold. Reading.

div3.head: 15. Thurs
div3.p: Rested very badly till after 1 a.m. Unwell this morning. This the coldest day for two years & but one colder for 9 years. Could hardly read any-so cold.

div3.head: 16. Fri
div3.p: Very cold. Only reading. Could not study.

div3.head: 17. Sat
div3.p: Moderated a little. Mary Lewis went to Staunton to see Mary Lou, who is again afflicted-abscess discharging & her back so weak she has to lie & cannot attend school. Recd . two Letters from Genl. Patterson-one of them containing a Certificate of Deposit to my Credit for One Hundred Dollars-a generous present from himself. I thank God who put it in his heart, & pray that the Lord may reward him.

div3.head: 18. Sab
div3.p: I am very unwell with my cold-I could not have gone to Bethel; but it rained moderately all day. No Congn. I presume.

div3.head: Feb. 19. Mon
div3.p: My cold very oppressive-did not rise till 11 a.m. Burned my breast severely with Mustard. Wrote to Genl. Patterson.

div3.head: 20. Tues
div3.p: I rested & slept much better than usual. James took Mr Gilkeson's cariage to Staunton & brought home Mary & Mary Lou. The latter not so ill as expected & feared, but I doubt whether she will be able to return to school soon. I am still much indisposed with this cold.

div3.head: 21. Wed
div3.p: Had another bad night. I am not improving.
Dr. Tate here. James is complaining. We have bad news about Francis. I fear his health is hopelessly gone; but Miss Mary Tyler writes that he trusts he is a Christian. May the Lord have mercy on him.
Weaker. I am . I rose in the night & attempted to walk, but fell. From this time confined to bed.

div3.head: 22. Thurs
div3.p: I am much confined it closely to bed.
Very ill, but cannot specify.

div3.head: 25. Sab
div3.p: No better.

div3.head: 26. Mon
div3.p: I still think I am no better. Dr. Tate here. B. McClung & several kind lades here.

div3.head: 27. Tues
div3.p: a little better, but oppressed by visitors. My poor son Francis brought home almost in a dying state.

div3.head: 28. Wed
div3.p: I am a little more comfortable. Saw Francis today-looks badly but is not so ill as he was.

div3.head: 1866. March 1. Thurs
div3.p: Mild & pleasant day. Rev. J.L. Preston came to see me. I am not so well.

div3.head: 2. Fri
div3.p: Very mild. Improve very slowly. My gums are very sore-cause unknown. I am depressed this afternoon-tea revived me.

div3.head: 3. Sat
div3.p: Spent a wretched night. Tea in the morning wonderfully revived me-but feel very badly.
Rev. E. Thomas came & spent the night here.

div3.head: 4. Sab
div3.p: Rested a little better-drank toddy. Today a little more comfortable. Mr Thomas preached at Bethel. The Congn. Resd to invite a Mr Velangingham of Del to come & preach as a Candidate.
Rev. Wm. Pinkerton called to see me.

div3.head: 5. Mon
div3.p: Not quite so well-but little change.
The Box from Genl . & Mrs Patterson arrived-a valuable present containing goods, I think worth $100. & all of excellent quality. Thanks be to God as well as to kind friends.

div3.head: 6. Tues
div3.p: I am certainly better today. A.F. Humphreys here.

div3.head: 7. Wed
div3.p: Improving slowly. Dr. Tate here.

div3.head: 8. Thurs
div3.p: Better. J. Calhoon, D. Blackwood & M. Pilson here.

div3.head: 9. Fri
div3.p: Slept pretty well. Uncomfortable today.

div3.head: March 10. Sat
div3.p: Slept tolerably-in the morning not pretty well-p.m. not so well. Mrs Shray here.

div3.head: 11. Sab
div3.p: Had a restless bad night-today uncomfortable. Very slow improvement if any. Francis not so well.

div3.head: 12. Mon
div3.p: Beyond my expectation, had a good night. Today I am very variable, on the whole uncomfortable. James went to Staunton & made return to the Assessor of the Internal Revenue.

div3.head: 13. Tues
div3.p: Did not rest so well, pretty comfortable today. Emeline Sproul & Mary Pilson here. Francis as usual.

div3.head: 14. Wed
div3.p: Rested tolerably-comfortable today. Mrs Gardner Mrs Wright, Mrs Larew, miss L. Hayden & Dr. Tate here. Francis stronger-walked to the kitchen today.

div3.head: 15. Thurs
div3.p: A little stronger. Wm. J. Gilkeson here. Mr Towberman came to collect taxes = mine & James' amounted to $13.50

div3.head: 16. Fri
div3.p: Spent a very uncomfortable night, today better, but not very well. Sowed oats in the NW field.

div3.head: 17. Sat
div3.p: Nervous & restless last night-today not comfortable. A marvelous & sudden & extreme change in temperature.

div3.head: 18. Sab
div3.p: Slept pretty well-feel dull. Only James went to Bethel-Prayer meeting. Francis about the same.

div3.head: 19. Mon
div3.p: Spent a wretched night. Today uncomfortable. My meals are followed by much discomfort.

div3.head: 1866. March 20. Tues
div3.p: Slept better-more comfortable today. Moderate showers. Francis better.

div3.head: 21. Wed
div3.p: A restless night-morning uncomfortable, afternoon better. Dr. Tate, Mrs Gilkeson & J. Shields here. Francis I fear is declining.

div3.head: 22. Thurs
div3.p: Slept pretty well. Rose at 11 a.m. & put on my clothes for the first time in 4 weeks, remained up till 2 p.m. but came to bed in a state of excessive exhaustion. Francis comfortable. James went to Staunton.

div3.head: 23. Fri
div3.p: Last night rose to have my bed made & sat say 10 minutes, & came to bed in a state of great exhaustion, which continued most of the night. Today not as strong as yesterday. Francis quiet.

div3.head: 24. Sat
div3.p: I am better-sat up half an hour, but did not put on my clothes. Walked several times around the room. Francis lies mostly in bed, as he is more comfortable there.

div3.head: 25. Sab
div3.p: Rested pretty well & am comfortable. Day Cold. Rev. Wm. Pinkerton preached at Bethel to a full house.
They held a Congregational Meeting & instructed the Session to invite some minister to come & preach to them, with the view of calling a Co-Pastor.

div3.head: March 26. Mon
div3.p: I am comfortable, appetite good, but I gain strength very slowly. I was up 1 1/2 hours. Mr Pilson came to see me. Francis rather worse.

div3.head: 27. Tues
div3.p: I am better, up from 1 p.m. to 6-went in to see Francis-he seems comfortable-many visitors.

div3.head: 28. Wed
div3.p: Still improving-rose at 12 M. & up till 5 p.m.

div3.head: 29. Thurs
div3.p: Not quite so comfortable. Rose at 10 1/2 a.m. up till 6 p.m. Francis tolerably comfortable. Mrs Henderson here.

div3.head: 30. Fri
div3.p: Slept well-rose at 9 a.m. up till 8 p.m. Mr See preached at Bethel today, & spent the night here. Brainard McClung & James Wallace also here.

div3.head: 31. Sat
div3.p: Rested badly from the irritation in my skin. Mr See preached again today, Mr Preston there. Francis not so well-suffers much from laborious breathing, which he thinks is asthma-very doubtful.

div3.head: April 1. Sab
div3.p: This is the Communion Sab in Bethel. It was the Lord's will that I should not be there. Rev. Mr Preston conducted the services. There was a large Congn. & I trust Christians enjoyed it. Margaret Ann Gardner, dughter of Alexr. G. the only addition.

div3.head: 2. Mon
div3.p: Rested better, but my strength increases but little. I think Francis is still declining.

div3.head: 1866. April 3. Tues
div3.p: Slept pretty well. Today I thought I was able to clean the Clock in my study, which has not been going for near two months & I felt the want of it very much. I succeeded in cleaning it. Francis more comfortable today. Dr. Tate here. Capt Jener called.

div3.head: 4. Wed
div3.p: Better. On yesterday & today dined with my family for the first time for many weeks. Rose & kindled my fire. Francis is weaker but more comfortable today.

div3.head: 5. Thurs
div3.p: I rose & made my fire a little after sunrise and ate my Breakfast out of be for the first time, at home, for several months. Francis is better-was out on the front porch this evening.

div3.head: 6. Fri
div3.p: I was not so comfortable this morning, but better through the day. Francis not so well.

div3.head: 7. Sat
div3.p: As there was a NE rain & much cooler, I felt dull all day, but not unwell. Francis in bed all day.

div3.head: 8. Sab
div3.p: I had hoped to have preached at Bethel today, but the weather was such I could not go-James went & found but three persons there. I feel pretty well, but dull. Francis not so well-suffers strangely with paroxisms of laborious breathing-they come on & go off without any apparent cause-lasting from a half to 3 or 4 hours.

div3.head: Apl. 9. Mon
div3.p: I am pretty comfortable-rose a little after 6 a.m. & ate breakfast with my family for the time for 3 or 4 months. Rev. E. Junkin dined with us & made us a very pleasant visit.
Francis had a bad spill today & is quite unwell.

div3.head: 10. Tues
div3.p: I continue weak, but my health is pretty good. Francis is pretty comfortable, but seems weaker.

div3.head: 11. Wed
div3.p: Rose at 6 a.m. Up till 9 p.m. My limbs at times weak. No change on Francis of any importance.

div3.head: 12. Thurs
div3.p: Up all day. Reading. Francis better.

div3.head: 13. Fri
div3.p: Could not study. Francis better than since he came home. James & Roxa went to Staunton.

div3.head: 14. Sat
div3.p: Finished harrowing for corn. I was studying. Francis not quite so well. A fine shower.

div3.head: 15. Sab
div3.p: I am not so well. I went to Bethel expecting to preach, but found Mr Thomas there, who had kindly come to preach for me, & did preach. I came home fatigued with the ride. Francis pretty comfortable.

div3.head: 16. Mon
div3.p: Very unwell-took cold yesterday. Mr Pilson here on Congregational business. Francis tolerable.

div3.head: 17. Tues
div3.p: Last night was one of the most afflictive of my life. Coughed very hard & almost incessantly & slept very little. I am better today, but in bed all day. Francis better.

div3.head: 1866. Apl. 18th Wed
div3.p: Today the Presbytery meets in Waynesboro. If I were more tolerably well I could not go on account of the state of the weather. I rose between 9 & 10 O'clock, but feel so unwell had to go to bed again.

div3.head: 19. Thurs
div3.p: I rested tolerably, but felt so unwell after Breakfast I did not rise till 4 p.m. then better, but very weak. Mrs McFarland who has been very unwell with a cold for several days is better. Francis as usual.

div3.head: 20. Fri
div3.p: Had much prostration-continued in bed all day. I fear my strength will return very slowly.
James & Jeff. went to Staunton with a load of hay. Charley here making rails.

div3.head: 21. Sat
div3.p: No better-sent for Dr. Tate, did not come-in the afternoon better-in bed all day.

div3.head: 22. Sab
div3.p: A little Better-Dr. Tate came & prescribed. I remained in bed all day. Dr. Wm. Brown preached at Bethel & came here to dinner with Mr Pilson I learn Francis is very low spirited today.

div3.head: 23. Mon
div3.p: Not quite so well-cough very troublesome. Dr. Brown's visit was very pleasant to me indeed. James took him to Grenville & Mr Pilson to Mr Morrison's Francis is more comfortable today.

div3.head: April 24. Mon
div3.p: I am not so comfortable. I had hoped, if it was warm today, to have gotten out of bed some hours but have been disappointed. My strength is increasing. Francis more uneasy.
My daughter Mary today recd. very kind letter from Rev. Peyton Harrison enclosing a Check for $50. This was a very kind providence to her.

div3.head: 25. Tues
div3.p: I am no better could not sit up any time. Francis more unwell. Mrs McFarland still unwell. About 4 p.m. while lying quietly in bed I was seized with a severe pain in the small of my back.

div3.head: 26. Wed
div3.p: The pain in my back severe-not well otherwise. Mrs McFarland suffers much with neuralgia in her head through the day. Francis better today.

div3.head: 27. Thurs
div3.p: My back no better. Rose at 10 a.m. & up till 6 1/2 p.m. Mrs McFarland better-taking Quinine. Francis better. Mr David Kunkle & wife made us a pleasant visit.

div3.head: 28. Fri
div3.p: I spent an uncomfortable night from a feeling of sickness & oppression. Today better-rose at 10 1/2 a.m. & up till 6 1/2 p.m. Mrs McFarland & Francis better. Planted Corn in the Springhouse Field.

div3.head: 1866. April 19. Sat
div3.p: Rested better-pain in my back a little better. Four of the family went to Bethel-no preaching, prayer-meeting. The Session have written for a Mr Flournoy to come & preach to the congregation for some time.

div3.head: 30. Sab
div3.p: I rested well & felt better & rose at 8 a.m. but my back becomes painful sitting up, & I feel quite languid. Mrs McFarland not so well. Francis not so well.

div3.head: May 1. Tues
div3.p: I am pretty comfortable except my back which is no better. Mrs McFarland still suffering. Francis rather better.
Planting corn beyond the Creek. Mr Nutter & son helping.

div3.head: 2. Wed
div3.p: Last night I applied Cloriform to my back in hopes of relieving the pain, but it produced distressing effects on my head, I rather think through the Spinal Column. It continued till about midnight. This morning feel very badly so that I did not rise till 2 p.m. Mrs McF. & Francis better.
Planted our late Potatos in the lower end of the meadow.

div3.head: May 3d. Thurs
div3.p: I am not well-my head uncomfortable. Did not rise till 2 p.m. then better. Lat evening F. McF. Swoope came here & staid all night. He proved to be very much deranged & gave us a great deal of trouble.

James went to Staunton to see the agent of the Freedman's Bureau about a Complaint that Rhoda had lodged there that she had been hired to me for two years after she had been made free by the will of her mistress & had recd. no compensation. When the facts were stated there was no difficulty.

div3.head: 4. Fri
div3.p: I am about as yesterday. Mrs McF. better Francis still very feeble.
A Box of valuable articles, chiefly dry goods, left from the fair in Baltimore was recd. through Mrs Dr. Brown-principally for Mary Lewis.

div3.head: 5. Sat
div3.p: This morning very weak-rose at 11 a.m. better Francis still very feeble & suffering.

div3.head: 6. Sab
div3.p: Not able to go to Bethel. Mr Flournoy preached, as I learn, acceptably. I am better today-so is Mrs McF. Francis is worse-sat up on an easy chair all last night.

div3.head: 1866. May 7. Mon
div3.p: I am rather stronger. Mrs McF. better. Francis not much easier. Mr Pilson brought Mr Flournoy to see us. He seems to be a modest pleasant young man. Rev. J.S. Blain came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 8. Tues
div3.p: A little better-rode out a little way.

div3.head: 9. Wed
div3.p: I am comfortable. Mrs McF. pretty well. Francis very changeable.

div3.head: 10. Thurs
div3.p: As yesterday, myself & family.

div3.head: 11. Fri
div3.p: Very dull. The weather cloudy & damp.
Mr Donahue came to take a list of taxable property.

div3.head: 12. Sat
div3.p: I am not improving-very feeble-have to lie on the sofa much of my time.

div3.head: 13. Sab
div3.p: Not so well-did not rise till 11 a.m. then better. All went to Bethel but Mary & I. Mr Flournoy preached very well, it is said. Francis rather better.

div3.head: 14. Mon
div3.p: No marked change in any of us. Mr Flournoy dined with us. Chris. & Lizzie Merritt here.

div3.head: 15. Tues
div3.p: I am better-rode out. Francis still better.

div3.head: 16. Wed
div3.p: I am stronger-Francis still better.

div3.head: 17. Thurs
div3.p: No change worthy of note. Wrote to Rev. P. Harrison.

div3.head: May 18th. Fri
div3.p: Wrote to Wm. C. Patterson-rode to Mrs Wright's & took supper there-in the evening not so well. Francis weaker from laborious breathing. My ride was followed by a restless suffering night.

div3.head: 19. Sat
div3.p: Unwell & quite weak-my unfortunate visit has disquieted me for everything. James & Mary went to Staunton.

div3.head: 20. Sab
div3.p: Very unwell this morning-much disappointed that I could not go to Bethel-continued unwell all day.
Roxa, Mary & James went to Bethel. Mr Flournoy preached.

div3.head: 21. Mon
div3.p: I am better today. Francis seems better. Mrs McF. pretty well. Mrs King & Mrs Larew here.

div3.head: 22. Tues
div3.p: Still I think slowly improving. Francis about as yesterday. Replanting corn. Allen & his boys making rails (oak) at 50 cents per hundred. Made 550 in two days.

div3.head: 23. Wed
div3.p: Mr Flournoy spent last night with us. I am about as usual. Francis had a Chill-not so well.

div3.head: 24. Thurs
div3.p: James went to Fishervill to get a saddle made. Frank took Mary Lou to Staunton. No change with the sick.

div3.head: 25. Fri
div3.p: I am as usual. Francis not so well. Mr Shuey & Mr Wayland came to see us. A good rain in the evening. Broke a waggon wheel-sent it to Greenville.

div3.head: 1866. May 26. Sat
div3.p: I am as usual-Francis better. Have had last night & this morning a very fine rain.

div3.head: 27. Sab
div3.p: Went to Bethel-heard Mr. Flournoy preach a very good sermon from Eph. 1:15 to 23. He has now preached 4 Sabs . A Congregational meeting was held at which I was called to preside, they voted to pay him 1/12 of $550, the salary paid to me heretofore, & a collection & subscription was taken for that purpose. Then after his necessary absence of a month they voted to invite him to return & preach six months & that his compensation for that time shall be $300. to be raised by subscription. I came home not very much fatigued.

div3.head: 28. Mon
div3.p: All about as usual. James & Roxa went to Staunton.

div3.head: 29. Tues
div3.p: All pretty well, but Francis is not so well.

div3.head: 30. Wed
div3.p: Wrote to Dr. Wm Brown. Francis rather worse.

div3.head: 31. Thurs
div3.p: Francis better-rode out-then worse. Dr. Tate here.

div3.head: June 1. Fri
div3.p: All as usual. Fr. rode out. Worse in the night. Right hind wheel of the Waggon filled with new hib & spoke, $5.

div3.head: 2. Sat
div3.p: I am pretty well-Francis not so well.

div3.head: 3. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel the first time for nearly four months succeeded better than I expected, but much fatigued.
A Mr Anderson from Lewisburg there. Francis rode out on horseback.

div3.head: June 4. Mon
div3.p: More sick. Francis seemed to be much better this morning & rode to the springhouse on horseback. In the evening had most laborious breathing I have seen.

div3.head: 5. Tues
div3.p: Francis rested pretty well & today is better-rode out again. Mary is better. My stomach feels badly every morning.

div3.head: 6. Wed
div3.p: All about as usual. James went to Fisherville for a new Saddle made there by Hall which cost $14. but the tree was found.

div3.head: 7. Thurs
div3.p: I am not so well. Francis as usual. Mr & Mrs Kunkle & Mr Pilson here.

div3.head: 8. Fri
div3.p: Francis & I are both better today. James went to Staunton for whiskey for Francis-has used 2 quarts in 11 days.

div3.head: 9. Sat
div3.p: I am as usual. Francis very changeable.

div3.head: 10. Sab
div3.p: I feel weak. Preached at Bethel to a large Congn. a special discourse on a Call to the Eldership to induce our four Elders-elect to accept of the Office. Not very much fatigued. Francis suffers much with fits of laborious breathing.

div3.head: 11. Mon
div3.p: I am pretty well. Francis as yesterday.

div3.head: 12. Tues
div3.p: All as usual. Francis had a fit of extreme Dysproea.

div3.head: 13. Wed
div3.p: I am pretty well, but feel great debility. James working on the Road. Francis as usual.

div3.head: 1866. June 14. Thurs
div3.p: Pretty well-rose to breakfast the first time for several months. In the evening I married Lewis Johns & Martha Ann Harris, Coloured persons, who came here to be married.

div3.head: 15. Fri
div3.p: Pretty well-breakfast with the family. Francis better-he rode to Geo. Rosen's & dined there.

div3.head: 16. Sat
div3.p: All as usual. Mrs McFarland & James went to Staunton. James got 2 qts. more of whiskey for Francis. He has used the last 2 qts. in about 8 days.

div3.head: 17. Sab
div3.p: My bowels were so disordered that I could not have gone to But about 8 a.m. it began to rain & continued so that I presume there was no one at church. James went to Hebron where the Lord's supper was to be administered.
Francis suffers so in bed with pain his shoulder that he slept on his chair last night till 1.30' a.m. & rose early. I took my breakfast in bed. In the afternoon took Oil.

div3.head: 18. Mon
div3.p: I am better, but breakfasted in bed. Spent the day in reading-mostly Newspapers. Francis sat up all last night-the pain he suffers hakes him fear to lie down.

div3.head: 19. Tues
div3.p: I am pretty well-began to record the minutes of Synod. Francis is bed all night, better-dined at Mr McPheeters'. Dr. Humphreys & his children came here today.

div3.head: June 20th Wed
div3.p: Rested badly-have taken some cold. Better this afternoon. Francis as usual. James went to Staunton. Dr Humphreys & his children left us.

div3.head: 21. Thurs
div3.p: I have a troublesome cold did not rest well, breakfasted in bed. Francis rode to Mr Gilkesons & dined there, but suffered much in the evening, I think in consequence-pain & foot swelled.

div3.head: 22. Fri
div3.p: I am as yesterday. Francis not so well, did not ride out, right leg & foot much swelled.

div3.head: 23. Sat
div3.p: I am better. Francis better.

div3.head: 24. Sab
div3.p: Preached at Bethel over an hour to a rather thin Congn. I am pretty well. Francis foot much swoolen. Dr. Humphreys here.

div3.head: 25. Mon
div3.p: As usual. James went to Deerfield. Dr. Humphreys remained & he & Francis dined at Mr McPheeters.
Sold the Miss Heydens 21 1/2 lbs of wool at 40 cents per lb.

div3.head: 26. Tues
div3.p: I am pretty well-day very warm. Dr. Humphreys left us. Francis rather worse, suffers with swollen legs & feet. James returned from Deerfield.

div3.head: 27. Wed
div3.p: Francis better. I have been all day occupied reading the proceedings of the Old School Genl. Assembly at St. Louis. It is a mournful exhibition of Radicalism & usurpation of power, very much resembling the U. States Congress.

div3.head: 1866. June 28th. Thurs
div3.p: All as usual. Reading. Wrote to Frederick Johnston. W.W. Trimble and Dr. J.B. Ramsey as Treasr of Pbys. for money.

div3.head: 29. Fri
div3.p: All pretty comfortable. I dined at Jas. Bumgardner's and visited Mrs Brawford, who I fear is far gone in Consumption. She is a good woman.

div3.head: 30. Sat
div3.p: I am not well, suffered with cramp in my legs & headache, which continued all day. Could do nothing.

div3.head: July 1. Sab
div3.p: Still unwell, but went to Bethel, & would have preached, but Mr Flournoy having returned, he preached about the Brazen Serpent. I was better.

div3.head: 2. Mon
div3.p: Had asthma. Reading & working. Began to cut wheat in the Orchard, Mr Flournoy here.

div3.head: 3. Tues
div3.p: Very feeble-asthma. Cutting wheat NW field, Jas. Jef. & Frank.

div3.head: 4. Wed
div3.p: Very unwell this morning-did not rise till 1 p.m. Yesterday & today Francis much worse than usual. Cutting wheat in the Orchard.

div3.head: 5. Thurs
div3.p: I am better. Francis had a bad night & day. Finished cutting wheat in the orchard.

div3.head: 6. Fri
div3.p: Suffered great debility this morning, in the afternoon better. Francis rode out on horseback. Still cutting wheat in the N.W. field.

div3.head: July 7. Sat
div3.p: The heat oppressive. I feel much debility. Cutting wheat. Francis occasionally suffers much. He has drank 1 1/2 Galls. of whiskey in precisely 3 weeks. Got another Gallon this evening Cost $4.00

div3.head: 8. Sab
div3.p: Still very feeble, but went to Bethel intending to preach, but Rev. Archd. Scott from Paris, Ky, Grandson to Rev. Archd. Scott, the first Pastor of Bethel was there & preached a good sermon from Prov. 14:9, Fools make a mock at sin. He & his sister dined with us. Francis suffering great pain.
I am rather stronger. Francis weaker than for weeks. Cutting wheat. A fine rain which was much needed.

div3.head: 10. Tues
div3.p: Rained all day. Sent for Dr. Tate to see Frank Lewis, who seems to have a bileous attack-he came & prescribed. Francis suffered extreme pain today.

div3.head: 11. Wed
div3.p: I am better; Francis worse. James went to Staunton. Sold 21 lbs of Butter at 20 cents & bought 9 lbs Coffee at 35 cents

div3.head: 12. Thurs
div3.p: Pretty well-Francis as usual. Recd. & ansd. a letter from Rev. W.W. Tremble. Mrs Wright, Polly Larew & Jacob Larew here.

div3.head: 13. Fri
div3.p: I am Pretty well. Francis not so well. I went to Greenville to see Wm. F. Smith about the Eldership, his acceptance of the office is very doubtful. I am fatigued. Hauling in

div3.head: 1866. July 14. Sat
div3.p: I am pretty well. Francis had a very sick suffering day. Dr. Tate & Dr. Humphreys here. Hauled in nearly all our wheat.

div3.head: 15. Sab
div3.p: Went to Bethel. Rev. Mr Lambeth (Methodist) preached. Francis had a bad day-is declining fast. Mary and James staid with Francis. The heat very oppressive.

div3.head: 16. Mon
div3.p: Francis suffers much pain, is then feeling more comfortable. Mr Flournoy & Mrs Pilson spent the day here. Rev. James Humphreys & son & nephew came & spent the night with us. Finished hauling in wheat have about 204 Dozens. Began to cut oats.

div3.head: 17. Tues
div3.p: I am pretty well, but debilitated by heat. Francis no better. Finished cutting Oats. A shower. Got another gallon of whiskey for Francis-the Doctors recommend the free use of it, but I decidedly disapprove of it. The effects of the stimulus is very perceptible.

div3.head: 18. Wed
div3.p: Heat not so oppressive. Francis suffers intensely at times. Hands binding Oats, and Robert McPheeters snowing the meadow with his Mower.

div3.head: 19. Thurs
div3.p: Francis still suffering greatly. I am comfortable. Hauling in Oats. Mr Flournoy spent last night here. James Patterson has been here since Tuesday.

div3.head: July 20. Fri
div3.p: Last night we expected poor Francis to die, but he survived through tremendous sufferings. Today his sufferings are very great, with some intervals of comparative ease, but I regard him as dying. I am so feeble I cannot sit up all the time. Numbers of neighbours here.

div3.head: 21. Sat
