div3.p: This is a sorrowful day. My poor son Francis has been lingering on the borders of the dark valley till at 4 O'clock P.M. he expired. His sufferings for many week have been often agonizing-they were less so at the last. What a tide of reflection rush through my mind embracing the whole history of the deceased. What numerous anxieties about him from his birth, what care, what watchfulness, what labour & expense & how many anxious prayers. And now the whole is closed up for the Judgment.

I deeply regret that he was so influenced as to join the Campbell Church in Richmond, & yet I think he gave good evidence of saving Faith in the Lord Jesus Christ. His uncomplaining patience was remarkable.

div3.head: 1866. July 22. Sab
div3.p: This is a sorrowful Sabbath. The body of my poor Son lies uncoffined till one is made. I went to Bethel. Rev. James Humphreys preached a short sermon, he was not well. Mr Flournoy there. I did not go into the pulpit.

div3.head: 23. Mon
div3.p: The body of Francis was undergoing rapid decomposition & was very offensive. The coffin came & a very large procession proceeded to Bethel where a great Congn. was assembled. Rev. Mr Preston made the first prayer-a very excellent one. Mr Flournoy preached from Is. 45:15 to 17-a respectable discourse, but not as impressive as I could have wished. The body was then buried in the presence of a large number of people. I feel grateful to God that we have so many friends; & to those kind friends who have rendered many acceptable services to us.

Out of Eight children we have but two left. But, blessed be God, those which have died in mature years have given us good hopes of their interest in Christ. I, in all human probability, will go next. God grant that I many be enabled, in life & in death, to glorify & enjoy him, & glorify him eternally in heaven.

div3.head: July 24. Tues
div3.p: I am tolerably well as all the family are, thanks be to God. It seems wonderfully still, after the company we have had daily for months. They are hauling in hay.

div3.head: 25. Wed
div3.p: Reading & working. Two heavy Showers.

div3.head: 26. Thurs
div3.p: Working & Studying. Hauled in 2 loads of hay.

div3.head: 27. Fri
div3.p: James took Mary's Rockaway to Staunton for repairs. I am pretty well. Rained much last night. Hay in cock too wet to put in.

div3.head: 28. Sat
div3.p: Studying. Feel dull. Not a hay-day.

div3.head: 29. Sab
div3.p: Very unwell this morning-better after breakfast. Preached at Bethel to a good Congn. Prepn . Sabbath.

div3.head: 30. Mon
div3.p: Again breakfasted in bed. Working & reading.

div3.head: 31. Tues
div3.p: I have been unwell all day-taking cold. Could not sit up much or read. James went to Staunton for the Rockaway.

div3.head: August 1. Wed
div3.p: I rested better last night & am better today. Finished hauling in hay-the end of harvest.

div3.head: 2. Thur.
div3.p: A more unwell-did not rise till 10 a.m. Can do nothing.

div3.head: 3. Fri
div3.p: A little better-rose at 8 a.m. James &c. mending our road.

div3.head: 4. Sat
div3.p: Very unwell, but went to Bethel, & moderated the session. Received Francis Walton Lewis, my grandson, into the Communion of the Church. Thanks be to God.

div3.head: Aug. 4th 1866. Sat (continued)
div3.p: This the day before the Communion. Mr Flournoy preached very well. I Ordained three Elders-Benjamin F. McClung, James Hays and Archibald F. Sproul, with the imposition of hands. They were elected Jan. 14th last. Mr Flournoy went to get the aid of Mr. Preston on tomorrow, but he could not come. Mr F. returned here and spent the night.

div3.head: 5. Sab
div3.p: Went to Bethel, though very unwell. Mr Flournoy preached well on Mat. I took the whole communion service, and blessed be God, he strengthened me & enabled me to conduct in some good degree acceptably. Came home much fatigued.

div3.head: 6. Mon
div3.p: I rested tolerably well & am better than for several days. Working & Reading. Mrs Paxton &c here.

div3.head: 7. Tues
div3.p: Very unwell-did not rise till 10 1/2 a.m. then better. Reading a little. Betsey Blackwood & Mrs Wm. Swink spent the day here.

div3.head: 8. Wed
div3.p: I am better. Working & reading.

div3.head: 9. Thurs
div3.p: Not so well. Sent Roxa D. Bent to Staunton on her way home to Winchester. I gave her $9.00 to pay her stage fare &c. She has been a kind & faithful friend in our trouble. has been here nine months.
She has been here nine Months today.

div3.head: 10. Fri
div3.p: Had a very uncomfortable night with headache. This morning very unwell. Very weak today.

div3.head: 11. Sat
div3.p: A little better. Reading & studying a little.

div3.head: 12. Sab
div3.p: Felt great debility, but went to Bethel and preached 45 minutes with a degree of energy that I did not think I was capable of. Came home very much fatigued.

div3.head: 13. Mon
div3.p: Spent a night of extreme exhaustion-better today. Mary went to Mr Pilson's Rev. Mr Golzendaner here.

div3.head: 14. Tues
div3.p: I had a better night but feel great debility today. Could only read a little. Lay much on the Sofa.

div3.head: 15. Wed
div3.p: Very unwell after breakfast. Reading & working. James went to the Baptist association at Goshen.

div3.head: 16. Thurs
div3.p: I am still very feeble-can do nothing but read. Rev. J.S. Blain spent last night with us.

div3.head: 17. Fri
div3.p: I am rather better. Reading & writing with us.

div3.head: 18. Sat
div3.p: About as yesterday. Wrote to Dr. B.M. Smith, Dr. Brown Gen. Patterson & James Patrick. A good Shower.

div3.head: 19. Sab
div3.p: Spent an uncomfortable night-too unwell to go to Bethel-unwell all day. Mr Flournoy preached-he & Brainard McClung dined here. Mr F. going to Hampden Sidney expecting to be married.

div3.head: 1866. Aug. 20. Mon
div3.p: I rested rather better last night. But today I am by no means well-very weak.

div3.head: 21. Tues
div3.p: Had a bad night & very unwell today-in bed all day. Head & stomach disordered. John Plunkett whitewashing yesterday & today.

div3.head: 22. Wed
div3.p: The early part of last night better but worse in the morning-took out very weak. I rested all day. Plunkett still here whitewashing. James returned.

div3.head: 23. Thurs
div3.p: Rather better, but in bed all day. Plunkett still here.

div3.head: 24. Fri
div3.p: Very unwell the early part of last night. This morning better. At 3 p.m. rose & dressed myself-the first time since Monday. John Plunkett finished whitewashing. He charges $2.50 per day when he uses his own brush. He did this work in payment of a Barrel of Flour got more than a year ago.

div3.head: 25. Sat
div3.p: Sitting up yesterday fatigued me so that I spent a very uncomfortable night & today too unwell to rise. In bed all day. Weather cool and dry.

div3.head: 26. Sab
div3.p: No better-in bed all day. Suffer from a sense of sickness after eating. No preaching at Bethel. Alas.

div3.head: 27. Mon
div3.p: Spent a restless wakeful night-very unwell this morning, then better. Dr. Tate came to see me. Hauling manure on the Orchard.

div3.head: Aug. 28th Tues
div3.p: Took a blue pill at night & in the morning. Had a restless night & today more comfortable. Still confined to bed. James & Mary went to Staunton sent my letter to Genl. Patterson. Dr. Humphreys came to see me.

div3.head: 29. Wed
div3.p: I am better today than for a week, I think, but still in bed. Sat in a chair 15 or 20 minutes. My appetite is good. Weakness my chief complaint.

div3.head: 30. Thurs
div3.p: Not so well. Mr Humphreys, Mr Blackwood & Mr McPheeters came to see me. Took Blue mass.

div3.head: 31. Fri
div3.p: Rested pretty well-took oil-did well. Better. At 3 p.m. rose & dressed-up till 6.

div3.head: September 1. Sat
div3.p: Rested pretty well, but quite unwell after breakfast, could not rise till 4.35' p.m. up till 8.35' We had Mr Plecker's eight-horse threshing Machine taking out our wheat & oats. Wheat 128 lbs. needing farther cleaning. Oats 104 Bs. J. Wright, Nutty, Weaver & Allen's Son for Lou. Johns helping.

div3.head: 2. Sab
div3.p: I am as usual. Rose at 12 M. up 4 hours. Mrs McF. remained at home with me. Others went to Bethel. Mr Flournoy preached.

div3.head: 1866. September 3. Mon
div3.p: I rested better than usual. Rose at 11 a.m. up 6 1/2 hours. Mr Flournoy came to see me.

div3.head: 4. Tues
div3.p: Rose at 9 a.m. up till night. Strength increasing.

div3.head: 5. Wed
div3.p: Rose at 8.15' a.m. sick after breakfast. Up till 8 p.m. Finished plowing the NW field.

div3.head: 6. Thurs
div3.p: Did not rest so well. Unwell this morning, did not rise till 11.30', rather better. Up till 8.30' p.m. Took Blue pill-continue bileous.

div3.head: 7. Fri
div3.p: Took Oil, it did well, but I was sick all the morning. Rose about noon, but could sit up but little.

div3.head: 8. Sat
div3.p: Very unwell this morning-rose at 10 a.m. My pulse intermitted more this morning than I ever knew it before-sometimes every other beat. In the afternoon much better. Up till 8.30' p.m.

div3.head: 9. Sab
div3.p: Rested pretty well-rose at 8.30' a.m. up till 7.45' p.m. All the white family went to Bethel. Mr Flournoy they said preached well.

div3.head: 10. Mon
div3.p: Rode around the meadow-the first time I have out of the yard for a month. Mrs McFarland went to see Mr Gilkeson who is ill with Pneumonia. Mr & Mrs Flournoy spent the night with us.

div3.head: Sept. 11.
div3.p: I had a pretty good night. rose at 8.15' Mr Pilson came to see me & presented me $55.00 to purchase me a suit of clothes if I choose so to use it, being $5.00 from M. Pilson, R.T. Wallace, John T. Shields, D.A. Trite, John Merritt John M. Tate, A.S. Sproul, Wm F. Smith, John Mc Clure, F.M. Gilkeson & David Kunkle.

div3.head: 12. Wed
div3.p: I rested pretty well-when I woke, was as well as usual. After Mrs McF. rose I fell asleep & slept 15 or 20 minutes & when I awoke I was very unwell-pulse very irregular & a great sense of oppression. I continued unwell all day & did not rise till 5 p.m. & still feeling badly.

div3.head: 13. Thurs
div3.p: I rested tolerably well, and am much better today, especially in the afternoon.

div3.head: 14. Fri
div3.p: I continue better. Went in my Buggy to see Mr Wm. J. Gilkeson & spent the afternoon there. This the first day I have felt able to ride so far. Finished seeding the NW field. Sowed on it 17 Bs. of wheat.

div3.head: 15. Sat
div3.p: I rested as well as usual but have been sick all day. Sowed 3 Bs. of wheat on the lot N. of the house.

div3.head: 16. Sab
div3.p: Rested tolerably well. With anxiety went to Bethel & stood it better than expected though I came home much fatigued. Mr Flournoy preached.

div3.head: 17. Mon
div3.p: I rested pretty well, but am not as well as usual today. Can hardly read or write any. Sarah Bragg came here.

div3.head: 18. Tues
div3.p: Not well in the morning, but better in the afternoon.

div3.head: 19. Wed
div3.p: I am better. The Presby of Lexington meet at Bethel. I attended all day. Rev. Wm. G. Campbell preached the opening serMon Rev. Bell was elected Moderator. Rev. Messrs. Baker & Buffner & Mrs E.H. Brown came home with us.

div3.head: 20. Thurs
div3.p: Attended Pby. all day. Mr See preached. Dr. White Mr Campbell S. Brown & Mr Daniel Blain came home with us.

Attended Presby . all day. Mr Houston preached his trial Sermon & was ordained. I made the prayer at the Ordination. Dr. Bowman, John R. Bowman Mr Bell, Mr Hogshead & Dr. Humphreys here-also Mrs E.H. Brown, suffered less than I expected.

div3.head: 22. Sat
div3.p: Felt very unwell through the night & this morning. I attended Pby all day,-attended the meeting of Session.

div3.head: Sept. 22. Sat continued.
div3.p: Recd. Bettie P. Graham on Examn . & David Kunkle & Sallie Kunkle on Certificate from Hebron. Mr Junkin preached an excellent SerMon

div3.head: 23. Sab
div3.p: Went to Bethel. Rev. Mr Bell preached a good & an impressive Sermon from John 3:16. Dr. F. Bowman introduced the Communion Service-Rev. S. Brown made the prayer & distributed the Bread. Dr. White distributed the Cup & returned thanks. Mr John Pike Bowman made the closing address to non-communicants. Thanks be to God the whole meeting has been a pleasant one, no uncomfortable jars.

Rev. E. Thomas came home with us & Squire Montgomery & his sister Mrs Gleady & her daughter, & Mr Bell & Mrs Lockridge from Mt Solon. Mary Guy & Mr Irvine & A. Bratton & Sarah Bragg-ten persons & seven horses.

div3.head: 24. Mond.
div3.p: Had Asthma worse than for a long season, felt badly this morning-could not go to Breakfast nor worship, poorly all day. Our company all left us. James took Sarah Bragg home.

div3.head: 25. Tues
div3.p: I am rather better. Mrs McFarland & I visited Mr Wm. J. Gilkeson who has been worse but is better today.

div3.head: 1866. Sept. 26. Wed
div3.p: I am much improved today.

div3.head: 27. Thurs
div3.p: About as yesterday can scarcely read.

div3.head: 28. Fri
div3.p: Still find my food produces sick stomach, and unfits me for everything.
Sowed ten Bushels of wheat in the Orchard today.

div3.head: 29. Sat
div3.p: [entire sentence illegible] Near noon a genuine NE. Storm commenced-the Equinoctial, I suppose.

div3.head: 30. Sab
div3.p: Weather as yesterday. Did not rise till 3 p.m. feel more debility as usual-all went to Bethel but Mary Lou & I.

div3.head: October 1. Mon
div3.p: I am better than usual-rose at 8.15'. Mrs McFarland went to see widow Hays & Mrs Brawford I copied some Minutes of Synod. Day Cloudy, but fair.

div3.head: 2. Tues
div3.p: I rested pretty well. Mrs McFarland spent the night at Mr Brawford's. I continue better. Continued to copy minutes of Synod.

div3.head: 3. Wed
div3.p: I spent an uncomfortable night, a sense of oppression & my head disordered. Did not rise till after noon. Mr Pilson dined with us. Mrs McFarland & I went to see Mr Gilkeson-he is much worse & I fear he will not recover.

div3.head: October 4. Thurs
div3.p: I am better. James brought home a Bullcalf, which he got in exchange from Col. Turk. It is said to be most object.

div3.head: 5. Fri
div3.p: A little better. Wrote to Dr. Wm Brown & to Gen. R. Patterson.

div3.head: 6. Sat
div3.p: I rested pretty well, but after eating my breakfast in bed I became so sick I could not rise till near 11 O'clock. Still feel very weak.

div3.head: 7. Sab
div3.p: Did not rest well till after Midnight. All the white family went to Bethel. I felt so weak I took no part. Came home much fatigued, but Mr Gilkeson is so low I went to see him. I am greatly exhausted. Mr Flournoy preached.

div3.head: 8. Mon
div3.p: I spent an uncomfortable night-a dull pain in my breast, induced I think by the jolting of the Buggy, has made & kept me very restless. I did not rise till 10 a.m. and then no better. At 4 p.m. went to bed to apply mustard to my breast. James set off for McDowell before day to bring home our steers.
At 6 O'clock P.M. my excellent friend. Wm. J. Gilkeson died. Alas, he was one of my best & unwavering friends. I had great confidence in his piety.

div3.head: 1866. October 9. Tuesday.
div3.p: I am now satisfied that the pain & soreness in my breast is from cold taken in church on the Sab a chilled atmosphere & no fire. I burned my breast severely with mustard both last night & this morning. Did not rise till 11 a.m. better in the evening.

div3.head: 10. Wed
div3.p: I rested badly. Soreness on my breast continues. It rained in heavy drops till the afternoon. I rose at M. Not able to attend the funeral of Wm. J. Gilkeson. Mrs McFarland & Mary there.

div3.head: 11. Thurs
div3.p: I am a little better. Copied a page of minutes. Rained much in the night & this morning.

div3.head: 12. Fri
div3.p: I rested pretty well, but feel more prostration today than heretofore-my breast feels worse. I again burned it with Mustard.
George Pilson came with the sad news that Jennie Pilson died this morning at 8 1/2 O'clock.

div3.head: 13. Sat
div3.p: Rested tolerably & am about as yesterday.

div3.head: 14. Sab
div3.p: I am rather better today, but could not go to Bethel. Mr Flournoy preached-Mary at home.
Mrs Rebecca Brawford died this morning. She was, I think, a truly pious woman & one of my warm friends. Saw her last, June 29th.

div3.head: Octr. 15. Mon
div3.p: I spent a bad night, & this morning had a violent chill which lasted a long time, and while Dr. Tate was here I became unconscious & could neither speak nor swallow for about 5 minutes. In bed all day, my head feels badly.
Killed some Beef weighing 325 lbs.
I have painful & am seriously burdened, I think with suppressing of urine. Took hip-bath.

div3.head: 16. Tues
div3.p: Slept better, but the painful symptoms continue. Took another hip-bath which has been very beneficial. Took a dose of Salts. Uncomfortable.

div3.head: 18. Wed. Thurs
div3.p: Spent an uncomfortable night, this morning feel badly under the operation of medicine. Micturition somewhat less painful. Closely confined to bed. [I have somehow lost a day this week.]

div3.head: 19. Fri
div3.p: Rested badly. The suffering about the same. Sent for Dr. Tate-he came-made but little change.

div3.head: 20. Sat
div3.p: No better, spent a restless night, pain continues-a little improvement otherwise. Dr. Humphreys came to see me.

div3.head: 1866. October 21. Sab
div3.p: Spent not a very comfortable night, but one greatly relieved as I now pass water with very little pain. This is indeed a very great mercy.

div3.head: 22. Mon
div3.p: Spent a restless might I awake out of sleep with a sense of exhaustion & oppression. I am very feeble. James went to Staunton, Dr. Tate here Mr Pilson also came to see me.

div3.head: 23. Tues
div3.p: Had a more comfortable night. But after Breakfast, I became very sick-not more so for years. Was overwhelmed with female visitors. Mrs McClung, Mrs D.C. Gilkeson & Miss Gilkeson, sister to Mrs McC. Mrs Pilson & Mrs Vanlear. Mrs Coleman, Mrs R.Y. Conrad & Mrs Fantleroy Wife of Dr. F. The last three staid all night.

div3.head: 24. Wed
div3.p: A restless night. Much depressed. Pulse weak & small, but improved. Mr Flournoy called & prayed-affected my head badly.

div3.head: 25. Thurs
div3.p: Had a better night-after breakfast, not so well. Mr Pilson & Mrs Wright here. In the afternoon better than usual-read some in the C. Pbn.

div3.head: October 26. Fri
div3.p: Had a bad night from nervousness. today about as other days.

div3.head: 27. Sat
div3.p: rested imperfectly, in the morning a little better. Ate a little rice pudding for my dinner which I thought disagreed with me & had a very quiet afternoon. Mary & her children went to Staunton.

div3.head: 28. Sab
div3.p: The night & day rather better than the preceding, but neither comfortable.

div3.head: 29. Mon
div3.p: Slept tolerably, but night & day as uncomfortable as usual. Rained all day.

div3.head: 30. Tues
div3.p: Had a better night than usual & better today, which I ascribe to the relief of my bowels by medicine. Dr. Tate & Mr Flournoy came.

div3.head: 31. Wed
div3.p: Suffered with my head the early part of last night. This morning felt extreme depression, but rallied. Dr. Tate & Dr. Humphreys here.

div3.head: November 1. Thurs
div3.p: Had a pretty good night, but my food produced great discomfort. Mr A.F. Humphreys & Mrs Christian from Indiana, daughter of John Humphreys came to see me.

div3.head: 1866. Nov. 2. Fri
div3.p: Rested very badly the early part of last night, & am by no means as well as usual today. The eruption on my limbs is again troubling me.

div3.head: 3. Sat
div3.p: Spent a very feverish restless night, caused I think by eating a piece of sweet potato. Today I have been very unwell. Mrs King, Mrs J. Henderson & Dr. Tate here.

div3.head: 4. Sab
div3.p: Slept pretty well-eruption some better today, appetite better.

div3.head: 5. Mon
div3.p: Slept tolerably-feel better. Mr A.F. Sproul called on his way to Synod in New York, & with him I sent the various papers & documents necessary from me as Stated Clerk & Treasurer. Also a letter Resigning those offices, & $22.00 the balance in the Treasury. Mr Pilson came to see me & Mr McPheeters just returned from Ioway. My head felt badly-otherwise better.

div3.head: 6. Tues
div3.p:
Last night was one of the most distressing of my life, from an indescribable affection of my head.
I feared I should have lost my reason & about midnight woke my wife to be here. But God in mercy enabled me to sleep a good deal & the distress abated but continues more or less today. It is probably the effect of Quinine pills. Cold.

div3.head: 9. Fri
div3.p: Eruption troublesome last night. Today I am better than usual. I made out my account of "Income" Wrote to the Journal of Commerce & enclosed two Dollars for the Wakely Journal for one year. Paid E.T. McGuffin for Francis' coffin & the use of his hearse twenty-five dollars, $25.00

div3.head: 10. Sat
div3.p: Eruption aggravated, took Salt in the night, which relieved me. Today farther improved. Got in all the Corn from behind the Run.

div3.head: 11. Sab
div3.p: Better. Frank staid with me-others went to Bethel. Mr Flournoy preached. Unable to sit up yet out of bed. Dr. Alexr. Waddell came & made me a very kind visit.

div3.head: 1866. Nov. 12. Mon
div3.p: Terrible night. My pulse became alarmingly but in the morning became better. I was not as uncomfortable today as yesterday.
James went to Staunton & made of taxable property. [entire sentence illegible]

div3.head: 13. Tues
div3.p: Slept pretty well but on my left side-my right hench so sore could not lie on it. Feel still better today.

div3.head: 14. Wed
div3.p: I rested pretty well, & today am still better than heretofore. Mr Flournoy & Jas. Hays here.

div3.head: 15. Thurs
div3.p: Eruption worse. Not at all well today.

div3.head: 16. Fri
div3.p: Contrary to my fears, I had a pretty comfortable night & today feel a decided improvement. At 1.40' p.m. I rose & put on my Clothes for the first time since Oct. 15th Reclining occasionally on the sofa, I remained up till 7 p.m.
James set off to bring me sulphur water from Crawford's Spring for the eruption.
Ate my supper out of bed.

div3.head: Nov. 17. Sat
div3.p: The eruption troubled me much till midnight after that slept pretty well. Rose at 10 am & remained up till . I was engaged in reading . James returned with with sulphur water but when it arrived I found not any taste or smell of sulphur. Dr. Humphreys came to see me.

div3.head: 18. Sab
div3.p: The Eruption very troublesome last night. Rose at 10.30' a.m. Up till 3 p.m. Do not feel so well this afternoon. All at Bethel but Mary. Mr Flournoy preached.

div3.head: 19. Mon
div3.p: Suffered with the Eruption last night. Rose at 10 a.m. up till 7 p.m.

div3.head: 20. Tues
div3.p: The suffering from the eruption same to increase each succeeding night. Last night could not sleep till near midnight, then slept tolerably till near 4 a.m. then no more till morning. Rose at 11 a.m. up till 1 p.m.-my appetite is very good.

div3.head: 21. Wed
div3.p: Had a better night-rose at 9.15' up till Mr McGilney here fixing Mary's sewing Machine.

div3.head: 22. Thurs
div3.p: My suffering was very great last night till after midnight, then slept imperfectly.

div3.head: 1866. Nov. 22. Thurs continued.
div3.p: I remained in bed all day hoping the eruption would be less irritated. Not too uncomfortable. Mr McGilney came back to fix my sewing machine.

div3.head: 23. Fri
div3.p: I was more comfortable last night & slept pretty well. Still feel badly-did not rise till after 12 M. Day cold & I am chilly. Up till 5 p.m.

div3.head: 24. Sat
div3.p: Rested tolerably rose at 9 a.m. Up till 7 1/2 p.m. I am better than usual-dined with my family for the first time in perhaps in six weeks.
Mr Pilson dined with us.

div3.head: 25. Sab
div3.p: The eruption worse, especially on lower arms. Did not rise till 2 p.m. Up only till 4 p.m.
I am very uncomfortable every where; all the family went to Bethel but Frank. Mr Flournoy preached, & appointed to preach to the Negros at 3 p.m. which he did.

div3.head: 26. Mon
div3.p: Had a rather better night than the preceding. Rose at 9.45' a.m. Up till 7.30' I am better today. Wm. Hall came & I paid him 8 dollars in full of my Note for $50, currency, (Confederate) being Rhoda's hire for 1864. Note mislaid-took a receipt in full.

div3.head: Nov. 27. Tues
div3.p: From 9 till after 10 last night, I suffered severely with the eruption, especially in my arms. Then slept tolerably till 4 a.m. when it again became excited. Today I am pretty easy. Rose at 9 a.m. up till 8 p.m.
Yesterday James went to Staunton & bought of Alby an Overcoat-cost $17.00 Mary & James went to Greenville. Mary remained.

div3.head: 28. Wed
div3.p: Suffered much as usual last night in my arms till after 11 O'clock, then slept tolerably, rose at 10 a.m. up till 7.30' p.m. It is remarkable that I am very little troubled in day light.

div3.head: 29. Thurs
div3.p: Suffered but little last night or today. But I am not very well today. Mrs McFarland also quite unwell yesterday & today.

div3.head: 30. Fri
div3.p: Spent the most comfortable night I have experienced for many Weeks-thanks be to God. Mr Flournoy came home with Mary.

div3.head: 1866 December 1. Sat
div3.p: The eruption has troubled me but little & I am pretty comfortable. Got in the last of our corn except what was cut up, the crop is a good one for the ground we had planted; the Crib is which I think holds Bushels of corn.

div3.head: 2. Sab
div3.p: Last night the eruption a little more troublesome. The day very cold. Mrs McF. & I remained at home. I am pretty comfortable. I have not been at Bethel since the 7th of Octr. 8 weeks-have been brought very low & as I thought near to death & suffered much, but the Lord has spared me-may he enable me to promote his Glory on the earth.

div3.head: 3. Mon
div3.p: During a part of last very uncomfortable. Today well as for several days past.

div3.head: 4. Tues
div3.p: Rested better-today am as usual.

div3.head: 5. Wed
div3.p: Rested pretty well-am still improving, I think. Rode out a little on horseback.

div3.head: 6. Thurs
div3.p: Rose early & at 9 a.m. Mary & I set off for Mr Sproul's wehre we arrived without stopping at 11.30'. At 12.45' I married Samuel Hays Bell & Emaline Louisa Sproul, and for which I received a fee of $50. which certainly was very generous.
The company was small but pleasant. I thought it safest for me to come home, which I did-was much fatigued but not otherwise the worse-thanks be to God.

div3.head: 7. Fri
div3.p: As well as usual. Rode down to see Mr & Mrs McPheeter, who have been very ill. Rev. Mr Walker came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 8. Sat
div3.p: It rained so heavily this morning that Mrs McF. & I did not go to Bethel, although the day before our Communion-I was afraid. Mr Walker they say preached a good SerMon

div3.head: 9. Sab
div3.p:
Went to Bethel & moderated the Session, & Recd. Thompson Lambert (son of Harvey L.) on
1866 Examination, thought to be a very promising young man, & said to be very desirous of a liberal education. Mr Walker preached well. I Baptized young Lambert, & then introduced the ordinance of the Last Supper & served the first Table, thanks be to God for the privilege. Mr Walker served the second & closed the service. Mr Flournoy preached to the Negroes at 3 p.m. Mr & Mrs Flournoy came to spend some days here.

div3.head: 1866. Dec. 10. Mon
div3.p: Very cold-Killed a cow for Beef. Mr & Mrs Flournoy here all day.

div3.head: 11. Tues
div3.p: Still very cold. I rested better than usual-was not disturbed by the Eruption. With difficulty could keep warm. Mr & Mrs F. still here.

div3.head: 12. Wed
div3.p: Rested tolerably, but the cold weather seems to have caused the Eruption to increase. Mrs Gilkeson & Mrs Christian (from Indiana) here, also Dr. Tate. Mr & Mrs Flournoy left us.

div3.head: 13. Thurs
div3.p: Eruption more troublesome. Weather very cold. Killed six Hogs-Wt. 140, 187, 200, 233, 244, 315 = 1319, which at 8 cents per lb. is $105.52

div3.head: 1866. Dec. 14. Fri
div3.p: About as yesterday in health. The day very cold no variation in temperature!!!

div3.head: 15. Sat
div3.p: the coldest. I suffered intensely last night for a short time with neuralgia it is extending. In the day I am
Wrote to Genl. Patterson & Rev. Joseph Smith D.D.

div3.head: 16. Sab
div3.p: Spent a pretty comfortable night-very cold. Last evening before sunset, the first snow of the season began to fall & continued moderately till near noon, today about 5 inches fell. None of the family went to Church.

div3.head: 17. Mon
div3.p: Everything much as usual. Cold.

div3.head: 18. Tues
div3.p: As usual-reading-cannot keep warm.
Today I married Christian G. Merritt & Elisabeth E. Wilson. I recd. the liberal fee of $20. The day was comparatively mild, but my lungs are so sensitive I took some cold.

div3.head: 20. Thurs
div3.p: I spent a restless & suffering night-the eruption harassed me exceedingly.
Rev. Henry Brown spent the night with us. James went to Staunton & brought 10 lbs. Sugar at 16 2/3 & one lb. of Tea at $2.50

div3.head: 21. Fri
div3.p: Day very cold-rested better last night. Dr Humphries & his children came & Finby McClure.

div3.head: 1866. Dec. 22. Sat
div3.p: I had a distressing night with pain in my left breast-no doubt in consequence of the Cold taken on Wednesday. The pain abated before day, but continued to all day. I did not rise till noon. Dr. H. & Finby McC. went away & left David & Theda. Paid Caroline in full.

div3.head: 23. Sab
div3.p: My cough was distressing part of last night. Rose at 11.15' a.m. but feel badly. James, Frank & David went to Church. Mr Flournoy preached the last Sermon of his engagement.

div3.head: 24. Mon
div3.p: Last night applied a mustard plaster to my breast & coughed but little. The mildness of the weather seems to have relieved me much today. I settled with Jefferson Howard this evening & paid him in full $84.25 He has recd. a Coat, Vest, Pantaloons and shoes. He lost 27 days.
I have hired him for next year at $120-no clothes.

div3.head: 25. Tues
div3.p: Had a restless night, coughing: rose before 9 a.m. This is Christmas the Children enjoy it-I think the ordinary observance of the day wrong-has no divine warrant.

div3.head: 26. Wed
div3.p: Coughed hard last night. Wrote to Mr Blanton. Recd. a letter from Genl. R. Patterson. Cold weather.

div3.head: Dec. 27. Thurs
div3.p: Very cold. At daybreak 14 at 10 a.m. 10 at noon 11 afternoon 15 at 8 p.m. 6.
I was sent to preach at the funeral of Mrs Sally Hays tomorrow but I had to decline. I think it would risk my life to go out in such intensely cold weather. Mr Pilson here.

div3.head: 28. Fri
div3.p: Colder. Rev. Mr Preston preached at the Funeral of Mrs Hays. I am gaining strength. I suffer with extreme itching in my back in the evenings.

div3.head: 29. Sat
div3.p: Still . I coughed very hard last night. James went to Staunton.

div3.head: 30. Sab
div3.p: So cold I dare not to leave the house. James and Frank went to Bethel-Rev. Henry Brown preached. The Congregation, I am told, voted unanimously to invite Mr Flournoy to supply them six months longer at a salary of $350. for the time. May God bless the work.

div3.head: 31. Mon
div3.p: About 4 inches of snow fell last night. Diana, a coloured woman formerly belonging to Mr Shields came here & I hired her at a dollar per week.

div3.head: 1867. January 1. Tuesday
div3.p: Through God's Mercy I am tolerably comfortable. My chief affliction is that the morbid humour which produced the Eruption now occasions a very troublesome itching in my back. I am gaining strength but my lungs are so liable to Bronchitis that I dare not expose myself at all in a cold atmosphere. During the last year, I have regularly taken my breakfast in bed with the exception of perhaps a dozen times.

My wife & Daughter & Son James & Mary's children enjoy their usual health. Dr. Humphries & his children who are now here enjoy good health. For all this I would render most hearty thanks to the God of mercy.
On the 21st of July last my poor Son Francis was taken from us but blessed be God, we have hope in his death. Thus we are becoming very few on earth
I have preached very little the last year from sickness, & I fear shall be able to preach but little more. The Congregation must have another Pastor.

div3.head: Jany. 2. Wed
div3.p: Very cold. James set off to meet a wedding party at Mr Bratton's to go by Railroad from Swoope's Depot.

div3.head: 3. Thurs
div3.p: Night very cold. We have procured a little girl (coloured, Maria) for her victuals and clothes. She came yesterday. Jefferson Howard also commenced work yesterday.

div3.head: 4. Fri
div3.p: The itching is less troublesome I think. James returned. Weather a little moderated.

div3.head: 5. Sat
div3.p: The eruption has disappeared, & the itching in my back has almost ceased. I think that taking Epsom salts, every 3d or 4th night has had a good effect. But it is so cold I dare not venture out for fear of Bronchitis.

div3.head: 6. Sab
div3.p: The day too cold for me to venture to go to Bethel. Mary, James & Frank went & took David & his Father took him home to go to school. Theda still here. A Collection was taken for Missions.

div3.head: 7. Mon
div3.p: I have suffered for two nights with the laborious breathing like Asthma. Feel very dull & alas, can do almost nothing.

div3.head: 1867. Jan. 8. Tuesday.
div3.p: My Birth-day!!! Glory be to God Most High, who has spared my life to see the end of my 79th year & to enter on my 80th. I wonder at it-for in my life I never expected to reach such an age. I wonder too that my faculties are as yet very little impaired except my bodily strength & I am strong enough to preach if the weather were such that my lungs would not be in danger of bronchitis. My sight is wonderfully improved-I can now read ordinary print without glasses. My hearing is good. In regard to my mental faculties, I am conscious of no failure except in remembering names.
I rest pretty well at night, & have a good appetite.

div3.head: 9. Wed
div3.p: A little unwell. On yesterday James took two steers we raised & sold them to Mr Saml. H. Bell. The weighed-one 1000 lbs. the other 874 at 5 cents per pound gross = $93.70

div3.head: 10. Thurs
div3.p: I am better, but grieved that I am almost like a hibernating animal-just trying to pass the winter & hoping in the Spring to be reinvigorated. May the Lord cause me to grow in grace.

div3.head: Jan. 11. Fri
div3.p: Health is of late. Day very cold, cannot venture out. We are now getting on comfortably in our domestic affairs-servants doing very well.

div3.head: 12. Sat
div3.p: Still uncomfortably Cold. I am as usual. Wrote to Rev Dr. Wm. Brown.

div3.head: 13. Sab
div3.p: Snow fell last night 3 inches-day damp & cloudy. I could not go to Bethel, no preaching. Mr Flournoy wrote, I learn, that he must know whether the Congn. would engage to pay him in currency at its present value; and where he can board.
Last night till near 3 a.m. I spent an exceedingly nervous & restless night & almost sleepless.

div3.head: 14. Mon
div3.p: Some snow in the night, but a very heavy Rain this morning. In the afternoon 2 inches of snow. I am pretty well. Finished my letter of 6 pages to Dr. Brown.

div3.head: 15. Tues
div3.p: I am pretty well. Reading only. Liz. went to Staunton.

div3.head: 16. Wed
div3.p: Employed as yesterday. Letter from Mr Blanton. Also from Winchester-Messrs Bent better.

div3.head: 17. Thurs
div3.p: Very cold. Reading. Pretty well. Mr. Pilson here.

div3.head: 18. Fri
div3.p: This morning in my sleep, the right side of my head became painfully affected with a dizzy confused sensation & it continued through the day. In the evening a little better. James & Jeff. helping Mr Mc Pheeters to get ice.

div3.head: 1867. Jan. 19. Sat
div3.p: Last night I suffered all night from the state of my head. The pain extending from my neck-also from a pain in my knees.
I greatly feared a day of suffering, but thanks be to God, I am almost entirely relieved.

div3.head: 20. Sab
div3.p: I am as usual in health, but the day so cold I dared not to go to Bethel. James & Frank went. Rev. Henry Brown was expected but did not come. About 10 1/2 a.m. it began to snow with a strong NE wind & continued to snow very fast all day. After dark say 8 p.m. it ceased.

div3.head: 21. Mon
div3.p: I suffered much with Asthma last night from 2 a.m. till morning, but today I have been as well as usual. In the evening Mr Robert Patterson of Tennessee who has been attending Judge Brokenburoughs two lectures.

div3.head: 22. Tues
div3.p: I had a distressing night with Asthma, all night. Today feel very languid. Mr Patterson seems a very pleasant gentleman. He is on his way to be married to a Miss Gastleman of Clark County in this state.

div3.head: 23. Wed
div3.p: Slept on the sofa till near 6 a.m. Feel very dull. James took Robert Patterson Esq. to Staunton.

div3.head: Jan. 24. Thurs
div3.p: Lay on the sofa all night, some asthma. Feel exceedingly tired all day.

div3.head: 27. Sab
div3.p: Spent a suffering night on the sofa. Lay down at 6 a.m. & rose at 4.30' p.m. Mr J. Brown went away because Mr F. was expected.

div3.head: 28. Mon
div3.p: Remained in bed all night by keeping up the fire. Today not well, & have a distressing pain in my back. Could scarcely read any. James went to Staunton.

div3.head: 29. Tues
div3.p: Had our bed moved nearer the fire, & lay all night by Mrs McFarland rising & recruiting the fire. My back a little better, but I was unwell all day. Recd. payment for the two steers sold to Mr Saml. H. Brown $93.75 Gave James $10. of it. Mrs E. Merritt here.

div3.head: 30. Wed
div3.p: Still uncomfortable. Moved our bed into the Dining room. The study is too cold. Reading.

div3.head: 31. Thurs
div3.p: I am better-rested pretty well. Reading.

div3.head: 1867. February 1. Fri
div3.p: Rested pretty well. But after I ate my breakfast in bed I was sick to my stomach till noon. Mary & James took Theda to Mr R.T. Wallace's. She has been here six weeks. This the warmest day for nearly two months.

div3.head: 2. Sat
div3.p: Better today. Thick fog today-very damp.

div3.head: 3. Sab
div3.p: Day pleasant but cold. I was too unwell to go to Bethel. Mr Flournoy returned last night & today preached the first time of the second six months. He has been absent since before Christmas.

div3.head: 4. Mon
div3.p: Day mild-moderate rain. I am better.
A letter from Winchester reports N. Bent to be a great sufferer with inflamatory Rheumatism, entirely helpless. I fear his life is in danger.

div3.head: 5. Tues
div3.p: I spent a restless night, slept almost none till after midnight-very unwell-did not rise till near 2 p.m.

div3.head: 6. Wed
div3.p: Rested better. Reading as usual.

div3.head: 7. Thurs
div3.p: Rested tolerably-sick after breakfast. Rev. Mr Erwin dined with us-a pleasant Brother.

div3.head: 8. Fri
div3.p: I am as usual-quite infirm & suffer pain. Day very gloomy. Wrote to Rev. L.H. Blanton.

div3.head: Feb. 9. Sat
div3.p: I suffered much with pain last night but am comparatively free from it in the latter part of the day. This day more gloomy & wet than yesterday.

div3.head: 10. Sab
div3.p: The wind high, and it turned very cold. Suffered rather less last night, but not as well as usual today. Mr Flournoy was taken with Typhoid fever last Monday night at Mr Sprouls. No preaching today at Bethel.
Rev. Luther Emerson, it is said, was buried today. Alas! He was a good man & leaves a family, I suppose, with very slender support.

div3.head: 11. Mon
div3.p: I rested badly the early part of last night. Today I am about as yesterday-perhaps a little more comfortable in the afternoon.

div3.head: 12. Tues
div3.p: Rested pretty well, better today. The Miss Humphreys from Indiana & Mary Humphreys (A.F.H.'s D.) dined here. Rev. E.D. Junkin came to see me and staid all night, making me a very pleasant Brotherly visit. Mary left home to make a visit to Col. Wm. P. Tate in Staunton, who is said to be very low.

div3.head: 1867. Feby. 13.
div3.p: I felt poorly last night I was wretched by a sleight eruption on my right hip. I feel great prostration today in consequence.

div3.head: 14. Thurs
div3.p: I rested rather better last night, but did not rise till 11 a.m. Better today.

div3.head: 15. Fri
div3.p: My health about the same.

div3.head: 16. Sat
div3.p: Not so good a night, & had a sick day. My morning sickness is as usual irritable. Col. John Lilley came to get me to give a testimonial to his brother Gen. R.D. Lilley who is now acting as an agent for the endowment of Whington College. I prepared it.

div3.head: 17. Sab
div3.p: Rested imperfectly. A sick day. Did not rise till noon. No preaching at Bethel. Mr Flournoy there but not able to preach.

div3.head: 18. Mon
div3.p: James went to Staunton and paid our Revenue tax on 3 Gold watches & a Buggy = $4.00 also bought several necessaries & brought Mary home.

div3.head: 19. Tues
div3.p: Not well a.m. better p.m.
Mr McPheeter and Mr James Bumgarner came to see me. A moderate rain in the afternoon & night.

div3.head: Feb. 20. Wed
div3.p: I began to use Drakes. Irritation better. I have felt better today. Received a letter from Mrs Annie G. Patterson with much pleasure.

div3.head: 21. Thurs
div3.p: I have had distressing chills. Have bad nights not any better in the two last days but today did not rise till 1 p.m.

div3.head: 22. Fri
div3.p: I rested better last night. Rose at 8 1/2 a.m. Mercury falling throughout the day.

div3.head: 23. Sat
div3.p: A better night. Better today-nothing new.

div3.head: 24. Sab
div3.p: Had another chill last night, better in the morning, but the Bitter sickness I could not rise till noon.
The white family all went to church. Mr Flournoy preached, though weak from his recent sickness. A little before night pain struck me in my kidneys.

div3.head: 25. Mon
div3.p: The pain continued all night. I rose at 8 a.m. but had to return to bed at noon, on account of the pain being worse.

div3.head: 26. Tues
div3.p: Pained all night. Suffered with pain all night, but slept. Remained in bed all day-not suffering much when still, but every movement gave pain.

div3.head: 27. Wed
div3.p: Rested as well as I could expect, perhaps a little better today, but not much. Began to plow for corn in the NE field. In bed all day.

div3.head: March 1. Fri
div3.p: Rested better I am a little better. Rose & dressed at 9 a.m. up 2 1/2 hours.

div3.head: 2. Sat
div3.p: Spent a wretched night much worse I think from being up yesterday. I was sick & suffering otherwise. I was quite unwell till noon-then better-in bed all day.

div3.head: 3. Sab
div3.p: Suffered much with pain in my back, but slept more than usual. Today still suffer rather more than usual. James & Frank went to Bethel-Mr Flournoy preached. Day cold & uncomfortable.

div3.head: 4. Mon
div3.p: Had a suffering night-after breakfast sick. A little easier in the afternoon. Mr Flournoy came to see me-also Dr. Tate came & prescribed-to use volatile lineament with Chloroform.

div3.head: 5. Tues
div3.p: About as usual-no sickness but a sleight chill. Day very gloomy-So wet cannot plow.

div3.head: 10. Sab
div3.p: Much rain. Mr Flournoy preached to a small Congn.

div3.head: 11. Mon
div3.p: Rested better, & am better than usual. Snow mostly disappeared. Dr. Tate came to see me.

div3.head: 12. Tues
div3.p: About as yesterday. John Gilkeson here.

div3.head: 13. Wed
div3.p: Back more pained. Rose & dressed at 11 1/2 a.m. & up till 3 p.m.

div3.head: 14. Thurs
div3.p: A pretty easy night-rose at 9.15' up till 6 p.m. Day cold. Today Mr Waddy's School closed.

div3.head: 15. Fri
div3.p: Last night & today I spent about as the preceding. Up from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. Dr Tate here.

div3.head: 1867. March 16. Sat
div3.p: Slept as usual, but my back much more painful in the night than in the day. It snowed in the night & this morning till about noon. Up from 8.15' a.m. to 8.15 p.m.

div3.head: 17. Sab
div3.p: Day cold & blustering. James & Frank went to Bethel. Mr Flournoy preached to about 40 hearers. Francis Gilkeson dine here.
I am sensibly improved less pain.

div3.head: 18. Mon
div3.p: Spent a bad night in various respects-more pain than for some time & sick all the morning. Rose at 8 a.m. up till 7.45 p.m.
Frank Lewis left here to go to school to Mr Wilson at Christian's Creek. Is to board gratis at Mrs King's. James took Frank over.

div3.head: 19. Tues
div3.p: Had a better night, & today not sick. Sold to John Brownlee Sr. 2 1/4 Bs. of Cloverseed at $9.

div3.head: 20. Wed
div3.p: About as yesterday. Weather cold & unpleasant. About 4 p.m. it began to rain & soon turned to snow.

div3.head: 21. Thurs
div3.p: My health as yesterday. We have an Equinoctial Storm in reality a high NE wind & moderate rain, but freezing as it falls-trees & every shrub loaded & many bent down.

div3.head: March 22. Fri
div3.p: I am better. Weather not so cold, but continued to snow moderately all day. The ice has mostly melted from the trees.

div3.head: 23. Sat
div3.p: As well as yesterday. Day cloudy & unpleasant.

div3.head: 24. Sab
div3.p: Alas the weather & roads are such that Mrs McF. & I cannot go to Bethel. James, Mary & Mary Lou went. Mr Flournoy preached, they say, very well.

div3.head: 25. Mon
div3.p: I am pretty comfortable. Delightful clear day. The ground has been covered in the Snow for a good while, but today it has melted away very much.

div3.head: 26. Tues
div3.p: My health as usual. An unfavorable change in the weather-wind again NE. Rain at night.

div3.head: 27. Wed
div3.p: I was quite uncomfortable last night, better today. Joe Fix helping to trim the trees around the house.

div3.head: 28. Thurs
div3.p: More unwell than usual. Cold. James went to Staunton to make return of Taxable property to the States Assessor. Bought various articles $6.50

div3.head: 29. Fri
div3.p: Had Asthma last night-unwell this morning. Mary Lewis went to Mr Pilson's & Mrs King's.

div3.head: 30. Sat
div3.p: I am better today.

div3.head: 31. Sab
div3.p: Not so well. Mrs McF. & Jas. went Bethel. I was not well enough. Rev. E.D. Junkin preached & came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 1867. April 1. Mon
div3.p: Spent a somewhat restless night. In the afternoon Mr Bumgarner to plow for -had not been able to plow any since March .

div3.head: 2. Tues
div3.p: Did not rest well, & sick after breakfast, & during the forenoon. Good weather for plowing.

div3.head: 3. Wed
div3.p: Very unwell last & this morning-becoming more so as the night advances. This afternoon better. Sowed clover & timothy seed on the NW. field.

div3.head: 4. Thurs
div3.p: I am better. Plowing for Oats-North

div3.head: 5. Fri
div3.p: Very unwell last night & today uncomfortable.

div3.head: 6. Sat
div3.p: Still feel unwell. The two Miss Tates Lizzie Merritt, Jas. Patterson & Benjn. F. McClung here.

div3.head: 7. Sab
div3.p: I was too sick to go to Bethel, even if the day had been thought sufficiently mild. It was pleasant but there was a cool wind. Mr Flournoy preached to a good Congn.

div3.head: 8. Mon
div3.p: I am better today-rode a little through the fields. Plowing for oats by the Springhouse.

div3.head: 9. Tues
div3.p: Pretty comfortable. Mr Wm. F. Smith came to see me on Congregational business. Dined with us.

div3.head: 10. Wed
div3.p: As well as yesterday. Mr Pilson came to see me I rode out yesterday & today sowed oats beyond the creek.

div3.head: April. 11. Thurs
div3.p: Not at all well. Finished Sowing Oats.

div3.head: 12. Fri
div3.p: Still unwell-in the afternoon better. Today Mr Flournoy preached preparatory to the communion-Mrs McF. & James went. I could not go-so unwell, & the day cold & damp.
Plowing for corn in the NE. field.

div3.head: 13. Sat
div3.p: Went to Bethel & moderated the session, & recd on Examn. Hannah C. Henderson. Rev. E.D. Junkin preached. Mrs McF. & I dined at Mrs Jas. Bumgardners & came home. I was very much fatigued.

div3.head: 14. Sab
div3.p: Went to Bethel & moderated the session. Rev. Mr Junkin preached-I introduced the Communion Service & Mr Junkin served the Tables & I concluded. It was a pleasant season & I thank God that I had the privilege of attending & participating after an absence of four long months. I was not so much fatigued.

div3.head: 15. Mon
div3.p: Sick after breakfast-better in the afternoon.

div3.head: 16. Tues
div3.p: Tolerably well. James took three of our young cattle to be sent to the mountains to pasture John Trimble takes them at 50 cents per month.

div3.head: 17. Wed
div3.p: Pretty well today. Reading.

div3.head: 1867. Apl. 18. Thurs
div3.p: Pretty well, rode down to Mrs Gilkeson's. Planted &c.

div3.head: 19. Fri
div3.p: As usual. Mr Flournoy called.

div3.head: 20. Sat
div3.p: Tolerably well. Reading.

div3.head: 21. Sab
div3.p: Went to Bethel Mr Flournoy preached well & I prayed-not so much fatigued as last Sabbath.

div3.head: 22. Mon
div3.p: I was very unwell last night, have taken cold. This the warmest day for seven months. Removed our bed back into the study after being out nearly three months. Cherry & Peach tress in full bloom.

div3.head: 23. Tues
div3.p: I spent a wretched night, in consequence, I think, of changing my lodging-the study over the sellar being cool & damp-had my bed moved back again. I have been very unwell today.

div3.head: 24. Wed
div3.p: Had a better night, & am better today, but very languid. It was raining heavily this morning & a drizzlein through the latter part of the day, but Jeff. could plow.

div3.head: 25. Thurs
div3.p: I am better than for several days.

div3.head: 26. Fri
div3.p: Not so well this morning-very dull in the afternoon. Today finished plowing the NE field for corn.

div3.head: 27. Sat
div3.p: I am better today. Harrowing corn ground.

div3.head: April 28. Sab
div3.p: Went to Bethel Mr Flournoy preached I prayed at the close. Am pretty well fatigued.

div3.head: 29. Mon
div3.p: Rained nearly all day. Could not harrow. I was reading-unwell in the morning.

div3.head: 30. Tues
div3.p: Too wet to harrow. Plowing in the lows and at the meadow planting some potatoes. I am better-working a little & read again with renewed interest Scott's of Truth.' Rained fully in the night.

div3.head: May 1. Wed
div3.p: Coughed much last night, today I am as well as for some time past.
Still too wet to prepare the ground for planting.

div3.head: 2. Thurs
div3.p: Cool. Mrs McF. & I dined at Mr Pilson's.
Went to Mr Christian's & Baptized three of their children two of Mr James Johnstons & one of Archd. Sproul's. Spent the night at Mr Blackwood's.

div3.head: 3. Fri
div3.p: Did not rest well. Day very cool & damp. Got home by 11.30' a.m. much fatigued-roads bad. Began to plant corn in the NE. field.

div3.head: 4. Sat
div3.p: I am much indisposed today. Planting corn.

div3.head: 5. Sab
div3.p: I was too unwell to go to Bethel-all the white family went-a good Congn. Collection for Forn. Missns. Mr Flournoy preached. Rose at 10 a.m. Retired at 5.30' p.m.

div3.head: 1867. May 6. Mon
div3.p: Still unwell, but better in the afternoon. Marking out for corn.
Had black Caroline shearing our sheep.

div3.head: 7. Tues
div3.p: Better today. It rained much last night & today steadily all day. Wrote to Dr. E.S. Beard for the Minutes of the Assembly & the Revised form of Govt and enclosed One Dollar.

div3.head: 8. Wed
div3.p: I continued tolerable. Day very cool. Reading.

div3.head: 9. Thurs
div3.p: I am about as yesterday. The day clear & pleasant. In the afternoon began again to plant corn in the NE field-having been delayed by the rain.

div3.head: 10. Fri
div3.p: Quite sick this morning-rose at 11 a.m. Planting corn. James went to Staunton.

div3.head: 11. Sat
div3.p: I was very unwell last night, better today, rode out. Finished planting corn in the NE. field. Mary returned from Staunton-been there since Monday.

div3.head: 12. Sab
div3.p: Rested rather better-still too unwell to go to Bethel-all the white family went but Mary Lou.

div3.head: 13. Mon
div3.p: I am better. Planted sorgum.

div3.head: 14. Tues
div3.p: Suffered much with my back & otherwise last night & today, more than for some time. Sent to Staunton 3 Bls. flour sold at 13.75 each for 2 & 12.00 for one, the Bl. defective. Bought 3/4 ton of Plaster for $11.25, 12 yds of Russia Duck $6.00 a Hat for James $2.25-a sack of salt $4.25.

div3.head: May 15. Wed
div3.p: Not by any means well. Today the Presby of Lexington met at Hebron but alas, I was too unwell to go, and so I fail to enjoy the delightful intercourse with my Brethren which I had hoped for. Mr B.F. McClung called on his way to Presby. Planted late Potatoes.

div3.head: 16. Thurs
div3.p: Rested badly last night, & so unwell this morning did not rise till after 11 a.m.

div3.head: 17. Fri
div3.p: Rested a little better, rose at 9 a.m. & feel better than yesterday. Mary & James & Mary Lou went to Hebron.

div3.head: 18. Sat
div3.p: I am better. Mrs McF. & I went to Hebron, where I with great pleasure met the Pby. of Lexington, and was received by the Modr. Rev. E.D. Junkin, with public expressions, kindness & respect which surprized me, and all manifested pleasure to see me there! Oh, I do thank God for the Christian friendship of so many excellent persons.
I Baptized Sarah Lyle, the child of Rev. T.L. Preston. Spent the night at Mr Preston's-his father there.

div3.head: 19. Sab
div3.p: Did not rest very well: Mr. Saml. Brown introduced the Comunion Service-I closed it. Dined at Mr Prestons & came home-fatigued.

div3.head: 1867. May 20. Mon
div3.p: Rested rather badly. So unwell, did not rise till 11 a.m. Taking cold. Mr & Mrs Gilkeson & Rev. Mr Kennedy came to see us.

div3.head: 21. Tues
div3.p: My Cold is worse-so unwell I did not rise till 11 a.m. Very unwell all day. Our company staid till evening. Sowed some Plaster on clover-hill field.

div3.head: 22. Wed
div3.p: Had a bad night with coughing-a bad cold. Did not rise till 1.30' p.m. much indisposed.

div3.head: 23. Thurs
div3.p: Harrassed with coughing at night-a little better. Mrs S. Bell & Mrs Christian here.

div3.head: 24. Fri
div3.p: About as yesterday. Mrs McF. & Mary went to see Peggy Hays. I was reading.

div3.head: 25. Sat
div3.p: Moderate rain nearly all day-very damp. I was much indisposed.

div3.head: 26. Sab
div3.p: Very unwell-did not rise till 1 p.m. then better. Mrs McFarland staid at home with me. Had some heavy showers-fine for vegetation.

div3.head: 27. Mon
div3.p: Rested rather, sick after breakfast, rose at 10 a.m. Better through the day-James went to Staunton.

div3.head: 28. Tues
div3.p: Rather Better. Very warm.

div3.head: 29. Wed
div3.p: Last night the most distressing night I have had lately. Cough extremely harrassing-applied Mustard.

div3.head: May 30. Thurs
div3.p: Cough not quite so troublesome. I am better today. This day the Chtn Creek School at which Frank Lewis has been ends. Mary & Mary Lou there.

div3.head: 31. Fri
div3.p: Rested poorly felt better in the morning, but through the day very feeble & not well.

div3.head: June 1. Sat
div3.p: I was in bed all day no appetite.

div3.head: 2. Sab
div3.p: I just but am not much better. Mrs McF. staid at home with me the other members of the family went to Bethel. Mr F preached I remained in bed all day.

div3.head: 3. Mon
div3.p: Had a rather better night-rose & dressed at 10 a.m. & though very feeble, remained out of bed all day. Dr. Humphries David came to see us.

On Friday a dog of Mrs Rebecca McClure's, afterwards ascertained to be mad, bit David on the forefinger of the left hand, slightly, but it bled. 14 1/2 hours after, the piece was cut out & it appeared that the tooth had not penetrated through the entire skin.

div3.head: 1867. June 4. Tues
div3.p: I am as well as yesterday. Dr. Tate came again to see me. Dr. H. & David left us after dinner. Finished planting the Corn, & began to work it with the cultivator.

div3.head: 5. Wed
div3.p: I am about as yesterday but did not rise till 10 a.m. Very pleasant weather. Reading.

div3.head: 6. Thurs
div3.p: Rested pretty well but I am more feeble than usual. Wrote Genl. R. Patterson.
James took the Gravestones to Bethel for the graves of Francis & Robert McFarland & set them up.

div3.head: 7. Fri
div3.p: I am better today. Mr M. Pilson came and spent the afternoon with me, a very pleasant visit.

div3.head: 8. Sat
div3.p: My strength somewhat increased. It rained much last night, & heavily this forenoon.

div3.head: 9. Sab
div3.p: Day too damp, as I thought, for me to go to Bethel. I am as well as yesterday. Mrs McF. Mary, James and Frank went to Bethel. Mr Flourney preached.

div3.head: 10. Mon
div3.p: Rather better. Mrs McF. & Mary went to Mrs Bryan's Working the corn.

div3.head: 11. Tues
div3.p: Quite sick this morning. In the afternoon I went to Mrs Gilkeson's for Mrs McFarland & Mary. Mrs Andw Gilkeson & Miss Mattie Gilkeson there.

div3.head: June 12. Wed
div3.p: Better today. Finished working the corn over once. Mrs McFarland and I dined at Mr Hendersons. Mr James Calhoon, Rev. Mr Flournoy & Mr James Hays there. Took some cold.

div3.head: 13. Thurs
div3.p: Spent an uncomfortable night with coughing. Mr Andw Bratton & wife (Mary ) dined here.

div3.head: 14. Fri
div3.p: Spent a worse night than that previous did not rise till 4 a.m.-applied mustard to my breast.

div3.head: 15. Sat
div3.p: Had a better night, but was quite sick after breakfast. Reading & wrote to Rev. Wm. S. Richardson, working in the corn.

div3.head: 16. Sab
div3.p: Coughed much last night. I would have gone to Bethel but it rained in the morning, & I was afraid to go. All the white family went. A Mr Lacy, son of Rev. Drury Lacy D.D. preached. Rev. Mr Kennedy was there and would preach in Greenville in the afternoon.

div3.head: 17. Mon
div3.p: I am very feeble & unwell today. James & Jef. went to Staunton & took three Barrels of Flour which James sold for $10.50 per Bl. Bought two Blls. Hydraulic Cement to make a Cistern, at $4.00 pr. Bl. 10 lbs Coffee. 1/2 Bl. Herrings $4.75 Paid Internal Revenue Tax $3.00 &c.

div3.head: 1867. June 18th Tues
div3.p: Rested better, but sick after breakfast. Mrs McF. went to Mr Kunkles & James wet out for Lexington to attend the Commencement.

div3.head: 19. Wed
div3.p: Spent another bad night-coughed much & hard-feel badly this morning-did not rise till 11 a.m. Another in the afternoon.

div3.head: 20. Thurs
div3.p: Had a better night but feel badly today. Mr Whitout came to make slaughter for the sheep. Mr Shelley came to help him to .

div3.head: 21. Fri
div3.p: I am about as yesterday.

div3.head: 22. Sat
div3.p: Sick this morning, but went to Bethel and Baptized the child of James Bumgarners & Mary M. Bumgarndners name James Sewick.

Rev. Dr. B.M. Smith preached a good serMon I was asked to sit as Chairman of a Congregational meeting to fix the manner of raising the Minister's Salary. It was carried to each of Pewholder how much he would agree to pay in addition to his pew rent.

div3.head: 23. Sab
div3.p: As well as yesterday. This day was appointed for the administration of the Lord's Lord's Supper, but it rained all day almost without intermission and Dr Smith was afraid to turn out-So was I and it was not done. Mrs Ann Derrick came here last night.

div3.head: June 24th Mon
div3.p: About as yesterday. It rained in the night & heavily this morning till about 8 a.m.

div3.head: 25. Tues
div3.p: I am better today-two heavy thunder showers.

div3.head: 26. Wed
div3.p: I am not quite so well as yesterday, but rose earlier & been able to read a good deal. Bed returned to study.

div3.head: 27. Thurs
div3.p: Rose at 8.15' a.m. Rather better today. James & Mary went to Staunton.

div3.head: 28. Fri
div3.p: As usual.

div3.head: 29. Sat
div3.p: As usual. Finished second corn plowing.

div3.head: 30. Sab
div3.p: Escaped sickness this morning. All, black & white went to Bethel. Mr Flournoy preached a good pastoral sermon on Sanctification of the Sabbath. Is. 58:13 Text.

div3.head: July 1. Mon
div3.p: I am still better. Mr Flournoy & wife had spent the night with us.
The heat today was very oppressive.

div3.head: 2. Tues
div3.p: Very unwell all morning-in the afternoon better. Began to cut wheat in the NW. field with the cradles.

div3.head: 3. Wed
div3.p: Sick in the morning as yesterday. Cutting wheat in the NW field with two Cradles as yesterday.

div3.head: 4. Thurs
div3.p: Somewhat better-rose at 6.30' a.m.
Still running two cradles cutting wheat-cut the lot below the Corn & part of the lot N. of the house. James too unwell to work this afternoon.

div3.head: 1867. July 5. Fri
div3.p: James too sick to work. I had asthma last night but better today. No harvest hands but Frank & Jeff.

div3.head: 6. Sat
div3.p: I am better today. James went to Staunton to bring Mary Lou home. No more harvest hands.

div3.head: 7. Sab
div3.p: Quite sick after breakfast. All went to Bethel but Frank. Mr Flournoy preached well.
Had the pleasure of meeting my dear Friend Rev. Dr. Wm. S. Wink. He & his wife are on their way to

div3.head: 8. Mon
div3.p: Sick again this morning. Cutting wheat in in the orchard, but could get no help.

div3.head: 9. Tues
div3.p: Spent an uncomfortable night, feverish & a severe headache which kept me in bed till near 11 a.m.
James & Mary took Mrs Anne Derrick to Staunton, she has been here two weeks & two days.
Today finished cutting wheat-had a cradler.

div3.head: 10. Wed
div3.p: Had a feverish night, did not rise till 10.50' a.m. better in the afternoon. James & Jeff. went to Greenville to Register as voters. I am not able to go.

div3.head: 11. Thurs
div3.p: Had Asthma worse last night than any time I remember for several years-rose & dressed at midnight & did not return to bed till morning. Began to haul in wheat & broke the hind axeltree of the waggon.

div3.head: July 12. Fri
div3.p: Less asthma but still unwell. Hauled in wheat till noon but then rained.

div3.head: 13. Sat
div3.p: Very unwell last night, much asthma this morning & very unwell, did not rise till near noon. Sent to get a new axeltree hauled in a little. Had our bed removed to the dining room.

div3.head: 14. Sab
div3.p: Had another bad night-not so much asthma. Too sick this morning to leave my bed, rose about 3.30' p.m. Mrs McFarland remained with me others went to Bethel. Mr Flournoy preached, good Congn.

div3.head: 15. Mon
div3.p: Had a better night last night than for a week. Rose at 9.30' a.m. feel very weak & no appetite. Robert McPheeters with his mowers cutting our meadow.

div3.head: 16. Tues
div3.p: Rested pretty well but sick after breakfast rose at 10.30' a.m. Got all our wheat in dry but two loads in heavy rain in the evening.

div3.head: 17. Wed
div3.p: Rested tolerably rose at 9 a.m. extremely feeble. Went to bed at 3.15' p.m. Got home the waggon-repaired.

div3.head: 18. Thurs
div3.p: I am a little stronger & more comfortable today. Making hay in the front meadow.

div3.head: 19. Fri
div3.p: I am as well as yesterday. All making hay.

div3.head: 20. Sat
div3.p: Not so well. Finished hauling in wheat & hauled in some hay. Genl. Lilley spent the day with us.

div3.head: 1867 July 20. Sat continued.
div3.p: Gen. Lilley also made me a present of $5. in gold & the same to Mrs McFarland. Rev. Wm. T. Richardson came & spent the night with us, & his wife sent us a bottle of excellent currant wine.

div3.head: 21. Sab
div3.p: Had an uncomfortable night & a sick day. Rose at 1 p.m. All the white family went to Bethel but Mary Lou & I. Mary went to Mr Kunkle's .

div3.head: 22. Mon
div3.p: I slept sufficiently, but it seems to me that I am always more unwell in the morning, & continues so till near noon & then I am better in the afternoon. Hauling in hay.

div3.head: 23. Tu.
div3.p: Rested better & am better today than usual. James and Jeff. Cutting oats. Mrs McFarland went to Mr Jas. Bumgardners & Frank to Mr Kunkle's for his mother.

div3.head: 24. Wed
div3.p: Finished cutting oats & hauling in hay. I was very sick this morning, better in the afternoon. Day so warm I cannot be comfortable.

div3.head: 25. Thurs
div3.p: I am better today. Very warm.

div3.head: 26. Fri
div3.p: More feeble. Hauling in Oats.

div3.head: 27. Sat
div3.p: Better. Finished hauling in Oats, & so harvest. James went to Staunton. He received for Mary & me 2 pr Ct. intst. on our Va. State Stocks, due the 6th inst with a deduction of 5 pr Ct. I recd. $19.00

div3.head: July 28. Sab
div3.p: Better. Went to Bethel. Rev. R.J. Kennedy preached for Mr Flournoy. A pretty good Sermon but very short. Came home much fatigued. Mr Kennedy came with us & spent the night. A pleasant man.

div3.head: 29. Mon
div3.p: A fine rain. I feel very weak.

div3.head: 30. Tues
div3.p: Cool. I am more unwell. James & Frank helping Mr McPheters with their Oats. Mrs McFarland & I rode up to Mr Rosen's. Went to bed about 6 p.m.

div3.head: 31. Wed
div3.p: Very unwell through the night & most of the day better in the evening. Cultivating the sugar cane.

div3.head: August 1. Thurs
div3.p: I am about as yesterday.

div3.head: 2. Fri
div3.p: I spent a sick & suffering night today very feeble.

div3.head: 3. Sat
div3.p: Rested pretty well. Better but very feeble. Arranging some thoughts as I may have to preach tomorrow if able.

div3.head: 4. Sab
div3.p: Not so well, but went to Bethel. The Revd. Thomas was there & preached a Sermon which interested me more than any sermon I have heard for a long time. The Text was 1 John 2:1 last clause. Doctrine-Christ an Advocate. He came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 5. Mon
div3.p: Rested pretty well and am better today. Clearing out the Old Cistern & enlarging it. Sent for sand.

div3.head: 6. Tues
div3.p: I am as well as yesterday. Mrs Donaghe & Mrs Gregg here.

div3.head: 1867. August 7. Wed
div3.p: I am pretty comfortable. James & Frank went on a whortelby excursion yesterday & were away all night. James returned.

div3.head: 8. Thurs
div3.p: As well as yesterday. Mr Henderson here.

div3.head: 9. Fri
div3.p: Not so well. Went to Bethel. Mr Thomas preached, came home fatigued. James went to Staunton, and bought 3 yds of Cassimere for pantaloons for $5.25

div3.head: 10. Sat
div3.p: Not quite so well. Went to Bethel. Mr Thomas preached. A heavy rain. Called the Congl. meeting on the subject of calling a Collegiate Pastor.

It was reported to the meeting that the whole amount which was subscribed as salary was $647. and was voted, in view of the inadequate sum so furnished, to postpone the subject indefinitely. The session were authorized to provide a supply for the pulpit. Steps were taken to secure the tithe to our Church-property, according to a late law. I was the moderator of the meeting.

div3.head: 11. Sab
div3.p:
I feel better, went to Bethel. Mr Thomas preached an excellent Sermon, text-"God is love." I introduced the Communion Service & served the first Table with a good deal of strength of Voice
and some liberty of speech, thanks to God. Mr Thomas spent last night with us and by direction of the Session I paid him $20.00 to be refunded by them. It was a privilege to give it, he seemed so grateful, & said he had not one dollar.

div3.head: Aug. 12. Mon
div3.p: I am as well as yesterday. Began to plow beyond the creek for wheat.

div3.head: 13. Tues
div3.p: Pretty well. James went to Staunton to wait on Mr Baker who is to be married tomorrow to Miss Baylor. Mary went to see Mrs Tate.

div3.head: 14. Wed
div3.p: Rev. Dr. Dabney dined here. Had a very heavy Rain in the afternoon.

div3.head: 15. Thurs
div3.p: Rained all day. About 1 p.m. My cousin Col. Wm. C. Patterson of Phila. & his daughter Carie called to see us. We were delighted to see such valued Friends. But to our great disappointment they were obliged to return to Staunton.

div3.head: 16. Fri
div3.p: Not as well as usual. Plowing beyond the Springhouse.

div3.head: 17. Sat
div3.p: As well as Usual. Francis McF. Swoope came to consult me about going to Princeton Theol. Semy. I approved, under the circumstances.

div3.head: 1867. Aug. 18. Sab
div3.p: I preached today at Bethel for 50 minutes to a small Congn. & I think without much failure in voice or manner. It is a year since I preached last, thanks to God for the privilege.

div3.head: 19. Mon
div3.p: I am pretty well. James Mary & her children went to see the animal show in Greenville. Genl. Lilley & his cousin came to see us.

div3.head: 20. Tues
div3.p: James & Frank went with us to Staunton and Mrs McFarland & I went by Railroad to Pond Gap & to Crawford Spring. Mr Kunkle & A. Sproul & families there & we were treated very kindly.

div3.head: 21. Wed
div3.p: Reading. Conversing-drinking sulphur water.

div3.head: 22. Thurs
div3.p: Employed as yesterday.

div3.head: 23. Fri
div3.p: Mrs McF & Mrs Kunkle & John White went to Mr Saml. Bell's. A Mr Beall, who bought the Furnace of Burke & Kunkle spent the day with me-a very inteligent man & a great talker.

div3.head: 24. Sat
div3.p: Asthma last night. But little employed.

div3.head: 25. Sab
div3.p: I preached in the afternoon to more than 20 persons on the porch. Text, Rom. 8:6.

div3.head: 26. Mon
div3.p: Reached the Depot at 6.30 & Staunton about 7.30' Made a number of purchases & Dined at Andw Gilkeson's. James & Frank brought the Buggy & Rockaway and we came home. Glory to God. Mary Pringle here.

div3.head: 27. Tues
div3.p: Still feel fatigue. Reading &c. Miss Pringle left us. James finished the Cistern. Hauling manure.

div3.head: 28. Wed
div3.p: Reading. Yesterday wrote to Dr. Wm. S. White.

div3.head: 29. Thurs
div3.p: I have taken a bad cold. Burned my breast severely this morning with Mustard-feel badly.

div3.head: 30. Fri
div3.p: Last night I had a severe attack of Bileous Diarhea, which continued in some degree today. I also have a very troublesome Cough. Applied a poultice of Onions to my breast. Rose at 11.30 a.m.

div3.head: 31. Sat
div3.p: Better a little, able to study but little.

div3.head: September 1. Sab
div3.p: I rested badly & still not well, but went to Bethel expecting to preach, but found there Rev. John Randolph of the Baptist Church, who was raised in Middlebrook, in this Congn. but now resides in Albemarle Co. I prevailed on him to preach, which he did very acceptably.

At the close he stated that the first deep & permanent religious impression made on his mind was made in that house, under a sermon of mine from Josh. 10:12, 13, & that I was his spiritual Father. That must have been about 33 years ago. Let all the glory be to God.

div3.head: 1867. Sept 2. Mon
div3.p: Health as yesterday. Reading.

div3.head: 3. Tues
div3.p: I am more comfortable today.

div3.head: 4. Wed
div3.p: Not so well Francis McF. Gilkeson & his Bride called to see me. She seems a pleasant lady.

div3.head: 5. Thurs
div3.p: A little better. called.

div3.head: 6. Fri
div3.p: As usual. Nothing new.

div3.head: 7. Sat
div3.p: Not so well. A heavy Rain in the afternoon.

div3.head: 8. Sab
div3.p: The morning so damp & such a chilling NE wind that I dared not to go to Bethel. I was aware too that the Congn. would be very small. James & Frank went; they reported about two dozzen there. I felt much disappointed.

div3.head: 9. Mon
div3.p: I am as usual. Mr Houser with an 8 horse machine here threshing took out today 224 Bs. of wheat & 38 of Oats.

div3.head: 10. Tues
div3.p: Finished threshing before noon-had 260 Bs. of wheat, 17 sheaves made a bushel on an average. Had 150 Bushels of Oats, besides what we have fed.

div3.head: 11. Wed
div3.p: As well as usual. Day very cool. Sent 18 1/4 Bs. of wheat to mill.

div3.head: 12. Thurs
div3.p: As usual. Reading. Began to sow Wheat beyond the spring.

div3.head: 13. Fri
div3.p: Asthma last night, nothing new. Reading.

div3.head: 14. Sat
div3.p: Better. James & Frank went to Staunton. Sent 25 Bs. of wheat to mill. Brought home 2 Bls. of Flour.

div3.head: Sep. 15. Sab
div3.p: Day very damp, but I went & preached at Bethel to a tolerable Congn. for the day. I was much broken down. Had to go to bed at 5.30 & burn my breast severely with mustard.

div3.head: 16. Mon
div3.p: Spent a restless night. Had to burn my breast again with mustard, did not rise till 10 a.m. Today Frank left us to go to Washington College. May the Lord watch over him.

div3.head: 17. Tues
div3.p: had rather a better night, but I am feverish.

div3.head: 18. Wed
div3.p: Better. Finished harrowing in wheat beyond the creek. Sent to Cochrans mill 30 Bushels more of wheat. Mary went to Lexington today to see about Frank's affairs.

div3.head: 19. Thurs
div3.p: I am pretty comfortable. Sent 30 Bushels of Corn to Staunton which James sold at 87 1/2 ct. per 15.

div3.head: 20. Fri
div3.p: As yesterday. James took 25 Bs. of wheat to Staunton where he has sold 100 Bushels to the Bakers at $2. per Bl.

div3.head: 21. Sat
div3.p: Damp in the evening. Rain. James took the running years of the Old Carriage to Greenville for remoddleing.

div3.head: 22. Sab
div3.p: I feel feeble. Went to Bethel & preached to a good & attentive Congn. for about 45 minutes with a good degree of liberty. Thanks be to God. Much fatigued.

div3.head: 1867. Sep. 23. Mon
div3.p: Spent a restless night from fatigue. Feel better today. James went to Staunton for Bags to deliver the wheat in-got 38.

div3.head: 24. Tues
div3.p: I am better. John Wright hauled a load of wheat to Staunton (53 Bs) And James took a two horse load (25 Bs) Have delivered 104 Bushels & 20 lbs.

div3.head: 25. Wed
div3.p: I was sick in the night-better when up. J. Fix came after Breakfast & wrought till 3 p.m. putting a Frame on the Cistern Made Cider for apple Butter.

div3.head: 26. Thurs
div3.p: Not as well as usual. Cutting up corn to sow wheat on the ground.

div3.head: 27. Fri
div3.p: Better, but fatigued exceedingly with a little work. Began to sow wheat on corn ground, NE. end of NE. Field.

div3.head: 28. Sat
div3.p: Trying to study a little, but not over my fatigue.

div3.head: 29. Sab
div3.p: Feeble. Preached at Bethel 50 minutes, with a good deal of earnestness & liberty. I am very much fatigued. Mary Lou went to Wallace's.

div3.head: 30. Mon
div3.p: Partially rested. Wrote to Presby. my reason for absence. Mr Pilson came & we together made out the Statistical Report to Presbytery.

div3.head: Nov. 31. Tu
div3.p: I was quite sick last night, better today. James is plowing. The meadow white with frost.

div3.head: Nov. 2. Wed
div3.p: I am not as well as usual. Finished sowing wheat on the corn ground.

div3.head: 3. Thurs
div3.p: More unwell than yesterday. A very uncomfortable feeling in my breast & great debility. Last night the Rev. John Mathews Clymer came here and spent the night; he is collecting money to repair the Churches of Woodstock, Strasburg & Cedarbrook.

div3.head: 4. Fri
div3.p: I am very unwell. Mr Clymer returned this evening-has collected in Bethel $45.60

div3.head: 5. Sat
div3.p: Spent a very sick night more so than for months. This morning raining heavily. Mr Clymer left us, he is a very pleasant man. Liz leaves our service this evening, and we again employ Caroline Taper.

div3.head: 6. Sab
div3.p: I am very feeble & suffering with pain in my stomach, I think from Dyspepsy. Too weak to preach or even to go to Bethel. The white family all there, & a good Congn.

div3.head: 7. Mon
div3.p: I think I am a little better. James went to Staunton.

div3.head: 8. Tues
div3.p: I am about as yesterday. Reading.

div3.head: 9. Wed
div3.p: Last night was one of intense suffering from the eruption on my limbs-so great was the irritation that I often trembled all over & shuddered. Much distressed through the day. Rose at 11 a.m. went to bed 3 1/2 p.m. Mr & Mrs Pilson here.

div3.head: 1867. October 10. Thurs
div3.p: Although I suffered much last night, it was less than the night before. Today I am much depressed & remained in bed all day. The eruption has increased very little but the pimples are intensely sensitive in in the early part of the night.

div3.head: 11. Fri
div3.p: Had a better night than the two before preceding-eruption comparatively worse. Again in bed all day. I find it is better for the eruption, but I am quite unwell.

div3.head: 12. Sat
div3.p: Last night passed much like the preceding. I am not by any means well but rose at 1.30' p.m. James & Mary went to Staunton & brought Margarethe Lyons and Emma Derrick to make me a vest.

div3.head: 13. Sab
div3.p: An uncomfortable night & day. In bed all day. All went to Bethel except Miss Derrick & myself. Rev. Saml McNutt from Indiana preached.

div3.head: 14. Mon
div3.p: Rested rather badly-eruption increase to a little. In bed all day & not comfortable
Jacob Halyburton, a Freedman began today to work a month for me at Eleven dollars.
Wrote to Rev. W.M. McElwee & to James J. Whites & enclosed Rev. Dr. Smith's Check on Baltimore for $75. for Frank Lewis Tuition.

div3.head: 15. Wed. T.
div3.p: First part of last night very uncomfortable today rather better-rose at 11 a.m. & up till 5 p.m.

div3.head: 16. Wed
div3.p: Worse last night, sick this morning, then better. Wrote to Dr. B.M. Smith.

div3.head: 1867. October 17. Thurs
div3.p: Passed the best night for a week. The Eruption has ceased almost entirely to trouble me. But I have been quite sick. Made 4 Blls of Cider.

div3.head: 18. Fri
div3.p: Sick last night & suffer today with pain in my stomach-probably dyspepsy. Eruption a little worse. Rose about noon & dressed but back to return to bed.

div3.head: 19. Sat
div3.p: About as usual. Eruption not very troublesome. Rev. E.D. Junkin & P.P. Flournoy spent the night here, making me a kind visit. Gathering winter apples.
In bed all day. No symptoms of dispepsy.

div3.head: 20. Sab
div3.p: Rested better than usual, rose at 10.50' up till 4. All went to Bethel but Mrs McF. & I-no preaching.

div3.head: 21. Mon
div3.p: Still rested better-today as yesterday.

div3.head: 22. Tues
div3.p: Excessively fatigued last night-today as usual. Rose at 10 a.m. up till 5.30'. Lizzie & Mary Pilson here.

div3.head: 23. Wed
div3.p: A restless nervous night-not well today.

div3.head: 24. Thurs
div3.p: Almost sleepless till midnight, intended to remain in bed all day, but at 1 p.m. I rose & Married Benjamin Beagles & Catharine Weaver. James, Mrs McF. Margarethe & Emma went to Staunton.

div3.head: 25. Fri
div3.p: I am about as yesterday. Eruption somewhat troublesome.

div3.head: 26. Sat
div3.p: The Eruption aggravated & extended last night. Today better, up from noon till 5 p.m. Wrote to Blanton.

div3.head: 1867. Octr. 27. Sab
div3.p: The Eruption troublesome till after midnight, always easy towards morning. Today better, rose at noon. Up to worship. No preaching at Bethel.

div3.head: 28. Mon
div3.p: Rained all night & steadily all day today. I am as well as usual.

div3.head: 29. Tues
div3.p: I am not near as well as usual. My appetite has in a great manner failed. One of the heifers that we sent to the mountains was brought home having a Calf, One died as they said from eating , & one is missing.

div3.head: 30. Wed
div3.p: Spent a wretched time the first part of last night, nervous-restless & sleepless. Today I feel very badly feeble & uncomfortable. Eruption perfectly easy.
James took Margaretta Lyons & Emma Derrick to Staunton on their way to Washington.

div3.head: 31. Thurs
div3.p: Eruption scarcely perceptible. Snow fell in the night 6 inches deep, but all melted today.

div3.head: November 1. Fri
div3.p: Rested better than usual. Today I am pretty Comfortable.

div3.head: 2. Sat
div3.p: Rested tolerably-felt the eruption a little. Today as usual. Mr A.A. Sproul came to see me.

div3.head: 3. Sab
div3.p: I am rather better. All the white family at Bethel. No preaching.

div3.head: November 4. Mon
