div3.p: Rested pretty well. I am improving.

div3.head: 5. Tues
div3.p: Rested not very well, strength increasing.

div3.head: 6. Wed
div3.p: Slept as usual, not well today.

div3.head: 7. Thurs
div3.p: The eruption more troublesome. Mrs Sarah Ann Tate came to visit us. Sent the Minutes of Synod to Rev. W.E. Baker.

div3.head: 8. Fri
div3.p: Eruption increasing & the irritation rendered me so nervous that I suffered very much till midnight. Tolerably easy through the day.

div3.head: 9. Sat
div3.p: Last night I was miserable till near midnight-then pretty easy. Remained in bed all day, hoping thus to make the suffering of the two preceding nights. Mrs L.A. Trite left us. Day damp.

div3.head: 10. Sab
div3.p: I rested better-escaped nervousness, but I am very weak from the suffering of those two nights. Disappointed in not being able to go to Bethel. No preaching. Rev Wm. M. McElwee declines visiting us.

div3.head: 11. Mon
div3.p: Somewhat nervous-eruption a little troublesome. I feel great prostration today & quite unwell.

div3.head: 12. Tues
div3.p: Slept pretty well. Feeble. Rev. W.E. Baker & Rev. S.J. Baird, D.D. came to see me, the latter staid all night & we engaged to send him home.

div3.head: 1867. Nov. 13. Wed
div3.p: Rested badly till near midnight, then tolerably, today as usual.

div3.head: 14. Thurs
div3.p: Rested tolerably, but the Cold weather has increased the eruption which is troublesome.

div3.head: 15. Fri
div3.p: As usual. Rev. E. Thomas came & spent the night here. Remitted $2.00 by mail for the N.Y. Journal of Commerce.

div3.head: 16. Sat
div3.p: Eruption troublesome last night-today as usual. Sent for Rev. Dr. S.J. Baird to preach tomorrow.

div3.head: 17. Sab
div3.p: I am as usual, but could not venture to go to Bethel. Dr. Baird preached & Mr Thomas made an address-both dined here. James took Dr. B. home.

div3.head: 18. Mon
div3.p: Quite as well as usual. Mrs McF. & Mary went to Blackwood's and returned.

div3.head: 19. Tues
div3.p: Slept pretty well, but feel dull today.

div3.head: 20. Wed
div3.p: As usual, wrote to Dr. G. Junkin.

div3.head: 21. Thurs
div3.p: As usual. The Eruption has almost entirely left my lower limbs & now is very harrassing on the inside of my fore-arms. Mr & Mrs Kunkle made us a pleasant visit.

div3.head: 22. Fri
div3.p: Eruption as yesterday-otherwise the same.

div3.head: 23. Sat
div3.p: Eruption in my arms no better.

div3.head: 24. Sab
div3.p: As usual with me. Day very damp. I could not go to Bethel. Mrs McF. Mary & James went. No preaching.

div3.head: Nov. 25. Mon
div3.p: Eruption on my arms more troublesome. James, Mary & Mary Lou went to Staunton.

div3.head: 26. Tues
div3.p: About as usual

div3.head: 27. Wed
div3.p: Arms better. In other respects as usual.

div3.head: 28. Thurs
div3.p: As well as yesterday.

div3.head: 29. Fri
div3.p: Day such as I could not go to Bethel. Rev. Mr See preached & came & spent the night here.

div3.head: 30. Sat
div3.p: I am as usual, but the day so intensely cold I could not go to Bethel. Mr See preached.

div3.head: December 1. Sab
div3.p: The morning intensely cold-it was manifestly not my duty to go to Bethel. The white family went. Rev. Dr. S.L. Baird preached (they said very well) & administered the Lord's Supper. A good Congn. Dr. Baird spent the night with us.

div3.head: 2. Mon
div3.p: Had a very restless night-arms much irritated. Not as well as usual today.

div3.head: 3. Tues
div3.p: Rather better-arms still diseased. Finished husking corn on the stalk & hauling in. Supposed to have now 400 Bushels, not counting what was fed.

div3.head: 4. Wed
div3.p: As usual. Hauling wood.

div3.head: 5. Thurs
div3.p: Do. Snow last night, about 8 inches.

div3.head: 6. Fri
div3.p: Eruption less troublesome. Day very gloomy.

div3.head: 1867. Dec. 7. Sat
div3.p: The Eruption better. James went to Staunton & brought out Rev. James Murray he has been invited to preach at Bethel, in hopes he might suit the people for a Pastor. He is a pleasant gentleman.

div3.head: 8. Sab
div3.p: Too cold for me to venture out. Mr Murray preached, they say well.

div3.head: 9. Mon
div3.p: Eruption troubles me but little. After I rose I became very unwell-my pulse was more irregular than I ever knew it-a beat or two & then a flutter. Lay on the sofa all day.

div3.head: 10. Tues
div3.p: Still unwell, but better. In the night my pulse became regular. Did not rise till near 1 p.m.

div3.head: 11. Wed
div3.p: Better. Rose at 8 a.m. Killed 11 hogs weighing 1720 lbs.

div3.head: 12. Thurs
div3.p: Raing this morning, then sleeting, then snowing with a strong NE. wind, the Thermometer gradually sunk from 32 to 18 about 3 p.m. Rev. Mr Murry came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 13. Fri
div3.p: Very cold. Mr. Murray went to Staunton. (at 9 O'clock p.m. -1

div3.head: 14. Sat
div3.p: Suffered in the night from cold. Mr Murray returned, & spent the night.

div3.head: December 15. Sab
div3.p: Rested better. Mr Murray went to Bethel & preached, they said, a very good SerMon Rev. Mr Finley there.

div3.head: 16. Mon
div3.p: I am a little better, the cold weather has made the eruption a little troublesome. Dr. Humphreys spent the night here.

div3.head: 17. Tues
div3.p: As usual-day mild. In the evening Mary Pilson came & brought Rev. George W. Finley a Licentiate who comes by invitation of the Session to preach as a Candidate. He seems to be a pleasant man.

div3.head: 18. Wed
div3.p: I am as usual. Our friends left us.

div3.head: 19. Thurs
div3.p: Not well last night-languid today.

div3.head: 20. Fri
div3.p: Much as yesterday. Killed a Cow-Wt. 462 lbs.

div3.head: 21. Sat
div3.p: Rather Better. Day very threatening.

div3.head: 22. Sab
div3.p: Day very mild. All the white family went to Bl. Mr Finley, they said, preached well, & to a large Congn.

div3.head: 23. Mon
div3.p: Slept almost none last night till midnight. Unwell this morning-did not rise till near noon.

div3.head: 24. Tues
div3.p: I am better. Today Jefferson Howard's year ends and I paid him in full the ballance due = $30.00 He has been in my service six years altogether, & has been a faithful & pleasant servant.

div3.head: 1867. Dec. 25th Wed
div3.p: Christmas day. Pleasant. I am well today as is usual to me, of late. The family are all invited to dine at Mr Kunkles. Mrs McFarland, Mary, Mary Lou & Theda went. James went to a singing at Bethel. I and some of the servants remained at home.
Rev. Mr. Finley came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 26. Thurs
div3.p: As well as usual. Mr. Finley spent the day here. George Pilson dined with us.
I married at my own house George H. Buchanan and Sarah McManaway from Middlebrook. David Humphreys & two cousins came here.
I am as usual. Day very mild. James & David went to Staunton in the light waggon.

div3.head: 28. Sat
div3.p: Nothing new to note. Sent a new pair of Calfskin shoes to Frank Lewis.

div3.head: 29. Sab
div3.p: Weather moderate. all the white family went to Bethel. I ventured after an absence of three months. Mr. Finley preached a pretty good sermon from John 10:27. My sheep hear my voice & I know them & they follow me. A large Congn. By direction of the Session I gave notice of a Congl. meeting on Thursday on the subject of calling a Co-Pastor.

div3.head: Dec. 30. Mon
div3.p: Much colder an inche of Snow. As usual. James & Mary Lou went to Mrs Kings.

div3.head: 31. Tues
div3.p: I am as well as usual. The Eruption has entirely disappeared during the last two weeks.
It began to snow in the & continued snowing all day today-a fine snow driven by a strong NE wind.

I have this day endeavored to praise my God for his blessings to me and mine. Though not in perfect health yet it is as good, I suppose, as at my advanced age I have a right to expect. My Dear wife also enjoys good health, & my Daughter Mary Lewis is pretty well & James very well. My son-in-law & grand children also well.

This evening, before it was dark, Caroline discovered a heap of wheat under the Granary, where some person had bored a hole with an inch augur up through the floor, & probably carried away several bushels & left it running out.

div3.head: January 1. Wednesday.
div3.p: Diary for 1868
This Diary kept by Francis McFarland in regard to passing events in some affairs, I have found heretofore as an important aid to memory, especially in reference to matters of business.

Blessed be God I am in tolerably comfortable in health, though infirm & not daring to expose myself on account of my liability to Bronchitis. My family also all well, & all at home but Frank Lewis who is at Washington College. David & Theda Humphreys here.

div3.head: 2. Thurs
div3.p:
This day was appointed for a Congregational meeting to be held at Bethel to Call a Co-Pastor. Mrs McFarland, Mary & James went. Rev. T.L. Preston preached & moderated the meeting. No nominations, I am told, were made-each voted by ballot, & for whom he pleased. The only persons voted for were Rev. James Murray & Rev. George W. Finley. Mr Murray recd. 49 votes, & Mr Finley 21 or 22. Mr. Archd Christian, who voted for Mr Finley, moved that this vote be made unanimously for Mr Murray,
and it was done, wm can, & was declared unanimous by the Moderator.
I thin them both worthy men, but I trust the choice was ordered by the wisdom of God in answer to prayer.

div3.head: Jan. 3. Fri
div3.p: Sent off a letter to Mr Murray. James & Mary went on a visit to Mr Pilson, who is quite unwell. Mary remained.

div3.head: 4. Sat
div3.p: I am as usual. Benjn. McClung & Mrs McClung came & spent the day with us. Choice Friends.

div3.head: 5. Sab
div3.p: I feared to go to Bethel today-so much snow on the ground. Other members of the family went. No preaching but prayer-meeting.

div3.head: 6. Mon
div3.p: I am very languid. Reading. Snow 1 1/2 inches then rain

div3.head: 7. Tues
div3.p: Nothing new-reading-weather gloomy.

div3.head: 8. Wed
div3.p:
Health as usual. This is my Birth Day!!! I mark it as a wonder of God's Mercy, that he should allow me to complete Four Score Years. That I should have so much health & strength & such use of my faculties at such an age.
My Strength indeed is small, but my eyes seem to be improving so that I can read any tolerable print comfortably without glasses. And I think I could preach without much difficulty, if I could go to Church.

div3.head: 9. Thurs
div3.p: Very cold. James, Mary, Mary Lou & Theda went to Staunton in the Spring waggon. Dr. Humphreys spent last night with us.

div3.head: 10. Fri
div3.p: Day very cold. All as usual. I writing.

div3.head: 11. Sat
div3.p: Very cold. Rested badly. Not very well.

div3.head: 12. Sab
div3.p: I rested better, but the day is too cold for me to venture to go to Bethel. James went-said there was a pretty good Congn.-some expected me. Alas, how glad I would have been to have preached Christ to them.

div3.head: 13. Mon
div3.p: As well as usual. Jeff. & George getting wood.

div3.head: 14. Tues
div3.p: Snowing or sleeting all day. Wash came about noon to commence work for the remainder of the year. I wrote to Mrs E.H. Brown.

div3.head: 15. Wed
div3.p: Nothing new-day comparatively mild. Recd. letters from Rev. James Murray. Rev. Saml. Fulton & Mrs Annie Hale.

div3.head: 16. Thurs
div3.p: As usual. Liz. left us for Salem.

div3.head: 1868. January 17. Fri
div3.p: Cold Reading. Wrote to Rev. John S. Blain.

div3.head: 18. Sat
div3.p: Wrote to Frank Lewis. As well as usual.

div3.head: 19. Sab
div3.p: So cold I feared to venture out the white family went to Bethel. No preacher there alas. A letter was recd. from Rev. Mr Murray saying that he would be here on next Saturday to commence his labours as next Sabbath.
As usual. Recd. a letter from Col. Wm. C. Patterson, also one was recd. from Sister Roxa D. Bent. Day gloomy.

div3.head: 21. Tues
div3.p: James took Seven Barrels of Flour to Staunton, & sent it to Richmond through James Hardin, for a better price.

div3.head: 22. Wed
div3.p: Had an uncomfortable night-not well today. Mr James Hays & wife spent the day here. Sally & Lovey Gilkeson called in the afternoon.

div3.head: 23. Thurs
div3.p: Very unwell last night & not well today.

div3.head: 24. Fri
div3.p: I am better today. Reading & Writing some Reminicences respecting my beloved Pastor, Rev. Elisha Macurdy, for Rev. Richard for publication.
John Shields, Lizzie Wallace & Miss Bettie Shaw spent the night with us.

div3.head: January 25. Sat
div3.p: Having company, after eating my Breakfast in bed, I rose & conducted worship.

div3.head: 26. Sab
div3.p: Rested rather badly & not well this morning. Did not go to Bethel. The white family all went. Rev. James Murray preached, commencing his labors as Pastor of Bethel Church. This a Solemn fact in regard to myself who has been its sole Pastor so long. It meets my cordial approbation, and may God make his ministry a rich blessing to the Congregation. His text was 1 Cor. 2:2. For I determined not to know anything among you save Jesus Christ & him crucified. Certainly a very appropriate text.

div3.head: 27. Mon
div3.p: Day gloomy. I am not very well. Reading & writing.

div3.head: 28. Tues
div3.p: Breakfasted in bed-rose at 6.45' and at 7.30' I left home in a snow-storm & rode in my Buggy to Mrs Gilkeson's & there about 8.30' I married Dr. Carter Berkley & Lovie Gilkeson for which I recd. a fee of $10. They immediately set off for for Baltimore. I reached home by 10 a.m. without harm.

div3.head: 29. Wed
div3.p: I am as usual. It began to snow in the night & continued moderately all day.

div3.head: 1868. Jan. 30. Thurs
div3.p: I am as well as usual. James went to Staunton & sold 14 1/2 Bushels of Corn at 82 cents = $11.50. Also 3 tons of extra flour at $11.15 = $33.45 Total $45.65 Recd. payment of Baher & Brother. Paid for a Cornsheller $16.00 Also for 12 Flour Barrels at .75 = $9.00. Rev. Mr Murray & Mr Wm F. Smith came to see me. The former staid all night.

div3.head: 31. Fri
div3.p: Very cold. I am comfortable.

div3.head: February 1. Sat
div3.p: Colder. I am pretty well. Very little can be done of Business.

div3.head: 2. Sab
div3.p: All the white family at Bethel-too cold for me. Mr. Murray they said preached well.

div3.head: 3. Mon
div3.p: James took Mary to Rebecca McClure's, on her way to Lexington. I am as usual. 9 p.m. +3

div3.head: 4. Tues
div3.p: Nothing to note. Reading. Hauling wood.

div3.head: 5. Wed
div3.p: Snow or Sleet or Rain nearly all day. James went to Staunton & hired a Buggy at $1.25 per day to go to Robert McPheeters' wedding. Mine was too frail. The wedding to be tonight at Mr Speck's.

div3.head: 6. Thurs
div3.p: Very unwell last night-rose at 10.30' At 9.30' a.m. +41 mercury gradually sunk at 5 p.m. 20.

div3.head: Feb. 7. Fri
div3.p: Day very cold. James went to Staunton with the Buggy he had hired.

div3.head: 8. Sat
div3.p: Nothing important to note. Threatens snow.

div3.head: 9. Sab
div3.p: This morning there was about three inches of snow on the ground, but it rained nearly all day. James alone went to Bethel-only 12 or 13 persons there. Mr Murray preached.

div3.head: 10. Mon
div3.p: Had serious trouble on Saturday with our female servant Caroline from her outrageous temper. Today I proposed to dismiss her, but she seems unwilling to go away.

div3.head: 11. Tues
div3.p: Nothing to note in particular. Caroline working.

div3.head: 12. Wed
div3.p: I am pretty well. Nothing remarkable occurred.

div3.head: 13. Thurs
div3.p: Mr John McClung brought Mary home. James went to a Bridal Party at Mr James Gilkesons.

div3.head: 14. Fri
div3.p: Nothing of interest. Reading.

div3.head: 15. Sat
div3.p: Unwell last night. In the day I am pretty well, but feel badly in the night-cause unknown.

div3.head: 16. Sab
div3.p: had a bad nervous night-quite unwell this morning-not well enough to go to Bethel-all the white family went. Mr Murray, they said, preached an excellent Sermon

div3.head: 1868. Feb. 17. Mond.
div3.p: James went to Stuanton Suffered rather less last night, but my strength is declining.

div3.head: 18. Tues
div3.p: Rested badly again, but better when I rose. All the white family went to visit at Cris. Merritt's Mary staid to make some suits, & Theda left us to go to her home at Mr Donnells. She has been here since Nov. 30th

div3.head: 19. Wed
div3.p: Another bad night-feel very feeble today.

div3.head: 20. Thurs
div3.p: Had a comfortable night-blessed be God. Today I feel much better. Mrs McFarland & Mary Lou went to Mrs Gilkeson's. James went to a Party at Steel's, near Newport.

div3.head: 21. Fri
div3.p: Nearly as well as yesterday. Atmosphere very smoky.

div3.head: 22. Sat
div3.p: Nothing worthy of note.
All went to Church but me. Mr Murray preached.

div3.head: 24. Mon
div3.p: Cold & gloomy-a little Snow & sleet. I feel very dull.

div3.head: 25. Tues
div3.p: I feel great languor. One of the most gloomy days I ever saw.

div3.head: 26. Wed
div3.p: The gloom even deeper to for much of the day the woods could not be seen in any direction & the mist froze on the trees & on everything. Sad news-that Congress have voted to impeach President Johnston.

div3.head: 27. Thurs
div3.p: Gradually cleared off pretty mild. Suffered greatly last night, better in the afternoon-cause unknown.

div3.head: Feb. 28. Fri
div3.p: Rested rather better. The day has been exceedingly cold. Nothing new. Reading.

div3.head: 29. Sat
div3.p: I am as usual. Nothing to note.

div3.head: March 1. Sab
div3.p: Last night from 11 O'clock to 1 a.m. I was distressed exceedingly with nervous excitement. An eruption has for some day affected the small of my back & my henches & my left leg. I was easier in the early part of the day, but in the afternoon suffered more. Went to bed at dark. The family were delighted with Mr Murray's SerMon

div3.head: 2. Mon
div3.p: Rested rather better, but uncomfortably nervous I feel much prostration today Mr Murray here visiting us.

div3.head: 3. Tues
div3.p: Had a distressing time till after midnight, with extreme prostration & nervous excitement. Rose at 9 a.m. Better through the day. Mr Murray went to Staunton and returned & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 4. Wed
div3.p: Suffered as much last night as the preceding. This morning greatly depressed & through the day I felt very badly. Mr Murray & Mary went to Mr Preston's.

div3.head: 5. Thurs
div3.p: Rested rather better, still suffering much. Mr Murray & Mary returned to dinner.

div3.head: 1868. March 6. Fri
div3.p: Rested badly till about 2 a.m. I think the eruption is extending down my thighs & up the outside of my legs & is more irritable. I am taking Salts & a little Sulphur.
Mr Murray left us this morning.

div3.head: 7. Sat
div3.p: Rested somewhat better & feel better today. The day the mildest since early in Novr. I trust the warm weather will relieve me.

div3.head: 8. Sab
div3.p: Rested better than for a week past. Thanks be to God. Day very mild, but I am too weak to go to Bethel. I am tolerable comfortable at home. All the white family went to Church.

div3.head: 9. Mon
div3.p: As well as yesterday. Rode out on horseback.

div3.head: 10. Tues
div3.p: Very nervous last night. Rode out again. Began to plow for corn in the meadow in front of the house. This the warmest day since last October.

div3.head: 11. Wed
div3.p: Spent a pretty comfortable night, & am better than usual today.

div3.head: 12. Thurs
div3.p: Very nervous last night. Today very feeble.

div3.head: 13. Frid.
div3.p: Had a better night-better today. Reading Newspapers. Still plowing for corn.

div3.head: March 14th Sat
div3.p: Rested pretty well. The Eruption has ceased to trouble me almost entirely. A moderate shower today. Wrote to Dr. Junkin.

div3.head: 15. Sab
div3.p: Better. We all went to Bethel the first time for me this year. I was fatigued but stood it better than I expected. heard Mr Murray for the first time Text. Psm. 139:1,2, subject the Omniscience of God. The discourse was carefully written & notes used, but not servilely. It was a good discourse, but too rhetorical for my taste, as I love a severe simplicity.

div3.head: 16. Mon
div3.p: I thank God, except fatigue, I did not suffer from going to church yesterday. I am as well today as I have been of late.

div3.head: 17. Tues
div3.p: As usual. Day very warm. Jacob Halyburton came & began to work. I have hired him from this time till Christmas for $100. Dr. Humphreys and David came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 18. Wed
div3.p: Pretty well-cooler-finished plowing the sod of the meadow, & began to plow for oats in the NE. field.

div3.head: 19. Thur.
div3.p: As usual. Nothing worth noting. Washington finished his two months today.

div3.head: 1868. March 20. Fri
div3.p: Began to Snow very early & snowed very fast till, say 2 p.m. & gradually abated & ceased by dark. Although much melted, it accumulated to the depth of 8 inches. Reading.

div3.head: 21. Sat
div3.p: Cold. Nothing important to note.

div3.head: 22. Sab
div3.p: The day too cold for me to go to Bethel. All the white family went Mr Murray preached.

div3.head: 23. Mon
div3.p: I am not quite so well-a troublesome cough. James went to Staunton. Snow almost all gone. Bought a Bushel of Cloverseed for $10.00

div3.head: 24. Tues
div3.p: Not so well-cough harrassing. Sally Gilkeson, Lovey Berkley & Mr Murray here. Sowing cloverseed beyond the Springhouse.

div3.head: 25. W.
div3.p: Cough bad-applied mustard-it did good. A very unpleasant damp day-heavy rain.

div3.head: 26. Thurs
div3.p: Had a bad night with cough & oppression. Applied mustard again-felt so badly I remained in bed all day. Mr Murray left us in the afternoon.

div3.head: 27. Fri
div3.p: A somewhat better night-kept the fire up all night-am rather better today-rose about 1 p.m. Snow melted fast.

div3.head: March 28. Sat
div3.p: I was rather worse last night. Today not as well as yesterday-rose at 2 p.m. I breathe with difficulty & cough much.

div3.head: 29. Sab
div3.p: Last night much as the preceding-very weak. In bed all day. All went to Bethel-good Congn. & serMon

div3.head: 30. Mon
div3.p: Coughed rather less & slept better, but today not well. Remained in bed all day. Mrs Gilkeson & Dr Irwin Gilkeson came to see me. Mr Murray also came.

div3.head: 31. Tues
div3.p: I am still very unwell-burned my breast again with mustard. About 2 p.m. I rose & dressed Mr Pilson came see me & I sat up & talked with him till after sunset.

div3.head: April 1. Wed
div3.p: Very nervous for a while last night. Rested rather better, but sick after breakfast. Rose at noon. Mrs Wright came to see me.

div3.head: 2. Thurs
div3.p: Distressingly nervous-slept none till after midnight-rose at 11 a.m. Wrote to Mrs A.G. Hale.

div3.head: 3. Fri
div3.p: Rested much better last night. Rose at 8 a.m. and am much better today. Services preparatory to the Communion commenced today. Mary & I were unable to go. Rev. Wm. E. Baker preached.

div3.head: 1868. April 4. Sat
div3.p: Rested pretty well-rose at 8 a.m. All the white family went to Bethel but myself. Mary Lou Lewis was received into the Communion of the Church. Thanks be to God. I trust she has experienced the needful change. There were also recd. Anne L. Smith, Mollie Mooman, Mary F. Wilson, Ellen J. Wilson on Exm. & Bettie Beard on Cert. from Old Providence. Rev. Wm. E. Baker preached.

div3.head: 5. Sab
div3.p: Did not rest so well, & alas, unable to go to Bethel. The day cold. Mr Baker came & dined with us.

div3.head: 6. Mon
div3.p: Rested tolerably-not so well today. Plowed the Garden. Plowing for oats NE field.

div3.head: 7. Tues
div3.p: Did not sleep well-rose at 10 a.m. It began to rain before day & continued till the afternoon.

div3.head: 8. Wed
div3.p: Slept better & am better today. James went to a wedding at Mr Dunlap's.

div3.head: 9. Thurs
div3.p: As usual, the Eruption on my legs troublesome. Mr Donohe came to list taxable property.

div3.head: 10. Fri
div3.p: Eruption less irritated. James & Mary returned. Nothing worth noting.

div3.head: April 11. Sat
div3.p: I am rather better.

div3.head: 12. Sab
div3.p: Better. All went to Bethel. Mr Murray preached from Mat. 12:20-Brused Reed &c. I closed with prayer. Came home much fatigued-had to go to bed at 4.30' p.m.

div3.head: 13. Mon
div3.p: Rested pretty well-today I am as usual. Mrs McFarland, James & Mary Lou went to Mr Blackwoods

div3.head: 14. Tues
div3.p: A very heavy rain with thunder & lightening. James went to Staunton for a Bundle of useful articles sent to us by Mrs E.H. Brown which came to her in a Box from Rev. Dr. Vandeke's Church in Brooklin, N.Y.

div3.head: 15. Wed
div3.p: Was very unwell in the night-weak today. Ground to wet to plow or harrow.

div3.head: 16. Thurs
div3.p: Still very feeble & feel badly but am reading & writing.

div3.head: 17. Fri
div3.p: I am rather better. Mary has been suffering severely for 3 days with Pain in her head & back &c. Sent for Dr. Tate-he came & prescribed.

div3.head: 18. Sat
div3.p: I am as usual. Mary is better-sat up for some time. Harrowing in oats. Wrote to Wm. L. Bent.

div3.head: 1868. April 19. Sab
div3.p: Last night I suffered from extreme debility. Did not rise till noon. Mary & I alone at home. Sleet for some hours, then moderate rain. Dr. Tate to see Mary who is still better.

div3.head: 20. Mon
div3.p: Spent a restless night, today better.

div3.head: 21. Tues
div3.p: I am rather better-nothing new.

div3.head: 22. Wed
div3.p: In status quo-day very fine. Reading.

div3.head: 23. Thurs
div3.p: I am much distressed with pain in my back. The warmest day since Oct. last. James went to Staunton-took some potatoes & corn & brought home half a ton of Plaster.

div3.head: 24. Fri
div3.p: Sowed more Oats on the NE field My back very painful.

div3.head: 25. Sat
div3.p: Back very llittle better. L.C. Brown & son working in the garden. James plowing. Rain.

div3.head: 26. Sab
div3.p: Back no better. Mary & I at home. Rev. Mr Junkin preached & came & spent the night here-a very kind visit.

div3.head: 27. Mon
div3.p: Back worse. Rose at 11 a.m.

div3.head: 28. Tues
div3.p: Back a little better-rose about noon.

div3.head: April 29. Wed
div3.p: Back no better-in bed all day.

div3.head: 30. Thurs
div3.p: Had a bad night-coughed much-better today, but thought it best to remain in bed all day. Finished sowing Oats on the NE field.

div3.head: May 1. Thurs. Fri
div3.p: Rested rather better till about 2 p.m. My back a little better. Plowing for corn.

div3.head: 2. Sat
div3.p: Rested better-back better. Mr Pilson came to see me. Finished plowing for corn in front of the house.

div3.head: 3. Sab
div3.p: About as yesterday. Distressing news-James Hays was found dead yesterday on the road near Cris. Merritts, supposed to be from disease of the heart. He was an Elder of our Church & I think a truly good man. All the white family left me. Mr Murray preached.

div3.head: 4. Mon
div3.p: James & his mother went to the Funeral. Mr J.S. Blain came on a visit to us.

div3.head: 5. Tues
div3.p: Mr Blain remained all day with us. James & Mary went to Staunton.

div3.head: 6. Wed
div3.p: I am as usual. Mr Blain returne toward home.

div3.head: 7. Thurs
div3.p: Wrote to Col. W.C. Patterson. Rain stopped work.

div3.head: 8. Fri
div3.p: I am as usual-Sowed Plaster NW field.

div3.head: 9. Sat
div3.p: My back worse. Marking out for corn.

div3.head: 1868. May 10. Sab
div3.p: Better but not able to go to Bethel. All the white family went. Mr Murray preached.

div3.head: 11. Mon
div3.p: Not well. Lay in bed till 2 p.m. Began to plant corn in front of the house.

div3.head: 12. Tues
div3.p: From 2 a.m. coughed much-breast feels very badly. I feel worse today than heretofore-in bed all day. Finished planting. Day very damp & uncomfortable.

div3.head: 13. Wed
div3.p: Had a somewhat better night. It rained incessantly all night & heavily till 10 a.m. then showers. I remained in bed all day, & in the morning could not even read I felt so uncomfortable. But my breast is better & I cough less. My back still painful.

div3.head: 14. Thurs
div3.p: Rested not so well-coughed much-felt badly about 10 a.m. a little better-rose & dressed, but felt badly-ate my dinner with the family, but had to go to bed about 4 p.m. My breast is sore & my cough of a threatening character.

div3.head: 15. Fri
div3.p: Another uncomfortable night-worse in every way. Sent James for Dr Tate-he came about 3 p.m. prescribed Ipicac powder & mustard between my shoulders & Petroleum on my breast.

div3.head: May 16. Sat
div3.p: I thought myself decidedly worse this morning, but I improved somewhat during the day-but I still regard my health as dangerous-my cough is a bad one & breast sore internally.

div3.head: 17. Sab
div3.p: Rested tolerably, but felt badly in the morning. My most favourable symptom is less internal soreness in my breast, but my cough is not lessened. I take Ipicac 5 times a day. In bed all day. No preaching at Bethel. James went to Staunton to hear Rev. Dr. J.R. Wilson sent the Minutes of Synod by him to the Assembly.

div3.head: 18. Mon
div3.p: Not so well-pulse excited. Sent for Dr. Tate-he came about 4 p.m. made me some pills of bluemass. Ipecac & quinine-one to be taken morning & evening.

div3.head: 19. Tues
div3.p: Took the pills as preserved-slept tolerably-the Ipecac in the pills kept me sick all morning, in the afternoon much better. In bed all day. Mr Merritt, Rev. Murray, Dr. Tate & Dr. Gilkeson & Fannie Wright here. Planted Potatoes.

div3.head: 20. Wed
div3.p: had not a good night-felt badly this morning. In the afternoon as well as yesterday again had my breast rubed with Petrolatum. I think it has done me good. Mr Pilson came to see me.

div3.head: 1868. May 21. Thurs
div3.p: Had a distressing time last night with coughing-felt very badly this morning, but better in the afternoon.

div3.head: 22. Fri
div3.p: Night & morning much like the preceding. Near noon rose & dressed for the first time since the 11th Remained up till near 5 p.m. Not very comfortable.

div3.head: 23. Sat
div3.p: Spent a pretty comfortable night-rose at 11 a.m. Rained in the night, & all day, moderately.

div3.head: 24. Sab
div3.p: Had a tolerable night-rose at 11 a.m. Subsequently felt great debility. Rained moderately in the morning. Mrs McFarland & I staid at home-others went to Bethel. Mr M preached. The weather partially cleared off.

div3.head: 25. Mon
div3.p: Perhaps a little better. C. Merritt & wife here. Remained up till 9 p.m. Led in family prayer-fatigued.

div3.head: 26. Tues
div3.p: About as yesterday-Mr & Mrs Merrit left us to be absent several days.

div3.head: 27. Wed
div3.p: Not as well as on yesterday. Mrs McF. & Mary Lou & Mrs Wright made a visit at Mr Wm. Swink's.

div3.head: 28. Thurs
div3.p: I suffered more real sickness this morning than for many days-in the afternoon better. Rose at 1.15' p.m.

div3.head: May 29. Fri
div3.p: Rested better. I am better today. Rose at 9.30'a.m. The welcome news has arrived-the Impeachment of the Pres. of the U.S. has failed.

div3.head: 30. Sat
div3.p: Not so well this morning. Rose at 9 a.m. Better. James returned in the afternoon.

div3.head: 31. Sab
div3.p: All went to Bethel. I remained at home alone. Mr Murray preached.

div3.head: June 1. Mon
div3.p: Coughed very much last night somewhat sick this morning-better when I rose. Rev. Wm. Pinkerton came to see me.

div3.head: 2. Tues
div3.p: Had a better night, but sick after breakfast.

div3.head: 3. Wed
div3.p: Not so well. Rose at 11 a.m.

div3.head: 4. Thurs
div3.p: Suffered much last night with a burning sensation in my breast. Rose near 11 a.m. Dr. Tate came to see me. He gave me some quinine powders. In the afternoon I felt much worse than usual.

div3.head: 5. Fri
div3.p: Rested rather better, but this morning suffered with my breast-burned it with mustard.

div3.head: 6. Sat Sat
div3.p: Slept pretty well, but have felt badly today. Heat & soreness in my breast, & my spittle frequently redish as if discoloured with blood.

div3.head: 1868. June 6. Sat continued.
div3.p: The day appointed for the Installation of Rev. James Murray as Collegiate Pastor in Bethel. I desired much to be present but was entirely unable.

Rev. Wm. E. Baker preached the sermon, Rev. Mr Preston Charged the Pastor & Mr Richeson on the People. The Congn. it was said was large & the services interesting. May God follow it with his Blessing.

div3.head: 7. Sab
div3.p: Still suffer with my breast but slept tolerably. Rose about noon & feel somewhat better. Mary is suffering with Palpitation of the heart. Sent James to Staunton to see Dr. Waddell & to get some Medicines. He returned brought a bottle of Cod-liver Oil ($1.50) A vial consisting of Mur. Tinc. Iron 11 Fowler's Solution 11 Strychnine 2 grains Dose 15 drops 3 times a day. 35 cents.

div3.head: 8. Mon
div3.p: Rested tolerably but had a sick day-took no medicine today-rose at noon.

div3.head: 9. Tues
div3.p: Very feeble. Mr. D. Kunkle & wife made us a visit.

div3.head: 10. Wed
div3.p: About as yesterday. Dr. J.A. Waddell made me a kind professional visit. Began to take Cod-liver Oil and drops compounded of mer. of iron, Fowlers Solution & Strycnine.

div3.head: 11. Thurs
div3.p: Little change rose at noon. Medicine made me sick yesterday-took none today.

div3.head: 12. Fri
div3.p: Rested tolerably & am better today. Took one dose of Cod liver Oil & 8 drops of the mixture.

div3.head: 13. Sat
div3.p: In statu quo 8 drops of the mixture me.

div3.head: 14. Sab
div3.p: Mr Murray & B. McClung spent the night here. I talked so much, my breast became sore and painful. I rested badly. Mr Murray preached at Hebron. Mrs McFarland, James & Mary Lou went there. I rose about 10 a.m. not well-retired early.

div3.head: 15. Mon
div3.p: Had Asthma badly sleeping in the study. Had to rise a little after midnight & sat up till day break. Today my breathing has been bad.

div3.head: 16. Tues
div3.p: Still so astmatic I feared to go to bed & slept on the sofa in the central room till daybreak when I ventured to go to bed. I am better today. James went to Lexington to the College Commencement & to arrange for getting Frank Lewis home.

div3.head: 17. Wed
div3.p: Slept in the study-tolerably-better. Wrote to Rev. Richard Lea. In the Afternoon the heaviest rain of the season-flooded our corn & washed it badly.

div3.head: 1868. June 18. Thurs
div3.p: Rested better. Very weak today & my back more painful. More rain.

div3.head: 19. Fri
div3.p: Rested tolerably, but quite sick this morning, then better. Dr. Tate called to see me before I was up. Frank W. Lewis came down in the stage last night, and walked home from Mint Spring before dinner Fare $3.00

div3.head: 20. Sat
div3.p: Rather better today. Began to take Tinc. of Gentian. Frank went to Staunton to bring out Mrs Anna P. Derrick, who came.

On yesterday there was a fearful thunderstorm, tremendous wind some hail & the greatest flood for years. The lightening struck a locust tree close to our Back-house & took one of the cornerposts of the house & tore several pieces off it.

div3.head: 21. Sab
div3.p: Rested tolerably, but felt badly this morning. All went to Bethel but Mrs Derrick & myself.

div3.head: 22. Mon
div3.p: Rather better-working-mending articles. Frank went to Staunton to see about Mrs Derrick's trunk. A Telegram reported it safe in Charlottesville. Finished working corn till after Harvest.

div3.head: 23. Tues
div3.p: As well as yesterday. Rode out a little. Began to mow Clover in the NW. field with two hands beside our own = 4.

div3.head: June 24. Wed
div3.p: Was very unwell last night. Did not rise till 10.30' a.m. then better. Four hands mowing again today.

div3.head: 25. Thurs
div3.p: Slept pretty well after breakfast & during the day felt badly. It rained heavily in the night with thunder & lightening & rained again in the morning, so that we declined mowing any more.

div3.head: 26. Fri
div3.p: Had a bad night-felt so unwell I did not rise till noon. Fearing the atmosphere of the study was injurious-removed back to the middle room, after remaining in the study two weeks.

div3.head: 27. Sat
div3.p: Rested much better last night-but feeble today. James took Mrs A.P. Derrick to Staunton, & brought home a sack of salt. About 2 p.m. had the greatest flood which we have had for many years.

div3.head: 28. Sab
div3.p: All went to Bethel but me. I am as usual.

div3.head: 29. Mon
div3.p: I am as yesterday. Making & hauling in hay. In the afternoon, John Gilkeson cutting clover for us with his mower.

div3.head: 30. Tues
div3.p: As usual. Began to cut Wheat. Hauling in hay. Wrote to Rev. James P. Smith's.

div3.head: 1868. July 1. Wed
div3.p: I am rather better. Harvesting.

div3.head: 2. Thurs
div3.p: I am as yesterday. Cutting Wheat.

div3.head: 3. Fri
div3.p: A little improved. James & Jac. assisting John Wright cutting wheat. Day exceedingly warm.

div3.head: 4. Sat
div3.p: I think I am gaining a little more strength. Cutting wheat beyond the springhouse.

div3.head: 5. Sab
div3.p: All went to Bethel-the first time for me since Apl. 12. Mr Murray preached an excellent sermon on Hag. 1:7-"consider your ways." I came home much fatigued-day warm-probably 90, but no one at home to see-two very light showers. Went to bed at 5 p.m.

div3.head: 6. Mon
div3.p: Slept pretty well & feel rested & tolerably well.

div3.head: 7. Tues
div3.p: As well as usual. Jac. & Jeff. & Frank harvesting for me at Mr Gilkeson's.

div3.head: 8. Wed
div3.p: Nothing new. Cutting wheat NE. field.

div3.head: 9. Thurs
div3.p: I am not so well-perhaps have taken cold. Finished our wheat harvest-have 221 dozens.

div3.head: 10. Fri
div3.p: I am very feeble today. Rev. Mr Murray came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 11. Sat
div3.p: Unusually sick this morning. Mr Murry remained & Rev. E. Thomas came. Finished mowing the NW Field. J. Gilkeson cut it with his mower.

div3.head: July 12. Sab
div3.p: We all went to Bethel. I was not well. Mr Murry preached well-an awful serMon Text Mat. 3:7 Flee from the wrath to come. I came home excessively fatigued-went to bed at 5 p.m.

div3.head: 13. Mon
div3.p: Not very well today. Putting up hay.

div3.head: 14. Tues
div3.p: Much better today. Very warm-hauling hay, and began to haul in wheat.

div3.head: 15. Wed
div3.p: Better, but suffering with heat. On Monday, James accidentally turning his head, had a dead twig to run into his ear causing it to bleed & it is now quite painful. Hauling in wheat.

div3.head: 16. Thurs
div3.p: As usual. This the warmest day for many years: 1860 one day as warm. Finished hauling in Wheat & hay-all in good order.

div3.head: 17. Fri
div3.p: Not quite so well. Nothing worthy of note.

div3.head: 18. Sat
div3.p: James went to Staunton to see the Doctor about his ear & they pronounce that the Tympanum is perforated, as I feared. I am as usual.

div3.head: 19. Sab
div3.p: Last night was one of pain & suffering. I did not rise till 11 a.m. Mrs McF. remained at home with me.

div3.head: 1868. July 20. Mon
div3.p: I am better. A little rain last night & today, & it is somewhat cooler.

div3.head: 21. Tues
div3.p: As yesterday. Mrs McFarland, Mary, James & Frank went to Hebron where the Presbytery is called to meet for the purpose of dissolving Mr Prestons Pastoral Relation that he may accept a call from the church of Salem. The family spent the night at Mr Saml Bell's.

div3.head: 22. Wed
div3.p: I rested pretty well but sick this morning. The family returned at noon. Cutting Oats.

div3.head: 23. Thurs
div3.p: I had an uncomfortable night, but better through the day. James took his mother & sister to a meeting of the Female Cent Society in Greenville.

div3.head: 24. Fri
div3.p: Rested better, but very unwell today. Cutting Oats.

div3.head: 25. Sat
div3.p: Still unwell-head disordered. Cutting & hauling in oats. Mr. Murray here.

div3.head: 26. Sab
div3.p: Too unwell to go to Church. All the family went but me. Pain over my right eye. Began to rain early in the night & rained moderately all night.

div3.head: 27. Mon
div3.p: I suffered much with the pain over my eyes. Applied a volatile Linament much better this afternoon. It rained moderately all day.

div3.head: July 28. Tues
div3.p: Rested tolerably, but suffered much this morning with Neuralgia in my face. Had a brief but pleasant visit from Gen. R.D. Sidey. Cutting Oats. I am able to read a little.

div3.head: 29. Wed
div3.p: Rather better today. Asthma & Neuralgia also.

div3.head: 30. Thur.
div3.p: Rested pretty well. About 4 a.m. the pain above my eye began & grew worse till 8 then abated a little. At 10, all but Mary Lou went to Bethel. This a day of Fasting & prayer appointed by our Gen. Assy. I spoke about half an hour. The jolting &c &c made the pain in my head worse & it continued bad till I reached home, then gradually abated.

div3.head: 31. Fri
div3.p: Pain abated. Nothing of importance to note.

div3.head: August 1. Sat
div3.p: Pain aggravated. Better P.M. Finished cutting Oats. Showers.

div3.head: 2. Sab
div3.p: Not well rather less pain. Showers all day. All went to Bethel but me.

div3.head: 3. Mon
div3.p: As usuall-more pain. Hauling in Oats. Mrs Hays, Sarah Jane Hays, Miss Trotter & John Hays here.

div3.head: 4. Tues
div3.p: Less pain. Suffered from the too free operation of a portion of salts & Cream of Tartar. James went to Staunton.

div3.head: 1868. August 5. Wed
div3.p: I am better-pain moderate. Two heavy showers in the afternoon.

Mary went to Greenville to stay till Sabbath. I wrote to Rev. L.H. Blanton & remitted to him $7.25 the balance of his salary as Assistant stated Clerk of Synod $50. in a Post office order on the Postmaster of Danville Ky.

div3.head: 6. Thurs
div3.p: As well as usual for me. Putting pitch & charcoal on the roof of the house above the tin.

div3.head: 7. Fri
div3.p: Not so well. Got in the last of our oats. James took a load of corn to Staunton, which he sold to Baker Brothers for $1.15 per Bushel.
David & Theda Humphreys came on a visit to us.

div3.head: 8. Sat
div3.p: Not well. James took another load of corn to Staunton. Rev. Dr. S.J. Baird & wife came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 9. Sab
div3.p: Suffered with pain in my bowels last night. Took Ginger & Camphor. This morning my head is so affected I did not rise till near noon. All went to Bethel but me. Dr. Baird preached & they came back to dinner & in the evening returned to Staunton.

div3.head: August 10. Mon
div3.p: I am as well as usual. Began to haul out Manure on NE field.

div3.head: 11. Tues
div3.p: As yesterday-rain in the evening.

div3.head: 12. Wed
div3.p: In statu quo. Mrs McF went to Mr Hendersons

div3.head: 13. Thurs
div3.p: Dr Humphreys spent the night with us. James left home this morning.

div3.head: 14. Fri
div3.p: Spent a very uncomfortable night-the first part entirely sleepless-today very languid. Frank & Jac at noon went to help John Wright to thresh

div3.head: 15. Sat
div3.p: I am rather better. Frank at Wrights half the day & Jac all day. James returned. Mary feeble.

div3.head: 16. Sab
div3.p: Mary & I are both too feeble to go to church. All other went. Rev. Mr M.H. Houston preached. he is about to go to China as a Missionary. He came here & spent the night with us. He is a pleasant man.

div3.head: 17. Mon
div3.p: I am about as yesterday. We sent Mr. Houston to Staunton. A moderate rain here in the afternoon, but I think it must have been very heavy eastward. Rain in the night.

div3.head: 18. Tu.
div3.p: Nothing new. Wrote to Gen. R. Patterson.

div3.head: 19. Wed
div3.p: I am not so well. Finished hauling out manure.

div3.head: 1868. August 20. Thurs
div3.p: As well as I have been. All hands went to mend the road to Bethel. Mrs Jas. Henderson came to see me, & brought me a kind present of nine Peaches & a jar of honey.

div3.head: 21. Fri
div3.p: Services preparatory to the Communion began to-all went to Church but Mary & me. Mr Murray preached-no assistance.

div3.head: 22. Sat
div3.p: I am very feeble. Mary also-we both remained at home. Mr Murray preached.

div3.head: 23d. Sab
div3.p: I am very unwell, but made a desperate effort to go to Bethel. Mary too feeble & unwell to go. Mr Murray preached & I introduced the Communion & served the first table. Mr Murray closed. I came much fatigued-but I thank God for the privilege of being there & participating in the services.

div3.head: 24. Mon
div3.p: Spent an uncomfortable night-much unwell this morning. Mrs McF went to Staunton with John Wright. Mr Housers Threshing machine brought here & threshed a few hours. Miss Baird came home with Mrs McF.

div3.head: 25. Tues
div3.p: A restless night-threshed till near noon. 180 Bl. of oats & 42 1/2 of Wheat.

div3.head: August 26. Wed
div3.p: Had a better night, but not so well today. Began to plow oat stubble for wheat in the NE. field.

div3.head: 27. Thurs
div3.p: My condition about as yesterday.

div3.head: 28. Fri
div3.p: Nothing new. Mr Pilson here-says he thinks the Congn. has subscribed about $125 for Frank.

div3.head: 29. Sat
div3.p: As well as usual. Plowing. Wrote yesterday & today to Wm. L. Bent.

div3.head: 30. Sab
div3.p: Went to Bethel. Mr Murray sick, I had to conduct the worship. Messrs. Pilson & Humphries Prayed & I spoke about 35 minutes from Phil. 2:1-11, extempore. David & Theda Humphreys left us. I came home very much fatigued.

div3.head: 31. Mon
div3.p: I am as well as usual. Nothing new.

div3.head: September 1. Tues
div3.p: Warm. Still plowing. I am better.

div3.head: 2. Wed
div3.p: I am taking cold. At 5 p.m. a heavy rain & a great flood.

div3.head: 3. Thurs
div3.p: Had a distressing night with hard coughing. Feel very badly today-pulse 110.

div3.head: 4. Fri
div3.p: Did not suffer quite so much last night, but today I am very feeble & unwell no appetite pulse 96.

div3.head: 1868. Sept. 5. Sat
div3.p: Had an uncomfortable night & today very unwell. In bed all day, food makes me sick. I have almost no appetite. Mrs Coleman Jr came here.

div3.head: 6. Sab
div3.p: I spent a wretched night. Slept but little suffered much from nervousness. This morning food sickens me. Sent for Dr. Tate-he came & prescribed blue pill. In bed all day. Very feeble.

div3.head: 7. Mon
div3.p: Spent another night of suffering-sick for several hours-then severe head-ache. Toward noon rather better. Almost no appetite. In bed all day.

div3.head: 8. Tues
div3.p: Had a much better night, but in the morning felt extreme debility-afterwards felt better. Dr. Tate came-thinks I need no more medicine, but left me a vial of Bromide of Polassia-to take a teaspoonful at night to produce repose of nervous & excitement. In bed all day. Mrs Wright here.

div3.head: 9. Wed
div3.p: Amid great prostration rested rather better. I think I am a little better today. William Pilson here all night.

div3.head: 10. Thurs
div3.p: Slept tolerably-am a little stronger & my appetite a little improved, but still in bed. Finished plowing for wheat NE field.

div3.head: Sept. 11. Fri
div3.p: As well as yesterday. Mr Pilson & Andw Sarah Stuart came & I Baptized Stuart's daughter Sarah Steel Stuart-rose & dressed for that purpose-the first time for a week. Dined at the table. Very feeble.

div3.head: 12. Sat
div3.p: a little farther improved. Rose at 9.30' up till 5. Dr. Gilkeson & Miss Tate here. Cutting Cloverseed with McPheeters Reaper.

div3.head: 13. Sab
div3.p: An uncomfortable night-very feeble. All went to Bethel but Mary Lou & I-rose at 11 & up till 5. A heavy shower.

div3.head: 14. Mon
div3.p: Rested better but still am very weak. Frank & James went to Staunton & took Mrs Coleman home. A very heavy rain today.

div3.head: 15. Tues
div3.p: About as usual-day gloomy & damp. Ground too wet to sow wheat.
Mrs McFarland & Frank went to Mr Blackwood.

div3.head: 16. Wed
div3.p: Rested only tolerably-not well today.

div3.head: 17. Thurs
div3.p: Still unwell-can sit up but little. Sent Frank to Mr Pilson's on his way to College.

div3.head: 1868. Sep. 18. Fri
div3.p: Rested better than usual. Quite a white frost this morning. Began to sow wheat in the NE field.

div3.head: 19. Sat
div3.p: Rested badly. Unwell today, did not rise till 1.30' p.m. then could not sit up. Taking Confodder. L Brown assisting.

div3.head: 20. Sab
div3.p: An uncomfortable night, but better through the day. All went to Bethel but me.

div3.head: 21. Mon
div3.p: I am about as yesterday. Sowing wheat & taking Cornfodder. L. Brown here at work.

div3.head: 22. Tues
div3.p: I am rather better. Business as yesterday. L. Brown here half the day. A shower near noon.

div3.head: 23. Wed
div3.p: I am still better. Same business carried on.

div3.head: 24. Thurs
div3.p: Rested pretty well, very languid today. Day very damp & mizzleing-business as yesterday.
I am as usual. Too wet to harrow.
As usual. Still too wet. Mrs McF & Mary went to dine at Mrs Gilkeson's. Mr Murray spent the night here.

div3.head: 27. Sab
div3.p: I am tolerable. Mrs McF. James & Mary Lou went to Hebron where Mr Bell & Mr Murray administered the Lord's Supper. Rev. Mr Finley preached by invitation in the afternoon.

div3.head: Sept. 28. Mon
div3.p: As usual. Day fine-ground in good order-finished seeding in the NE field.

div3.head: 29. Tues
div3.p: Some increase in strength. Finished the corn-fodder & hauling in cloverseed. Removed my bed to the South end of the room.

div3.head: 30. Wed
div3.p: As yesterday. All the white family went to Staunton.

div3.head: October 1. Thurs
div3.p: Not so well-did not rise 11 a.m. then better. James went to Midway & got 3,100 Chestnut shingles at $4 per thousand = $12. In the evening I married John W. Hays to Frances V. Wright, & returned home at 8.30'.

div3.head: 2. Fri
div3.p: I am better than yesterday. Nothing new.

div3.head: 3. Sat
div3.p: I am as yesterday. Mr Murray, Wife & son came to dinner, & to remain all night.

div3.head: 4. Sab
div3.p: Mr Murray & family left us. It rained so all day that none of us but James went to Bethel-Only 12 persons there. It rained much of the night.

div3.head: 5. Mon
div3.p: I am as usual-nothing new.

div3.head: 6. Tues
div3.p: James & Jac. & Caroline & Arpy went to Staunton with a load of Corn (10) & Oats (24 lbs.)

div3.head: 1868. Octr. 7. Wed
div3.p: Not as well as usual.

div3.head: 8. Thurs
div3.p: I am better than yesterday. Mary & Mary Lou & James went to Greenvill & to Cris. Merritt's, & James to R.T. Wallace's.

div3.head: 9. Fri
div3.p: As usual. Jas. & Mary Lou returned. I have been reading & Wrote to John B. Baldwin informing him that I was unable to go to Staunton to offer the opening Prayer at the Fair.

div3.head: 10. Sat
div3.p: As usual. Nothing special to record.

div3.head: 11. Sab
div3.p: Better but the eruption on my thighs troubles me. All went to Bethel-I had not been there for six weeks-Mr Murray preached a good Serm. Col. 3:1,2.

div3.head: 12. Mon
div3.p: As well as yesterday-reading.

div3.head: 13. Tues
div3.p: The Eruption on my thighs troublesome. Mary Lou went to Mr Merritts to go with Mr Murray &c to the Natl. Bridge. Shingling the shop.

div3.head: 14. Wed
div3.p: Very feeble & dull. Rained incessantly all day. James & White out making Gates.

div3.head: 15. Thurs
div3.p: It rained all last night. Cloudy all day. I continue very feeble, but not suffering much.

div3.head: October 16. Fri
div3.p: I am rather better. James bought a Mare ( ) today from T.A Lightner, 4 years old last Spring-price $130 Cash.

div3.head: 17. Sat
div3.p: Eruption less troublesome. Nothing new.

div3.head: 18. Sab
div3.p: Cold. All went to Bethel. I went early-the Session had a meeting. I was moderator. Mr John Pilson voluntarily appeared before the session & acknowledged that in a strife & conflict between his Brother Samuel and Wm. Vanlear, at which he was present, he became greatly excited & used language unbecoming a Christian, & some degree interfered in the conflict, for all which he was sincerely sorry, & had as he believed sincerely repented before God. With this acknowledgment the session were entirely satisfied.

div3.head: 19. Mon
div3.p: Suffering greatly with the eruption. Finished shingling the shop. I was writing Reports for Synod. Mrs McF. & Mary Lou went to Mr Blackwood.

div3.head: 1868. October 20. Tues
div3.p: I am as yesterday. Sent my Check to T.A. Lightner for $130.00 in payment for the Mare James bought of him on the 16th inst. Shingling the Smoke House.

div3.head: 21. Wed
div3.p: Not as well as usual. Rained nearly all day.

div3.head: 22. Thurs
div3.p: Better-day cool-nothing worth recording.

div3.head: 23. Fri
div3.p: Not very well. Finished the Shingling of the two houses & I paid Mr Whitelel for his work $7.25 Mrs McFarland & James went to Mr Sprouls on the way to visit Mr Morrison's family.
Mrs Jerusha Wilson & daughter dined with us.

div3.head: 24. Sat
div3.p: Last night was one of great distress to me from the eruption in my limbs & extreme nervousness. I scarcely slept at all till near 1 a.m. & then but imperfectly-did not rise till near 11 a.m. Felt badly through the day.

div3.head: 25. Sab
div3.p: Suffered as much or more last night than the preceding-did not rise till 11 a.m. Very uncomfortable. Mary & Mary Lou went to Bethel to prayer-meeting. Mrs McFarland & James returned at dark.

div3.head: October 26. Mon
div3.p: had a rather better night, but feel great depression not of mind, & I do not know what else to call it. At dinner-time, Rev. Dr. Brown of Richmond stepped in-came to make me a kind visit & it was very acceptable, but he had to return to Staunton to go home tomorrow.

div3.head: 27. Tues
div3.p: Suffered with the Eruption about my ancles. I am somewhat better. All the white family went to Staunton to the Agricultural Fair. Mary & Mary Lou stayed.

div3.head: 28. Wed
div3.p: I am better. James, the blacks went to Staunton-all returned in the evening but James. Rev. J.S. Blain came to see us.

div3.head: 29. Thurs
div3.p: As yesterday. Mr Blain remained all day. In the evening Mr & Mrs Donald & son Saml & Mrs McClure & Theda Humphries came & spent the night here. A very pleasant visit from warm friends.

div3.head: 30. Fri
div3.p: Did not rest well. Our friends left us.

div3.head: 31. Sat
div3.p: I slept better than usual-eruption quiet. I received a very kind & courteous letter from the Synod of Virginia Resigning the office of Stated Clerk & Treasurer.

div3.head: 1868. November 1. Sab
div3.p: Rested tolerably, but the day is too cool & damp for me to go to Bethel. All went but me. Mary went to Mr Kunkles to make them a visit.

div3.head: 2. Mon
div3.p: Eruption less troublesome. Day quite cold-nothing else worth recording.

div3.head: 3. Tues
div3.p: About as yesterday. Hands working on the road

div3.head: 4. Wed
div3.p: I am as usual. Wrote to Rev. Wm. Dinwidde & enclosed my Rect. for his Check of $32.50 as the balance of salary due me from Synod. Wrote to B.F. Cootes, care of Hodges & Bors. No. 23 Hanover St. Baltimore, Md about a Rag Carpet. Husking Corn in the field.

div3.head: 5. Thurs
div3.p: No change to note.

div3.head: 6. Fri
div3.p: I am not so well, but the Eruption is less troublesome. James hauling logs to the sawmill.

div3.head: 7. Sat
div3.p: As usual. Husking Corn.

div3.head: 8. Sab
div3.p:
Not so well, but the day fine I went to Ch. Mr Murray absent. I led the worship-after two prayers I spoke & prayed & read a hymn which occupied
three quarters of an hour, though very weak. I went to Mr J. Bumgardners & dined & came home fairly broken down-went to bed, but so fatigued I could not sleep till near 11 O'clock. Spent a very uncomfortable night.

div3.head: 9. Mon
div3.p: I felt so badly that I did not rise till after dinner-near 1 O'clock. A delightfully warm day. Husking Corn.

div3.head: 10. Tues
div3.p: I am better. Business as yesterday. Rain at night.

div3.head: 11. Wed
div3.p: Rested badly last night-very dull today. Day quite cool. Hands at the corn.

div3.head: 12. Thurs
div3.p: Slept well, but suffered much today from an unpleasant giddiness of my head. Still husking.

div3.head: 13. Fri
div3.p: As usual. L. Brown & Griner husking Corn. Paid my State & County tax $19.32 exclusive of James tax $3.87 of which he paid $1.00

div3.head: 14. Sat
div3.p: Finished husking & hauling in Corn.
Sent to the P.O. a letter to the Journal of Commerce enclosing two dollars for another year Subscripn. Hundreds of Moetors seen last night. I saw about ten out of my window-from NE to SW horizontal.

div3.head: 15. Sab
div3.p: Not very well, but went to Bethel-day fine. Mr Murray not there his Father died. I led a Prayer-meeting but venture to speak but little. Still I was much fatigued. Mrs Argenbright came home with us.

div3.head: 16. Mon
div3.p: I am as usual. Mrs McFarland & James & Mary Lou went to Staunton.

div3.head: 17. Tues
div3.p: Rained all day. Nothing to note.

div3.head: 18. Wed
div3.p: Not so well in the morning, then better-day clear & cool.

div3.head: 19. Thurs
div3.p: Better. Nothing of interest to note.

div3.head: 20. Fri
div3.p: Snowing this morning, the first of the season. About an inch fell.

div3.head: 21. Sat
div3.p: I am as usual. I wrote to J. Marshal McCue Esqr. & enclosed a note of introduction to Gen. R. Patterson & Col. Wm. C. Patterson. James took Mrs Argenbright home.

div3.head: 22. Sab
div3.p: I am as usual-a wintry day. No service of any kind at Bethel. James went to Staunton.

div3.head: Nov. 23. Mon
div3.p: I am about as usual-feel the cold. Mr Houser here with his threshing machine-2 Housers, Whitesel, Hall & Wright here.

div3.head: 24. Tues
div3.p: Still threshing-some hands & young Brown & Swartzel here. Had 8 3/4 Bs. Cloverseed, 83 Bs. of Wheat & 153 of Oats.

div3.head: 25. Wed
div3.p: Very unwell last night & this morning. James & Jac. at Wrights threshing.
Caroline set out for Newton after Adaline. She brought Jane here in her place.

div3.head: 26. Thurs
div3.p: I am better. Sending wheat to Mill.

div3.head: 27. Fri
div3.p: As yesterday. All the wheat in the mill.

div3.head: 28. Sat
div3.p: There was preaching at Bethel yesterday but we did not expect it & no one went. Today all went but me. Dr. S.J. Baird preached & he & Mr Murray came here & spent the night.

div3.head: 29. Sab
div3.p: The Lord's Supper was administered today. I was not able to attend from weakness & felt also unwell, but, blessed be God, I spent a pretty pleasant Sabbath at home. But the first Comn. at Bethel I have missed, I think, when out of bed.

div3.head: 1868. Nov. 30. Mon
div3.p: Spent rather an uncomfortable night-laborious breathing & a distressing cough & headache. Did not rise till near 11 O'clock a.m. then better but I am very feeble.

div3.head: December 1. Tues
div3.p: Rested rather better, but very feeble today. In the afternoon a little flurry of Snow, but none lay & it cleared off.

div3.head: 2. Wed
div3.p: Spent a more comfortable day. Mrs McFarland & Mary went to visit Mr Gardner who is sick. The day unusually cold.

div3.head: 3. Thurs
div3.p: I rested better. Butchered 9 Hogs-aggregate weight [blank space]. Mr Weaver & wife assisting.

div3.head: 4. Fri
div3.p: I am as usual. About 10 a.m. it began to snow & continued for some hours-afterward sleet. James went to Staunton in the Rockaway, & took a little Box containing 3 Bottles of domestic wine for Mrs Genl. Patterson, sent by Express 75 cents. Brought home a Box sent by Roxa D. Bent from Allegheny City containing articles for the children.

div3.head: Decr. 5. Sat
div3.p: nothing to note through the day. At night, when I was getting into bed I lost my ballance & fell to the floor on my back & my left side must below the short rib, struck the corner of a small table hurting me severely internally, for no external injury appeared. My head also was badly jarred.

div3.head: 6. Sab
div3.p: Spent an painfully night with my side, but slept a good deal. I remained in bed all day. It distresses me greatly to cough.

div3.head: 7. Mon
div3.p: Had another distressing night even more restless than the preceding. About noon I rose & dressed, hoping to feel better, but did not. Up till after 4 p.m. From 6 to 7 inches of snow fell last night.

div3.head: 8. Tues
div3.p: Another night of suffering-perhaps a little less than the preceding. Coughing distressing me most, as it irritates the injured part. I find the soreness felt on pressure is extending up above the places injured. I rose about 11 a.m. but felt worse than heretofore.

div3.head: 1868. Dec. 9. Wed
div3.p: Spent another wretched night-worse I think than any heretofore. In the morning rather better. Had my side & back bathed with warm vinegar which I thought did good. In bed all day. Day intensely cold.

div3.head: 10. Thurs
div3.p: My suffering perhaps less last night, but today feel very badly. Rose about 1 p.m. I cannot explain my feelings. Lay on the sofa. Killed a Beef Cow today weighing 520 lbs.

div3.head: 11. Fri
div3.p: Last night in bed hurt my side in some way that I spent a very miserable night. I slept but little. Today some better-slept some, remained in bed all day. James went to Greenville with the Hide.

div3.head: 12. Sat
div3.p: Last night suffered rather less. But the eruption from the application of Vinegar, is more afflicting than the hurt. Drs Tate & Gilkeson came to see me & prescribed. Mr Murray also came & spent the night.

div3.head: Decr. 13. Sab
div3.p: Eruption very troublesome, using sugar of lead, but with little benefit. Day so cold Mrs McF & Mary at home.

div3.head: 14. Mon
div3.p: A very restless night, today better. A Protracted Meeting commenced today. Mr. Murray preached Mrs McF at home.

div3.head: 15. Tues
div3.p: Had a better night-rather restless today. The eruption much easier relieved by sal. Am. the place hurt keeps me uneasy. All but Mrs McF went to Bethel. Dr. Baird preached. I have confined myself closely to bed since Thursday last. Cannot read.

div3.head: 16. Wed
div3.p: Had a bad night with my hurt, but am better today. Cannot sit up.
Mary & Mary Lou did not come home yesterday or to today. James went to Staunton to sell some pigs, but sold them to Mr Palmer.

div3.head: 17. Thurs
div3.p: The night spent as the preceding. I am better today. Dr. Baird & Mr Murray came & spent the night with us.

div3.head: 1868. Decr. 18. Fri
div3.p: Last night I coughed much & till a late hour & spent the remainder of it miserably so nervous slept none till after midnight-feel feeble & nervous today. Mrs McF. went to Bethel & Mary remained at home. Dr. Baird preached & returned.

div3.head: 19. Sat
div3.p: Rested a little better, but still had an uncomfortable night-today pretty comfortable. Mrs McF. & Mary went to Ch. Mary Lou remained with me.
James took Dr. Baird home last night & returned today. Dr. Churchman called to see me.

div3.head: 20. Sab
div3.p: Another restless night but better to today. Mrs McF. staid at home with me.

div3.head: 21. Mon
div3.p: Still rest badly at night & better in the day. A black girl came here to hire, Hannah.

div3.head: 22. Tues
div3.p: Spent a more comfortable night than usual & today still continue better.

div3.head: Decr. 23. Wed
div3.p: Last night I experienced distressing sickness & to not near as well as yesterday. had my bed removed from the SW to the NE corner of the room

div3.head: 24. Thurs
div3.p: My side hurt me more than usual. Paid Jac. $4.00 being the balance due him & he left our service. He was a good hand. Frank Lewis returned in the Stage. The weather terribly cold.

div3.head: 25. Fri
div3.p: About as usual-so cold I cannot sit out of bed.
A very quiet Christmas day & Blessed be God I am yet alive & my family well.

div3.head: 26. Sat
div3.p: Extremely nervous & restless the first part of last night. Today I am about as usual. In bed all day & must remain till more moderate weather. David & Theda came this evening.

div3.head: 27. Sab
div3.p: Had a bad night & a very sick day. I do not know the cause. All went to Bethel but Mrs McF. who staid with me.

div3.head: 1868. Decr. 28. Mon
div3.p: Rested imperfectly my side pained. Very sick this morning.

div3.head: 29. Tues
div3.p: Very sick & feverish in the night-in the day better. James & Mary Lou went to Staunton. She remained at Dr. Bairds.

div3.head: 30. Wed
div3.p: I am as usual. A very unpleasant day. Sleeting & raining. Mr Sproul & his Wife dined here & made us a very pleasant visit.

div3.head: 31. Thurs
div3.p: I was distressingly nervous till near midnight & slept none. Today better.
This day Caroline & Armistead left us finally. I trust God will order it so that their places will be supplied by servants less wicked & more agreeable.

div3.head: January 1st Friday
div3.p:
Last night I took a dose of Bromade of Pota---
but slept soundly. Today I saw
aneribe to its effects. last night heavily - to day very Ther. 32[degrees] & 34[degrees] Wind E.
Mr. McFarland, Mary & & I was all alone today, very quiet. blessed but me & I am suffering but little.

div3.head: 2. Sat.
div3.p: Day precisely like yesterday - exceedingly gloomy. I am about as yesterday. Ther. 29[degrees] 33[degrees] & foggy.

div3.head: 3. Sun
div3.p: Had a very bad night. very broken rest - feel badly this morning. Rose about 12 1/2 O'clock & dressed, the first time since the 10 ult. I sat up but little, but my side did not hurt me much. Up 4 hours.
Ther. 32[degrees] 46[degrees] SW C. & pleasant.

div3.head: 4. Mon
div3.p: Another wretche night rose & dressed at 4 a.m. but sat up very little and went to bed at p.m. Discouraging experience. Ther. 42[deg] 56[deg] SW. cs.by.

div3.head: 1869. January 5. Tues
div3.p: Took a teaspoonful of Bromade of Potassa & rested rather better the early part of the night but not well the latter. I think it day not were with me. Very dull today - Rose at 2 p.m. Up 2 hours. Ther. 46[deg] at 9 a.m. 4[deg] 44[deg] W. C.

div3.head: 6. Wed.
div3.p: Rested better than usual & better To day. Nothing of note to record. Day fine. Ther. 32[deg] 46[deg] W. C.

div3.head: 7. Thurs.
div3.p: Very sick the latter part of last night & this morning - in the afternoon better. Up 5 hours. Ther. 34[deg] 56[deg] W. C.

div3.head: 8. Fri.
div3.p: I am rather better. Up several hours. Wrote to Genl Patterson. This is my 81st Birthday! The last one in all probability I shall ever see. Ther. 35[deg] 64[deg] SW. C.

div3.head: Jany 9. Sat.
div3.p: Spent an uncomfortable & restless night, feel much exhaustion to day. Rose about 12,30 until
Ther. 45[deg] 54[deg] S. Cy. R

div3.head: 10 Sat.
div3.p: Had another bad night took berry wine several through the night and thought it did me good but to day I feel great debility - could not venture to put on my clothes. Day fine. all went to Bethel but Mr. McFarland would not leave me. Ther. 32[deg] 47[deg] W. C.

div3.head: 11. Mon.
div3.p: Had a tolerable night but a sick morning - in bed all day. Dr. Tate came to see me, prevented nothing special. Sleeting all day, quite stormy. Ther. 28[deg] 29[deg] NE very gloomy.

div3.head: 12. Tues.
div3.p: Not so good a night as previously. Today feeble, in bed all day. Mr. M. Pilson came & spent several hours with one, a kind friend. The day cool 30[deg] 39[deg] W.es. C. Today Alek Moore, Negro, came to work perhaps for a month, at $8.00
